webTitle: The ins and outs of the new transfer system

fields.headline: The ins and outs of the new transfer system
fields.standfirst: Vivek Chaudhary  answers the many questions raised by Europe's new treaty for football
fields.trailText: Q: Have negotiations over a new transfer system been concluded?
fields.body:
Q: Have negotiations over a new transfer system been concluded?

A Yes, but it might not be the end of the matter. After six months of negotiations the football authorities and the EU hope to have found a solution. But Fifpro, the European players' union, plans a legal challenge to the new rules.

Q: So what are the new rules and how will the new transfer system look?

A From the start of next season the new system will be in force. Players will be allowed only one move each season. There will be only two transfer windows: a main one in the summer and a mid-season window limited to buying and selling to replace injured players or for technical reasons.

Q: Will there still be contracts for players?

A Yes. All contracts will be for a minimum of one year and a maximum of five. Players aged 28 or under will have to honour their contracts for a minimum of three years, those over 28 for a minimum of two. These time spans are called the protected periods.

Q: Will it be easier for players to move clubs?

A Yes. Once a player has honoured the minimum contract time he can terminate it by giving notice and leaving at the end of a season.

Q: What happens if a player wants to break his contract and move before two or three years?

A Players who unilaterally break contracts during a protected period will be suspended for a minimum of four months. Clubs inducing players to break contracts can be prevented from making a signing for a year or more, have league points deducted or even be excluded from competitions. Agents involved in breach of contract can be fined. If a player leaves for a new club during his protected period, the new club will be deemed to have induced him and sporting sanctions will be applied.

Q: Will players be allowed to break contracts without facing sporting sanctions?

A Yes, if they can prove there was sporting just cause for doing so. This means that if, say, a player plays in less than 10% of his club's games in a season but they refuse to let him go, he has the right to break his contract. Tribunals set up to judge these issues will also entertain claims from players who have been played out of position by their managers.

Q: Will there still be transfer fees?

A Only for players who are under 23 when they are transferred. Compensation is then payable according to a complex formula which has yet to be fully worked out.

Q: If transfer fees fall sharply, how will small clubs survive - those who rely on the sale of players, particularly young emerging ones, for extra revenue?

A Clubs with players aged 23 or under will receive special compensation for the amount of time they have spent on their development. Training compensation will be calculated from the age of 12 to 23, when he leaves the club.

Q: How will training compensation be calculated?

A The EU has set up four bands of clubs. Category 1 roughly equates to the English Premiership and Category 4 to the Third Division. Fifa/Uefa will set a value per year of training at each level with that in Category 1 worth more than in Category 4. If any player is transferred before he is 23 all the clubs that have trained him between 12 and 21 will receive compensation in accordance with the number of years they have trained him.

Q: So will all clubs receive the same?

A No. If a player is transferred from a lower to a higher category club, the fee is calculated as an average of training the player had at the lower and the higher club. If a player is transferred from a higher to a lower category club the fee is calculated as the cost of training at the lower. And if a player is transferred from a higher category club into Category 4, no fee is payable.

Q: How does this benefit the smaller clubs?

A A percentage of the fee payable when a player moves from a club in Category 3 or 4 to a club in a higher category is given to all clubs who have helped train that player from the age of 12.

Q: What happens if there is a dispute over compensation, or whether a player should face sanctions for breaking his contract?

A Two bodies will be set up to deal with these issues. The first is the Dispute Resolution Chamber and its decisions can be appealed to the Football Arbitration Panel. Both bodies will have half their members nominated by the players and half by the clubs, both with an independent chairman.

fields.headline: United look to Keane to cover losses
fields.trailText: Alex Ferguson's men need only two points from their last two games to make the last eight for a fifth successive season, but with Ryan Giggs and Nicky Butt ruled out tonight's game will be no stroll for United.
fields.body:
Manchester United would be less than human if they did not glance round the corner to start weighing up their chances against Real Madrid or other heavyweights they might encounter in later Champions' League rounds.

Last season United went out to Real in the quarter-finals after losing 3-2 at Old Trafford. "If we meet them again I'm sure we'll do better than we did then," Sir Alex Ferguson declared yesterday. "The stability and maturity of our team is improving all the time. We've got greater mental strength now."

First, however, Manchester United have to make sure that they are in the last eight for a fifth successive season and to this end they need to beat Panathinaikos in the Olympic Stadium here tonight - or at least not lose. Two points are all United want to qualify from the second phase and they still have to meet Sturm Graz at Old Trafford on Tuesday.

Either way United cannot afford to assume that tonight's game will be a stroll, although Panathinaikos may have hit a wall after losing at home to Graz. Angelos Anastasiadis, their coach of nine months, immediately resigned to be replaced by a caretaker, Stratos Apostolakis, who called for unity in a dissenting squad.

Ferguson, though, will doubtless send his team out with the usual caveats about not losing discipline or concentration and the need to keep the play tight in all parts of the pitch. Ryan Giggs's hamstring injury has deprived the United manager of an important counter-attacking strength and, with Nicky Butt suspended, United will look even more to Roy Keane.

Ferguson has suggested that he might start the match with Luke Chadwick but is more likely to replace Butt with Phil Neville and use Paul Scholes wider on the left.

A Greek double of Eric Cantona turned up for yesterday's press conference here to be assailed by photographers. The fact that, while Manchester United might remember the real thing with affection, they no longer pine for his presence is a measure of how far the present side has come.

 Raimond van der Gouw, Manchester United's reserve keeper, is to have a knee operation. The American teenager Paul Rachubka is expected to be on the bench in Greece.

Manchester United (4-4-2, probable): Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, P Neville, Scholes; Sheringham, Cole.

fields.headline: Leeds lose out to hand of Raul
fields.standfirst: Raul 7, 59; Figo 41 | Smith 6, Viduka 54
fields.trailText: Alan Smith and Mark Viduka kept Leeds's pride intact on a soggy night in Spain , but it is Real Madrid that go into the quarter-final draw as Group D winners.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor  at the Bernabeu stadium
fields.body:
With the white handkerchiefs fluttering appreciatively across the Bernabeu's fondo sur last night, David O'Leary was given a sharp reminder of why Don Revie used Real Madrid as his inspiration when, almost four decades ago, he changed Leeds United's strip to all-white.

In the end Real got the win they needed to finish as Group D winners. Yet Leeds can take credit from extending the European champions to the odd goal in five after a soggy night here in the Spanish capital which brought out equal measures of the best and worst in Vicente del Bosque's side.

With both sides already qualified for the knockout stages, the consequence of defeat was not overwhelming. Yet the prize of finishing top of the group represented more than just bragging rights. When the draw is made in Geneva on Friday week the group winners will have the luxury of avoiding each other in the final eight, as well as the theoretical advantage of playing the second leg of their quarter-final on home soil.

Such rewards should not be underestimated and Leeds, playing their 33rd European Cup game compared to 225 for Real, swiftly set about banishing any preconceptions that they would opt for a policy of contentment.

Even so their audacity in fashioning the opening goal after only five minutes was going some even by the irreverent standards they have shown already across Europe.

It may have owed much to good fortune - television replays indicated Alan Smith was marginally offside - but in a one-on-one situation there are few better exponents of finishing than the young Leeds striker. Mark Viduka was the instigator, flummoxing the left-back Santiago Solari with a smart turn and change of pace, and with the Polish linesman charitably declining to raise his flag Smith was set free to slip the ball past the oncoming Cesar.

If that was something of an injustice, the reply was a blatant travesty and, from a Leeds viewpoint, excruciatingly timed. Eirik Bakke conceded a free-kick to the left of goal but when Figo whipped in the ball it seemed that the finishing touch had been applied by Raul's hand. The protests were long and vociferous but the referee would not be swayed and Leeds's advantage gone in 60 seconds.

After such a fulminating opening the first half swiftly degenerated into a glorified training session, Real content to play their elaborate keep-ball and Leeds always alert to the possibilities of launching counter-attacking raids. For the most part they seemed to have quelled Real's most potent attacking forces but four minutes before the interval Figo put the hosts ahead with a goal owing more to outrageous good luck than his customary skill.

As the Portuguese international advanced to the right of goal his intention was clearly to sweep a low delivery across the face of Nigel Martyn's goal. Instead, his cross took a preposterous kick off the turf, wrongfooted everyone and spun into the net.

At times Leeds found it hard to win the ball back from the eight-times European champions but when they did have possession Smith and Viduka were alert in attack while Harry Kewell, making his first start since Boxing Day, brought natural width and penetration.

It was Kewell who forced the corner for Leeds's equaliser. Ian Harte speared his delivery into the six-yard area and from such close range Viduka, scarcely believing the space he had been allowed, directed his header into a hopelessly exposed goal.

Once again, however, their joy was short-lived. Figo worked his way to the byline from a short corner and Raul - this time with his head - flicked in Real's third before Lucas Radebe was taken off on a stretcher after an awkward fall to be replaced by Gary Kelly, making his first appearance after seven weeks out recovering from a hernia operation.

Still Leeds continued to search for an equaliser during a second half of unremitting drama. Viduka near levelled when his fierce drive hit the angle of post and crossbar.

 The battle between the two already eliminated teams ended in a 2-1 win for Lazio. Anderlecht's Alin Stoica equalised Claudio Lopez's opener but Roberto Baronio's late goal meant the Italian champions leapfrogged Anderlecht into third place.

Real Madrid (4-4-2): Cesar; Geremi, Karanka, Hierro, Solari; Figo (Rivera, 90min), Makelele (Savio, 86), Celades, McManaman; Raul, Morientes (Munitis, 75).

Leeds United (4-4-2): Martyn; Harte, Radebe (Kelly, 65), Ferdinand, Matteo; Bakke (Wilcox, 85), Dacourt, Batty, Kewell; Viduka, Smith.

Referee : R Wojcik (Poland).

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Panathinaikos 1 - 1 Man Utd
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Panathinaikos: Nikopolidis, Fissas, Henriksen, Goumas, Seitaridis, Olivares, Karagounis, Boateng, Vlaovic, Basinas, Liberopoulos. Subs: Chalkias, Galetto, Warzycha, Pflipsen, Sigurdsson, Nasiopoulos, Koutelieris.

Man Utd: Barthez, Silvestre, Stam, Brown, Gary Neville, Phil Neville, Scholes, Keane, Beckham, Yorke, Cole. Subs: Rachubka, Irwin, May, Sheringham, Solskjaer, Greening, Chadwick.

Referee: K Nilsson (Sweden)

1 The situation is clear for United: if they win, they go through to the quarter-finals; if they don't, they'll have to sweat it out until next week. Panathinaikos kick-off with nothing to lose as they are already eliminated. Barthez called out of his area in the first minute when Pana hoof the ball upfield.
2 Seitaridis makes a run down the right for Pana but United stand firm and stop him in his tracks.
4 Olivares gets away from Phil Neville on the left but is stopped by Brown on the edge of the area. Stam then gives the ball back to Olivares before United can clear.
5 Scholes gives away two free-kicks in succession, prompting a word from the ref. Scholes already on a yellow in this competition.
6 Sloppy from United as Beckham then gives away a free-kick; all gives Pana a chance to compse themselves and get into the game
7 Olivares again threatens down the left, and wins a free-kick just over 25 yards out and square-on to goal. Vlaovic takes, just wide of Barthez's right-hand post.
9 Beckham floats in a free-kick to the Pana area and after a bit of head tennis keeper Nikopolidis claims.
10 Scholes has a pop from 25 yards; just wide.
12 Cole picks up possession 30 yards out and tries to poke a shot through from the edge of the area, but it is a gift for Nikopolidis.
15 Barthez and Gary Neville get in a tangle on the edge of the area when Liberopoulos tries to get on the end of a looping pass from midfield.
16 Booking Olivares for clouting Beckham under pressure near the by-line. Beckham's free-kick finds Brown in the six-yard box, Nikopolidis uneasy before claiming, with Brown penalised for muscling in on Nikopolidis.
19 Corner to United; Beckham takes and Pana clear when Olivares just beats Keane to the rebound
21 Pana knock the ball around in United's half; the ball is smacked in a couple of times before Boateng charges through and is marshalled out of play by Keane for a corner. Comes to nothing.
23 Pana break again after another poor pass by United; Karagounis shoots over from the left side of the area when a cross to Vlaovic or Liberopoulos may have been better.
25 GOAL Panathinaikos 1 - 0 Man Utd United continue to live dangerously and pay the price when Seitaridis fires home from 20 yards to give Pana the lead.
28 Pana free-kick 25 yards out when Karagounis goes down under pressure from Phil Neville. Karagounis takes and Barthez claims with ease.
30 Karagounis barges his way through on the left before being blocked by Brown. Pana with their tails up and United still giving the ball away far too much.
32 Silvestre gets to the by-line but his cross finds no one.
33 Cole finds the back of the net but is called offside from Yorke's through-ball.
35 Basinas very unlucky to be called offside when away on goal - he was a good yard on.
36 A weaving run from Scholes opens things up for Cole to turn on the edge of the Pana area and shoot low; Nikopolidis gets down well to save.
37 Yorke threads the ball through to Gary Neville running into the area, but Nikopolidis blocks the 10-yard shot. Beckham's corner is cleared.
39 United corner after Silvestre is upended on the left. Beckham takes towards Cole but Nikopolidis claims.
41 Two corners in row to Pana after Vlaovic forces a flying save from Barthez.
42 Pana running the show at the moment as Liberopoulos threads balls through to Boateng and Vlaovic lurking around the United area.
44 Pana come very close to getting a second when Vlaovic is called offside under pressure in the United area.
45 United all over the place as Stam gives the ball away to hand Boateng a run on goal; Silvestre does very well to keep up and force him wide. Half-time. A very poor half from United and they could easily be three down by now. Oh, to be a fly on the wall in the United dressing room.

46 United get the second 45 underway. no doubt with their ears still burning after Sir Alex Ferguson's half-time talk.
48 Silvestre threads the ball through to Cole, who tries to peel away from Goumas.
50 United show no signs of having tightened up their game; if anything Pana look even more confident this half.
50 Karagounis cuts in from the right after some swift play by Liberopoulos in midfield. Goes for a corner which comes to nothing.
53 A great cross by Beckham just fails to find Cole in the area.
55 Much tighter from United now as Beckham on the right finds Phil Neville on the far side of the area; a few more passes before Pana break out with Olivares.
57 Silvestre charges in from the left to find Scholes on the edge of the area, but Sholes can only fire straight at Nikopolidis.
50 Substitution Galetto on for Vlaovic.
59 United free-kick nearly 30 yards out. Beckham takes but a deflection makes it easy for Nikopolidis.
62 Beckham tries to thread the ball through to Keane on the edge of the area but Pana crowd him out. Good period of possession for United that led up to the move.
63 Cole outnumbered on the edge of the Pana area from a probing pass by Yorke.
64 Substitution Chadwick on for Silvestre.
65 Karagounis forces a flying save from Barthez from 20 yards. Galetto picks up the rebound and then gives the ball straight to Keane.
66 Substitution Warzycha on for Liberopoulos.
67 Two or three glimpses of goal as the ball is popped in and out of the area by United, but it will just not fall.
70 Pana break with men over after another good period of possession in and around the Pana box by United; Barthez pulls off a critical save to deny a side-footed shot by Boateng from 15 yards.
71 Yet another break by Pana as United leave themselves short at the back.
72 United holding the ball up well in the Pana half before Henriksen clears.
74 Boateng gets the better of Brown on the right before gifting it to Stam. Boateng doing a good job up front for Pana now that Vlaovic is off.
76 Scholes gives the ball away to Warzycha and the Greek side gladly accept the chance to prove that United are having a bit of a mare.
77 Two United corners in a row as Barthez moves up to the centre circle. United knock it around before Henriksen clears and Barthez legs it back to goal.
78 Substitution Solskjaer on for Cole: Sheringham on for Phil Neville.
80 Barthez with another crucial save after Basinas gets away from Beckham and shoots from 18 yards.
82 Booking Seitaridis for time-wasting.
84 Substitution Pflipsen on for Basinas as Beckham takes a United corner; Nikopolidis claims easily.
86 Sheringham, crosses towards Yorke in the area but Pana clear. Looking increasingly desperate for United now, particularly as Pana show no signs of sitting back.
88 Gary Neville finds Sheringham coming on to the six-yard box, but the header is straight at Nikopolidis.
90 Everyone up in the Pana half bar Barthez. Again, agonisingly close for United when Solskjaer's glancing header drifts wide of the far post from Gary Neville's cross. Four minutes to play. GOAL: Panthinaikos 1 - 1 Man Utd Corner to United, Barthez comes up into the Pana half and before you know it the ball is in out of the Pana area for Scholes to fire home from 20 yards. So United have pulled it out of the fire at the last minute, in true Champions League fashion. Not that they deserved it.
Panathinaikos 1 - 1 Man Utd

Vlaovic takes, just wide of Barthez's right-hand post. 9 Beckham floats in a free-kick to the Pana area and after a bit of head tennis keeper Nikopolidis claims. 10 Scholes has a pop from 25 yards; just wide. 12 Cole picks up possession 30 yards out and tries to poke a shot through from the edge of the area, but it is a gift for Nikopolidis. 15 Barthez and Gary Neville get in a tangle on the edge of the area when Liberopoulos tries to get on the end of a looping pass from midfield. 16 Booking Olivares for clouting Beckham under pressure near the by-line. Beckham's free-kick finds Brown in the six-yard box, Nikopolidis uneasy before claiming, with Brown penalised for muscling in on Nikopolidis. 19 Corner to United; Beckham takes and Pana clear when Olivares just beats Keane to the rebound 21 Pana knock the ball around in United's half; the ball is smacked in a couple of times before Boateng charges through and is marshalled out of play by Keane for a corner. Karagounis takes and Barthez claims with ease. 30 Karagounis barges his way through on the left before being blocked by Brown. Pana with their tails up and United still giving the ball away far too much. 32 Silvestre gets to the by-line but his cross finds no one. 33 Cole finds the back of the net but is called offside from Yorke's through-ball. 35 Basinas very unlucky to be called offside when away on goal - he was a good yard on. 36 A weaving run from Scholes opens things up for Cole to turn on the edge of the Pana area and shoot low; Nikopolidis gets down well to save. 37 Yorke threads the ball through to Gary Neville running into the area, but Nikopolidis blocks the 10-yard shot. Beckham's corner is cleared. 39 United corner after Silvestre is upended on the left. Beckham takes towards Cole but Nikopolidis claims. 41 Two corners in row to Pana after Vlaovic forces a flying save from Barthez. 42 Pana running the show at the moment as Liberopoulos threads balls through to Boateng and Vlaovic lurking around the United area. 44 Pana come very close to getting a second when Vlaovic is called offside under pressure in the United area. 45 United all over the place as Stam gives the ball away to hand Boateng a run on goal; Silvestre does very well to keep up and force him wide. Half-time. A very poor half from United and they could easily be three down by now. Oh, to be a fly on the wall in the United dressing room. 46 United get the second 45 underway. no doubt with their ears still burning after Sir Alex Ferguson's half-time talk. 48 Silvestre threads the ball through to Cole, who tries to peel away from Goumas. 50 United show no signs of having tightened up their game; if anything Pana look even more confident this half. 50 Karagounis cuts in from the right after some swift play by Liberopoulos in midfield. Goes for a corner which comes to nothing. 53 A great cross by Beckham just fails to find Cole in the area. 55 Much tighter from United now as Beckham on the right finds Phil Neville on the far side of the area; a few more passes before Pana break out with Olivares. 57 Silvestre charges in from the left to find Scholes on the edge of the area, but Sholes can only fire straight at Nikopolidis. 50 Substitution Galetto on for Vlaovic. 59 United free-kick nearly 30 yards out. Beckham takes but a deflection makes it easy for Nikopolidis. 62 Beckham tries to thread the ball through to Keane on the edge of the area but Pana crowd him out. Good period of possession for United that led up to the move. 63 Cole outnumbered on the edge of the Pana area from a probing pass by Yorke. 64 Substitution Chadwick on for Silvestre. 65 Karagounis forces a flying save from Barthez from 20 yards. Galetto picks up the rebound and then gives the ball straight to Keane. 66 Substitution Warzycha on for Liberopoulos. 67 Two or three glimpses of goal as the ball is popped in and out of the area by United, but it will just not fall. 70 Pana break with men over after another good period of possession in and around the Pana box by United; Barthez pulls off a critical save to deny a side-footed shot by Boateng from 15 yards. 71 Yet another break by Pana as United leave themselves short at the back. 72 United holding the ball up well in the Pana half before Henriksen clears. 74 Boateng gets the better of Brown on the right before gifting it to Stam. Boateng doing a good job up front for Pana now that Vlaovic is off. 76 Scholes gives the ball away to Warzycha and the Greek side gladly accept the chance to prove that United are having a bit of a mare. 77 Two United corners in a row as Barthez moves up to the centre circle. fields.headline: Sector-wide response to the Budget
fields.trailText:
NHS confederation
Confederation chief executive Stephen Thornton said the budgets package of tax and benefit measures focused on reducing child poverty and would make a significant impact on child health inequalities.
fields.body:
NHS confederation
Confederation chief executive Stephen Thornton said the budgets package of tax and benefit measures focused on reducing child poverty and would make a significant impact on child health inequalities.

He said: While this will not have an immediate impact on reducing pressure on the NHS, this is a long-term measure that will ensure healthier lives for our children. Mr Thornton welcomed the new money for capital investment to improve the fabric of hospitals and buy new equipment. But he urged similar investment in community and mental health services.

British Medical Association
The BMA said the extra £1bn for the NHS must be good news but added that it awaited details of how it would be spent. It called for the £135m recruitment drive for frontline staff to pay special attention to primary care.

Dr John Chisholm, chairman of the BMA GPs committee, said: We are desperately short of family doctors. There is a crisis in general practice recruitment and retention which must be taken seriously by the government and urgently addressed.

Child Poverty Action Group
Geoff Fimister, research officer at the CPAG, said: "We welcome the fact that the chancellor has chanelled additional resources for families with children. The only reservation is that the emphasis seems to be very much on the tax credit side rather than child benefit. We hope children benefit is not forgotten about."

National Housing Federation
James Tickell, deputy chief executive of the NHF said: "The government underlined its commitment to improve work opportunities and invest in health and education. New affordable housing should also be recognised as a third priority area for major investment."

He pointed out that the measures introduced were expected, and added: A far bolder move would have been to extend the 5% VAT rate to all building repair and renovation work. This would have a much greater positive effect on the areas in need of regeneration and renewal."

NSPCC
While welcoming the chancellor's continuing commitment to abolish child poverty and to raise family incomes, the childrens charity said that one in three children still live in poverty and more needs to be done. The childrens charity would also like a statutory right to work flexible hours or part time, so that families could balance work and home throughout a child's life.

A spokesperson said: There was no mention in the Budget of more affordable, high quality and flexible childcare for parents. This is a particular problem for those living in rural and disadvantaged areas. Children are also placed at risk if parents decide to work but have to rely on unregistered and informal childcare.

The NSPCC was disappointed at the chancellors failure to build in an adequate safety net for 16 and 17-year-olds in the benefits system. However, the charity welcomed the increase in tax allowances for families. The dropping of charges for criminal record checks for volunteers was also praised.

Daycare Trust
The childcare charity hailed the budget as a key step to creating a more family-friendly Britain and further cutting child poverty. It particularly welcomed the substantial increase in the childcare tax credit and improvement in maternity pay.

The expansion in childcare will also be boosted by budget initiatives to support small businesses, regeneration in disadvantaged areas and skills training, said director Stephen Burke. "Many more parents on low incomes will now be able to access quality childcare.

Unison
The public sector union praised the budget as offering "something for everyone" and boosting public services. "Pensioners and families are in the frontline to benefit from today's budget," said general secretary Dave Prentis. The chancellor "has launched this latest salvo of budget benefits designed to attack in-work poverty, help parents, pensioners, motorists and the low paid. At the same time, he has drawn a clear line between Tory plans for spending cuts and Labour's new investment programme in public services.

"Unison is particularly pleased to see that an additional £335m is to be set aside aimed at improving recruitment and retention of nurses and teachers. This much needed money will go some way to stop the steady drain of workers away from the NHS and education."

But Mr Prentis warned that local government was "fast becoming the poor relation of the public sector, with many vital services still facing cuts and privatisation after today's budget. The government needs to recognise the need for year-on-year investment to maintain and improve frontline services that the public rely on, such as social care, housing, libraries, sports and leisure facilities."

Royal College of Physicians
RCP president Professor Sir George Alberti welcomed the extra money for the NHS but he warned that many more steps will be needed before the UK had an NHS of which it could be proud. Prof Alberti said he was disappointed that the chancellor had frozen duty on alcohol and pulled back from his commitment in earlier years to increase the taxation on cigarettes by 5% in real terms every year.

He said: Tobacco and alcohol are the UKs major killers and causes of disease  this budget does nothing to discourage consumption of either of them  its a bit like reversing down a one-way street with the UKs smokers and drinkers right behind you.

Liberal Democrats
Leader of the Lib Dems Charles Kennedy said: "Gordon Brown is up to his old tricks of double counting again. His £2bn of extra spending is actually only £1bn. Half of todays announcement on extra spending on public services is simply money he failed to spend last year.

The reality of this Budget is almost £4bn of tax cuts and less than £1bn of extra spending. He has tinkered with the tax system but failed to make a significant impact on police shortages, teacher shortages and nursing shortages. This Budget will not make nearly enough impact on waiting lists, class sizes and getting more police on the streets, neither will it give pensioners dignity and security in retirement.

Royal College of Nursing
RCN general secretary Christine Hancock welcomed the extra cash to recruit more NHS staff. "This major new fund clearly demonstrates how seriously the government is taking the issue of nurse recruitment," she said. But Ms Hancock warned: "Pay is still a key factor in improving nurse recruitment and retention and we'd like to see this new money targeted at continuing the trend of above-inflation pay increases.

"We are particularly glad to see extension to maternity benefits and maternity and paternity leave - we would like to see further investment in initiatives that help staff balance their caring responsibilities with their home life."

fields.headline: Social services ignored in Budget
fields.standfirst: The £135m allocated for the recruitment of health care workers contrasts sharply with the complete lack of funding for social services, writes Fiona Campbell
fields.trailText: The £135m allocated for the recruitment of health care workers contrasts sharply with the complete lack of funding for social services, writes Fiona Campbell.
fields.body:
There is mixed news in today's Budget for those who need and provide for social care. Chancellor Gordon Brown announced a £135m fund for the recruitment of health care workers, plus £0.5-1m extra for each NHS trust and an unspecified extra amount to go "direct to GPs".

This contrasts starkly with the complete lack of any funding for social services - particularly disappointing for those hoping for recognition that social care is experiencing perhaps worse recruitment problems than the health sector. Social workers can only hope that some of the money for health will not be siphoned off straight away to acute care, but will help in some of the social care aspects of health, such as intermediate care and home care.

Other aspects of the Budget will impact on users of social and health services - positively and negatively. It used to be thought that progressive income tax and universal benefits were the best way to ensure that people gave to the state according to ability and received according to need. Universal child benefit recognises a collective responsibility for children and the disproportionate cost of childcare to parents.

But, although he emphasised the need to recognise the costs of bringing up children, the chancellor has begun to move away from policies that reflect these principles in a simple way. More benefits are now means tested and there has been a move away from benefits to tax credits. These moves were summed up by Mr Brown today as "changes to reward work". So there will be self-employment grants for lone parents, increases in working families tax credit, childcare tax credit and disabled person's tax credit.

Maternity pay will be increased by £100 over two years and extended to 26 weeks. This will be good news for families who are working and earning enough to pay tax. None of this will assist those who are unemployed, who cannot work or who have stopped working, many of whom are high users of social services.

However, child benefit is to go up from April 6 to £10 a week more than was originally announced. This is not employment-related and will be of greatest benefit to the poorest families. There will also be a Sure Start maternity grant of £500, an increase of £200. This will be welcomed by social services departments in Sure Start areas. Nonetheless, some social workers may be thinking ruefully of how much collective community provision they could make with the aggregated sum of these small individual grants.

The allowance for the 10p basic tax rate has been increased to £1,880, with the result that 7.5m pensioners and 17.5m others will pay no tax or will pay the 10p rate. The chancellor has again used tax credits to "reward" pensioners for savings and pensioners' tax allowances will in future be linked to earnings. But again, you have to have savings to get tax credit on them; and the Budget did not increase the basic pension rates beyond the levels already announced. Social workers are unlikely to find that their poorest pensioner clients are significantly better off.

Social care staff will want to use their influence to ensure that the £220m over three years allocated to drug prevention through crime and disorder reduction partnerships assists with prevention and social support initiatives for young people vulnerable to drugs misuse.

Many new types of tax credit, new types of grant, changes in tax allowances and money for the health care sector have been allocated, but nothing for social services. One of the most useful skills a social care worker can have these days is an understanding of the tax and benefits system. This will probably be where they can contribute most to ensuring that social services users benefit from this year's Budget.

fields.headline: 'Chancellor could have been more charitable'
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown's emphasis on prudence  has disappointed the voluntary sector, says Stephen Burgess
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's emphasis on prudence has disappointed the voluntary sector, says Stephen Burgess.
fields.body:
Given the strength of the economy and government's finances we are disappointed that prudence seems to have prevented the chancellor being more charitable.

However, we welcome the modest simplifications and changes to VAT which will help many charities by allowing free entry to museums and assist property conversions, churches and sports clubs

We are particularly pleased the chancellor has found a way to override the normal VAT rules through lower rates and a grant back mechanism for which charities have been calling for many years.

We hope this will be soon be extended - eliminating the half billion pounds VAT burden which charities suffer every year.

The tax incentives for savers are also welcome but again this generosity has not been extended to charities. The chancellor imposed an annual £400m burden on the charity sector by abolishing advance corporation tax in 1997.

It is extremely disappointing that in view of the government's finances and the chancellor's generosity in other areas, he has chosen not to exempt charities from this punitive tax.

We are pleased that the chancellor has decided to reduce income tax through extension of the lower 10p rate rather than reducing the basic rate, which would have reduced tax reclaims by charities on gift aid donations.

The impact of a reduced basic rate on tax reclaims has been a real worry for many charities so early following introduction of the new gift aid scheme.

The tax incentives for giving introduced in the 2000 Budget have not increased donations by the levels we hoped and more advertising and simplification is urgently needed.

 Stephen Burgess is charities consultant at chartered accountants Saffery Champness and an adviser to the Charity Finance Directors' Group

fields.headline: Yahoo! suspends shares
fields.trailText:
Trading in leading internet player Yahoo! has been halted in the US as investors await a company announcement.
Feb 15: Yahoo! MD quits
fields.body:
Trading in leading internet player Yahoo! has been halted in the US as investors await a company announcement.

Speculation about the reason for the suspension of Yahoo! shares range from a possible earnings warning to an acquisition, a partnership or a management shake-up.

The shares were halted soon after US technology stock market Nasdaq opened on this afternoon because of "news pending".

Yahoo! declined to comment on the nature of its announcement, which is set for 10pm London time - 2pm at the company's California base.

Like most internet businesses, Yahoo! has seen its stock price collapse in recent months, while facing a tougher market for its biggest source of revenues, online advertising.

Because the online advertising market continues to deteriorate, some analysts speculated Yahoo! could be about to lower earnings or revenue guidance like so many other internet companies have done in recent weeks.

However, they said it would be unusual for such a routine announcement to be delayed for so long.

Another possibility was that Yahoo! would announce some kind of acquisition or partnership.

Speculation also remained strong that Yahoo! could be about to announce some changes in its management structure.

webTitle: Charities to indirectly benefit from Budget

fields.headline: Charities to indirectly benefit from Budget
fields.trailText: Although Gordon Brown's Budget gave nothing directly to the voluntary sector, charities and their clients should benefit from measures to create a better environment for business and boost urban regeneration.
fields.body:
Although Gordon Brown's Budget gave nothing directly to the voluntary sector, charities and their clients should benefit from measures to create a better environment for business and boost urban regeneration.

Many voluntary organisations operating at a regional level will benefit from the chancellor's measures to give regional development agencies more power.

Radical reform of tax incentives to raise business investment in areas with high unemployment should benefit charities working with unemployed people.

Mr Brown set out a £1bn package of tax cuts to speed up regeneration. Stamp duty will be abolished in designated areas and VAT on residential property conversions cut from 17.5% to 5%.

The chancellor will also provide 100% capital allowances to renovate empty flats over shops, set up a new community investment tax credit and create the first community development venture capital fund.

Charities working with the unemployed, including disabled people and drug users, should also benefit from the Budget. The chancellor announced a £200m programme of intensive training for the unemployed, while 30,000 drug addict benefit claimants will share in £40m scheme providing they kick their habits.

A new minimum guaranteed income for severely disabled people of £142 was also announced. For those in full-time work, the disabled person's tax credit will also rise by £5 a week from June.

Charities working in the childcare sphere will be pleased by further tax cuts for families. Child benefit will rise to £15.50 a week and a new child tax credit will reduce the burden of direct taxation for the average family to 18% - the lowest level in 30 years.

Charities focusing on the needs of older people also received good news. About 7.5m pensioners will now pay no tax or only pay it at the 10% rate - which is 70% of pensioners in the UK.

Charities working overseas may also gain from a new fund for global health to develop new life-saving drugs and make existing drugs more widely available. This should help them tackle malaria, TB and Aids.

Museum charities should also save several million pounds due to changes in the law on VAT aimed at making entrance free.

The extended tax relief on tax relief on individual savings accounts could also result in a boost to the income charities receive from legacies.
fields.bodyText: Although Gordon Brown's Budget gave nothing directly to the voluntary sector, charities and their clients should benefit from measures to create a better environment for business and boost urban regeneration. Many voluntary organisations operating at a regional level will benefit from the chancellor's measures to give regional development agencies more power. Radical reform of tax incentives to raise business investment in areas with high unemployment should benefit charities working with unemployed people. Mr Brown set out a £1bn package of tax cuts to speed up regeneration. Stamp duty will be abolished in designated areas and VAT on residential property conversions cut from 17.5% to 5%. The chancellor will also provide 100% capital allowances to renovate empty flats over shops, set up a new community investment tax credit and create the first community development venture capital fund. Charities working with the unemployed, including disabled people and drug users, should also benefit from the Budget. The chancellor announced a £200m programme of intensive training for the unemployed, while 30,000 drug addict benefit claimants will share in £40m scheme providing they kick their habits. A new minimum guaranteed income for severely disabled people of £142 was also announced. For those in full-time work, the disabled person's tax credit will also rise by £5 a week from June. Charities working in the childcare sphere will be pleased by further tax cuts for families. Child benefit will rise to £15.50 a week and a new child tax credit will reduce the burden of direct taxation for the average family to 18% - the lowest level in 30 years. Charities focusing on the needs of older people also received good news. About 7.5m pensioners will now pay no tax or only pay it at the 10% rate - which is 70% of pensioners in the UK. Charities working overseas may also gain from a new fund for global health to develop new life-saving drugs and make existing drugs more widely available. This should help them tackle malaria, TB and Aids. Museum charities should also save several million pounds due to changes in the law on VAT aimed at making entrance free. The extended tax relief on tax relief on individual savings accounts could also result in a boost to the income charities receive from legacies.

fields.headline: Families at heart of Budget
fields.trailText: Families and the stamping out of child poverty were at the heart of chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget speech.
fields.body:
Families and the stamping out of child poverty were at the heart of chancellor Gordon Brown's Budget speech.

"Our greatest long-term investment is in children," said the Labour chancellor, launching his fifth Budget. "It is right that we have a Budget that puts families first."

The main planks of his family-friendly Budget are the new children's tax credit, help for low-paid workers with child care costs, and improved maternity and paternity rights and benefits. Low-income families could be up to £2,240 better off, said the chancellor.

A new children's tax credit will be £10 a week, or £520 a year - equivalent to a 2.5% cut in income tax for families on average earnings. Parents earning up to £50,000 with new-born children will get an extra boost, with a tax allowance of £1,000 for the first year of a baby's life. Adoptive parents are to get similar benefits.

Statutory maternity pay is to rise from £60 to £100 and will be paid for 26 weeks, rather than the current 18. New fathers will for the first time be entitled to paid paternity leave - two weeks' worth.

Families with at least one parent in full-time employment will be guaranteed an annual income of £11,700, thanks to a £5 a week rise in the working families tax credit in June. The national minimum wage should also rise to £4.20 an hour.

Low-income families will be able to get up to 70% of their child care costs paid from June - up to a limit of £135 a week for one child and £150 a week for two or more. This rise in New Labour's child care tax credit was "in addition to the child care places being created for one million children", said Mr Brown. But there was a sting in the tail - lone parents on income support will be interviewed regularly about trying to find work, even if their children are under five.

Child benefit, paid to all 7.5m families with children, will go up in April to £15.50 a week. The Sure Start maternity grant would be set at £500 a week.

The needs of women and children in the tax system had gone unrecognised in previous Budgets, said the chancellor.

But now, family income would be looked at, by integrating the tax and benefit system and moving to "our goal of full employment". While the Budget would help all families, it would also "give help to those who need it most".

Disability benefits also get a boost, with a bigger than expected guaranteed weekly income for the severely disabled of £142. For those in full-time work, the disabled person's tax allowance goes up this year by £5, to ensure a weekly family income of £250.

As already trailed, pensions will go up by £5 a week for a single person and £8 a week for a couple. A new pensioner tax allowance, aimed at the poorest pensioners with an income of less than £135 per week, will rise in line with earnings from 2003. Seven in 10 pensioners will now either pay no tax or just at the 10p rate.

Anti-drugs partnerships around England are to get, on average, £500,000 from a new £200m three-year Budget, with similar funds set up in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Around 30,000 unemployed former addicts will have the chance to join a mentoring programme aimed at helping them find work. The chancellor also announced a new anti-drugs campaign, backed by business leaders and sports personalities.

Promising investment for the long term, Mr Brown said hard-working British families deserved the best hospitals, schools and public services in a period of sustained investment and modernisation.

The NHS is to get an extra £1bn, including a new £135m fund to recruit frontline health staff.

The chancellor also pledged another £1bn for education, including a £2m teacher recruitment and retention campaign. Every primary head teacher will get a £13,000 or £63,000 payment every year for three years, depending on school size. Secondary schools will attract £68,000 or £115,000.

webTitle: Budget cash should come with no strings attached

fields.headline: Budget cash should come with no strings attached
fields.trailText: The sum of £1bn pledged by Gordon Brown is not a huge amount of money - and it does not move UK health spending much nearer the EU target set by Tony Blair a year ago, writes John Appleby, of the King's Fund.
fields.body:
The sum of £1bn pledged by Gordon Brown is not a huge amount of money - it's equivalent to about 0.5% of the NHS budget over three years. It does not move UK health spending much nearer the EU target set by Tony Blair a year ago.

That said, more money for the NHS has got be to be welcome. I'm actually surprised that they had any extra money for the NHS. To be perfectly honest, you might wonder if they got their calculations right last year.

The £1bn announced "for hospitals" appears to be directed at capital developments and refurbishments, such as cancer scanners and converting Nightingale wards. The cash is targeted - between £500,000 and £1m of capital for each hospital trust.

They would have been better off just giving it to trusts with no strings attached. Many trusts have big deficits, and this could have been a way of paying off the NHS "national debt".

I sense from the managers I speak to that they would have appreciated a little more freedom to spend the cash in their own way in dealing with their own local pressures.

It would have been preferable to see £500m allocated in this way, on a no-strings-attached basis for trusts to spend on local initiatives.

Earmarking £135m for staff recruitment suggests it is clearly not going to go on pay rises for the 400,000 nurses in the NHS, but on recruitment advertising campaigns.

I was expecting an announcement on affordable housing for key public sector workers, but I'm not sure if this money is for that.

I thought the chancellor seemed to rush through the section on health. He could have made much more of what the money was actually for - he mentioned "scanners" for example, but didn't say that these would be used to treat cancer patients.

Overall Mr Brown seems to have been reasonably cautious. He clearly wasn't going to put it into big tax cuts, and not all of it on repaying the national debt, so they ended up putting it into health. It was almost like an afterthought.

 John Appleby is the director of health systems at the health think-tank the King's Fund.

fields.headline: 'Budget creates climate for growth'
fields.standfirst: The Budget provides incentives for economic growth to aid regeneration, says Alex Stephenson of regional development agency Advantage West Midlands, although some action on cutting red tape would have been appreciated
fields.trailText: The Budget provides incentives for economic growth to aid regeneration, says Alex Stephenson of regional development agency Advantage West Midlands, although some action on cutting red tape would have been appreciated
fields.body:
Regional development agencies will see the Budget as providing the conditions for economic growth. We have been urging the chancellor not to step on the gas as far as the economy is concerned, and to work towards providing the conditions that will encourage steady progress rather than boom and bust.

There are several incentives that will stimulate business growth and also allow the RDAs to improve social conditions for deprived areas with the extra funds and flexibility announced in the Budget.

RDAs will particularly welcome the tax relief for the development of brownfield sites, the encouragement for pension funds and life assurance companies to invest in risky ventures - a process that has been common practice in the United States for some time - and the extension of tax relief on research and development.

The Budget also includes new benefits for disadvantaged communities providing support and encouragement for people to find the jobs which are available.

There were good words in the Budget about reducing the burden of red tape for small businesses, but there are a number of things in the Budget which will actually increase bureaucracy slightly. The government knows this is a problem and we must not let go of this issue. But that is a minor point given the very positive actions that have been taken.

Overall the Budget has created a climate for growth and has recognised the importance of the RDAs with a £1bn package for regeneration.

 Alex Stephenson chairs the regional development agency Advantage West Midlands

fields.headline: The big Budget give-away
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown has turned his earlier prudence into generosity. Kamal Ahmed reports on the chancellor's tax-cutting and family-targeted Budget

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:
Gordon Brown has turned his earlier prudence into generosity. Kamal Ahmed reports on the chancellor's tax-cutting and family-targeted Budget.

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed, political editor of the Observer
fields.body:
It was, as ever, the most political of Budgets. But chancellor Gordon Brown, rather than giving with one hand and whipping it away with the other, just gave this year.

And then gave a bit more. And gave a bit more. The word prudence hardly figured, although 'caution' was thrown around with rather greater elan. But those were mere fig leaves, reminders of a bygone age. This Budget will not be remembered for either.

It will be remembered instead for being a tax-cutting and family-targeted Budget. The large increase in the 10p tax band was trumpeted - as it was in the judicious leaks which have been peppering the newspapers in the last few weeks - as 'a tax cut for all'.

There would be more money for mothers. More money for fathers. More money for education, more money for health. Fuel prices decreased and, in a little Budget gift to show he isn't such a hard-hearted chancellor after all: there's even a freeze on the duty on spirits and beer.

He was trying to achieve one thing. A feel-good boost that would get the public trooping out to the polls on election day. This was always going to be a pre-election Budget, tax cuts plus increases in public spending, the classic final-year wake-up call which any chancellor would give his eye-teeth to deliver.

By this stage of a Labour government, chancellors would usually be announcing spending cuts and tax increases and facing defeat as a result. Brown has engineered the cycle so that he announced the cuts at the beginning of this government and the big increases at the end.

No jam yesterday, lots of jam today. It is the essential lesson of this government: plan for all four years in power rather than the first two. By doing that, it will be the chancellor who will win the next election rather than the man sitting next to him in the commons this afternoon, Tony Blair. It is the economy, stupid.

fields.headline: A typical Brown Budget
fields.standfirst:
Today's announcements come as no surprise from a man who is widely regarded as Britain's best postwar chancellor, says Will Hutton

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Today's announcements come as no surprise from a man who is widely regarded as Britain's best postwar chancellor, says Will Hutton
fields.body:
This was a Budget very much as expected; Mr Brown injected just under £4 billion into the economy next year so that he will stay within the limits of fiscal prudence, but managed to find some money to help him advance Labour's key commitments in front of the likely May 3rd election.

The eye-catching initiatives are the stamp duty exemptions that should trigger major redevelopment of Britain's depressed inner cities and help for children - the baby tax credit and the children's tax credit are important means of alleviating child poverty.

The chancellor has pledged to halve child poverty by 2010 and eliminate it by 2020 - these are important landmarks in meeting that pledge.

There is help for pensioners and working families, and the freeze on drink duties is a useful sop before an election. But perhaps the most important long-term initiative is the chancellor's acceptance of the Myners review on pensions along with some further reductions in capital gains tax for those who take a long term view.

This may seem arcane stuff to most voters, but the chancellor shares the view that British business suffers from short-term investors who are greedy without taking sufficient risks. He wants to encourage more long term investment and more risk capital for young companies; and the Myners report will contribute to that ambition.

It will also have the unpublished side-effect of greatly reducing brokers' commissions from share-dealing, and will be a welcome cap on some crazy City salaries - something which the stealthy Brown will doubtless know even if cares not to say too much about it.

This will please the financial markets while hitting their bonuses, working families and ordinary voters - and give a boost to long term investment and closing Britain's productivity gap with Europe and America.

In short a typical Brown Budget from the chancellor who many now regard as Britain's best postwar holder of the post.

 Will Hutton is a contributing editor to The Observer and chief executive of the Industrial Society

fields.headline: Pre-election Budget 'puts families first'
fields.standfirst:
 £1bn more for hospitals in next three years
 £1bn more for schools
 Minimum wage up to £4.10
 Car tax frozen
 Drugs boost for third world
 10p income tax band raised from £1,520 to £1,880

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown today unveiled a Budget that he said "puts families first".
fields.body:
Gordon Brown today unveiled a Budget that he said "puts families first".

Delivering his first Budget as a married man, and what is virtually certain to be the last before the election, the chancellor said families would receive more money from the tax system and promised £1bn for hospitals and £1bn for schools over the next three years.

In a wide-ranging 52-minute address, Mr Brown said that childcare tax credit would rise to £135 a week for one child and £200 a week for two or more children. Tax credit for families with new babies will also be increased.

The new children's tax credit, which replaces the married couple's allowance in April, will be paid at a rate not of £8.50 a week as planned, but at £10 a week or £520 a year. "For families on average earnings this is worth more than a 2.5 pence cut in the basic rate of income tax."

The government, he said, also wanted to make it easier for mothers who wanted to stay at home after their child was born.

Maternity pay will be paid for 26 weeks instead of 18 from 2003 and increased from £60 to £100 a week. Two weeks paternity leave at the same rate will also be introduced, and for the first time adoptive parents also will qualify for the payments.

Mr Brown said he had looked back at Budgets from the last 100 years and discovered that the needs of children had gone almost unrecognised in the tax system while the needs of women had barely been mentioned.

"And when the story of Britain is of families struggling to do the best by their children, to balance work and family life, and all the daily pressures they face, it is right that we have a Budget that puts families first."

He said 25 million people would benefit from a rise in the threshold, to £1,880 from £1520, for the 10p starting rate for income tax.

By striking a balance between long-term investment and affordable tax cuts, the government would meet the needs of not just some but all of Britain's families, he said

The Tory leader, William Hague, later dismissed Mr Brown's claims that the Budget proved Labour was cutting taxes, branding it a "10p up, 1p down pre-election Budget". He compared the chancellor to "the thief who steals your car and comes back the next day to return the hub caps."

Mr Brown used the speech to outline an increase in public spending of 3.7% a year by 2003-04, with £1bn going to both education and health. The schools money will be used for teacher recruitment, school repairs and headteachers' budgets. In the NHS, up to £1 million will go directly to each acute hospital trust every year for the next three years.

Alcohol, tobacco, betting and cars

The duty on spirits, beer and wine is frozen, while cigarettes will go up by an inflationary 6p. Betting tax is to abolished from January 1 next year.

Vehicle excise tax is frozen, with the lower rate of car tax extended to cover 9m cars with engines of 1,500 cc or less. The chancellor also said there would be no inflation rise in petrol tax, and a 2p a litre cut in the duty on ultra-low sulphur petrol.

"To make sure all motorists can benefit from this 2p cut, I will extend it to unleaded petrol until June 14," he said.

"The cuts will take effect at 6pm tonight. Lead replacement petrol will also be cut by a further 2p a litre."

Business

Mr Brown announced a series of measures to help business and encourage enterprise. He promised to consult on the modernisation of corporation tax and extend tax breaks on research and development to larger firms.

He also announced a cut in the long-term capital gains tax rate for all employees to 10p from 40p to help encourage wider employee share ownership.

Communities

Measures to aid urban and rural regeneration were also announced. Mr Brown confirmed that stamp duty was being abolished in certain areas to help regeneration and gave details of tax breaks for cleaning up contaminated land and renovating empty flats over shops.

A new community investment tax credit and the first community development venture capital fund will also be created, he said.

'Locking in stability'

Mr Brown said that the Budget was designed to lock in stability for the long term.

"Since we came into government our first duty has been to secure stability [...] the stability built on the first years will be our foundation for building opportunity and prosperity for all in the years to come."

Labour had produced the lowest inflation for 30 years, the lowest interest rates for 35 years, more people in work than ever before and the lowest level of unemployment since 1975, he said.

Despite the slowdown in the world economy Mr Brown said that he expected growth to be between 2.25 and 2.75% in 2001.

He added that stability meant Britain was well placed to ride out global economic storms. He said exports and manufacturing would continue to grow.

The current surplus forecast is £23bn in 2000-01 and £17bn, £15bn, £8bn, £9bn, and £9bn in successive years.

The government will pay back £34bn of debt this year, which will reduce debt to 30.3% of GDP in 2001-02, then 29.6%, 29.7%, 29.9% and 30% in the following years. When Labour came to power the national debt stood at 44% of national income.

To cheers from the Labour benches, the chancellor said that this year's repayment was more than the total repaid by all British governments in the last 50 years.

fields.body:
 We've been to South Africa two years running and spent time in Capetown on both occasions. Certainly there are horror stories about the crime situation, but we loved Capetown and it really seemed fine... at least during daylight hours! We followed the usual advice on avoiding trouble.

Further out, Stellenbosch was also an excellent base.

We'll be back, so that's a testimony!

fields.headline: The Budget speech in full (4)
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText:
Part three of Budget speech
We could choose to repeat the pattern of Budgets at this stage of the Parliament and make tax cuts that are unaffordable in the long term.
fields.body:
Part three of Budget speech
We could choose to repeat the pattern of Budgets at this stage of the Parliament and make tax cuts that are unaffordable in the long term.

But it is right to chose the prudent course for Britain.

Let me tell the House what the Government has decided.

For savers, as I announced in November, the Government is extending the tax reliefs for individual savings accounts. 9 million new accounts were opened in the first year, with 48 billion pounds now being saved. Because of the high number of ISAs, tax reliefs for savers will by 2006 exceed projected tax relief for PEPS and TESSAS by 800 million pounds a year, tax incentives for savings to total 3 billion pounds. We wish to see more ISAS and more tax free saving, so for the next five years up to 7,000 pounds a year of savings can generate income and capital gains that will both be tax free. In this Budget I want to do more to cut tax for all savers, including pensioners.

For pensioners we have already announced that from April we will raise pensions well above inflation, indeed above earnings, by 5 pounds a week for single pensioners and 8 pounds for couples and next year by 3 pounds and 4.80 pounds

We will retain the winter allowance and the free TV licence for the over 75s that we introduced and the Christmas bonus. Detailed announcements will be made in this year's social security uprating statement.

Since November, we have been consulting on our new pension credit, to be introduced in 2003. Pensioner couples with incomes below 200 pounds and single pensioners with incomes below 135 pounds a week, many millions of pensioners, will receive the new pension credit. It will rise in line with earnings every year and in this way, it will give recipients more than even the earnings link in the basic state pension would give them.

In this Budget I have decided that from 2003 when the pension credit is introduced pensioners' tax allowances will be linked not just to prices but to earnings. And I will do more on tax for savers, pensioners and working families.

To achieve our goal of full employment and reward hard work I have previously cut the basic rate of income tax and introduced a 10 pence tax rate. And for national insurance we announced and legislated in 1999 upper and lower earnings limits of 575 pounds a week and 87 pounds a week respectively for the coming year, taking three hundred thousand men and women out of tax altogether, in all a national insurance cut of 590 million pounds this coming year.

So to reward savers, pensioners and hard working families, my aim now and in the next Parliament is to ensure that more of savers', pensioners' and working people's income, now taxed at the 22 pence rate, should be taxed at the lower 10 pence rate.

And I propose to make a start today with a one billion pounds a year tax cut: instead of the first one thousand five hundred and twenty pounds of taxable income at 10 pence rather than 22 pence, the first one thousand eight hundred and eighty pounds of the taxable income of every taxpayer in the country will be taxed at the lower 10 pence rate.

A measure which will benefit 25 million taxpayers.

And cutting income tax by extending the 10 pence band shows our intention for the next Parliament too: that all those who work hard and save for their retirement will find that more of their income, taxed at 22 pence today, should be taxed at the lower 10 pence rate.

Seven and a half million pensioners will now pay no tax or tax at just the 10 pence rate, 70 per cent of all pensioners in the country.

Taking into account the direct tax and benefit changes in this Budget, and changes coming in this year, households will be on average 240 pounds a year, over 4 pounds a week better off after inflation.

With the new children's tax credit now paid from April the direct tax burden for the average family falls from 21 per cent in 1997 to 18 per cent, the lowest level for thirty years.

I said that our long term goals for Britain are full employment, high productivity, strong public services, tackling child poverty and opportunity for all.

Now having made this tax cut for work and savings, and locked in our fiscal tightening, our economic strength allows us to release over the next three years a further two billion pounds in total.

There is a choice. I have had representations from some for billions in further tax cuts. But our priority has been and is Britain's public services. So we will not cut investment but raise it. We will increase spending not by 3.4 per cent a year as we planned by 2003-4 but by 3.7 per cent a year.

I can give more detailed figures for the benefit of the House.

To cut spending growth from 3.7 per cent to two and a quarter per cent a year, as has been proposed, would mean, if started now, annual cuts rising above 16 billions a year by 2003-4; and even if started next April cuts of 10.1 billion pounds a year by 2003-4.

So I have rejected this course for Britain's future not only because such deep cuts would move us from our long term goals, and put hospitals and schools at risk, but also because Britain must not repeat the short-termist mistakes of the 1980s - unfunded, unaffordable tax cuts, higher interest rates, cuts in necessary investment, with no fiscal rules.

Mr Deputy Speaker we will not return to boom and bust.

Within our tough fiscal rules, education spending is already set to rise by 5.2 per cent a year even after inflation.

I now propose to increase substantially the sum of current and capital money paid to every school and directly to every head teacher to allow them to make their own decisions as they meet the nation's educational targets.

Head-teachers of every primary school will receive not 10,000 pounds as planned but 13,000 pounds with the larger primary schools receiving not 50,000 pounds but 63,000 pounds.

And the head-teacher of each secondary school will receive for the smaller schools not 57,000 pounds but 68,000 pounds and the larger schools a payment of not 92,000 pounds but 115,000 pounds.

And these payments will not be made for just one year, but for every year through to 2004.

As a result of our spending review, cash spending on the NHS is rising by 50 per cent over five years. Today we add to it. There is a strong case for extra capital investment in equipment, new scanners and renovating old Nightingale wards, with money going direct to each hospital trust, and a case for more primary care money going direct to local GP surgeries.

I am not however able to give 100,000 pounds to each of the 200 acute hospital trusts.

Instead from April, for work on Nightingale wards and new investment, acute hospital trusts will receive as a result of this Budget every year for the next three years extra money of between half a million pounds and a million pounds.

Further announcements including cash for GP trusts will follow, as well as allocations by the Scottish and Welsh administrations.

So I have one final announcement.

The Secretary of State for Health wishes to recruit an extra 20,000 more nurses by 2004. Next week he will announce three year allocations from a new 135 million pounds fund for recruitment of front-line staff.

And next week also the Secretary of State for Education will announce his three year allocations from a new 200 million pound fund for retention, and recruitment of extra teachers.

In total over the next three years one billion pounds more to our hospitals and one billion more to our schools - money that we could not provide if we made irresponsible tax cuts.

We have made our choice:

- more investment not less;

- stability the foundation;

- tax cuts we can afford;

- schools and hospitals first.

And I commend this Budget to this House.

fields.headline: Opposition reaction to the Budget
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Tory leader William Hague  who had to respond to the Budget immediately after the chancellor sat down - branded the speech a "cynical election Budget".
fields.body:
Tory leader William Hague  who had to respond to the Budget immediately after the chancellor sat down - branded the speech a "cynical election Budget".

Mr Hague added: "Taxes have gone up on marriages, mortgages, pensions, petrol, diesel, cars, homes, medical insurance, savings, small businesses, large businesses and the self-employed."

Moments after Gordon Brown had sat down to cheers from Labour backbenchers, Mr Hague joked: "You are like the thief who steals someone's car and comes back the next day to return the hubcaps. That is the story of your five Budgets."

To jeers from the Labour backbenches, he claimed Gordon Brown had brought in 45 stealth taxes since 1997.

Mr Hague said: "The Labour benches can be fooled all of the time  they cheer in ignorance."

The Tory leader aid the country had the lowest increase in disposable income "for a generation" from a government with the "highest increase in disposable promises.

"All this from a government that said it had no plans to increase taxes at all."

He also claimed there were huge raises in council taxes and even a £10 VAT charge on spectacles.

On business, he said the government are "steadily destroying Britain's competitive advantage".

He added: "The chancellor would have done better to tackle business burdens head on, to stop forcing businesses to act as unpaid tax and benefit administrators, to have scrapped the IR35 tax that will drive people oversees.

"He should have set British business free to compete.

"These election tax cuts are for a limited period only.

"He could have given the people's surplus to people.

"It is a Budget for a limited period only and, given the chance, we know he would take it all back.

"Only this side of the House will give people back their money.

"Only the Conservatives will tax less and look after people's money."

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy accused the chancellor of devoting five times as much financial priority to reducing tax as investing in health and education.

The Budget had to be seen in the context of rising class sizes, longer hospital waiting lists, fewer police, more violent crime, immobilised public transport and a record number of winter deaths among pensioners, he added.

"Why had the chancellor not taken the chance to follow the lead of the Scottish parliament in scrapping student tuition fees and providing free personal care for the elderly?

"The country is going to have a real chance for real change in probably just a few weeks' time. That's called not a pre-election over-hyped Budget it's called an honest, rational, sincere Liberal Democrat alternative."
