fields.body:
Introduction

I can report to the House that today because of the choices Britain made our country now has: the lowest inflation for 30 years; the lowest long term interest rates for 35 years; mortgages now averaging one thousand two hundred pounds a year lower than under the last Government; more people in work than ever before; and the lowest unemployment since 1975.

Children and women

Our greatest long term investment is in children. I have looked back at a century and more of past Budgets which have had one common feature: the needs of children in the tax system go almost unrecognised; the needs of women barely mentioned.

Inflation

So I can confirm that because stability will guide our approach, the inflation target will remain at two and a half per cent.

Surplus

In the last Budget I forecast a current surplus for the financial year 2000-2001 at 14 billion pounds. I now forecast this surplus to be 23 billions pounds. Over the economic cycle, even on the most cautious of cases, we will meet our first fiscal rule and balance the current Budget.

Debt

I can tell the House that this year the net cash debt repayment will be 34 billion pounds: more debt repaid by one British Government in one year than all the total debt repaid by all the previous British Governments of the last fifty years. Whereas from 1979 to 1997 42 pence in every extra pound spent went to debt and social security, now the figure is only 16 pence, leaving more than 80 pence in every extra pound to go direct to front-line public services.

Venture capital

Institutional investors are responsible for assets of 1.5 trillion pounds. To promote long term investment and to protect investors, I have accepted the recommendations of the Myners report. We will abolish the minimum funding requirement; through tax and regulatory reform make it easier for life insurers and pension funds to invest in venture capital; and we will ensure both a strengthened role for pension fund trustees and a clearer duty on fund managers to promote beneficiaries' interests.

Business

After further consultation with business, I propose to introduce a new tax relief for intellectual property and goodwill. We will also consult in detail on relieving tax when companies sell substantial shareholdings. And from next month I will abolish the withholding tax not only on international bonds but also on payments of interest and royalties between companies in the UK.

International development

And we will legislate a new and special tax credit that will help British companies contribute to the relief of disease round the world, an incentive to accelerate research on diseases - like Aids, TB, Malaria and other diseases - that each year kill eight million people, including three million children in our poorest countries: deaths that in many cases are avoidable, diseases that in many places are preventible. We have a capacity to help and a moral duty to act. Subject to a commitment by the pharmaceutical companies to invest in and deliver new drugs and vaccines in ways that truly meet the needs of the poor and sick, the Secretary of State for International Development and I are prepared to extend this new tax credit even further.

Farming

For farming, an industry essential to Britain which today faces both immediate and long standing difficulties, the Government, over and above its statutory obligations, has made available agri-compensation money worth 150 million pounds. And I can confirm that the Minister for Agriculture is taking steps to advance agri-money and other payments.

Business and employees

For employees in all types of companies including venture capital and non trading companies the long term capital gains tax rate will no longer be 40 pence but 10 pence. Growing companies offering share options will benefit from today's extension of the Enterprise Management Incentive scheme. I have decided to double to 3 million pounds the share options that benefit from tax relief and in qualifying companies I will extend the right to benefit from these share options to all employees.

Small businesses

We propose a new regime to simplify VAT for small business, which will be of direct help to up to half a million companies. For firms with a turnover of up to fifty four thousand pounds, VAT will not be charged at all: more of business' income not subject to VAT in Britain than anywhere else in Europe. For firms with a turnover of up to one hundred thousand pounds, we propose a simpler and lower flat rate which after consultation we will implement next year. For firms with a turnover of up to six hundred thousand pounds we will also consult upon a simplified VAT payments scheme. The next step is an even more radical proposal: to make the annual company accounts the basis for calculating tax, thus cutting more red tape and cutting business costs once again.

Urban regneration

I see our inner cities and older industrial communities not as no-go areas for new enterprise but as places of untapped potential, where there are young people with dynamism looking for work and markets waiting to develop and grow.

To speed up regeneration I now propose, after our Pre-Budget consultation, a total of six tax cuts targeted on enterprise at a cost - over the next five years - of one billion pounds.

To make the first stages of buying property and bringing land back into use tax free, in designated areas stamp duty will be abolished.

To bring disused properties back into use, we will cut VAT on residential property conversions from seventeen and a half per cent to five per cent.

To help revitalise our high streets, we will provide one hundred per cent first year capital allowances for bringing empty flats over shops back into the residential market.

Churches

In both urban and rural areas, our churches are essential centres for civic life and are at the heart of our rich heritage as a nation. To help preserve that heritage and to cut the costs of saving and repairing our listed church buildings we will introduce for repairs started after April 1st a new grant, the equivalent of aVAT reduction from seventeen and a half per cent to five per cent: a reform long sought by congregations across the country.

Film

The film industry tax incentive we introduced in 1997 which is contributing to the unprecedented success now enjoyed by independent British films, will at a cost of 50 million pounds next year be extended until 2005.

Unemployment

The starting point is a new 'employment first' principle. In the past the unemployed signed on for benefit before they looked for work. Now before receiving benefit the employment first principle means they will first have to be interviewed about job opportunities and the steps they are ready to take to get back into work. For the hard to employ, those still left behind, we are proposing from April at a cost of two hundred million pounds a year a new regime built around more intensive coaching and stronger sanctions for the over twenty fives. For thirty thousand benefit claimants who have been drug addicts, a new three year budget of forty million pounds will mean they can receive the mentoring and training they need, but to get on the programme they will have to get off drugs. Next, to link the unemployed without skills to the jobs that require skills, we will announce separate initiatives to fill job vacancies in the IT industry, construction, hotels, retail and financial services.

Minimum wage

This Government introduced the first ever national minimum wage and it is this Government which has this week raised the minimum wage as of October this year from £3.70 an hour to £4.10 an hour and then, next year, subject to economic conditions, to £4.20.

And as part of our programme to ensure new disability rights I can announce that in addition to a new guaranteed minimum income for a severely disabled person on benefit of 142 pounds a week, for those in full time work the Disabled Person's Tax Credit will also be raised from June this year by 5 pounds a week to guarantee a minimum weekly family income of 250 pounds.

Child care tax credit

In addition to the childcare places being created for one million children, the child care tax credit will, from June, pay up to 70 per cent of child care costs up to - instead of 100 pounds a week as now - 135 pounds a week for one child and - instead of 150 pounds a week - up to 200 pounds a week for two or more children, another step in our plan to place affordable child care within the reach of all working families who need it.

Cars

I can announce that for the coming financial year we will freeze all rates of car vehicle excise duty. Having completed our consultation on new duty rates, I will now move ahead with the proposal to extend the 55 pounds reduction on the standard licence fee from all cars up to 1200 cc to all cars up to and including 1.5 litres. This will include for example Escorts, Astras, Micras and Rover Metros, in total an extra 5 million cars. This reduction, to be implemented in July, will be backdated to November last year. In total 9 million cars up to I.5 litres will pay 55 pounds less.

Fuel duty

As I stated in the Pre-Budget Report: this year we will not proceed with the annual inflation rise in petrol tax that has been the norm on Budget day. After consultation on my Pre-Budget Report I am able to confirm further changes. In addition to the 1 pence cut in ultra low sulphur petrol last October, the duty on ultra low sulphur petrol will be further cut by 2 pence litre. To make sure all motorists can benefit from this 2 pence cut I will extend it to unleaded petrol until June 14th: when the industry says ultra low sulphur petrol will be 100 per cent available.

Green taxes

To reward businesses investing in energy saving improvements, the Government is publishing this month the list of technologies that will qualify for 100 per cent tax relief and later this year we will launch a green technology challenge offering this 100 per cent tax relief to companies investing in the next generation of environmental technologies.

Booze and fags

Because of the competitive position of the industry I will this year continue to freeze duty on whisky and on all spirits. And this year I propose to go further and freeze duty on wine and on beer. Beyond the normal inflation rise of 6 pence, I will not go ahead with any real terms rise in cigarette taxes.

Betting

Following our consultation with the betting and gaming industry over the impact of internet trading, I have decided from January 1st to abolish betting duty which has been in existence ever since betting shops were legalised.

Inheritance tax

For inheritance tax I propose to raise the allowance, so that no tax will be charged on estates up to almost a quarter of a million pounds, a threshold of 242,000. 96 per cent of estates will pay no tax.

Families

From April child benefit will be fifteen pounds fifty a week, 806 pounds a year. So in addition to child benefit the new children's tax credit is being introduced on April 6th. And after consultation I have decided that our new children's tax credit will be paid not at eight pounds fifty a week or 442 pounds a year - as originally proposed - but it will be paid at 10 pounds a week, 520 pounds a year.

For families on average earnings this is worth more than a two and a half pence cut in the basic rate of income tax.

With this major change in our tax system, financial support for families with children has never been higher.

We know also that greatest help should be there when children are youngest; the time when family income tends to fall as family costs rise.

We can do more to help mothers and fathers balance work and family responsibilities. Indeed, we want to make it easier for mothers to make the choice to stay at home after their child is born and for much longer than previously.

I can announce that following the maternity review set up in last year's Budget under the leadership of the Secretary of State for Trade and Industry, maternity pay which is 60 pounds will be increased in successive stages to 75 pounds next year and the year after to 100 pounds a week, as big a rise in two years as in the previous forty.

Maternity pay

We will also legislate so that, at the same time as the 100 pounds is introduced, the statutory obligation to maternity pay will be raised from 18 weeks to 26 weeks.

And we will introduce two weeks paid paternity leave, set at the same level of 100 pounds, paid for by the Government.

£1,000 child tax credit

For the first year of a child's life, I propose a further innovation. From April next year for families with new-born children, the children's tax credit will be set at an even higher level and paid up the income scale to all households where the main earner earns up to 50,000 pounds a year.

I propose to set this children's credit at over 1,000 pounds a year, worth 20 pounds a week.

So to summarise these changes: families receiving the higher children's credit and maternity pay will be up to two thousand two hundred and forty pounds better off.

War on drugs

To every one of the country's 350 partnerships against crime and disorder, direct payments averaging half a million pounds and up to one million pounds will be made straight to police commanders and anti drugs leaders. Similar funds will be available for Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Savers

For savers, as I announced in November, the Government is extending the tax reliefs for individual savings accounts.

Pensioners

For pensioners we have already announced that from April we will raise pensions well above inflation, indeed above earnings, by 5 pounds a week for single pensioners and 8 pounds for couples and next year by 3 pounds and 4.80 pounds In this Budget I have decided that from 2003 when the pension credit is introduced pensioners' tax allowances will be linked not just to prices but to earnings.

10p tax rate

So to reward savers, pensioners and hard working families, my aim now and in the next Parliament is to ensure that more of savers', pensioners' and working people's income, now taxed at the 22 pence rate, should be taxed at the lower 10 pence rate. And I propose to make a start today with a one billion pounds a year tax cut: instead of the first one thousand five hundred and twenty pounds of taxable income at 10 pence rather than 22 pence, the first one thousand eight hundred and eighty pounds of the taxable income of every taxpayer in the country will be taxed at the lower 10 pence rate.

A measure which will benefit 25 million taxpayers.

Conclusion

Taking into account the direct tax and benefit changes in this Budget, and changes coming in this year, households will be on average 240 pounds a year, over 4 pounds a week better off after inflation. With the new children's tax credit now paid from April the direct tax burden for the average family falls from 21 per cent in 1997 to 18 per cent, the lowest level for thirty years.

Goals

I said that our long term goals for Britain are full employment, high productivity, strong public services, tackling child poverty and opportunity for all.

There is a choice. I have had representations from some for billions in further tax cuts. But our priority has been and is Britain's public services.

So I have rejected this course for Britain's future not only because such deep cuts would move us from our long term goals, and put hospitals and schools at risk, but also because Britain must not repeat the short-termist mistakes of the 1980s - unfunded, unaffordable tax cuts, higher interest rates, cuts in necessary investment, with no fiscal rules.

Mr Deputy Speaker we will not return to boom and bust.

Schools

Head-teachers of every primary school will receive not 10,000 pounds as planned but 13,000 pounds with the larger primary schools receiving not 50,000 pounds but 63,000 pounds. And the head-teacher of each secondary school will receive for the smaller schools not 57,000 pounds but 68,000 pounds and the larger schools a payment of not 92,000 pounds but 115,000 pounds.

Health

There is a strong case for extra capital investment in equipment, new scanners and renovating old Nightingale wards, with money going direct to each hospital trust, and a case for more primary care money going direct to local GP surgeries.

Instead from April, for work on Nightingale wards and new investment, acute hospital trusts will receive as a result of this Budget every year for the next three years extra money of between half a million pounds and a million pounds. In total over the next three years one billion pounds more to our hospitals and one billion more to our schools - money that we could not provide if we made irresponsible tax cuts.

We have made our choice: - more investment not less; - stability the foundation; - tax cuts we can afford; - schools and hospitals first.

And I commend this Budget to this House.

webTitle: Collymore wants to open trendy clothes shop

fields.headline: Collymore wants to open trendy clothes shop
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore is hoping to open a trendy clothes shop in London after deciding to quit football, Guardian Unlimited can reveal.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore is hoping to open a trendy clothes shop in London after deciding to quit football, Guardian Unlimited can reveal.

The troubled striker today announced his retirement at the age of 30 to spend more time with his family and "explore other career opportunities which are available to him." Guardian Unlimited understands that these opportunities include moving into retail and fashion.

He has told friends that he really wants to open an upmarket clothes shop, using what he calls his "extensive knowledge" of buying and wearing clothes.

A source close to Collymore told Guardian Unlimited: "Stan loves clothes. When he was in the Priory all that he talked about was moving to London to set up a clothes shop. Now he's retired that's what the area I think he'll move into."

webTitle: A billion pounds to revamp the NHS

fields.headline: A billion pounds to revamp the NHS
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown unveiled a £1bn package of investment in the NHS in today's budget aimed at reducing key staff shortages and modernising decrepit hospital wards.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown unveiled a £1bn package of investment in the NHS in today's budget aimed at reducing key staff shortages and modernising decrepit hospital wards.

The chancellor said £135m would go towards recruiting frontline NHS staff such as nurses. Health secretary Alan Milburn will announce the allocation of these funds next week.

Acute hospital trusts will receive grants worth between £500,000 and £1m extra each year for three years, said Mr Brown. This will go towards equipment such as scanners and renovating old-fashioned, nurse-run Nightingale wards.

Further announcements on investment in GP surgeries and funding for services in Scotland and Wales will follow.

New measures to tackle drug abuse were also announced. Mr Brown said 30,000 former drug addict benefit claimants would gain from a £40m scheme to help them into work, providing they kicked their habits.

The UK will also help set up a fund for global health, developing new life-saving drugs and making existing drugs more widely available.

A new tax credit will give British pharmaceutical companies more incentive to pursue research on combating illnesses - such as Aids, tuberculosis and malaria - which kill millions in the third world.

The duty on cigarettes will only go up by a 6p, which could raise up to £80m ringfenced for the health service. Analysts had predicted tax rises of up to 21%, which would have given the NHS up to £300m.

webTitle: Welcome help to bridge housing funding gap

fields.headline: Welcome help to bridge housing funding gap
fields.standfirst: The chancellor is offering landlords a chance to spearhead community regeneration projects, but David Fotheringham of the Chartered Institute of Housing says Mr Brown could have done more for the sector
fields.trailText: The chancellor is offering landlords a chance to spearhead community regeneration projects, but David Fotheringham of the Chartered Institute of Housing says Mr Brown could have done more for the sector.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown has offered a potential boost to help bridge the funding gap facing social landlords' regeneration spending through the community investment tax credit. Housing providers will be very interested by the tax credit proposal and their potential to attract additional resources into communities where they work.

While the details of the scheme are still to be finalised, there would appear to be potential for social landlords to use the initiative as a mechanism for driving sustained regeneration work and keeping resources within local communities. With social landlords already under pressure to keep rents down, we are keen that all the options for directing resources into disadvantaged communities are investigated.

Registered social landlords are well placed to work with the new community investment tax credit scheme. They are often one of the few businesses with a presence on the ground in deprived neighbourhoods and have extensive experience of dealing with private finance.

We also welcome the measures to reduce VAT on residential property conversions and the costs of renovating homes empty for three years or more. The chancellor has moved some way to meeting the calls of bodies such as the Chartered Institute of Housing, the Confederation of British Industry and Lord Rogers's Urban Task Force.

But he has fallen short of bringing in the full harmonisation of VAT on refurbishment and new build that is needed to promote inner city regeneration and reduce the incentive for building on green fields.

While the relief on stamp duty may encourage businesses to buy properties in deprived areas it may have only a marginal impact on residential sales. In many deprived areas, properties are changing hands for much less than the £60,000 level at which stamp duty kicks in.

 David Fotheringham is head of policy at the Chartered Institute of Housing

fields.headline: Jacko's Oxford: Verdict on the PR
fields.trailText:
11.15am: Press and TV journalists were kept waiting for hours for a story without an angle, reports Julia Day.
Mar 6: Jacko bans cameras
Feb 22: Jacko bans TV from Union address
fields.body:
The relief on the face of PR man Ian Monk was a picture. He was finally able to tell a sodden press pack that Michael Jackson, almost three hours late, really was about to put in an appearance at the Oxford University Union. Honest.

Having almost resigned the PR account to orchestrate Jackson's visit, PR firm MacLaurin was already familiar with the demands from the superstar's camp.

So it was inevitable not everyone would be seduced by Jackson's tears or saddened by his woefully fragile appearance.

The Daily Star today splashed on the melodramatic news that it, along with the Express and - most gravely of all - OK! had been barred from the event.

That was something the Star hadn't expected - MacLaurin, after all, handles the PR for Richard Desmond's Express group.

Last night, the throng of TV camera crews, photographers and journalists - almost outnumbering Jackson fans - had all grown weary and suspicious.

They had stood for hours in the rain-lashed courtyard press pens - some TV crews had been there since 10am.

A rumour rippling through their ranks was beginning to be taken seriously - Jackson wasn't going to show.

Hacks began to discuss what they might possibly fill page three of tomorrow's national newspapers with instead.

Most of all, they wondered what they were doing there, fishing for an angle at a glorified photo opportunity.

Prayers were said for a Jarvis Cocker-style bum-waggling incident to liven up the proceedings.

But the PR strategy worked. Lacking any juicy angles, the press duly obliged and printed the star's seven-point bill of rights for children.

Everyone complained about the ban on recording Jackson's address from inside the debating chamber and no one had been given told why the ban was in place.

The New York Daily News journalist said she was struggling to find the story and was unimpressed with the media turnout.

"Three times as many for OJ Simpson," she observed proudly.

Some 40 journalists were permitted into the debating chamber while another 40 were in the ante-room, watching the proceedings by video link.

At 7.15pm, Jackson was already late. But that, for a popstar, is fashionable.

Nevertheless, all 80 hacks were unceremoniously shooed outside for a glimpse of the star as rumours of his impending arrival reached a crescendo.

What the PR didn't count on was Jackson's sicknote.

An hour later, he still hadn't appeared, leaving precious little time for appearances on the late evening news on BBC, ITV and Sky.

Print journalists gleefully thought the delay was to their advantage. "We'll be the first with the news," said one.

But one cameraman summed up the mood: "When I got this job I thought great, I'll get to see what Jacko really looks like. It's just a freakshow."

But by the time the star deigned to show, the fans had stopped singing and first editions had gone to press.

By the time the final editions of the newspapers emerged, only three bothered to put the story on their front page.

Michael Jackson - freak or unique?
The Star: freak
"Pop freak Michael Jackson last night banned the Daily Star from his speech at the Oxford Union"
Daily Express: unique
"Superstar sheds a tear over his lost childhood"
The Sun: freak
"Limping star rambles at launch of kids charter"
Daily Mail: unique
"I was starved of love to make me a star"
The Mirror: unique
"Jacko sobs over lost youth"
The Guardian: unique
"No kidding as Jacko calls for bill of rights"
The Times: unique
"Jackson opens heart about childhood at Oxford lecture"
The Daily Telegraph: unique
"What he said in his address to the Oxford Union"

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Melanie
fields.trailText: I took a long trip around Oz about two years ago. If you liked the east, you'll rave about the west. More laid back and far more friendly. Certainly get to Freo and try and get down to Margaret River (try the Eco-lodge - very friendly if a little pricey) for some of the best surf ever - too big for me!
fields.body:
Sam,

I took a long trip around Oz about two years ago. If you liked the east, you'll rave about the west. More laid back and far more friendly. Certainly get to Freo and try and get down to Margaret River (try the Eco-lodge - very friendly if a little pricey) for some of the best surf ever - too big for me!

Up the the coast to Coral Bay where the diving and snorkelling is sublime, probably as good as it is at the Barrier Reef (and you can reach the reef from the beach), although it has to be said that the Backpackers there was one of the worst in the world: cockroaches ruled the kitchen, toilet, and showers. Darwin's OK if you like to drink and fight and is a good place to get out of (by plane, I mean).

fields.headline: Kirch heads for World Cup talks
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText:
10.45am: Kirch is heading for crunch talks with the UK government over World Cup broadcasting rights. By Dan Milmo
Mar 6: Mogul who rules the World Cup
Mar 5: BBC sports chief slams Kirch
Feb 16: MPs warn Kirch over World Cup rights
fields.body:
German media group Kirch is heading for crunch talks with the UK government over World Cup broadcasting rights.

But officials at the Department of Culture, Media and Sport are determined that Kirch will come away empty handed from this morning's meeting with representatives of culture secretary Chris Smith.

Kirch is on a collision course with UK politicians because it wants to sell the rights to the 2002 and 2006 tournaments to the highest bidder.

Such an auction threatens to exclude free-to-air broadcasters such as the BBC or ITV.

However, a DCMS spokeswoman said the competition is protected by the 1996 Broadcasting Act.

The act states that a free-to-air station must be allowed to screen the entire tournament.

"Kirch wants to put its case to us, but our position has not changed and is unlikely to change," said the spokeswoman.

"As far as we are concerned, British viewers should be able to see the matches."

Speculation is also mounting that a deal struck with the German government yesterday will force Kirch's hand in the UK.

The company has been forced to sell the World Cup rights to two public-TV broadcasters following intervention by Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder.

He acted after the media and general public reacted angrily to the prospect of paying to see the tournaments.

In the UK, the fear that Kirch will sell the broadcasting franchise to a pay-TV bidder such as BSkyB or ONdigital has prompted a furious response from MPs and millions of football fans.

The German group has underlined its resolve to get around UK broadcasting laws by filing a complaint to the European court of justice.

It claims that the restrictions are a restraint of trade.

The group is also embroiled in a tussle for control of the broadcasting rights to Formula One.

It has only managed to strike a World Cup pay-per-view deal in Spain and is desperate to claw back the £550m it invested in the rights.

Kirch was unavailable for comment.

fields.headline: Curbs shut down rural recreation
fields.standfirst:
As restrictions ruin businesses workers ask if right priorities are in place

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: As restrictions ruin businesses workers in tourism ask if the right priorities are in place.
fields.body:
With Snowdonia experiencing the best winter mountaineering conditions for more than 15 years, staff at the National Mountain Centre, deep in the heart of the national park, should be getting ready for their busiest weekend of the year so far.

Usually thousands of climbers, walkers and other outdoor enthusiasts would be descending on the centre at Plas y Brenin in their droves. But with police tape swirling across the entrances to the park, shut down because of the foot and mouth epidemic, the centre is deserted.

Iain Peter, the chief executive, has been forced to lay off 40 staff and the remaining 60 are down to a three-day week. With no end to the crisis in sight he can envisage having to shut down the £120,000-a-month operation.

The foot and mouth crisis, now in its third week, is having a devastating effect on trade and many who work in the tourism industry are demanding action before their livelihoods are destroyed.

In north Wales, the Lake District and the highlands of Scotland tourism is the largest economy's largest sector employing, the lifeblood of the community, bringing in far more money than farming - the industry the ban was brought in to protect. The Cumbrian tourist board estimated the crisis was costing the local economy between £5m and £8m a week.

The government accepted yesterday that the foot and mouth outbreak was causing "real difficulty and hardship" to tourism, but with the Easter holidays fast approaching those working in the industry want more than just words.

"Everybody is suffering," said Mr Peter. "Everything round here, from the pubs to the post office and petrol station rely on the trade that we bring in. With nobody here they are all starting to feel the pinch."

"We know we are not going to get any compensation from the government. I don't want the ban lifted if it is going to wreck the farming community, but the government has put in place some pretty stringent powers without thinking of the full implications. We need to see drastic action taken quickly. At the moment we have no idea when this is going to end, but if it goes on much longer I am going to have to lay off the rest of my staff."

Richard Townsend from the Association of Mountain Instructors said the organisation was trying to negotiate with the national parks and land owners for limited access to the mountains. "We have 700 members, most of whom are self employed, and they are losing on average £500 a week each as a result of the crisis."

Howard Christie, who owns the Wasdale Head Hotel in the Lake District, estimates he has lost about £24,000 in the last 10 days. "I have respect for my farming neighbours and I hope they have respect for me, but the fact is the 15 people I employ at the hotel are more than the total number employed in agriculture in the valley. With the money I have lost I could have bought every piece of livestock in the valley and had change to spare."

Rick Potter is a self employed mountain instructor who works out of Llanberis in the shadow of Snowdon in north Wales. "The area is like a ghost town. The car parks are empty and taped shut, the National Parks are all closed," he said yesterday. "The place is usually a mecca for outdoor activities, children and people who just want stroll or walk their dog but now it's completely dead."

Just down the road at Pete's Eats, one of the most famous mountaineering hangouts in Britain, the crisis is also beginning to bite. "Everyone is respecting the ban and we have lost most of out trade," said the manager, Ted Sylvester. "We are losing thousands a week and if you multiply that through the village, where 70% of revenue is tourist based, the crisis must have cost something like £200,000.

"When you think that the restrictions on movement were put in mainly for economic reasons in the first place at some point the government is going to have to start considering the effect it is having on other areas and not just farming."

Special report: the landfill tax scandal
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will today announce that the government's only "green tax" - the landfill tax - is to go up by nearly 10% from next month, three times the rate of inflation.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will today announce that the government's only "green tax" - the landfill tax - is to go up by nearly 10% from next month, three times the rate of inflation.

The rise from £11 to £12 a tonne of dumped rubbish aims to deter councils and industry from putting waste in the ground and move towards recycling products. Councils are also to get extra help for kerb-side collection of bottles, paper, tins and plastics for recycling.

The chancellor is expected to publish the results of a review of the working of the complex Landfill Tax Credit Scheme, which allows waste companies to avoid paying up to 20% of the tax by giving away money to local environmental bodies.

The review - into the £350m scheme set up in 1994 - will say that too much cash has gone to local heritage projects, such as restoring church roofs and village halls. Only 30% of the money raised goes into minimising waste and new technology to develop recycling. The government is expected to say it wants to reverse the proportion, and freeze further increases on spending on heritage schemes.

Gordon Brown's announcement is intended to back up Tony Blair's "green credentials" speech yesterday by showing that the government is not afraid to continue to tax industry and local councils to improve the environment.

The government's new waste strategy aims to get councils to triple the amount of recycling by 2005, but ministers fear that they may not reach the target, despite the provision of an extra £140m a year. Figures to be released soon will show that some of the leading recycling councils, such as Bournemouth, will recycle less waste this year.

Ministers are also under pressure from some of the top waste collection companies, including Biffa, to increase the tax substantially after 2004. A delegation led by Barry Sheerman, Labour MP for Huddersfield, wants to commit the government to increasing the tax by £4 a tonne every year from 2004, to reach £35 a tonne by 2009.

fields.headline: Forces fear war crimes threat
fields.standfirst:
Commanders voice concern over new court and 'Brussels meddling'

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Top military commanders have warned ministers that the proposed new International Criminal Court championed by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, could lead to British troops being prosecuted for war crimes.
fields.body:
Top military commanders have warned ministers that the proposed new International Criminal Court championed by the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, could lead to British troops being prosecuted for war crimes.

They believe it could also prevent British peacekeepers from carrying out their tasks effectively.

Their deep unease reflects a broader concern about regulations restricting the operation of the military, covering health, safety, working practices and non-discrimination, by what a senior defence source described yesterday as "rules made in places other than our capital city" - a reference to Brussels, above all.

The plan for the permanent, UN-sponsored, court was agreed at a conference in Rome in 1998. Legislation ito incorporate into British law the treaty setting up the court is about to pass through the Lords before going to the Commons.

"Given wrong rules of engagement [British commanders] could find themselves liable to prosecution as war criminals", a senior defence source warned yesterday. He added that ministers were "very aware" of such a prospect. He said he was concerned in particular about conflicts and operations, short of a full-scale war, even - paradoxically - where British forces were engaged in support of the UN.

Another senior defence source said that future rules of engagement could, for instance, prevent a British warship from attacking a hostile vessel until it was too late.

The jurisdiction of the proposed new international court extends to genocide, and crimes against humanity, as well as war crimes. In the treaty setting it up, war crimes are broadly defined and include: "Intentionally launching an attack in the knowledge that such attack will cause incidental loss of life, or injury to civilians, or damage to civilian objects, or widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment which would be clearly excessive in relation to the concrete and direct overall military advantage anticipated."

The bill also states that "a military commander...is responsible for offences committed by forces under his effective command and control...as a result of his failure to exercise control properly over such forces."

This applies "where he either knew, or, owing to the circumstances at the time, should have known, that the forces were committing or about to commit such offences and he failed to take all necessary and reasonable measures within his power to prevent or repress their commission".

The treaty is not retrospective. However, Michael Caplan, a former lawyer to the Chilean ex-dictator, General Augusto Pinochet, questioned last month how Tony Blair would have been able to defend himself if he were charged with bombing targets in Kosovo in the knowledge that civilians might be killed.

The court will only be set up after the treaty has been ratified by 60 countries - so far only 29 have done so. Though Bill Clinton signed the treaty in the last days of his presidency, it is unlikely to pass through the US Senate, given fears that American soldiers might be targets of politically-motivated prosecutions.

However, the Foreign Office insisted yesterday that the treaty establishing the court merely incorporates existing tenets of international law. Rules of engagement for British commanders were always consistent with international law such as the Geneva conventions, it said.

Safeguards have been inserted into the bill to prevent politically-motivated prosecutions, a spokesman said. In the first instance any investigation will be carried out by authorities in the country whose nationals are accused of wrongdoing.

Humanitarian agencies and human rights groups strongly back the new court.

However, senior defence sources yesterday made clear that, in their view, the safeguards are not sufficient. "We have got to [ensure] there is a framework that does not prevent us from from doing what we set out to do", one senior official said. He said the new rules could make new types of weapons illegal.

In other walks of life, new regulations were being introduced with very good reason to make the workplace safer, he said. However, "when we see bits of European legislation [the military] should, not be forced to follow it slavishly".

Another military source cited as an example rules which might prevent helicopters from exercising - or even training for rescue missions - in bad weather.

Sir Charles Guthrie, former chief of defence staff, and his successor, Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, recently expressed concern about what they see as an increasingly "litigious society". Defence officials privately accuse the government of deferring too much to political correctness.

Last month, Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, claimed that the bill setting up the international court would allow officers to be prosecuted for crimes committed by their troops, even if those troops were not obeying orders at the time.

fields.headline: Blair pledges green industrial revolution
fields.standfirst:
Britain 'to lead world' in protecting environment and agriculture

Special report: green living
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Tony Blair promised yesterday to put Britain on a fast track into the global "green industrial revolution" and to lead the world in addressing environmental and agricultural problems.
fields.body:
Tony Blair promised yesterday to put Britain on a fast track into the global "green industrial revolution" and to lead the world in addressing environmental and agricultural problems.

In his second green speech in four months, the prime minister committed £100m of new money to renewable energy - wind, solar and wave power - and called for radical reform of the European common agricultural policy to help British farmers and developing countries.

"Green technologies are on the verge of becoming one of the next waves in the knowledge economy revolution," Mr Blair said in a speech to the Worldwide Fund for Nature. "The global market for environmental goods and services is projected to rise to £440bn a year in the next nine years. Shell estimates that 50% of the world's energy needs could be met by renewables by 2050. By 2010, the global solar market could be worth £150bn a year. I want Britain to be a leading player in this revolution."

In a wide ranging, sometimes passionate, speech that recalled Margaret Thatcher's awakening to green issues in 1989, Mr Blair restated the threats posed by climate change, desertification, and the abuse of resources - but sought to link them with "hypocritical" policies that exacerbated poverty in poor countries.

"The common agriculture policy is seriously outmoded. It distorts global agricultural markets and promotes forms of agriculture that damage the environment. It is hypocritical of us to to talk of concern to alleviate the poverty of the developing world whilst we block access to our markets.

"There is now an intense urgency about the politics of the environment. We would be irresponsible to treat predictions [about global warming, forest loss and water shortages] as scaremongering. They represent the considered opinions of some of the world's best scientists. We cannot afford to ignore them.

"The effects will be catastrophic for some parts of the world, particularly the poorer parts. Sustainable development is going to be the greatest challenge we face this century."

His comments were welcomed by industry and a plethora of green groups, but other political parties accused him of appealing for the environmental vote ahead of an election.

Charles Secrett, executive director of Friends of the Earth, said: "This is the strongest environment speech Tony Blair has yet made. We hope his commitment to sustainable farming will lead to a clear policy statement on how that shift can be achieved."

Francis Sullivan, of the charity WWF-UK, said: "We see this as a turning point in the government's position on the environment; we hope he follows it through in the next few months and it becomes a major plank of the manifesto."

Conservative environment spokesman Damian Green countered: "It is too late for Tony Blair to try and dress himself in green clothes. He is fooling no one with this sudden burst of fake concern.

"Britain is one of Europe's worst performers on renewable energy, one of Europe's worst performers on recycling domestic waste, and for the first three years Mr Blair's government blocked the construction of cleaner gas-fired power stations that emit fewer greenhouse gases."

Mr Blair's points were taken up by other cabinet members. Agriculture minister Nick Brown said that the common agriculture policy was in dire need of reform. First BSE and now the foot and mouth crisis, said Mr Brown, had led to a "very exciting opportunity" for change in Europe.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, said environmental degradation and poverty were intertwined. She called for improved trade access for developing countries and the dismantling of agricultural subsidies which damaged the developing world.

But she challenged environmentalists to stop being anti-development: "We must have a positive agenda. If we do not, developing countries will increasingly see environmental concerns as a pre-occupation of the north."

Harnessing the elements

The potential for alternative energy sources has been explored for 20 years but never became popular because of lack of government support. Last year's utilities bill changed all that by insisting that electricity suppliers bought 10% green electricity by 2010. This is likely to add £3 a year on average to householders' bills.

Wind power

Wind power is already commercially viable at some sites and is the fastest developing renewable energy in the UK.

Despite having more potential than anywhere else in Europe the technology has made a slow start because of the countryside lobby, which has campaigned successfully against onshore wind farms. However, there is virtually no opposition to offshore wind power. Its advantage is that much larger turbines can be used and the wind blows steadily out to sea, adding to efficiency.

The drawback is the extra cost of installation and the length of cables to the shore. In the last few months, and with another boost from the prime minister yesterday, the off-shore wind industry is about to take off. The crown estates are due to allocate 10 sites for offshore wind farms and industry has put up £1bn to build them.

The UK has high hopes of reaching 5% of electricity supply from wind power by 2010, while the rest of Europe has higher targets.

Solar power

This has the greatest potential worldwide and could, in theory, provide 85% of UK energy needs. Germany, with a programme to build 100,000 solar roofs, and Japan, with 70,000 already under way, are ahead of targets. However, the UK has fewer than 10 properties providing power to the national grid and would require £30m a year to catch up.

Greenpeace and others have pushed hard for the government to take up the challenge posed by other industrial nations and were celebrating Tony Blair's conversion yesterday. Solar Century, a company promoting solar power, said if every south facing roof in Britain carried a solar panel it would generate 85% of the country's electricity needs.

The mass production of photovoltaic cells, which turn sunlight into electricity, would be required. Shell and BP have already set up factories in other countries because of Britain's lack of commitment to the technology.

Wave & tidal power

A great resource for the UK because we have some of the highest tides in the world and are battered by Atlantic waves, which scientists tell us are getting bigger all the time.

Already there are plans to build three artificial islands off the coast of Wales to capture the incoming tide and generate electricity on the ebb. These islands would also have wind turbines on top and wave power generators attached making them energy islands. They would also have the advantage of creating protection against storms.

There is an experimental wave station on the Isle of Islay and the government has warmed to the technology. The greatest potential is lines of generators offshore gaining energy from floats bobbing on the waves like ducks. In the 1980s when the UK had a world lead the Thatcher government killed all research on a device called "Salter's Duck" because of a miscalculation on cost.

Unlike wind, tides are predictable so suppliers would know years in advance the precise energy yield from this technology.

There have also been successful experiments using turbines in tidal areas which are reversible to take advantage of the ebb and flow.

Taken together these technologies could provide up to 50% of the UK's power.

webTitle: Blair and Ahern scale down Ulster deal aims

fields.headline: Blair and Ahern scale down Ulster deal aims
fields.standfirst:
Prime ministers seek IRA gesture before election

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, have privately abandoned any hope of brokering a definitive deal to save the Northern Ireland peace process before the general election.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, have privately abandoned any hope of brokering a definitive deal to save the Northern Ireland peace process before the general election.

Sources in London and Dublin confirmed last night that the two prime ministers, who are expected to chair round table talks in Belfast tomorrow, have instead set their sights on finalising an interim agreement which would tide the process over until after the British election.

Under the revised Anglo-Irish plan, the IRA would make a gesture to unionists by reopening talks with the international body overseeing paramilitary disarmament. David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader and first minister, would respond to such a move by lifting his ban on Sinn Fein attending meetings of a special cross border ministerial council.

Political talks would be placed into a formal review, allowing Northern Ireland's power sharing executive and the assembly to continue to function throughout the election campaign. "This is the minimum to ensure that the institutions can continue to function through the election," an Irish source said.

The plan marks a significant scaling down of the definitive deal which Mr Blair and Mr Ahern had hoped to put in place ahead of the election. Under this plan, the IRA would have agreed to put some of its arms physically beyond use. In return, Mr Trimble would have lifted his ban on Sinn Fein and the British government would have started to dismantle army watch towers in border areas. In the new atmosphere, all sides would sign up to the new police force which replaces the RUC.

After conceding that these plans are now over-ambitious, British and Irish officials held talks yesterday in the hope of laying the ground for round table discussions tomorrow on the more modest interim plan.

Jonathan Powell, the prime minister's chief of staff, held talks in Downing Street with Dermot Gallagher, the taoiseach's adviser on Northern Ireland. This was followed by a 15-minute telephone conversation at lunchtime between the two prime ministers. The Irish officials then flew to Belfast for talks with Sinn Fein.

Sinn Fein and the Ulster Unionists will both find it difficult to accept even an interim deal. Mr Trimble has told the prime minister in recent weeks that he cannot accept any deal which stops short of delivering "product" - his term for the actual destruction of IRA weapons. Republicans will also be reluctant to make even a small gesture on disarmament in return for the lifting of the Trimble ban on Sinn Fein because they say it is illegal.

A spokesman for Mr Blair said last night that the two prime ministers still hoped to go ahead with the round table talks. "Both agreed that if it was possible to try and push things forward this week, then that was what we would try and do," the spokesman said.

There were signs of tensions earlier in the day when Irish officials reacted with some surprise to reports in yesterday's London papers that the talks would go ahead on Thursday. Irish officials said that the taoiseach had no plans to postpone a 10-day visit to Japan and the United States which starts on Thursday. There were signs last night that Mr Ahern would be prepared to postpone the visit.

British and Irish sources said last night that they had given up on a definitive deal until after the election because all the pro-agreement parties faced pressures in the election. Sinn Fein is concerned that a dramatic gesture on disarmament will strengthen the hands of republican dissidents who demonstrated their determination to step up their violence with the weekend attack on the BBC.

Mr Trimble is concerned that remaining in the power-sharing executive, without serious movement on decommissioning, will strengthen the position of Ian Paisley's Democrat Unionists in the election.

John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, attempted to maintain the momentum last night by insisting that the new police service would be in place by September even if nationalists refused to endorse the force.

Irish officials said that the taoiseach had no plans to postpone a 10-day visit to Japan and the United States which starts on Thursday. There were signs last night that Mr Ahern would be prepared to postpone the visit. British and Irish sources said last night that they had given up on a definitive deal until after the election because all the pro-agreement parties faced pressures in the election. Sinn Fein is concerned that a dramatic gesture on disarmament will strengthen the hands of republican dissidents who demonstrated their determination to step up their violence with the weekend attack on the BBC. Mr Trimble is concerned that remaining in the power-sharing executive, without serious movement on decommissioning, will strengthen the position of Ian Paisley's Democrat Unionists in the election. John Reid, the Northern Ireland secretary, attempted to maintain the momentum last night by insisting that the new police service would be in place by September even if nationalists refused to endorse the force.

webTitle: All livestock markets banned across Europe

fields.headline: All livestock markets banned across Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Fears that foot and mouth disease will cross the Channel last night prompted Britain's European partners to ban livestock markets throughout the EU in a move that will affect millions of animals.
fields.body:
Fears that foot and mouth disease will cross the Channel last night prompted Britain's European partners to ban livestock markets throughout the EU in a move that will affect millions of animals.

The EU's powerful standing veterinary committee also agreed that every vehicle leaving British shores for continental Europe must have its tyres disinfected.

The emergency measures were agreed at the end of a stormy eight-hour meeting in Brussels which heard repeated assurances from the UK's deputy chief veterinary officer, Richard Cawthorne, that the disease is nearing its peak in Britain.

Although there has not been a single confirmed case in mainland Europe, scares in France, Belgium and Denmark have sown panic. Seven new cases were confirmed in the UK yesterday, bringing the total to 81.

Officials claimed Italian and German representatives at yesterday's meeting were verging on the hysterical, sometimes demanding measures so extreme that they would have crippled Europe's farmers and served no useful purpose. Veterinary officers finally voted to extend a ban on exports of British meat and livestock products, due to expire on Friday, until March 27.

They also voted to ban all livestock markets throughout the EU until March 27.

Officials did agree, however, to allow farmers to take their animals to slaughter and transport them from farm to farm for the time being. Italy pushed yesterday for a total ban on livestock movements throughout the EU but was dissuaded. Germany wanted an EU-wide ban on the movement of horses but was defeated.

"I think there's quite a danger that if you're not seen to act in proportion to the risk that you could raise anxieties in the population and the farming community at large," a government source said last night.

"There is a general feeling that there is panic in Europe and the view from our vets was that a number of the extreme measures suggested were in danger of leaving the science behind."

The source said that the government felt that last night's measures were at the upper limit of what it found acceptable.

fields.body:
Bad day

Anne Robinson. Several MPs angrily demanded that The Weakest Link presenter be summoned to parliament to explain herself after she labelled the Welsh "irritating" and "so pleased with themselves" when she appeared on a TV programme with comedian Paul Merton. "What are they for?" she asked. Members of the Commons Welsh select committee were furious. "While we do have broad shoulders in Wales I think it is bordering on racist," Martin Jones, MP for Clwyd South, said.

Quote of the day

Veteran leftwinger Dennis Skinner in defence of Lord Irvine over party fundraising. "Why is it, if I'm running and racing round the country raising money for all these Labour MPs in these marginal seats, why is it that the lord chancellor can't pull his weight as well? I expect him to raise more money than me. He's a posh lawyer."

Retirement of day

Bruce Grocott, Tony Blair's parliamentary private secretary (or bag carrier as some would call the job), and MP for Telford, announced he is to stand down from the Commons at the election.

Today

Commons: Welsh questions. Prime minister's questions. Budget statement by the chancellor. Lords: Debates on potentially hazardous near-earth objects, and on southern Africa.

fields.headline: Missing files delay freedom act
fields.standfirst: Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Plans to introduce the Freedom of Information Act across government from April next year have been postponed after the discovery that thousands of Whitehall files are missing, a minister has admitted.
fields.body:
Plans to introduce the Freedom of Information Act across government from April next year have been postponed after the discovery that thousands of Whitehall files are missing, a minister has admitted.

Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister in charge of freedom of information, told a London conference that the earliest Whitehall could implement the new act was July 2002, and that date was not certain.

Mr O'Brien said that a management review he had launched inside the Home Office had revealed that documents were missing, had been misfiled or could not be retrieved easily.

"I do not want to introduce a new system and then find out it cannot work because we do not have a proper system to retrieve documents or that we cannot retrieve them because we do not know where they are", he told a conference on freedom of information at Canada House

Mr O'Brien's announcement is an embarrassment for Jack Straw, the home secretary, who told the information commissioner, Elizabeth France, earlier this year that he wanted the Home Office to be the Whitehall guinea pig for the Freedom of Information Act by implementing it in October, six months in advance of everybody else.

Civil servants attending this week's conference told the Guardian that the discovery of the missing files in the Home Office is expected to be replicated across government.

The act will be retrospective so that documents held over the past 30 years can be requested for the first time by the public.

Ministers will blame Lady Thatcher and John Major for much of the problem which stems from a decision to cut back on bureaucracy in the 1980s and 1990s.

One official said: "The cuts on bureaucracy meant that civil servants had to keep front line services running - so they cut back on filing or didn't keep any records at all unless it was essential."

webTitle: Tories reject 'myth' of cradle to grave welfare

fields.headline: Tories reject 'myth' of cradle to grave welfare
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday underlined their belief that the cradle to grave welfare system is gone for ever with proposals to encourage people to make their own provision for care in old age.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday underlined their belief that the cradle to grave welfare system is gone for ever with proposals to encourage people to make their own provision for care in old age.

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said that those who took out insurance for long term care costs would have "some of their assets" protected rather than being taken by the state to cover expenses. Families who took responsibility for care of elderly relatives would be rewarded with tax breaks, Dr Fox told the right-leaning Politeia think tank.

The proposals, condemned by Labour as covert privatisation of health and social care, underline Tory determination to use the tax system to shift responsibilities from the state to individuals.

Dr Fox said that 160,000 elderly people had been forced to sell their homes under the four years of Labour government to finance long term care under a policy that penalised thrift. "They believed the myth of cradle to grave welfare," he said. "People working today need to be encouraged to make more financial preparations for their later years in order not to repeat the experience of many current pensioners and put all their eggs in the state's basket."

Those who insured themselves would be expected to meet bills of up to around £20,000, but would then have all costs picked up by the state, leaving assets to be handed on to relatives, Tory sources said last night.

The Conservatives are attempting to exploit controversy over government plans on long term care, which will see a new division between nursing and personal care. Under the reforms, nursing care for the elderly will for the first time be free in care homes - a policy the Tories intend to maintain - but residents in England and Wales will continue to have to pay their own personal care costs, such as bathing, dressing and feeding.

In Scotland, where the Liberal Democrats share power with Labour, both personal and nursing care costs will be free, in line with national Lib Dem policy and with the recommendations of the government's own royal commission on long term care.

Campaigners for the elderly, who have condemned the government's decision not to make personal care free, last night questioned the Tory scheme. Tessa Harding, head of policy at Age Concern, said care insurance was "not viable for most people because of the cost and the difficulty of finding a policy to cover an unknown future".

fields.headline: Teacher training applicants up 19%
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Applications for teacher training courses are up 19% in England and Wales compared with this time last year, according to figures released today.
fields.body:
Applications for teacher training courses are up 19% in England and Wales compared with this time last year, according to figures released today.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, welcomed the increases, particularly in key shortage subjects at secondary level.

But the government will move to ease teacher shortages with measures in today's budget as incentives for retired and former teachers to return to the profession. About 230,000 people in Britain have a teaching certificate but are not working in schools.

Some 23,699 applications had been made to postgraduate courses of initial teacher training by March 2, up from 19,981 on 12 months ago.

Secondary applications, normally well below primary, have almost kept pace, at 18% compared with 20%.

In shortage subjects where new teachers receive a £4,000 golden hello, science applications are up 27% - including a 24% rise for physics, English applications are up 19%, maths 14% and modern languages 7%.

"Given that we are in a period of good economic growth, this rise in applications is particularly encouraging, and shows that teaching is finally getting the respect it deserves," Mr Blunkett said.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the National Union of Teachers, said: "Applications are simply that. They do not turn into young people on training courses nor do they necessarily turn into teachers."

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said it was "a huge turnaround - one has to say that it is welcome news".

But he added: "The government must not be complacent. Schools are reaching a critical point in terms of teacher supply. We need huge increases to turn around the persistent year on year to meet targets."

webTitle: Number of nurses struck off up by half

fields.headline: Number of nurses struck off up by half
fields.trailText: The number of nurses struck off the register for professional misconduct rose by 50% last year as the authorities responded to increased complaints from hospital managers, patients and relatives.
fields.body:
The number of nurses struck off the register for professional misconduct rose by 50% last year as the authorities responded to increased complaints from hospital managers, patients and relatives.

Figures released yesterday by the UK Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting showed that 113 nurses were removed from the register last year, compared with 74 in 1999. It also imposed 41 cautions, compared with 22 the year before.

The council said the increase in disciplinary sanctions was probably caused by the public's greater willingness to complain rather than by any deterioration of professional standards.

"We can see no reason why there should be more misconduct now than there was 10 or 15 years ago," a spokesman said.

But the figures suggest that cases reaching a full hearing of the council's professional conduct committee were more likely than before to result in disciplinary action, suggesting that many of the complaints were well founded.

The report came as the General Medical Council, the doctors' disciplinary body, said it had suspended 25 doctors under the emergency banning orders introduced six months ago in response to the Harold Shipman case. Immediate suspensions pending a full hearing by the GMC's disciplinary committee were running at about one a week. They were made in cases where the allegations against a doctor were grave and did not prejudge the outcome of proceedings, a spokeswoman said.

Interim suspensions were introduced to protect the public during the GMC's lengthy investigations. A further 15 doctors have had conditions imposed on their practice pending a hearing.

The GMC last month re ported an unprecedented 50% increase in the number of complaints against doctors. There were 4,470 last year, compared with about 3,000 in 1999. The council said the rise could be due to the body's higher profile: "Because we dealt with several big cases last year, more members of the public know about us and take grievances to us."

Giving detailed figures for nursing, the UKCC said allegations of misconduct increased 16% last year to 1,255. Nearly half came from nurses' employers, about 22% from the public, 22% from the police or courts and 9% from other professionals.

The council's preliminary proceedings committee screened 1,522 cases (some hanging over from the previous year). It took no further action in 793 cases and referred 214 to the professional conduct committee for a full hearing, compared with 160 in 1999.

A further 327 cases were submitted for further investigation and 101 were forwarded to a panel of screeners which considers cases of nurses who may be unfit to practice on health grounds rather than misconduct.

Liz McAnulty, the council's director of professional conduct, said: "In some ways, the UKCC is a victim of its own success. Because we are now processing more initial complaints, the number of cases awaiting a hearing currently stands at 135 and is continuing to grow."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "The vast majority of nurses are providing the high quality care the public expects and deserve. It's a positive trend that patients and their families increasingly feel they have the right, and are able, to raise concerns."

fields.headline: Collymore quits: the reaction
fields.trailText: Leicester manager Peter Taylor
fields.body:
Leicester manager Peter Taylor

"To be fair, Stan had the potential to be one of the best centre-forwards in England. He was capable of being the best - but you've got to want to be the best.

"You've got to want to train and improve every day. Stan still had a decent career but it could have been so much better and he could have achieved a lot more.

"He should have won a lot of England caps, a lot more, but this game is so hard and if you are not 100% for it then it is very hard. You've got to want to play and if Stan is not enjoying it, and the desire has gone, then perhaps he is right to retire.

"But I will say that he was a decent fellow to be with and it's a shame his career has ended like this."

Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond

"He was always talking about long contracts. I don't think retirement was on the agenda. It's come as a complete and total surprise. Stan was great to deal with. He's intelligent, he's articulate and he's a nice person. He's obviously had these problems. But that's Stan - he's only ever one half step away from the next problem."

"He should reconsider his decision. I'd tell him to go on a good holiday, forget about football for the rest of this season and spend the summer getting really fit. Then get back involved again at the start of next season.

"There remains great potential in Stan Collymore to still make a major contribution, I'm sure of that. His greatest talent is certainly as a footballer, and my strong advice to him would be to get the show back on the road in that direction."

"He was on £25,000 a week everywhere else, and I never once saw him smile. I don't know what has gone on in Spain. He had problems here, there and everywhere. I know Stan loves playing football and entertaining millions up and down the country. I hope he comes back on the circuit somewhere.

Barry Fry

"It was a wasted talent, like George Best. Best was the best footballer ever and quit too early. It's the same with Stan - it is too early. I urge him to reconsider.

"There will only be one Best, but Stan could have played for England far more times. He was very gifted, with magnificent pace, power in both feet and as well as a tremendous goal-scoring rate he made goals as well."

"He was brilliant at Southend. He played with a smile on his face and excited me every time he got the ball. He was not only brilliant on the field but brilliant off it as well. He met with kids to talk about the game and talked to them about the dangers of taking drugs.

"That is a side you never see. On his nights off he would watch another team play football. He was a football nut. I don't know what went on after leaving Southend - something went wrong."
