fields.headline: Stakeout, Sweep, and Swipe
fields.trailText: STANLEY VICTOR COLLYMORE 1989 - 2001
fields.body:
STANLEY VICTOR COLLYMORE 1989 - 2001

Since our stakeout of Luton airport only two months ago, the Fiver has made many friends in the world of air travel. Hostesses, grizzled pilots, baggage handlers, some fella who used to be mates with the cousin of Jeremy off of Airport, we know the lot. So when we got a tip-off that Stanley Victor Collymore had returned to the country in high dudgeon pulling umpteen suitcases through Heathrow airport, our ears pricked up.

And for good reason too, it seems. According to a statement released through his spokesman, Stanley has retired from the beautiful game at the age of 30 to "spend as much time as possible with his family". A two-month spell at Spanish side Real Oviedo which mustered only three appearances as substitute was the final chapter in a career which stirred up more controversy than most Neil Morrisseys manage in a lifetime. Stanley leaves behind seven clubs, a chunky wage packet, and an untidy bedroom.

Such is the enigmatic nature of the man that, even this afternoon, Oviedo officials were denying that Stanley had returned home for any other reason than to visit his pregnant girlfriend. "He has to check all things and then he will come back," said general manager Felix Ortega. "At this stage you have to believe your player. I personally spoke to him last night and he was very worried. I could tell from the tone of his voice, I don't think he's lying." D'oh.

Send your messages of condolence to the.boss@theguardian.com.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

FIXTURE NEWS FROM THE HORSE'S (FOOT-AND-)MOUTH

Foot-and-mouth: it's the disease that's sweeping the nation. And with cattle losing weight quicker than the cast of Ally McBeal, farmers' livelihoods are at stake. So far, thank goodness, the disease has been largely confined to Britain. But in lovely Oporto, an association of cattle dealers are already tinkering with their shotguns and firing up their cow-burning chambers. Because they fear they could be next. And with good reason - 6,000 Liverpool fans are about to touch down in Portugal, and foot-and-mouth could be making the ride with them.

Today, the Portuguese Association of Producers of Meat and Milk (Leicar), called for the huge Euro Vase match between Porto and Liverpool to be postponed until the disease burns itself out (or, more likely, all the animals in the UK are in cattle heaven). "The region around Porto holds half of Portugal's milk production," they warned. "And lots of UK sport has been called off," they harangued. Meanwhile, the Portuguese government just laughed at them.

So tomorrow's match will go ahead as planned, which is good news for football fans everywhere, although less so for the Portuguese dairy farming community. As a result, Porto have washed their hands of all responsibility if the disease spreads to Portugal. "This is nothing to do with Porto," a spokesman told the Fiver. "As someone in the government has pointed out, people travel from England to Portugal every day, so you can't blame a football match if the disease comes over here. It's nonsense." So will the club have any measures at all to stop foot-and-mouth? "No, nothing. But at the airport the Liverpool supporters will have to do the cleaning of the shoes," the spokesman added helpfully. That should be enough.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I love players but the modern player has more power than at any stage ever in professional football. I am all for modern change but you can go miles overboard" - Martin O'Neill, who knows a little bit about going overboard, says his £70,000-a-week-worth on the transfer issue.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

RAUL: GOAL MENACE

When Dastardly Diego Maradona tipped the ball over Peter Shilton's head with his stumpy mitt all those years ago, at least he did so with sleight of hand. (Come on, be honest, you weren't sure what had happened until you saw the replay either.) Real Madrid striker Raul, however, is a blatant little sod, and seven minutes into last night's Big Cup match against Leeds, he rose like a world-class volleyball player, spiked the ball into the Leeds net and raced off up the pitch slobbering all over his flipper. What a goal! What an opportunist! What a cheeky bugger!

Sadly for Leeds, Raul's deed can never be erased from the record books, and the result will forever stand. But at least they can take some satisfaction from the fact that the Spaniard is about to be put over Lennart Johansson's knee and given a jolly good Beano-style slippering. "We will be taking action against Real Madrid striker Raul," said a Uefa spokesman, angrily rolling up his sleeves like Mr The Menace and Mr The Dodger used to do when angry. "I don't think the disciplinary committee will ban Raul for the use of his hand but a fine may be applied."

Now, regular readers of the aforementioned august tome will remember that characters often escaped punishment by placing large items down their trousers in order to cushion the blows. But being a footballer, Raul was never likely to be as inventive, so he whined and pleaded innocence instead. "There is no way that I touched the ball with my hand," he denied flatly in the face of damning video evidence. "It was a rapid move, I jumped up strongly with a Leeds defender and when I saw the ball, it was already in the net. I don't know what I hit the ball with, but it was not with my hand." The Fiver doesn't know why he's bothering: if he simply got on with it and shoved his pay packet down his shorts, he won't feel a thing.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Tottenham are interested in Spartak Moscow midfielders Egor Titov and Victor Bulatov, according to Sergei Rebrov. "Yes, it is true," Rebrov admitted. "The Tottenham management was asking my opinion about Spartak Moscow midfielders Titov and Bulatov. They are both highly regarded in London."

Newcastle could make a renewed bid to sign Brazilian striker Ronaldo on loan, claims Teamtalk. According to the website, Newcastle are usually quick to dismiss transfer speculation, but when asked about Ronaldo "a spokeswoman merely said United 'have no comment to make on the story.'" So it must be true, then.

Newcastle's assistant manager Mick Wadsworth will watch Honduras defender Milton Reyes play against Peru in Miami tonight.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leeds United reserve player Tony Hackworth has walked free from court after being cleared of involvement in a violent attack on an Asian student in January last year. The 20-year-old striker was formally found not guilty of causing grievous bodily harm with intent and affray to Sarfaz Najeib and was discharged following legal submissions at Hull Crown Court.

Hackworth said through his solicitor outside court that he was glad that the "nightmare" of the last 12 months was over. His lawyer John Perry said: "Let's make it quite clear - he has been acquitted on the direction of the judge today. He has been awarded his costs and he is now free to pursue his career as a young sportsman. I wish him every success in that."

Football's international players' union FIFpro are likely to take the European Commission to court over new rules governing soccer transfers, which they believe infringe players' rights and break European law. "We are still thinking about it but really we have no other choice," FIFpro secretary-general Theo van Seggelen said today.

St Etienne fullback Patrice Carteron has been loaned to Sunderland until the end of the season with a view to a permanent move.

Roland Nilsson has been appointed as assistant coach to Gordon Strachan at Coventry City.

An Italian Football Federation technical committee has ruled that Roberto Mancini cannot take over as Fiorentina coach until the end of the season. "The rules are there and they have to be respected. No coach can be registered with more than one club in any one season," said Azeglio Vicini, the committee's vice-president.

Christoph Daum, discarded as German national coach last year after failing a drugs test, has signed an 18-month contract with his former club Besiktas.

Betting tax from will be abolished from January 1 2002, Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown confirmed in this afternoon's Budget.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match Live - Panathinaikos v Manchester United (7.30pm) "I am a ludicrously well-paid creative director at an ad agency in Boston," writes Jon Rice.

The Big Match (11.45pm) "It's rapidly going down the pan because of the economy (and because of the aforementioned ridiculous sums of cash thrown at me to talk in an English accent and appear knowledgeable)."

Sky Sports 1: The Last Word (6.30pm, 11pm SS3) "I reckon my 15 minutes with the Fiver every day has cost my company precisely $4,375 over the past year."

Futbol Mundial (7pm, 12midnight) "Impressive as this is, however, it is nothing compared to the estimated $14,000 worth of company time I have spent playing Championship Manager 00/01 and taking Sheffield Wednesday to the European Champions Cup final."

Soccer Special (7.30pm) But the Fiver isn't just losing company money. We're also taking food out of people's mouths.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm, 2am) "For over six months now myself and two other friends have been reading the Fiver every morning," writes Ed Worker.

ONsport 1: Big Cup Football - Arsenal v Spartak Moscow (5.10pm) "That's a total of 195 hours, using the incredibly slow reading standard of Jim."

ONgoals (7pm) "Slight difference is that we are all aid workers in Burundi (that small war torn country next to Rwanda)."

Big Cup Football - Panathinaikos v Manchester United (10pm) "Using the internationally renowned food aid distribution index, as unrecognised by the Economist, that results in 195 hours less of food distributions @ 10 metric tons-an-hour "

Radio 5 Live: Sport on 5 (7pm) " giving a grand total loss of 1,950 MT of food aid."

Midweek 6-0-6 (10pm) "I'm sure the United Nations would be very interested, although they manage to waste far more time by being crap alone."

Talksport: Football First Champions League (7pm) Using the estimated average cost per ton of wheat in, say, Eastern New Mexico and Texas, we reckon that's $80,301 down the pan. Add on Jon's $4,375 and today's total is $84,676, or £57,903.14, boosting the Fiver Scam Totaliser to £59,219.14. Keep 'em flooding in to the.boss@theguardian.com and let's keep this baby moving.

Newcastle's assistant manager Mick Wadsworth will watch Honduras defender Milton Reyes play against Peru in Miami tonight. * * * * * * * * * * * * * NEWS IN BRIEF Leeds United reserve player Tony Hackworth has walked free from court after being cleared of involvement in a violent attack on an Asian student in January last year. The 20-year-old striker was formally found not guilty of causing grievous bodily harm with intent and affray to Sarfaz Najeib and was discharged following legal submissions at Hull Crown Court. Hackworth said through his solicitor outside court that he was glad that the "nightmare" of the last 12 months was over. His lawyer John Perry said: "Let's make it quite clear - he has been acquitted on the direction of the judge today. St Etienne fullback Patrice Carteron has been loaned to Sunderland until the end of the season with a view to a permanent move. Roland Nilsson has been appointed as assistant coach to Gordon Strachan at Coventry City. fields.headline: Stan Collymore factfile
fields.trailText: 1971
fields.body:
1971

Born Stone, Staffordshire, January 22.

1989

Kicked off career with Walsall, who later cancelled his YTS contract. Wolves completed his trainee term and he scored 18 goals in 20 games for their youth side but failed to make first team. Joined Conference club Stafford Rangers, scoring eight goals in first season.

1990

Moved to Crystal Palace for £100,000. Made six league appearances as substitute in first season.

1992

Left Palace (four League starts, 16 sub appearances, one goal) after being deployed as a winger. Joined Southend (November) for £80,000 and scored 18 goals in 33 games (15 in 30 League).

1993

Nottingham Forest manager Brian Clough refused to pay Southend's £2.2million asking price. Forest relegated, Clough left club and Collymore signed for his successor Frank Clark for original fee, rising to £2.75m on goal and international achievements.

1994

Hit 24 goals (19 in 28 League games) as Forest won immediate return to Premiership. Clark says £10million offer might tempt a sale.

1995

Manchester United fail in New Year signing bid, settling instead for £7million Andy Cole. In February Collymore acquitted of assault charge for alleged fight outside nightclub. Scores season's total of 25 goals (22 League), including 10 in last two months, as Forest finish third in Premiership and qualify for UEFA Cup. First England cap against Japan on June 3 and second as a substitute against Brazil. Joins Liverpool for British record £8.5million.

1996

Makes 44 appearances in his first season at Anfield and scores 19 goals as Liverpool finish third in the Premiership. Scores the winner in a memorable 4-3 victory over Newcastle meaning the Magpies finish as runners-up to Manchester United. As new season kicks off, Collymore still commutes from his West Midlands home to Merseyside, and finds competition for his first team place from Czech Republic striker Patrik Berger. Aston Villa reported to have failed in a £6million bid for Collymore. Fined £20,000 for not attending training but Liverpool boss Roy Evans says Collymore will be staying even though he fails to play a reserve team fixture.

1997

Better form sees Collymore called up to the England squad to play Mexico in a Wembley friendly. Finishes season having made 37 appearances and scored 16 goals. May 13: Joins Villa in a £7million deal. October: Sent off and given a three-match ban after exchanging blows with Bolton defender Andy Todd. Undergoes nose operation to cure a breathing problem.

1998

March: Accuses Liverpool's Steve Harkness of racist abuse during and after Villa's 2-1 home victory. PFA forced to step in as neither player backs down. Both shake hands as they agree to disagree.

June: Involved in an altercation with girlfriend and television presenter Ulrika Jonsson in a bar in

Paris. Via a statement from his agent, Collymore "deeply regrets everything that occurred" and "is beside himself with remorse" before publicly apologising. September: Collymore scores a hat-trick in Villa's UEFA Cup win over Stromsgodset.

1999

January: Collymore announces that he is seeking counselling for troubles in his private life, and spends two weeks in a clinic to undergo treatment for depression.

February: Returns to Villa side against Leeds. After 3-0 home defeat by Chelsea, Villa boss John Gregory admits he will not pick Collymore again this season as he needs full-time treatment for his depression.

June: Collymore has talks with Greek club Panathinaikos but a proposed deal falls through.

August: Starts the season with a three-month loan at Fulham, with a view to a £1m permanent deal. But Collymore and Fulham fail to agree terms and he returns to Villa.

December: Collymore talks over a move to French club Montpellier but the deal is off when Collymore refuses to play in a practice match.

2000

February: Bradford end their interest in Collymore because they refuse to pay a £3million transfer fee. Leicester sign Collymore on an incentive-based pay-as-you-play deal.

February 16: Leicester are thrown out of their La Manga training base after Collymore is accused of letting off a fire extinguisher in a bar. The Spanish resort's bosses ordered the team to leave after the incident.

February 17: Fined two weeks' wages for letting off the fire extinguisher and warned about future conduct. Collymore is also required to undertake additional community duties for deserving causes in Leicestershire at the direction of manager Martin O'Neill. The former England international and all the Leicester players are told to pay all costs of the trip, and additional air fares will be paid for by the players. A hotel bill of £700 for damage to the bar area will also be paid by the players.

March: Collymore scores a hat-trick on his home debut for Leicester in the 5-2 victory over Sunderland.

April: Breaks left leg in the 17th minute of the 3-0 defeat at Derby.

August: Scores first goal after his horrific injury in a 3-0 friendly win at Wycombe. Targets an England recall, citing Paul Gascoigne as an example of a player who is still on the fringe of international recognition in his 30s.

September: The FA confirm that their video advisory panel will meet to review Collymore's tangle with Gascoigne in the Premiership clash with Everton, when the Leicester striker appeared to stamp on - and later elbow - Gascoigne.

October 2: Leicester officially accept Collymore's transfer request on the same day that the player is charged with violent conduct by the FA following the clash with Gascoigne.

October 29: Scores on his Bradford debut as they draw 1-1 with Leeds at Valley Parade.

November 28: Handed three-match ban by FA disciplinary committee over his attack on Gascoigne.

2001

January: Told he can leave Bradford by new boss Jim Jefferies.

January 31: Signs an 18-month contract with Spanish side Real Oviedo.

February 2: Makes his debut as a second-half substitute during the 1-0 defeat at Las Palmas and after another appearance from the bench, Collymore is dropped from the squad to face Real Zaragoza after coach Raddy Antic decided the striker was not fit enough to play.

March 6: Announces his retirement from professional football.

webTitle: Points jolted express into freight train

fields.headline: Points jolted express into freight train
fields.standfirst:
Rail inspector's report finds Selby crash was 'beyond control of industry' with no evidence of errors by staff or faults in equipment

Special report: Selby train crash
fields.trailText: Rail inspector's report finds Selby crash was 'beyond control of industry' with no evidence of errors by staff or faults in equipment.
fields.body:
A set of points almost certainly jolted the Newcastle-London express into hitting an early-running freight train a week ago in the highest speed accident yet recorded on the rail network, according to the first official report on the tragedy in which 10 people died.

The points at Great Heck near Selby, for a siding to a cement works, were 700 metres further from where the train had collided with a Land Rover. The second jolt they gave the train, causing it to strike the freight on a parallel line, had added to a string of coincidences the railway inspectorate described as "highly unlikely and unpredictable".

The coincidences included the Land Rover slewing off the M62 through a gap of only a few hundred metres between safety barriers, and the trains crossing less than a minute later. The chief inspector of railways, Vic Coleman, said the resulting impact at a combined speed of at least 140mph had been "beyond the control of the railway industry", and no immediate changes would be ordered by the health and safety executive.

Published in York, the express train's last stop last Wednesday morning, the report found "no evidence to suggest that there were any errors by railway staff or faults with the signalling, rolling stock or track".

The full inquiry will face pressure from rail unions and safety groups to look closely at GNER and other companies' use of "push-pull" locomotive units permanently coupled at one end of trains, which meant that the train in question was headed by a relatively light driving van trailer. At 30 tonnes, compared with the 80 tonnes of the power unit at the rear, the DVT was derailed by the front of the Land Rover and then jerked to the right by the points, before being crushed by hitting the Freightliner coal train. The flattened remains of the unit, initially thought to have been a brutally crushed carriage, formed one of the first and most horrific images shown from the field in North Yorkshire where most of the express ended up.

Mr Coleman said that the forces in the collision had been so great that the "push-pull" system - which sees the power car pulling going north and pushing going south - was unlikely to be a factor. But the report contrasted the shattering of the DVT with the "remarkable" way the steel-framed coaches and the rear locomotive stood up to the huge impact, and said further examination would be made.

Mr Coleman said that, in spite of the grievous loss of life, including four crew and two passengers who worked in the rail industry, engineering colleagues had "marvelled" at the way the express coped. Only the front wheels of the DVT were derailed by the Land Rover, and without the points, it was quite possible the catastrophe might have been avoided. The report confirmed that the freight train was 20 minutes early, but Mr Coleman said that this was in order and in itself presented no threat to safety. It had just been another horrible factor in the chain of unrelated events.

An interim report by the highways agency, also published yesterday, said the M62 had been free of snow and ice at 6.12am, when surveyor Gary Hart left the westbound carriageway and ploughed for more than 150 metres to the track. The report found the road was wet but well treated with salt, and the barrier protecting the bridge was more than 12 metres longer than the recommended minimum.

John Kerman, the agency's chief highways engineer, added that the Land Rover pulling a Renault on a trailer was larger and heavier than the maximum for which the barrier was designed. Stewart Francis, chairman of the rail passengers council, said: "Urgent attention needs to be given to the siting and crash worthiness of barriers between road and rail."

Two passengers remain in a serious condition out of 76 people taken to hospital, 40 with minor injuries. The police investigation is concentrating on the mechanical condition of the Land Rover, and further interviews with Mr Hart, 36, from Strubby, Lincolnshire, when he has fully recovered from shock and distress.

webTitle: 27 visits by social worker failed to save child

fields.headline: 27 visits by social worker failed to save child
fields.trailText: A man who subjected his two-year-old daughter to a systematic campaign of violent abuse despite numerous visits by social services was jailed for life yesterday for her murder. Paul Kelso reports.
fields.body:
A man who subjected his two-year-old daughter to a systematic campaign of violent abuse despite numerous visits by social services was jailed for life yesterday for her murder.

Robert Brown, 33, was visited by the same social worker 27 times in the 10 weeks before he killed his daughter Chelsea. On each occasion the social worker, Norma McDevitt, accepted his claim that he and his wife had not harmed the girl.

Ms McDevitt knew Brown was a convicted robber with a record of violent offences against children but took no action despite Chelsea's numerous injuries, Nottingham crown court was told.

Brown variously told Ms McDevitt that Chelsea had fallen in the garden, walked into a table, or banged her head while on a bus. He also blamed his other daughter, claiming the 17-month-old left Chelsea battered and bruised by pelting her with toys.

Chelsea died on December 6 1999 after Brown shook her with a force comparable to that of a high speed car crash. On the night of the attack at the family home in Kirk Hallam, Derbyshire, he pointed at his younger daughter and told paramedics: "There's the culprit." Chelsea died in hospital the following day.

A postmortem examination found 47 injuries on her head and body, including bruises running the length of her spine. At the house, police found the imprint of her head in a ceiling where Brown had smashed her into it.

Bruce Buckley, director of social services at Derbyshire county council, accepted the authority had failed in its duty of care. "We made mistakes and we got it wrong. We terribly regret what happened to Chelsea," he said. "But at the time she was returned to her home no one could have predicted the outcome. The workers were concerned - that's why they visited so regularly. But there were difficult decisions to be made, and in this case we didn't make the right ones."

He refused to comment on Ms McDevitt's conduct and declined to say whether she was still employed by the council.

Sentencing Brown to life, Mr Justice Hunt said: "I have detected no remorse and no regret - simply an attempt to shift the blame on to your wife and accept no responsibility."

Chelsea's mother, Maria Brown, 25, was jailed for 18 months after she admitted child cruelty. "You have limited intellectual capacity but sufficient understanding to know what was going on," the judge said.

"You did nothing to protect Chelsea from your husband. And I cannot ignore that you were also harsh in your punishments and often unfeeling."

The court heard that Brown killed Chelsea after almost four months of abuse. Until August 1999 she had led a healthy, happy life in the care of her paternal grandmother Janice Johnson. But Mrs Johnson felt she could no longer look after her and the child was returned to her parents.

Ms McDevitt would regularly find fresh bruises on her - yet, despite knowing Brown's history, she did not remove Chelsea from the home. She sobbed as she told how she once found a lock on the child's bedroom door during one of 27 visits to the family. She accepted the couple's explanation that it had been fitted to stop her falling down nearby stairs.

On another occasion, two months before Chelsea was killed, Ms McDevitt took her to hospital with a black eye. "She was seen by a sister, who got a doctor - and he was happy the injury was accidental," she said.

Ms McDevitt described Brown's behaviour as "inappropriate", criticising him for the physical way in which he played with his children. Brown claimed to have been throwing Chelsea in the air to "toughen her up" on the night she suffered her fatal injuries.

But neighbours said they were tormented for weeks by the sounds of him abusing his daughter. John Milmo QC, prosecuting, told the jury: "They said it was always in the same sequence - crying, shouting, silence .. crying, shouting, silence."

Banging and thumping was often followed by Brown screaming "Have you had enough yet?" and "Now do you understand?" Social services received more than half a dozen calls from worried neighbours but on one occasion did not even bother to respond.

Two days before the fatal attack the parents were offered respite care by Ms McDevitt but turned it down, insisting they wanted Chelsea to stay with them.

After the verdicts yesterday the court heard that Brown was convicted in 1984 of assaulting his sister's 16-month-old son. In 1986 he was jailed for four years for robbery, and 10 years later he was convicted of assaulting his sister.

In 1997 he was conditionally discharged for assaulting his eight-year-old nephew by kicking him and dragging him along the street. In February 1998 he was convicted of threatening to kill his mother and a social worker during a meeting about Chelsea's future.

fields.headline: Collymore announces his retirement
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore has announced his retirement from football at the age of 30.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has announced his retirement from football at the age of 30.

This afternoon his spokesman Ian Monk revealed: "Stan Collymore has decided, after discussions with his family and close friends, to give up playing professional football.

"He has just turned 30 and believes that the time is right to explore other career opportunities which are available to him. He also wants to spend as much time as possible with his family, in particular his son Thomas and his fiancée Estelle.

"Stan will always be grateful to the many people in football who have helped and supported him throughout his career. His club, Oviedo, is being informed of his decision," he added.

Suspicions were first raised last night when Collymore was seen coming through Heathrow with seven pieces of luggage. However his club, Real Oviedo insisted he had been allowed home to see his pregnant girlfriend, Estelle Williams.

"Stan has returned to England because his partner is pregnant and there was a problem," the spokesman said this morning. "We deal with reality rather than rumours. We expect the player to be back in Oviedo tomorrow morning."

But it soon became clear that the rumour was the reality. Reports in the London Evening Standard this afternoon claimed that Collymore had told Oviedo: "I've had enough," and soon after the player announced that his turbulent, and occasionally brilliant, career was over.

fields.headline: Blaming the breakers of statues
fields.standfirst: The west should perhaps temper its outrage at the Taliban's threats
fields.trailText: The west should perhaps temper its outrage at the Taliban's threats.
fields.body:
Archaeologists and historians, curators and collectors are peering into the blizzard of disinformation coming out of Afghanistan to discern whether the Taliban have carried out their threat to destroy the world's largest Buddhist statues at Bamiyan. Already at war with the present and the future, the Taliban seem to have declared war on the past.

The justification they offer, of course, is religious, the oldest and most common excuse for the destruction of art created by rival faiths. Although the international outrage is justified, it is also true that few countries are innocent of past zealotry and iconoclasm. Genghis Khan's forces destroyed Bamiyan in 1221, despite the fact that Genghis Khan himself was to become one of history's less likely Buddhists; British forces demolished most of the 15th-century mosque in Musallah in Afghanistan in 1885 and in China, temples and monasteries were demolished during the Great Leap Forward. From some perspectives, history seems like one long catalogue of destruction by one tribe of the treasures of another.

None of this excuses the destruction of the Bamiyan statues; the puzzle, though, is why the destruction should have become a matter of urgency to the Taliban now. Religious monuments were usually destroyed during active fighting or as part of a real struggle for power between competing ideologies. In this respect, the Bamiyan case is an oddity. This is not the first - or even, arguably, the greatest damage to Afghanistan's Buddhist treasures: the country's museums and their collections of early Buddhist art were looted in the early 90s. Even now, smuggled and looted treasures, including the unique Begram ivories from the Kabul museum, circulate in the world of unscrupulous dealers and collectors.

Even last year, the Taliban seemed content to live with the Bamiyan statues. When a local Taliban commander captured the valley in 1998 and began to destroy one of the Buddhas, he was ordered to stop by Mullah Mohammed Omar - the leader who has now ordered their destruction. Omar also ordered an end to the illegal excavations, organised out of Peshawar, and the Taliban appeared to be concerned to protect what was left, if only to encourage a revival of tourism.

The religious justification derives from the ban on graven images, common to the jealous God of the Old Testament and to Allah. But Dr Mohammad Hashim Kamali, himself an Afghan and professor of Islamic law and jurisprudence at the International Islamic University in Malaysia wrote, in an agonised public letter to the president of Afghanistan, "If destroying idols was justified at the time of the advent of Islam when the new faith was challenged by the idol-worshippers of Mecca, that logic does not obtain now, and there is no imminent fear of the Muslims of Afghanistan converting to idol worship ... Islam is not under threat of destruction, and justifying acts of destruction under its name is repugnant to reason, to the benefit of the people and the prevailing custom and experience which Islam itself demands to be protected and preserved." There is no battle now in Bamiyan and Buddhism has not been active there for more than a thousand years.

As Omar himself said last November when he announced that they would be protected as tourist attractions: "There are no Buddhists left in Afghanistan to worship them." If the Taliban's own pronouncements acknowledge that the religious imperative is not absolute, the question remains, why act now? The evidence points to a political gesture in which doctrine is only a pretext. Afghanistan has suffered Russian invasion, a proxy cold war, a devastating civil war, international isolation and now, UN sanctions in support of the United States' pursuit of Osama bin Laden. Only three countries recognise the Taliban government, despite the fact that it controls 90% of the country. It is not the most appealing regime, but nor is it the only regime in the world that stones adulterers to death, condemns women to a half-life behind the veil or amputates the hands of thieves. Since the moment last year when it briefly promoted tourism and today's bleak confrontation, relations with the west have deteriorated. In January another set of UN sanctions was imposed on Afghanistan, the first having produced no result.

With no commercial flights now, even last year's slim hopes of an increase in foreign visitors have withered. Afghanistan has suffered more than 20 years of war and a devastation that is as much the responsibility of outsiders as of Afghans. Afghanistan's cultural heritage, belatedly, has our attention. For the sake of the statues of Bamiyan, as well as the people of Afghanistan, perhaps we could find a more constructive response than another round of sanctions. Unless we do, the giant Buddhas will be remembered as the latest victims of a crisis the west contributed to then tried to forget.

fields.headline: The questions people ask
fields.standfirst: As well as publishing test reports, the Good Housekeeping Institute answers readers' queries. Here are the five questions most often asked about digital cameras.
fields.trailText: As well as publishing test reports, the Good Housekeeping Institute answers readers' queries. Here are the five questions most often asked about digital cameras.
fields.body:
1. How does the quality compare with conventional film cameras?

Picture quality is often much better than film cameras, and depends on the camera's resolution, measured in pixels. More pixels means more detail in a photograph. But a digital camera with a high megapixel rating does not necessarily produce the best pictures. Most digital cameras allow you to adjust the image size and quality depending on whether you want to print your photographs or email them. Changing these settings will also affect the number of pictures you can store.

2. How do digital cameras store pictures?

Pictures are stored on memory cards about the size of a large stamp, which come in a variety of memory sizes, measured in megabytes (Mb). On average, an 8Mb memory card can hold around 20 images, depending on the scene you're photographing and the quality setting used. It costs £20-£35 for an 8Mb card, but they can be reused over and over again.

3. What's the difference between optical and digital zoom?

Optical zoom lets you zoom in from a wide angle to a close-up; digital zoom just magnifies the centre of the image, reducing picture quality.

4. Do I need a computer to get prints from my digital camera?

No. Selected Boots (08450 708090) and Snappy Snaps (020-8741 7474) stores can print pictures from a memory card on to photo-quality paper. If you'd rather print your own, the Kodak Personal Picture Maker 200 (£250) can be used without a computer. If you do have a computer, there are many printers on the market. Alternatively, you can get photos printed on glossy photo paper by uploading images to Print@Kodak on Kodak's website (www.kodak.co.uk) The service costs 39p per 6x4in print (plus £1.50 p&p) and the pictures are posted to you within around five days.

5. Do I need to upgrade my computer to get the best from a digital camera?

If you bought your computer in the last five or six years, you should be fine. Most cameras come with software that is PC and Mac compatible, but check that your computer has the right type of connectors (USB or serial), and that it is up to the system requirements of the camera software.

fields.headline: It's different for boys
fields.standfirst: Jane Fonda's gender studies centre may have worthy goals, says Lynne Segal - but will it tell us anything we don't already know?
fields.trailText: Lynne Segal: Jane Fonda's gender studies centre may have worthy goals, but will it tell us anything we don't already know?
fields.body:
What will Jane Fonda learn from the millions she is pouring into gender research? I have no quarrel with her, but I somehow doubt whether the Center for Gender and Education that her $12.5m is funding will untangle the somewhat confusing thoughts underpinning her generosity. Why a centre at Harvard? Because it installed the first chair of gender studies in the heartland of the Ivy League, a post occupied by Professor Carol Gilligan.

Gilligan was an overnight celebrity feminist nearly 20 years ago. Voted Woman of the Year by Ms magazine in 1984, and gracing the cover of Newsweek, she used her psychological expertise to argue that women's moral development is distinct from that of men - different, and more desirable. Pace Thatcher, Widdecombe and Baroness Jay, women are more compassionate in their moral reasoning, less confident, dogmatic and prone to abstractions or the espousal of universal causes than men.

Since then, Gilligan has mined a seam that has uncovered the damage inflicted on adolescent girls in the US. Her work has de scribed how girls' confidence is undermined as they conform to gender scripts that silence the wisdom once acquired from earlier maternal attachments. Fonda was drawing directly on Gilligan's research when she told her Harvard audience that girls, "bright-eyed and bushy-tailed" at nine, are self-censoring and vague at 13 - despite increasing academic success. So is it, as Gilligan suggests (in tension with her own account of women's recoil from abstract thought), social pressure that undermines the wisdom that girls acquire at their mother's knee? This leaves Fonda a little muddled: "It's in my DNA. The ways girls internalise and express the difficulty of growing up, that all happened to me." Even in these days of fantastic genetic hype, we have yet to locate the DNA responsible for the tales our mothers tell us, at odds with other feminine stereotypes.

Fonda's enthusiasm for Gilligan is itself perplexing, for Fonda is concerned, primarily, with boys. "Men suffer more" from the strictures of gender, Fonda told the New York Times. They are twice as likely as girls to be diagnosed with the psychiatric illness, attention deficit hyper- activity disorder (ADHD), which is held responsible for making them aggressive and disruptive. These boys are now treated with Ritalin (and recent alternatives, Adderall or Dextrostat). Here, Fonda under- estimates the trouble with boys. Nine out of 10 children diagnosed with ADHD are boys, and prescriptions to pacify their antisocial behaviour have risen sevenfold in the US over the past decade. Contrary to popular perception, the drug is not new. What is new - and controversial - is the psychiatric diagnosis and treatment. Despite its side-effects (depression, lethargy and sleep disruption), prescriptions for Ritalin in Britain have jumped an astonishing 40-fold in five years: from 4,000 in 1994 to 157,900 in 1999. Where were all those boys suffering from this illness a decade ago?

Despite three decades of research on gender identities and differences, we have little agreement on how to understand them. Ironically, the problems with boys have strictly mirrored our attention to them. Men's studies and research on masculinity, like ADHD itself, rocketed in the 1990s. There are many alternative explanations for "bad", "mad" or "sad" boys, with just a little overlap.

The first, favoured by lawful drug dispensers, is that we are reluctant to recognise brain diseases. This is the argument proposed by Rolf Stahel, heading Shire Pharmaceuticals in the UK; meanwhile, profits of his company have increased by a factor of 177 in the last few years. Another explanation is that a diet of junk food causes children to ingest too much sulphur dioxide. Linked to ideas of "poor parenting", this accompanies the old trend of blaming working mothers. A third approach suggests that today's extraordinarily market-driven, work-oriented culture dislikes children - especially boys who seem harder to settle into the routines of nursery or school care, demanding attention from exhausted parents. A fourth account highlights the pressures on boys to compete and prove their masculine credentials of toughness and aggression. The final explanation, of course, comes from the dictates of hormones and DNA: it's the testosterone, stupid.

Given the billions already spent since the 1960s mapping the cognitive and emotional differences between the sexes - differences that are robust, albeit small overall - let us pause for thought. Clearly something happens to some little boys in our society to make them extremely troubled and troublesome. It does not happen to the majority of them, who still do as well as girls in school and fare far better in later life. In the US, it is only in families earning under $30,000 that a startling two-thirds of those reaching higher education are women. A staggering 80% of poor black American males will manage only to acquire criminal convictions. In Britain, although ADHD is said to affect all classes, it is far more prevalent among the poor. Serious behavioural problems among boys tend to appear along with the birth of younger siblings. Why male? Why black? Why poor? Why in expanding families?

A few things are certain. If anyone ever suffered from learning difficulties, ADHD and ineducability, it was two high-achieving Liverpool boys, now taking their A-levels, with clear career ambitions. They are not on Ritalin. How sad is it that as troubled pubescent boys, from poor northern families, their route to improvement was via the torture and murder of a toddler? No wonder James Bulger's parents cannot recover from their grief. Any children of their own are unlikely to enjoy similar "success".

Without question, whatever else we want to factor in, poverty and inequality feeds the tensions that boys face as they know themselves in school to be only "failures", as they live in families with either hard-working or despairing parents. These are parents who in turn fear they are failing those children whom they just might have loved better had they had the time, the money, the social respect of which the still-widening inequalities of our society deprive them. State funding for parental leave when children most need attention would be one tiny start. The majority of working parents cannot afford time whatever their need.

Dear Hanoi Jane: please return to the broader political fray. Study masculinity by all means. But do not imagine that you will help those boys suffering most simply by uncovering more gender cliche.

· Lynne Segal is professor of psychology and gender studies at Birkbeck College, London.

webTitle: Paul Morley enjoys his second childhood

fields.headline: Dad, 43, going on nine
fields.standfirst: Paul Morley enjoys his second childhood
fields.trailText: Paul Morley enjoys his second childhood.
fields.body:
In a very real sense, I am an ordinary 43-year-old man, with hair and stomach to match. But sometimes I feel that I am a nine-year-old girl. Let me explain. Madeleine, my nine-year-old daughter, hates being bored more than anything in the world. Boredom must be avoided at all costs. As far as she is concerned, my role in life is to entertain her. I might think that I am here to protect her from the Nigel Lythgows of the world, to work out exactly when she will be old enough for the rapping (or "****ing") of Eminem, and generally help prepare her for the delights and dangers of the world. I might hope that I am helping her to spell the word "beautiful" correctly, to see the benefits of a fairly early bedtime, and to appreciate that a brush - tooth or hair - can be a benefit in life. I might believe that I am here to improve her mind. But as far as Madeleine is concerned, I am mostly here to play with her, to keep her from being bored. And the only way to do that is to be a nine-year-old girl.

Being bored seems to mean having to think about, you know, things. It's difficult enough having to think about things as an adult, let alone as a nine-year-old girl. You don't really want to do it, unless you have learned, in a Zen sort of way, to appreciate these things, and see that they can be a way to calm rather than panic.

Believe me, speaking as a nine-year-old girl, I have to have things to do . I must not be bored, otherwise I have this strange urge to tear my hair out and scream at my mum. Banging the walls can be cool, too. If I'd heard of Nirvana, I'd be screaming at the top of my voice: "Entertain me!"

As a nine-year-old boy, which I was once, before I was a nine-year-old girl, I could spend hours on my own kicking a ball around in the garden. That stopped me thinking things, apart from things to do with the World Cup. Madeleine needs a lot more than that to get her through an hour: some telly, a manic game of cards, a few seconds on the jigsaw puzzle she got for Christmas, a quick read. A look at her current favourite comic, Sabrina's Secrets, which features Sabrina the teenage witch helping nine-year-old kids to paint their nails and plait their hair. The TV ad for the comic promised it would banish boredom for ever. To give the comic credit, it does occupy Maddy for a good 20 minutes - which is like a nine-year-old forever. I suffer 43-year-old shock that the comic costs £2.50. How boring is that ? For me, a comic is always going to be sixpence. Six old pence.

After Sabrina's crucial sleepover tips comes a blast of PlayStation, a form of relaxation that seems to prepare young children for a future as a machine. Eventually, she'll make an attempt at some homework.

Boredom is a fate even worse than fractions. Maddy think's it's seven-eighths of her problem. Or maybe nine-elevenths.

As a nine-year-old girl, I play along as much as I can, until I'm forced to admit that, as a 43-year-old man, there is a tendency for what keeps Madeleine's boredom at bay to magnify mine. She plays Spyro the Dragon on PlayStation (he's the cute, flying, purple one), and achieves a non-thinking bliss. In the end, I panic that I am Bad Dad for letting Maddy play the Sony boredom-buster, and I try to stop her. We have a pathetic argument; the kind of argument two nine-year-old girls tend to have.

We make up over a game of chess, and my panic subsides as I realise that the purple dragon hasn't yet ruined Maddy's ability with the knight. Madeleine, my nine-year-old daughter, hates being bored more than anything in the world. Boredom must be avoided at all costs. As far as she is concerned, my role in life is to entertain her. I might think that I am here to protect her from the Nigel Lythgows of the world, to work out exactly when she will be old enough for the rapping (or "****ing") of Eminem, and generally help prepare her for the delights and dangers of the world. I might hope that I am helping her to spell the word "beautiful" correctly, to see the benefits of a fairly early bedtime, and to appreciate that a brush - tooth or hair - can be a benefit in life. I might believe that I am here to improve her mind. But as far as Madeleine is concerned, I am mostly here to play with her, to keep her from being bored. And the only way to do that is to be a nine-year-old girl. Being bored seems to mean having to think about, you know, things. It's difficult enough having to think about things as an adult, let alone as a nine-year-old girl. You don't really want to do it, unless you have learned, in a Zen sort of way, to appreciate these things, and see that they can be a way to calm rather than panic. Believe me, speaking as a nine-year-old girl, I have to have things to do . I must not be bored, otherwise I have this strange urge to tear my hair out and scream at my mum. Banging the walls can be cool, too. If I'd heard of Nirvana, I'd be screaming at the top of my voice: "Entertain me!" webTitle: Returning to live with your parents

fields.headline: Hi, mum, I'm back!
fields.standfirst: Returning to live with your parents as an adult can be tricky for all concerned. Isla Dewar and Dolly Dhingra give both sides of the story
fields.trailText: Returning to live with your parents as an adult can be tricky for all concerned. Isla Dewar and Dolly Dhingra give both sides of the story.
fields.body:
A couple of years back I did something really uncool: I moved back in with Mum and Dad. It has taken a while to reconcile. Moving back in with your parents can be just as traumatic as moving out in the first place - and as satisfying (assuming you share a healthy relationship with your folks).

After moving out at 18, I lived with students, friends, strangers - even expeditionaries in the Zimbabwean bush. Later, I bought a house and lived on my own for several years. I was single and independent, and I loved it. I could do as I pleased. Friends from around the world stayed in my cosy abode. I had fantastic parties - life was dandy.

Then things changed. I embarked on a scriptwriting career. I sat for days on end at the PC, no longer the social butterfly of previous years. As I steered a precious script through the hellish corridors of the British film industry, my smile gave way to a constant frown.

At the same time, my mother was diagnosed with severe thyroid problems. Dynamic by nature, she now began gaining weight at an alarming rate and falling asleep at the most unlikely moments. I worried for the both of us.

It was a moment of clarity. I was tired of battling the world single-handedly. I was in no state to embark on a relationship, but no longer wanted to live with friends. I needed to experience some mutual tender loving care - it was time to go home.

"Can I move in?" I asked.

"Pack your bags right now," my mother responded. Dad was equally delighted: he needed a drinking partner and hoped that the food standards at home would improve.

I had huge reservations. The interior decor alone was enough to cause distress. Bright red carpet, garish lighting, out-of-date wallpaper: I was used to wooden floorboards, stylish Mediterranean hues, ambience.

Space, at least, was not an issue: I could have three rooms. All four siblings are married with children and have homes of their own. I had a separate phone line installed.

Accustomed to the hubbub of cosmopolitan city life, I was moving into the suburbs. Nights were silent and foxes instead of drunks prowled the streets. The neighbours were mostly white and middle-aged.

But there are excellent regular meals; tea in bed. Life has a healthier rhythm. Your identity becomes stronger as you get a second chance to understand the two most precious people in your life. Suddenly, you are in context. No more long drunken nights talking bollocks with friends you'd rather not have. Priorities become clearer.

Duties at first were tricky to establish: who was cooking and when? What about cleaning, cutting the grass? And was I really expected to provide entertainment for anyone and everyone who dropped in? My parents' home resembles a community centre.

Then there are my nieces and nephews - all eight of them, ranging from eight months to eight years. Mum and dad look after the smaller ones; the older ones visit after school before their parents finish work. Trying to have a professional conversation on the phone after school hours can be tricky, as one of the children is liable to shout, "Aunty Dolly, Simran needs his bum wiped!"

Violins, drums and the piano are practised by the kids - sometimes all at once. Otherwise, the cacophony can include the blare of Cartoon Network, a dodgy Asian cable channel, the dishwasher, a sewing machine and three phones ringing simultaneously. There are toys, shoes, coats and bikes strewn over the hallway. Stressed-out parents collecting the kids sit and share troubles. There is a lot of human traffic.

An Indian friend once remarked: "The problem with Indians is that they have no understanding of the individual." Trying to be alone is hard enough: kids want you to play, adults want you to chat, parents want you to get married. And all you want is to complete the latest script, read the book, listen to the radio - on your own.

I tend to be the envy of many single women who have lived solo and complain that it's expensive, wasteful and lonely. Many confess they wish they were brave enough to do the same. Mature Asian men, who often come in for a lot of stick for never leaving home, wonder why I left in the first place. And then there are those who just don't get it.

And what do my parents think? Sometimes that I'm still the sullen child of my adolescence; sometimes that I'm a pioneering single woman teaching, learning and growing within an extended family.

Living at home with the parents is no bed of roses: moods have to be negotiated, and parents have to discover that they can learn from their children. Mine use olive oil now instead of ghee; brown bread instead of white; semi-skimmed instead of full-fat milk. Even their punctuality is improving.

There are still times when you're heading out to party dressed to the nines, only to find that your security-conscious parents have locked the door at 9pm. When, in a bad mood at dinner, the only sound your ears amplify is that of your father sucking his food. Twice he's almost choked. Luckily, I'm qualified in first aid.

Then again, I'll probably be sucking my food when I get to his age.
Dolly Dhingra

I suppose the theory of rearing children is that you are bringing them up so that one day they can stand on their own. From the time you feel confident enough not to loom over the cot every 10 minutes, checking that they are still breathing, through a few hours at playgroup, a whole morning at nursery, to days away on school trips, it is a long, slow parting.

I had my final parting with my sons when they left home to go to university. New lives, new homes for both of them. Rooms cleared of hi-fis, books, clothes, posters. That was it. Shut the door. Have a cry. Get over it. And I did. I got on with my life. A new me emerged. A me who rediscovered the joy of thinking about me.

And then my sons came back.

It is common enough. Many of my friends have grown-up children who have come home while they look for new jobs or recover from a broken relationship. My sister's son, over 30, lived with her after a hurtful divorce while his flat was being renovated. It bothered her that they might not, after so many years apart, get along. But the experience was affirming for both of them, and brought them closer.

I belong to a generation that broke away from its parents, moved out early, lived a different life with different values. After I left, I only went back to visit. In fact, the deal was: "You've made your bed; now lie in it."

I desperately wanted my children to become my friends when they grew up. And they are. I think that I, and my friends, are more relaxed about the business of being young than our parents ever were. Maybe that's the problem. Our kids like being at home.

Still, as part of the standing-on-your-own-two-feet business, I taught my sons to iron their shirts and to cook. If you feel, like I felt, that your children should master such simple chores, a word of warning: don't. They will only return to the nest and criticise you. I blush to confess that when my sons came home they cleared out my salad tray swamp. "Did this used to be a lettuce?"

By the time they returned, my sons were better at household management than I have ever been. While they had been fending for themselves, I had been discovering the joys of self-indulgence. I left the loo door unlocked. I could wander about in whatever state of undress I wanted. I could eat an apple for supper.

But now, as they filled the house with their new lives, mine got shoved aside. They left their new skills at the door, became my boys again. Except they were men now: independent, needing their own space. Football roared on the telly. The rooms were filled with the bass thump of their music. I started wearing headphones. Friends and girl friends came to stay. I was catering for the masses. For a few years, I had shopped for two; now I was heaping the trolley high again. The phone was occupied whenever I needed it. Editors and agents could not get through. I nearly had a heart attack when the BT envelope arrived.

My younger son would dim the bathroom lights, surround the tub with scented candles and disappear to soak for hours. Lovey... but at two in the after noon , when his hard-pressed mother needed to get in for ordinary human purposes?

Loo rolls disappeared. The fridge emptied daily. The laundry basket was piled high. They took coffee to their rooms and never returned the cups. There were shoes everywhere. If I complained about having to pick them up, they glared at me.

Here we were, four people who loved each other dearly, choreographing new relationships, new routines. My sons had become used to doing as they pleased, but so had I. It must be one of life's hardest lessons to realise that your mother is also a person. But it is also hard to grasp the fact that your children don't need you any more.

We came to new agreements. They helped with the laundry, the shopping and cooking and were content to phone friends after six in the evening. I put up with the football. And I quite liked Primal Scream anyway.

Then, one at a time, they left again. One to New York, one to London. I drove them to the station. Said goodbye again. And, dammit, cried again.

They phone. They email. Send little gifts. Do I worry? Oh yes. I miss them. But these are my children: give them their milk and let them go.
Isla Dewar

 Isla Dewar's novel, Two Kinds of Wonderful (Review, £6.99), is published in paperback this month.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: The Mastertons gave away a male embryo because they wanted a girl. Do parents have the right to choose their baby's sex?
fields.trailText: The question: The Mastertons gave away a male embryo because they wanted a girl. Do parents have the right to choose their baby's sex?
fields.body:
Ruth Deech: Chair, Human Fertility and Embryology Authority

In 1993 we asked the public what their thoughts were on sex selection. There was strong support for using this technique to avoid passing on hereditary conditions only affecting males, such as muscular dystrophy, but many responses were opposed to sex selection for family balancing. There were worries that gender stereotypes would be reinforced. Concerns were also raised that couples might express preferences for male children. It was felt that this would be a "slippery slope" to selecting perfect children, and to a view of children as consumer goods while healthy embryos would be unnecessarily created and destroyed.
Verdict: No

Dr Peter Liu : Adviser to couples on gender selection

I give impartial advice to couples on the sex of their baby. If couples are looking for this treatment for reasons of family balance, I think it's completely ethical. I don't think it's ethical to try to select the sex of your first baby, but when it comes to the second or third child I can't see a problem. The case of the Mastertons, who already have four sons and lost their daughter in a fire, is tragic: all they want to do is complete their family with a baby of the same sex as the one they lost. When it comes to couples in the UK, more want to have a girl than a boy; but in various Asian and Middle Eastern countries, there seems to be a preference for boys.
Verdict: Yes

Chris Bailey: Director, Harley Street Gender Clinic

Gender selection by sperm separation is legal in this country; selecting by means of IVF is not. We are the only clinic in Britain providing this procedure and couples come to us from all over Europe. The chances of successfully having a boy with this method are approximately 90%; slightly lower for a girl. Many couples want to achieve balance in their family, and there's nothing wrong with that. Although we can make no guarantees with this treatment, it is heartwarming to see the enormous number of people we have helped to have a baby the gender of their choice.
Verdict: Yes

Suzanne Colton: Mother of two boys and twin girls

We live in New York, where gender selection is legal. We had two boys, and were keen to have a girl. I was artificially inseminated with sperm that had been selected as more likely to produce a girl when I was ovulating. I was lucky first time and found out that I was pregnant with not one, but two female babies. It was one of the best decisions we ever made. Our doctor interviewed us to make sure we would still go ahead with the pregnancy if it was a boy. Of course, there was no question of aborting a male baby. We just wanted to improve our chances of having a girl.
Verdict: Yes

Liz Merry: University lecturer, College of North-east London

Traditional Chinese families prefer male children. It goes back to the days when China's economy depended on a strong male workforce. I spent a year teaching there two years ago and was troubled by the unusually large number of boys under five. Six of my colleagues had boys, and one confirmed my suspicion that many couples sought abortions if scans showed a girl child. It is a terrible irony that China's One Child Policy has dealt a further blow to the status of women.
Verdict: Yes

Rev Paul Murray: Member, Catholic Bishops' Bio-Ethics Committee

The selection of one embryo rather than another, for any reason, involves the rejection and thus the destruction of innocent human life, which is unacceptable. None of us can fathom the anguish of a parent who loses a child. Even so, no child can be restored to its parents through the artificial production of a replacement. Faith teaches us to look forward to that time when we are reunited with our loved ones who have died in God's Kingdom at the end of time.
Verdict: No

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child
fields.body:
Ages 0-3

10 Minutes Till Bedtime by Peggy Rathmann (Puffin, £4.99)

Ten minutes is a lifetime when you are little and almost anything can happen. It certainly does in this surreal, almost wordless tale in which, as the countdown to bedtime begins, the house is invaded by a busload of hamsters arriving for the bedtime tour. They get everywhere, from the bathroom to bedroom. The great thing about this funny, odd little book is that it is so matter of fact in the way it presents a skewed reality. Neatly bridging the gap between reality and dream worlds, this book may encourage children to make a connection between their dream lives and their waking lives. At the very least, it will make them laugh and help them learn to count backwards from 10. The drawings are like detailed cartoons, busy and full of perceptive little touches that make this as enjoyable for adults as it is for children.

Daisy and the Beastie by Jane Simmons (Orchard, £4.99 )
When Daisy the Duck's grandpa reads her and little Pip a story about the Beastie, Daisy is determined to find the Beastie for herself on their own farm. So it's off to the chickens to see if the Beastie is lurking there, and down to the barn in case the Beastie is with the cows and the sheep. But it turns out there is something nasty in the woodshed. Simmons's vivid picture book knows that it is the beasties you can't see that are the most frightening, and it soothes small fears by revealing the terrible, fearsome beastie to be two playful kittens. Cynical adults will know that this alliance between beak and claw cannot last into adulthood but children fall for this gentle story without fail. Best of all, the pictures have a direct quality that cleverly captures the intensity of the world as experienced through young, not-yet-jaded eyes.

Ages 4-7

Lady Lollipop by Dick King-Smith (Walker, £3.99)
Another porky tale from the creator of Babe. Princess Penelope is so spoiled that she is more like a pig than a child. But when she demands a pet pig for her birthday, and Lollipop and her friend Johnny arrive, everyone's perceptions about themselves and each other are transformed. With Lollipop around, everyone starts behaving better. Penelope is not quite such a spoiled little madam, the queen stops having hysterics and the king becomes happier. Jill Barton's perceptive black and white illustrations capture both porcine and human expressions brilliantly; you can always see the one in the other, and the resemblance of Queen Ethelwynne to our own monarch is staggering. Even if you don't buy the idea that pigs make the world a nicer place, under-eights will happily pig out on this delightful fairy tale.

The Road to Somewhere by Helen Armstrong (Orion, £9.99)

Farmers are having a hard time at the moment, and they don't exactly get an easy ride in Armstrong's first novel. Cow, Woolly and Ratty run away from the farm when Cow overhears that she will soon be sent off in a truck never to return. Together the trio find that the outside world is a hard, cruel place. You could say that Armstrong takes a slightly sentimental view of animals - it is certainly an anthropomorphic one. But there are also some unsentimental truths in this deceptively simple story of courage, double-crossing and necessity that should stand any child in good stead for life in the playground. Armstrong writes well about how people and animals are sometimes both better and worse than they should be, and how sometimes it is only by taking a risk that you can find friendship and end up landing on your feet.

Ages 8-11

Secret Heart by David Almond (Hodder, £10)
David Almond's books are strange, unsettling, wild things - unfettered by the normal restraints of children's literature. It is hard to say with any certainty what age group they are for; they are, like all great literature, beyond classification. In the village of Helmouth (a nasty, brutish place), Almond's hero Joe Maloney is an outcast, an untamed child who doesn't know the things he is supposed to know or think the thoughts that he is supposed to think. Teachers and truant officers despair of him; other children, intent on growing up tough, bully him; his mother simply loves him. Then the circus comes to town. In Corinna, who flies through the air, and Nancy Solo, who is blind but can see into people's hearts, Joe finds kindred souls. An exhilarating, though not always easy read for anyone who, like Joe, has tigers and larks in their hearts.

Half Magic by Edward Eager (Oxford University Press, £4.99)
Last week the author of Horrid Henry, Francesca Simon, told us about her favourite childhood book: Edward Eager's Half Magic. Now this 1950s US classic is available here, and a good read it proves to be. The book acknowledges an enormous debt to E Nesbit's Five Children and It by combining fantasy and reality. It tells the story of Jane and her brother and sisters who have to survive summer while their mother works. Jane discovers a coin and soon the children realise that it fulfils wishes, or at least half-wishes. So in order to get what you want you must wish for twice as much as you actually need - a situation that often leads to double trouble. The moral may be that wishes need to be handled with care, but Eager weaves his story with such a fluent sense of fun that it slips in easily.

Ages 12+

Troy Adèle Geras (Point, £5.99)
Troy was a man's war, but in Adèle Geras's rich tapestry of a novel events are told from a woman's point of view. Xanthe and Marpessa are sisters, servants in the royal palaces of a Troy that has been under siege for almost 10 years. Then both fall in love with the same young warrior, and soon the bonds of sisterhood and survival are stretched thin. Geras's tale is a beautiful, compassionate, sometimes sneakily humorous retelling of an age-old story that mixes the old with the new and, in the process, offers an entirely new perspective on the siege of Troy and its aftermath.

Lending mythology a human face, this is a tale about human beings, not heroes, and about not the wisdom of the gods but their frailties. Written with a simple, urgent clarity, Troy makes for a truly excellent piece of epic storytelling.

Witch Hill by Marcus Sedgwick (Dolphin, £4.99)
The first distinctive thing about this pacy thriller are the author's own illustrations, a series of spiky woodcuts of a young girl accused of witchcraft. Marcus Sedgwick's writing doesn't quite have the same unsettling power, but it is still a page-turner: it tells the story of Jamie, survivor of the fire that saw his family home burned down, and who finds he is not out of danger when he goes to stay with his aunt and cousin in an unwelcoming village where the dark secrets of the past infect the present and Jamie's dreams. You can forgive the slight clumsiness in plotting as the book comes to a terrifying climax: you can almost smell the guilt and smoke as Jamie confronts what has happened. Not a sophisticated read, but it offers a glimpse into a more grown-up world for 12- and 13-year-olds.

fields.headline: Sharon 's 'guard dog' bares his teeth
fields.standfirst: Minister in new cabinet wants all Palestinians expelled
fields.trailText: March 7 2001: On this day Ariel Sharon was sworn in as Israel's prime minister. This is how the Guardian reported the news.
fields.body:
Rechavam Ze'evi, who takes his place in Ariel Sharon 's cabinet today, looked out of his office in the parliament building on to a glorious view of the hills coming alive with spring - and saw Arab armies at the gate.

"You can't defend Jerusalem from the hills. If a war was to start on the initiation of the Arabs, in three hours we would have to fight right here in the knesset," he said. "In four hours we would have to fight in Tel Aviv."

Mr Ze'evi's elevation to the cabinet has caused shivers in Israel. The former major-general, who is 74, wants the 3m Palestinians expelled from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

He considers Jordan part of Israel's birthright, and thinks that Israel's 1m Arab citizens should not be allowed to vote, because they do not serve in the army. The incoming tourist minister, he believes visitors to Israel must speak Hebrew.

Mr Sharon told the knesset yesterday that he had formed a coalition and was ready to be sworn in today.

Labour doves say Mr Ze'evi's membership of the coalition is a "nightmare", and that Shimon Peres dirtied his Nobel peace prize by agreeing to serve in the same government.

Labour's left wing is also dismayed by the naming of Avigdor Lieberman as infrastructure minister. The leader of a Russian immigrants' party, Mr Lieberman has called for Israel to bomb Egypt's Aswan dam.

Mr Ze'evi, who founded the Moledet (homeland) party, seems flattered by the uproar. "If they want to call me an extremist, I am an extremist," he said. "It doesn't bother me."

But he has his own misgivings, suspecting that Mr Sharon will back down from his promise to hang on to every Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

Describing himself as the prime ministerial "guard dog", Mr Ze'evi will push for the invasion of Palestinian-ruled towns to end the uprising.

To him, the hills outside his office are not just part of the West Bank which the Palestinians want for their state: they are the high ground from which the armies of Iraq, Syria and Libya would invade and wipe Israel off the map.

He wants to cleanse the West Bank of Palestinians. "The Arabs living in the West Bank and Gaza have to be transferred to their forefather's land," he said, adding that most Palestinians arrived as migrants during the last century. In the meantime he would "encourage" emigration by banning Palestinians from working in Israel and closing factories and universities in the West Bank.

He also wants Israel to lay claim to the kingdom of Jordan. "It's ours historically. Three of the tribes of Israel - Gad, Reuven, and Menashe, lived in what is now Jordan."

But those are long-term plans. For the immediate future he has been drawing up battle scenarios for the new prime minister, and has joined Mr Lieberman in demanding assurances that Mr Sharon will invade the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

He has also presented Mr Sharon with a plan to stop Palestinian gunmen on the edges of Ramallah from firing on the Jewish settlement of Psagot. "We move in and level the first row of houses," he said. "I can guarantee you that the people in the second row of houses will make sure nobody shoots from there again."

He also wants the army to unleash attack dogs on Palestinian demonstrators.

"We have to find the three or four weak places of the Palestinian Authority and press there, and they will crawl to us asking us to stop it," he said.

*The military wing of Hamas claimed responsibility yesterday for the suicide bomb attack that killed three Israelis in Netanya on Sunday.

Special report on Israel and the Middle East at theguardian.com/israel

fields.headline: Report says Mandelson cleared
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson has been cleared of lying by the inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair, according to the BBC who claim to have seen key extracts from the report.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson has been cleared of lying by the inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair, according to the BBC who claim to have seen key extracts from the report.

Andrew Marr, the BBC's political editor, last night quoted inquiry head Sir Anthony Hammond as saying in the report: "I have no reason to doubt Mr Mandelson's honesty throughout this period."

Mr Marr told the BBC2 Newsnight programme that he had seen only part of the report - and had not seen Sir Anthony's all-important conclusion - but said it appeared that Mr Mandelson had escaped serious criticism.

If this is true, it will prove an embarrassment to the prime minister, Tony Blair, and Mr Mandelson's enemies within government, who, his supporters say, forced him out.

Mr Mandelson resigned as Northern Ireland secretary in January after apparent inconsistencies emerged in his account of a phone call made to the home office regarding the passport application of Indian tycoon and £1m Millennium Dome donor Srichand Hinduja.

However, Mr Marr said that Sir Anthony had written: "I am happy to accept as genuine his belief that he did not recall the telephone call and didn't try to deceive anyone."

But he said that the former Treasury solicitor also wrote: "I have not, even now, been able to establish the exact course of events."

Mr Mandelson last night refused to make any comment on the report, a draft copy of which he received some time ago. But there was anger from opposition parties over the selective leaking of parts of the report, which is expected to be published on Friday.

Liberal democrat MP Norman Baker, whose parliamentary questions first brought attention to Mr Mandelson's links with Mr Hinduja and his brother Gopichand, said: "There have been so many leaks there ought to be an inquiry into the number of leaks.

"The report must be published as soon as possible, so we can see the contents for ourselves.

Gopichand Hinduja, speaking from India, where the brothers are embroiled in corruption allegations, said: "From the very first day Mr SP Hinduja and myself have been saying that there was no connection between the donation to the dome and to the citizenship, and we were shocked when this connection was made."

And he added: "We hope that now that the report is clearing Mr Mandelson ... If he has been asked to resign for this reason, of our citizenship, I can tell you he had never done any favour to us and he should be back in the government."

fields.headline: Unison ends Scottish dispute
fields.trailText: The long-running local government workers' pay dispute in Scotland is over after Unison members voted to accept an "inflation-proof" four-year deal.
fields.body:
The long-running local government workers' pay dispute in Scotland is over after Unison members voted to accept an "inflation-proof" four-year deal.

Unison has been in dispute with the Convention of Scottish Local Authorities (Cosla) since August, and staged a series of strikes over an initial 2.5% pay offer.

The deal agreed to last night gives workers a 14.2% pay increase over four years, and adds a £500 flat rate payment next year, raising the minimum wage in Scottish local government to over £5 an hour by March 2002.

Unison local government organiser Joe Di Paola said: "This is a good settlement. Unison members, in their solid support for the three days of action and the widespread selective action, have delivered considerable improvements to the original 2.5% offer.

"It is particularly important that we have got a deal which ring fences part of the long term funding of local authorities for proper pay increases. This offer does that by inflation-proofing pay."

Cosla vice-president Pat Watters said: "This is a good deal for both sides, bringing as it does certainty on pay until 2004. Councils across Scotland will welcome Unison's decision."

Unison members voted five to one to accept the deal. The results of ballots by two other unions, the GMB and T&GWU, are still awaited, although both unions are recommending acceptance.
