webTitle: The end of the annual pay round?

fields.headline: The end of the annual pay round?
fields.standfirst: Scotland's landmark three-year pay agreements struck with all local government staff may signal the beginning of a new culture on public sector pay, writes Mark Irvine
fields.trailText: Scotland's landmark three-year pay agreements struck with all local government staff may signal the beginning of a new culture on public sector pay, writes Mark Irvine.
fields.body:
After much huffing and puffing, predictable bloodcurdling threats and intermittent strike action from public sector union Unison, Scotland has finally achieved agreement on local government pay. Landmark three-year pay agreements have been struck with all council staff, which poses some big questions for employers in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Scottish teachers were the first group to settle - not surprisingly, with a rise of 21.5% on offer - but the real significance lies in the length of the agreement. Does it signal the end of the annual pay round?

Trade unions in the UK have traditionally been hostile to anything other than one-year settlements, despite any evidence that these produce better results over the longer term. Until recently, union activists would rather gnaw their own arms off than sell out to a two-, three- or four-year pay deal. The worry is that inflation might take off if the economy takes an unexpected nosedive, leaving the workers high and dry.

In reality, union members don't care how long a pay agreement lasts. Three- and four-year agreements are common in parts of Europe and across North America. The unions have nothing to lose other than a long tradition of "we've always done it this way and we're not changing now". Unless union negotiators abroad are incredibly stupid or in the pocket of fiendish foreign bosses, there is nothing intrinsically good about the UK's obsession with a 12-month pay fix.

Longer term agreements for employers and unions present obvious problems for both sides, but not insurmountable ones. Unexpected economic disasters, like the Wall Street crash of the 1930s or the oil-fired hyperinflation of the mid 1970s, are rare events. Arguably everyone has an interest in going back to the drawing board in exceptional circumstances. Nor does it take a genius to put a clause in an agreement that re-opens negotiations if some unforeseen disaster occurs. At the end of the day, negotiations are about good faith.

What employees really want to know is whether a pay agreement is any good. Does it make them better off? Are there other issues to consider such as the protection of jobs and services?

In Scotland, the result is that, for the first time ever, all employees are signed up to pay agreements that mirror the budget-setting process for local councils. webTitle: Farmers urge relaxation of virus rules

fields.headline: Farmers urge relaxation of virus rules
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth crisis
fields.trailText: Farmers today urged the government to allow a further relaxation of the ban on animal movement imposed during the foot and mouth crisis, so that they can cope with the lambing season.
fields.body:
Farmers today urged the government to allow a further relaxation of the ban on animal movement imposed during the foot and mouth crisis, so that they can cope with the lambing season.

The government has already sanctioned limited transfers of animals to slaughterhouses from areas unaffected by the virus. But the National Farmers' Union said it was pressing for licences to be granted in cases such as those where ewes and cows were trapped by the ban on the use of public roads.

Meanwhile, the first horse-racing meeting for a week was being held today despite calls from a farming industry still in the grip of the crisis for the sport to be suspended.

Racing was due to restart at Lingfield Park after a thorough review of the Ministry of Agriculture Fisheries and Food's risk assessment of the sport by the Jockey Club's chief veterinary adviser.

However, the NFU president, Ben Gill, wrote to the racing authorities asking them not to resume meetings for at least the next seven days.

Meanwhile, experts battling the crisis are focussing their efforts on Dartmoor, following a second suspected outbreak at the national park yesterday amid fears tens of thousands of animals there may have to be destroyed.

Ministry veterinary experts were seeking to establish how the virus spread to Dartmoor but ruled out "through the air".

The number of confirmed outbreaks in the United Kingdom reached 84 today after MAFF announced three new confirmed cases at sheep and cattle farms at Arthuret in Cumbria, Hawes in North Yorkshire, and Hilton in Derbyshire.

In Europe, the fight against foot-and-mouth was stepped up yesterday as a day of talks in Brussels ended with the European Union banning all livestock markets in the 15 member states and restricting the movement of animals across EU borders.

On the lambing issue, Tim Bennett, the NFU deputy president, said: "It is the start of the lambing season and it is important that we get sheep closer back to base and in some instances to get them into sheds. We are running into an animal welfare problem."

Baroness Hayman, a junior agriculture minister, said a total of 201 abattoirs had now received special licences to slaughter animals once again, while "hundreds and hundreds of farmers" were known to have also applied.

Fresh supplies had started getting through to supermarkets and butchers, while plans to set up holding centres for cattle and sheep en route to slaughterhouses would be up and running by next week, she said.

However, fears that some farmers were still breaking the national ban on unsanctioned livestock movements continued.

 At the Alton Towers theme park, a cow, six sheep, three pigs and eight goats were slaughtered yesterday after fears visitors could help the disease to spread. What's going on?

webTitle: Civilian casualties of war in Chechnya

fields.headline: Civilian casualties of war in Chechnya
fields.standfirst: Moscow's war on the rebel province is claiming more than soldiers' lives, according to a Russian human rights group. As many as 2,000 civilians may have disappeared, writes Amelia Gentleman
fields.trailText: Moscow's war on the rebel province is claiming more than soldiers' lives, according to a Russian human rights group. As many as 2,000 civilians may have disappeared, writes Amelia Gentleman
fields.body:
As Russia's war in Chechnya drags into its 17th month, human rights organisations are becoming increasingly concerned about the number of Chechen citizens who have disappeared without trace in the aftermath of Russian army "cleansing operations" - sweeping searches of villages for rebel fighters.

Research conducted by the Memorial human rights group suggests that as many as 2,000 Chechens may have gone missing after being detained by Russian forces; Russian officials put the number of people who have disappeared in the region, for whatever reason, at around 360.

The issue has gained new urgency this week with the publication of a detailed investigation into a large body dump discovered at the end of February outside the Russians' main military headquarters in the separatist region.

More than 50 bodies have already been recovered from the abandoned holiday village, Zdorovye, in the heavily-guarded area outside the Khankala base; the figure continues to rise as new bodies are found. Russian television today showed gruesome footage of 25 of the bodies - three of them women - laid out in a converted warehouse in Grozny waiting for relatives to identify the dead. Many of the badly decayed bodies had been mutilated. Some have razor wounds to their head and shoulders. Most of the dead had their arms bound together with rope before their death and many were blindfolded; some bodies bear the traces of gunshot wounds.

The Memorial report has confirmed that several of those individuals already identified went missing at the end of last year, shortly after being detained by the Russian military. Oleg Orlov, director of Memorial (founded by Nobel Peace Prize winner Andrei Sakharov), examined the corpses in the Grozny morgue and claimed that they were the victims of unauthorised punishments handed out by the Russian military outside the framework of the law. He concluded that they represented "incontrovertible proof of war crimes by the Russian forces".

Mr Orlov said that his organisation had long expected to discover such a dumping ground for dead bodies because of mounting disquiet over disappearing citizens. Human Rights Watch has echoed his concerns. "We have established a clear pattern of cases when people 'disappear' in the custody of Russian troops," a spokeswoman said. "The discovery of this mass grave is very alarming."

Russian officials have given contradictory explanations for the presence of the corpses. They claimed initially that the dead were rebel fighters (killed up to a year ago at a time when fighting was active in the region) and later that the bodies were rebels killed by their own side in internal guerrilla disputes.

A doctor working for Memorial concluded after inspecting the bodies that the majority of them were between one and four months old - killed long after the Russian forces declared Grozny and surrounding villages under its control.

"It seems unlikely that Chechen fighters would have hidden their dead in a region so close to the Russian military headquarters," Mr Orlov said. The investigation of military medical experts was severely impeded by the shortage of equipment in Grozny, he added. Doctors have complained that they do not even have enough body bags to store the mounting pile of corpses.

Sergei Yastrzhembsky, the presidential spokesman on Chechnya, said today that the Chechen prosecutor's office had launched an investigation and added that until their conclusions were published, it would be unwise to speculate on the identities of the dead or on the cause of their death. "I don't approve of Memorial's approach. It's very easy to point the finger of blame, but the military prosecutor has not yet finished his investigations," he said.

The Memorial reports also detail the growth of a clandestine trade in corpses between the Russian forces and Chechen villagers; relatives are informed by an intermediary if the identity of the victim is known, and a price for securing the body for burial is negotiated.

Information about the existence of large numbers of bodies at Zdorovye first emerged at the end of February as intermediaries involved in the corpse trade began informing families that their relatives' bodies had been deposited there.

The corpse of Adam Chimayev was the first to be identified by relatives. His family was invited by an intermediary to inspect a group of bodies deposited at Zdorvye. After positively identifying Chumayev, the family paid $3,000 to Russian soldiers to retrieve his body from the village so they could hold a funeral, his widow said. The 38-year-old Chechen had not been seen by his family since Russian soldiers detained him on December 3 last year. Three shots to his heart area had killed him, and there were the marks of torture on his body, relatives revealed.

webTitle: World dispatch: Moldova cosies up to Moscow

fields.headline: Destitute Moldova cosies up to Moscow
fields.standfirst: The communists, swept back to power by disillusioned voters in Europe's poorest country, are eyeing closer ties with Russia, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: The communists, swept back to power by disillusioned voters in Europe's poorest country, are eyeing closer ties with Russia, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
Sandwiched snugly between Romania and Ukraine, Moldova is one of those countries that causes a certain amount of unease when it is brought up in conversation, simply because most have no idea of its existence.

The ex-Soviet midget state, which became independent in 1991, is the poorest in Europe, with an average GDP per head of £1,360, less than a tenth of the EU average. In the old days it earned its keep from hi-tech plants and science labs serving Soviet space and marine programmes. Now that has all gone and half of all Moldovans scratch a living from subsistence farming. But even that industry has shrunk to the third of the size it was a decade ago.

In the 10 years of independence more than 14% - mainly young people - of Moldova's 4.3m population have abandoned their country in search of work overseas. It is no surprise when the average salary is around £13.50 per month and 80% of citizens struggle to survive on under 70p a day.

Much can be told about the desperate state of the nation from the fact that many Moldovans talk of moving to Romania - from which Moldova was annexed in 1940 - a country widely perceived as one of Europe's biggest losers, but viewed in Moldova as a considerable step up the ladder.

Last year Moldova's biggest export was its .md internet domain name, which it sells to medical professionals, mainly in the US. The growth of telephone sex chat lines has also been a boost to the tiny land. Its short dialling code (373) often convinces punters they are dialling domestic numbers rather than making expensive international calls.

Any hope of earnings from the country's badly managed state wine and tobacco industries was thwarted when the centre-right coalition of Ion Sturza collapsed in autumn 1999.

The collapse strengthened the clout of the communists and at the end of last month Moldova became the first of the 15 ex-Soviet satellites to return the communists to power. Voters disillusioned by a decade of harsh market reforms gave the communist party 70% of seats in parliament and opened the way for their leader, Vladimir Voronin, to become president.

Mr Voronin, 59, who started his working life as a baker and then became an economist, police general and now the most powerful man in his country, describes himself as "a Moldovan Deng Xiaoping", though he also insists: "We are not going to have a central Asian regime of personality cults." Many have expressed their fear that the country will slide into authoritarian rule and foreign investors are not convinced they can trust the new leader.

The success of Mr Voronin's party was largely based on his promise to restore the "upbeat mood" of days gone by, using video footage from Soviet election campaigns which tapped into the nostalgic longing of the elderly for the days of full unemployment and steady incomes.

The pictures were contrasted with modern-day views of beggars and people sifting through rubbish bins. These pictures are close to the truth: human rights organisations acknowledge that the average life expectancy has slumped by five years since communist days.

Since his party's victory, Mr Voronin has made unrealistic pledges to double salaries and pensions and said that state-owned television should act as a government propaganda tool.

Most significantly, he has clearly signalled that his country is keen to cosy up to Russia. One of his first and most important initiatives was to announce a referendum on Moldova joining the Russia-Belarus union.

The current loose union has plans eventually to tie its countries' currencies and budgets and is widely interpreted as an attempt by Russian president Vladimir Putin to reassert his influence on the former Soviet lands.

If Moldova joins, it would be a marked move away from its stated goal of joining the European Union, an organisation equated in the country with stability and prosperity but seen as far too distant a prospect to be taken seriously.

But it now risks cutting itself off from the EU as well as the World Trade Organisation, whose officials opened their doors to Moldova just days before the elections after three years of negotiations.

Moldova also risks prolongation of the issue of Transdniestria, a mainly Russian-speaking slice of land in the north which is currently manned by 2,000 Russian troops headed by former KGB officers.

The Kremlin has agreed to withdraw all troops by the end of 2002, but many are suspicious that a condition of union membership might be the scrapping of the plan.

The pro-Moscow Mr Voronin, himself half ethnically Russian and a great admirer of Mr Putin, has also angered young Moldovans with his plan to introduce Russian as an official language, alongside Moldovan, which is close to Romanian. The announcement sparked protests by students in the capital Chisinau who last week burned the flag of the former Moldovan Socialist Soviet Republic.

But the eloquent Mr Voronin insists he is applying the right medicine, viewing himself as the country's personal doctor who embraces the theory that Moldova, like other former Soviet satellites, is suffering like a limb cut from a body.

He said recently: "The breakup of the body was carried out without anaesthetic and we're suffering."

The question is whether reattaching the limbs will be possible without a lot more pain and the severing of links with the west.

webTitle: Boy held for killings was bullied

fields.headline: Boy held for killings was bullied
fields.standfirst: Special report: Gun violence in America
fields.trailText: The schoolboy accused of shooting dead two students at his suburban secondary school in San Diego on Monday was constantly mocked and picked on, and had his money, trainers and skateboards stolen, friends said.
fields.body:
The schoolboy accused of shooting dead two students at his suburban secondary school in San Diego on Monday was constantly mocked and picked on, and had his money, trainers and skateboards stolen, friends said.

For weeks Charles Andrew Williams, 15, known as Andy to his friends and family, harboured a grudge against those who bullied and stole from him, his classmates said, and he often talked about taking his revenge with a gun.

The portrait that emerges of Charles, who will appear in court today charged with murder, is of a small, troubled boy with skin so pale that he was nicknamed "albino".

He lives in Santee, 10 miles north-east of San Diego, with his father, Charles, who has a large collection of guns. One of them, a .22 revolver, is alleged to be the weapon used to kill the students in a toilet and wound 13 others, including two adults, in the school grounds. Yesterday the police took seven rifles from the boy's home.

"Even the people who got picked on picked on him," said a friend of the boy, who plays the bass and was trying to form a heavy metal band called Army of the Wicked.

His skateboard was stolen twice, and last week he was beaten up and punched in the face after being accused of trying to give a 12-year-old former girlfriend alcohol. Last week the police confiscated five bottles of beer from him.

Williams gradually responded to the mockery and bullying by saying that he would shoot students at school.

Williams was said to have tried hard to fit in at the 1,900-pupil Santana high school after moving to California last year from Maryland. He tried hard to excel at games but was teased for his failure.

His mother, Linda Wells, now lives in South Carolina and had seen her son at Christmas. She said he was a normal teenager who liked sports and was coached in football by his father, a lab technician. The parents divorced 10 years ago.

Santee, which has one of the lowest crime rates in California, is a traditional middle-class suburban community of about 58,000 people with little league baseball games and soccer matches. Most of the residents are white.

The police named the two dead students yesterday as Randy Gordon, 17, and Brian Zuckor, 14.

A survey of school shootings in the US shows that in 75% of cases the perpetrator told people of his plans but was not taken seriously.

All were carried out by boys, mainly in white suburban areas.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst: He is an expert on advertising in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the past 10 years. Every Wednesday morning Stefano, now based in New York heading up Ad Age Global,  will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue.
fields.trailText: March 7: Top British advertising talent is heading across the Atlantic despite the contraction of the US industry, writes Stefano Hatfield.
fields.body:
To lament the exit of some of London's top advertising names is hardly a surefire way to cajole readers to the bottom of a column. But this is becoming a serious problem.

This year alone, three of our leading CEOs have signed up to swap the West End for midtown Manhattan. The phenomenon is hardly new.

Like pop bands in the wake of the Beatles, numerous UK ad executives have sought to emulate the success of the late, legendary David Ogilvy in the US. Most have had as much impact as Bros.

However, the hiring of Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO's Andrew Robertson, Lowe Lintas's Paul Hammersley and Leo Burnett's Nick Brien represent the formal rehabilitation of the British adman's image abroad, a decade and a half after the Saatchi brothers tarnished it.

Their infamous, hostile acquisition of the venerable Ted Bates agency in the mid-80s compounded the already arrogant reputation of Brits in New York.

Then there was Sir Martin Sorrell, who scarcely endeared himself to Madison Avenue by mounting a hostile takeover of the American advertising institution J Walter Thompson.

A decade later, he revisited this insolence by acquiring Young & Rubicam.

In between, the executives became ever more senior.

Although Chris Jones left JWT recently for health reasons, and Jennifer Laing of Saatchis returned to Britain, Michael Bungey of Cordiant and Michael Greenlees of TBWA still run a worldwide holding company and network respectively.

And TBWA's Carl Johnson and Fallon's Alison Burns run New York agencies.

There is scarcely a decent planner left in London - any US agency with planning credentials now fields a token Brit in this discipline, which is very much a British specialism.

This year, expect to see others follow Mr Brien - and earlier immigrants like Paul Woolmington - into the world of the US media-buying independents.

The media independent has been commonplace in the UK for a decade now and the Americans, who continue to believe in the merits of the full-service ad agency, have had to be dragged kicking and screaming to this particular altar.

They consequently lack enough experienced executives to run the new entities.

This helps explain the current influx of Brits, despite the painful contraction of the US ad industry.

The dot.com dollars may have gone but the industry is being transformed belatedly after more than 30 years of the status quo prevailing.

A generation of older managers is approaching retirement at the same time and there are not the young managers to succeed them.

These were lost to Wall Street in the 80s, management consultancies and then dot.coms in the 90s. Until the downturn became the talk of the town, the talent shortage was one of the few serious problems Madison Avenue faced.

The downturn will go away, the talent shortage won't. This means we can expect to see more top British names follow the dollars this year.

Planners and media buyers will lead the way but perhaps not creatives. New York advertising is too businesslike and conservative for the average British creative. But, that's another column.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

fields.headline: Old people have votes too
fields.trailText: A hard-hitting poster featuring an old woman with a "best before date" stamped on her forehead is going up around Britain tomorrow as part of a campaign to combat ageism. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A hard-hitting poster featuring an old woman with a "best before date" stamped on her forehead is going up around Britain tomorrow as part of a campaign to combat ageism.

The poster is part of a national campaign from the charity Age Concern to persuade older people to use their vote in the upcoming general election. The message is that the views of older people should not be discounted just because of their age.

The woman on the posters is 72-year-old Flo Allen from Coventry, who also appears in Age Concern's video manifesto sent to political parties last month.

"The way society shelves older people is cruel. We're not past our best; now is when many of us have got the best to offer," she said. "Many of us are active in our communities and interested in the bigger picture - as the political parties should realise before it is too late."

Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern, added: "Despite their lifestyle of skills and experience older people are often treated as though they are past a sell-by date. Yet older people can also be a force to be reckoned with in the next election if they use their vote. They are the most rapidly growing proportion of the electorate and no candidate will be wise to ignore their voice."

The poster was created by Age Concern's advertising agency, Wieden & Kennedy.

webTitle: Joseph Fiennes on the magic of Marlowe

fields.headline: Who needs Shakespeare?
fields.standfirst: It took a very special writer to lure Joseph Fiennes back on stage after he became a Hollywood bigshot. He tells Lyn Gardner why Christopher Marlowe made such an impression
fields.trailText: It took a very special writer to lure Joseph Fiennes back on stage after he became a Hollywood bigshot. He tells Lyn Gardner why Christopher Marlowe made such an impression.
fields.body:
The stream of Hollywood big shots eager to gain credibility by appearing in the West End shows no sign of abating, but they have hardly been rushing to the regional reps. A stint at the Donmar or the Almeida is considered glamorous; three weeks in the provinces doesn't have quite the same allure.

Joseph Fiennes is breaking the mould. The 28-year-old star of Stealing Beauty, Shakespeare in Love, Elizabeth and now Enemy at the Gates, the forthcoming movie about the siege of Stalingrad, is about to open at the Sheffield Crucible. His choice of play is equally off-centre: Christopher Marlowe's Edward II. If Fiennes was going to return to the classical theatre - he cut his teeth on the repertoire during three seasons at the Royal Shakespeare Company in the mid-1990s - you'd expect it to be as Hamlet or Richard II, like his older brother Ralph.

But no, Fiennes has been swept off his feet by Marlowe's anti-hero king, a figure trashed by generations of literary critics for his lack of tragic status and absence of self-knowledge, who loses his heart to his favourite Gaveston and his kingdom to his restless barons, and who suffers the nastiest death in all of English drama (you know - the one with the red-hot poker).

When Bernard Levin saw Marlowe's play, he suggested the author should be shovelled back in his grave and left to rot. But Fiennes has no time for that sort of talk. "Oh, fuck off," he says good-humouredly. "If you are going to pit Marlowe against Shakespeare, then you have to accept that they present two unique, entirely different views of the world. In Edward II the language isn't a foil, like the wit in a play like Hamlet. It is a broadsword, and Marlowe uses it brutally. He is a poet of a different nature. This is a young man's play, and it feels like one. Who knows what Marlowe might have gone on to write if he had lived?"

Marlowe is generally believed to have died at the age of 29, stabbed in a fight after a life as both spy and writer. His more fervent fans, however, insist that he faked his death and wrote many of the plays now credited to Shakespeare.

Joseph Fiennes has never been one for obvious choices. After giving up an art course for drama school, he at first seemed set on imitating Ralph by going to the RSC and then to Hollywood. But he became as well known for his work in new plays as for his Shakespeare. His performance as Jesus in Dennis Potter's Son of Man was so intense that audiences were moved to tears, if not Christianity.

Fiennes has had just one stage role since he found overnight stardom in 1998's Shakespeare in Love: in Nick Grosso's twentysomething drama Real Classy Affair at the Royal Court. But he has long wanted to do Edward II, after reading it at drama school and seeing Simon Russell Beale in the title role in the RSC's 1991 production.

"There is nothing dressed up about this play," he says. "It is what it is - a muscular, blunt instrument. The occasional mighty line sings out, but on the whole it just tells a good story extremely well. If you get it right, it should have the audience on the edge of their seats." The absence of Shakespeare's rich imagery will, he feels, be a bonus in performance. At the very least, the audience's unfamiliarity with the play will spare him "some voice on the front row mumbling the lines with you as you plough through them".

Fiennes admits that the play, which is being directed by Michael Grandage, owes some of its appeal to Marlowe's short but action-filled life. The more we learn about his time in the Elizabethan secret service and his violent, mysterious death, the harder it is to separate biography from the plays. Even Marlowe's sexuality comes into play in Edward II, in which he writes with modern openness about a king who loses his throne and his life because of his love for another man.

"This is more than just a gay play. It is about politics and society, destiny and the illusion of power as well, but it is very much a play about love. Gaveston was probably Marlowe's ultimate sexual fantasy brought to life - you feel the energy of it. But you also feel the directness of love. It is there in the text: 'Why should you love him whom the world hates so?' 'Because he loves me more than all the world.' Those two lines say it all."

They do, but they don't redeem the wilful, immature Edward, a character who has the same faults but none of the growing self-knowledge of some of Shakespeare's great creations. "That's unfair," counters Fiennes. "Edward is ugly and petulant at times. But he is liberated by love. He finds himself, and it is telling that both Gaveston and Spencer, who initially are both out for their own ends, actually fall in love with him. There is something attractive about him, and he does grow - but in a very odd way. For most characters in classic texts a light grows in them towards death. But with Edward it is different. He explodes with anger and joy, and the rest of the play is a closing down, like a light being extinguished."

"Extinguished" is a genteel way of describing Edward's appalling death, an end that fitted in with the contemporary belief that crime (in this case sodomy) and punishment should be intimately connected.

"Yes," says Fiennes. "I think some people are going to be a bit surprised. With plays like Blasted and Shopping and Fucking we pride ourselves on being so brave and new about violence on stage. But 400 years ago Marlowe was writing something like this. Sex, power, love and violent murder: Marlowe made sure his play had got it all."

fields.headline: E-Loan ends British foray
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: US mortgage group E-Loan's ambitions of becoming a leading player in the British home loans market bit the dust yesterday with the sale of its UK operation to a rival financial services website. By Rupert Jones.
fields.body:
US mortgage group E-Loan's ambitions of becoming a leading player in the British home loans market bit the dust yesterday with the sale of its UK operation to a rival financial services website.

Moneygator, an online provider of mortgages, credit cards and personal loans, has bought the broking service for an undisclosed sum.

E-Loan, which is based in California and describes itself as the global leader in online mortgages, had a high-profile launch in Britain in January last year.

Led by former First Direct chief executive Andrew Armishaw and boasting Rupert Murdoch among its backers, the UK division aimed to replicate E-Loan's success in the US, where it has captured around 25% of the online lending market.

Despite spending an estimated £10m last year on marketing and software development, the company found the British market hard to crack and it is understood it decided at the end of last year to close it and seek a buyer.

Moneygator refused to comment on how much it had paid, although one industry observer said it was likely to be less than £1m.

This is the first acquisition for Moneygator, which went live in April last year and whose chairman is Jon Foulds, former chairman of Halifax. Moneygator describes itself as an "online marketplace" for financial services, allowing people to compare and apply for products from a range of providers.

Henning Holter, Moneygator's managing director, said it would be integrating E-Loan's mortgage and car finance services into its own operations.

E-Loan UK promised home buyers "a consumer-friendly alternative" to the "entrenched" traditional players. It received more than 10,000 visitors to its site in its first week of trading and was soon offering mortgages from about 40 leading lenders.

E-Loan was assisted in its UK launch by eVentures, a joint venture between Japan ese dot.com investment specialist Softbank and ePartners, an investment company set up by Mr Murdoch to enable News Corporation to exploit emerging online markets.

Mr Armishaw was recruited as chief executive and at one stage E-Loan UK employed about 60 people. But last autumn a decision was taken to scale down operations across Europe, and Mr Armishaw quit the company.

Nobody was available for comment at E-Loan and it is not clear how many people remain with the company in Britain. Mr Holter said he was taking on "very few" of the staff and the operation had been winding down for four or five months.

webTitle: Hackers redirect Hamas site to porn

fields.headline: Hackers redirect Hamas site to porn
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Hackers have redirected the online home of Hamas, the Arab fundamentalist organisation, to a pornographic website.
fields.body:
Hackers have redirected the online home of Hamas, the Arab fundamentalist organisation, to a pornographic website.

Users who type in the URL http://www.hamas.org are currently rerouted to two domains - "hotmotel.com" and "teenjuice.com". On both pages, explicit porngraphic images are shown on the front page, plus links to pay-per-view sites on a vast range of sexual fetishes.

Both windows must be closed before unsuspecting browsers can remove the material from their screens.

The web attack follows yesterday's admission by Hamas that it was responsible for Sunday's suicide bombing at Netanya, in which a bomber and three Israelis were killed.

Hamas's military wing, the Izz el-deen al-Qassam brigades, had said in a statement that Ahmed Omar Alian, 23, a prayer caller at a refugee camp, had carried out the bombing. That statement described Alian as a "hero and a martyr", the Jerusalem Post newspaper said.

Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of the political wing of Hamas, told the Reuters news agency that he thought Israeli intelligence was behind the attack.

"I'm telling them to die of their own fury," Yassin told the agency. He accused the hackers of trying to "disfigure the image of Islam".

The web attack is just the latest incident in the Middle East's internet war. In January a 16-year-old Israeli was shot dead after meeting a Palestinian woman in an internet chatroom and arranging to meet her.

Last year the website of Hizbullah, the Arab guerrilla group, was altered to display the Israeli flag. And in October Albawaba.com, a Jordanian-based portal site, was crashed by supporters of Israel - who bombarded its chatroom with emails containing large and offensive image files.

Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of the political wing of Hamas, told the Reuters news agency that he thought Israeli intelligence was behind the attack. "I'm telling them to die of their own fury," Yassin told the agency. He accused the hackers of trying to "disfigure the image of Islam". The web attack is just the latest incident in the Middle East's internet war. In January a 16-year-old Israeli was shot dead after meeting a Palestinian woman in an internet chatroom and arranging to meet her. Last year the website of Hizbullah, the Arab guerrilla group, was altered to display the Israeli flag. And in October Albawaba.com, a Jordanian-based portal site, was crashed by supporters of Israel - who bombarded its chatroom with emails containing large and offensive image files. fields.headline: 'Fireworks blast' kills 41 at China school
fields.trailText: A huge explosion at a school in China that killed at least 41 people may have been caused by fireworks being assembled by pupils in the cash-strapped school, residents said.
fields.body:
A huge explosion at a school in China that killed at least 41 people may have been caused by fireworks being assembled by pupils in the cash-strapped school, residents said.

The death toll, put by some reports at around 60 including many children, was expected to rise further. More than 30 people were injured, hospital officials said.

Yesterday's blast flattened the two-storey school building in the village of Fanglin in the southeastern province of Jiangxi, burying scores of children under rubble.

Unconfirmed reports on Chinese websites suggested children in the school were making fireworks in their classrooms to raise pocket money or funds for the school, and some villagers told the AFP news agency that teachers had been forcing children at the school to make fireworks for three years.

A spokesman for the local police in Tanbu, an impoverished rural region 250 miles north-east of Hong Kong, denied that the blast had been caused by fireworks, but a local government official said the authorities had received complaints about the matter from parents.

"Most probably it is because of fireworks, but a final result will come out after investigators convene," said a government spokesman in Wanzai county, where Fanglin is located in the township of Tanbu.

Ding Mingxing, whose nine-year-old son was killed, said he had rushed to the scene after the blast blew out the windows of his home 100 metres away.

"As soon as I heard a cry, I went toward it. When I saw a leg or an arm sticking out, I went after it. I rescued four kids, three boys and a girl, but I couldn't find my son," Mr Ding said.

A doctor at Tanbu township hospital who arrived at the scene within minutes said pupils aged eight and nine had been putting fuses into fireworks at the time of the blast.

Villagers said the fireworks business was set up by the headteacher with the help of the village's Communist party secretary. They said Wanzai was a haven for legal and illegal fireworks factories where accidents were common.

"They began forcing students to do this two to three years ago. Teachers gave responsibility to the kids to make fireworks during their lunch hour. The school wanted to make money," said Ding Haigen.

"They didn't pay the kids anything. The parents complained many times to the school and the township government, but nothing happened."

Starved of central government cash, many schools in China's impoverished rural regions are desperate to find other funding to keep schools open.

Besides assembling toys and producing small handicrafts, students in rural China have been known to work in mines and other labour intensive activity, according to human rights groups and officials.

Fireworks have caused a series of disasters in China in recent years. In March 2000, an explosion at a huge illegal firework factory killed 33 people in Jiangxi province - 60 miles west of Wanzai county.

In August, another explosion of firework ingredients stored illegally in an apartment killed 21 people, also in Jiangxi.

A blast in the southern province of Guangdong last June killed 38.

webTitle: Calls to break addict confidentiality rejected

fields.headline: Calls to break addict confidentiality rejected
fields.trailText: Doctors and social workers have rejected calls to break patient confidentiality to inform local authorities of all drug addicts with school-age children.
fields.body:
Doctors and social workers have rejected calls to break patient confidentiality to inform local authorities of all drug addicts with school-age children.

The professions warned that addicts would avoid seeking help, thereby placing their children in greater danger rather than protecting them from harm.

But they fear that powers to control patient information in the new health and social care bill could allow a moralistic health secretary to force them to breach addicts' confidentiality in the future, claiming it was in the public interest.

Their warnings came after Professor Neil McKeganey, head of Glasgow University's centre for drug misuse research, said GPs, social workers and drugs workers needed to breach confidentiality in the interests of children's welfare.

"The risks posed to these children far outweigh the principle of confidentiality," he argued.

The recommendation came as he revealed details of the first comprehensive study into the impact of drug abuse on the children of addicts in the UK. The three-year project interviewed 70 people who had overcome addiction to illegal drugs.

In the report, the Impact of Drug Dependence on Addicts' Children, parents revealed how their addiction had blighted their children's lives. One described stealing their children's clothes to support their habit, while another admitted failing to protect her son from physical abuse by her partner. Others took their children on late-night drug deals or on shoplifting trips. Children also witnessed their parents injecting drugs and accompanied them to police stations when they were arrested.

Prof McKeganey said: "Addicts said their children were suffering without any agencies' knowledge and schools often do not know, and are not routinely told, that pupils are living with a parent dependent on drugs. By sharing information professionals would be equipped to intervene before a child was seriously hurt."

The professor estimates that 20,000 children in Scotland alone have a parent who is an addict. "Sharing information about drug addicted parents would also lead to a more systematic recording of the number of children in danger," he said.

However, guidance from the General Medical Council, which regulates doctors, states that disclosure of personal information without consent may be justified only where failure to do so may expose the patient or others to death or serious harm.

Dr Michael Wilks, chairman of the British Medical Association's ethics committee, said the potential risks posed to addicts' children were not serious enough to breach confidentiality.

"If you're aware through a child that there's an addict in their family and that relative is also your patient then you have some responsibility to assess the child's welfare. However, you're likely to alienate both parent and child if you breach their trust."

Rob Hutchinson, chairman of the Association of Directors of Social Services' children's and families committee, said: "Under jointly agreed child protection procedures there is a need for professionals who believe a child or young person to be at risk of significant harm to share that information with appropriate agencies.

"It should not be assumed however that information should be shared simply because the parent has a drug problem. This does not on its own mean that the child is at risk."

Ian Robinson, deputy director of drug charity Release, warned addicts would avoid seeking help if their confidentiality was compromised. "There is already a problem with women not accessing services because they're afraid of losing their children."

 The findings of Professor McKeganey's study will be published in a book, Beating the Dragon, due out in August.

fields.headline: Sharon's coalition may prove fragile
fields.standfirst: The new Israeli government, the largest in history, will enjoy a comfortable majority but may be subject to infighting and power plays, says Derek Brown
fields.trailText: The new Israeli government, the largest in history, will enjoy a comfortable majority but may be subject to infighting and power plays, says Derek Brown.
fields.body:
Israelis will have a new prime minister this evening - the man they voted for a month and a day ago.

Ariel Sharon, leader of the rightwing Likud faction, has assembled a grand coalition of seven factions in the Knesset (parliament). The protracted and bad tempered negotiations have produced the biggest government in Israel's history, with 26 ministers and at least 15 deputies.

Altogether, the government will comprise more than a third of the 120-member Knesset.

It will also enjoy a comfortable majority in the notoriously fractious single-chamber parliament. But given Israeli politicians' propensity for in-fighting and internecine power plays, the new coalition may prove fragile.

One of its early tests is likely to be the involvement of the ultra-orthodox Shas party, which is chiefly supported by Sephardic (eastern) Jews. Rabbi Obadia Josef, the group's spiritual leader, has ordained that its support for the new coalition is conditional upon the continued - and hotly controversial - exclusion of religious students from national service.

Sharon, who will be Israel's 11th prime minister, will get more solid support from the Labour party, whose leader and sitting prime minister, Ehud Barak, he sensationally defeated in the February 6 election.

The Labour rank and file is bitterly divided over joining the coalition. Nevertheless the party's most senior figure, former four-time prime minister Shimon Peres, has joined Sharon's team as foreign minister.

Another senior Labour man, Binyamin Ben-Eliezar, has been given the key defence ministry. Ben Eliezar's deputy will be Dalia Rabin-Pelossof, whose father, Yitzhak Rabin, was assassinated because his peace policies. She now heads her own one-woman faction in the Knesset.

Sharon's typically bruising approach to coalition building has won him few friends in his own Likud bloc. A party source sarcastically congratulated him for managing to do, in just four weeks, something his predecessors had struggled to achieve: "He has managed to get nearly everyone in his party to hate him."

webTitle: A crack in Argentine immunity law

fields.headline: A crack in Argentine immunity law
fields.trailText: An Argentine judge cleared the way yesterday for hundreds of military personnel to face trial for human rights crimes during the 1976-83 dictatorship.
fields.body:
An Argentine judge cleared the way yesterday for hundreds of military personnel to face trial for human rights crimes during the 1976-83 dictatorship.

Ruling in a 1978 case of murder and kidnapping, Gabriel Cavallo declared unconstitutional two laws passed in the 1980s which shield all but the most senior officers against prosecution for crimes committed during the "dirty war".

While the ruling applies only to the case at hand - which involves 11 military men - it sets a precedent that could open the door for the trial of hun dreds of officers and other ranks who have escaped prosecution for nearly 25 years.

The top brass were tried and jailed in 1984, but later pardoned.

The ruling was made just a few weeks before the 25th anniversary of the 1976 coup which plunged Argentina into several years of military government, during which an estimated 15,000 to 30,000 people were killed or "disappeared" - meaning their bodies were never found.

The immunity laws were agreed in the 1980s as the young democracy sought to deal with the military crimes without alienating the armed forces. Judge Cavallo made the ruling in a case brought by a human rights group, the Legal and Social Studies Centre, which accused the 11 of being involved in the murder and kidnapping of a couple and their baby in 1978.

"This is the most important case I have overseen because, with its institutional weight, I could give my opinion as a judge ... on an event as horrific as the systematic repression from 1976 to '83," the judge told reporters outside the court.

Appeals could hold up the case, but Judge Cavallo said he would press ahead with questioning the accused.

The legal centre's director, Horacio Verbitsky, said: "For us this is a historic moment, because it marks the beginning of the end of impunity in Argentina."

Horacio Jaunarena, who was sworn in as defence minister on Monday, said the critical issue was "how Argentina can recover from its past".

He first held the defence post in the mid-1980s, when the immunity laws were agreed during the presidency of Raul Alfonsin.

"Anything that leads to a rapid clarification of these actions and responsibilities seems to me healthy for the future," Mr Jaunarena said.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Whatever you think of the way he won the election, it would be foolish to fall for the simplistic portrayal of George Bush as nothing more than the tool of his father.
fields.body:
 Whatever you think of the way he won the election, it would be foolish to fall for the simplistic portrayal of George Bush as nothing more than the tool of his father.

The fact that they share a name and have both held the office hardly makes the 43rd president the puppet of the 41st, and it would take a stand up comic of the laziest kind to keep peddling those hackneyed old gags now that George W has established himself as the man in control. All anyone who doubts his independence need do is visit the official website at www.whitehouse.org, and call up the page headlined Office of the President.

"George W Bush is the 43rd President of the United States," it begins. "Formerly the 46th Governor of Texas, Bush has earned a reputation as a compassionate conservative who shapes policy based on the principles of limited government, personal responsibility, strong families, and local control." Quite different, then, from his Reaganite dad. Exactly why the picture used is of George Bush Snr is unclear, but let that be an end to the confusion anyway.

 From one good ol' boy to another, and the bizarre revelation at the Times that sonorous managing editor George Brock - best known until now for his tank-top fetish - is a huge fan of country dancing of the kind practised in barns by inbred people in the American deep south. My colleague Marina Hyde has been trying to talk to George, with whom she built up such a rapport over the microwave plug saga, but he wasn't answering his phone, presumably because he was out dosey-do-ing or sewing gaudy tassels on to one of his more spangly tank tops.

 Conflicting reports on the contents of Skippy Hammond's Hinduja inquiry paralyse the Diary. If the Home Office placeman is indeed going to exonerate Mandy Mandelson, as reported on Sunday, the last thing we, the infantrymen of Hola! (Hartlepool One Liberation Army), want is to snatch widely predicted defeat from the jaws of unlikely victory by antagonising Skippy with someone dressed up as a kangaroo presenting him with a jigsaw. If, on the other hand, conflicting reports that he is going to make his report so fudged as to be meaningless are right, then the kangaroo would be the least he could expect as a pre-emptive strike. It's very hard, and frankly at the moment we don't have a clue.

 The mystery over which gay magazine intends to feature Sun columnist Richard Littlejohn as its pin-up of the month may be solved. Adam Mattera, editor of Attitude, tells us he is considering a double page spread, such is the level of interest in the gay community. fields.headline: Victims of sick housing market
fields.trailText: On Sylvia Thompson's street, there is broken glass caked in dog turd. Visitors wade through litter floating on the wind. Half the redbrick, pre-1920 terrace houses are empty. Addicts and alcoholics crawl in and use them as dens.
fields.body:
On Sylvia Thompson's street, there is broken glass caked in dog turd. Visitors wade through litter floating on the wind. Half the redbrick, pre-1920 terrace houses are empty. Addicts and alcoholics crawl in and use them as dens.

Between the rows of boarded up windows are the net curtains and carriage clocks of people who bought into Salford when the area was popular. They are now trapped there. The market has collapsed and houses are worth as little as £1,500.

Mrs Thompson, 60, and her husband Arthur bought a two bedroom house in Langworthy, Salford, when they married in 1967. It cost them £600. Over the last 20 years, they have paid off their mortgage, built a £19,000 extension and redecorated. Twelve years ago their house was worth £34,000. This year it was valued at £7,500.

Less than two miles away, in central Manchester, two bedroom flats sell for £500,000.

Mrs Thompson said: "When we bought this house it was a sought after area. You had to fight to get in. We had no idea what would happen to what was once a fantastic community. We invested for our children and our retirement but we'll never get that money back. They call this place the Bronx. The council wants us to leave so they can rebuild the street. They have had the house valued at £7,500. What are we supposed to do with that?"

Mrs Thompson is a cleaner and her husband is a van driver. On their salaries, if they had to leave, they could not afford to rent. At their age, they cannot get a mortgage.

The kitchen floor has begun to subside, and the bathroom will have to be refitted. Salford council is developing a plan to destroy streets where more than three quarters of houses are derelict. Green areas will be introduced, home owners whose house value has plummeted will be asked to leave their homes to the bulldozers and will be offered nearby houses that match their current status. Community facilities will be improved.

But the Thompsons do not want to move. They want the council to revamp the area. They and people who bought houses 10 years ago have little hope.

Stephen and Dawn Curwen bought a two bedroom terrace for £26,000 in 1993. It is now worth £5,000. The couple, both 33, have three children and a high mortgage. They cannot afford to install central heating or do repairs to their roof and rotting windows and doors. if they know they will not see a return on their investment.

The Curwens' 11-year-old daughter and eight-year-old son share a room. Their three-year-old sleeps in a cot in his parents' room. The couple wanted to build an extension for another bedroom but now they cannot afford to.

"We are trapped here. What sort of life is this? There is nothing for my kids to do. We wanted to get our foot on the ladder but we fell through to the cellar," Mrs Curwen said.

webTitle: Ministers say Brown will tread carefully

fields.headline: Ministers say Brown will tread carefully
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will take no chances with the economy when he delivers the Budget, ministers said today.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will take no chances with the economy when he delivers the Budget, ministers said today.

Labour MPs are looking for eyecatching policies and initiatives to set the stage for a general election, possibly in May, after the foot and mouth disease crisis is contained.

The chancellor is expected to announce £4bn in tax cuts, but social security secretary Alistair Darling said he will do nothing to jeopardise Britain's economic strength.

"What we want is stability so that businesses can plan for the future. Stability also gives you low interest rates which, in turn, means lower mortgage rates," he said.

Mr Brown has already said he intends to concentrate on "targeted" measures aimed at working families with young children, pensioners and savers.

Newspaper reports today said that the chancellor is planning to allocate £500 million to recruit teachers, police officers and health staff.

There is also speculation that he will cut income tax by widening the band for the 10p starting rate.

Analysts believe the chancellor can afford to give away £3bn to £4bn from the treasury surplus in tax cuts and extra spending.

The IMF has warned that a pre-election giveaway could prevent further interest rate cuts by the Bank of England but economists believe the strength of public finances will give Mr Brown room for manoeuvre.

According to the latest estimates, public finances are on course to show a surplus of about £15bn - 50% more than the £10 billion that Mr Brown predicted in November.

The Tories attempted to undercut the impact of the chancellor's expected largesse by leaking secret plans for £144bn tax cuts over 10 years if the party returns to power.

fields.headline: Crossroads slips in peaktime
fields.trailText: 12.45pm overnights: Crossroads' foray into ITV peaktime was a ratings disaster, pulling in fewer than 5m viewers. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Crossroads' foray into ITV peaktime was a ratings disaster last night, with the resurrected daytime soap pulling in fewer than 5m and losing out to BBC1 drama In Deep.

ITV repeated the first two episodes of Crossroads from 9-10pm last night in order to give a wider audience the chance to sample the show.

But the repeats had just 4.7m viewers and a 21% audience share, according to unofficial overnights.

In Deep, the BBC1 undercover cop drama starring Nick Berry and Stephen Tomkinson, had 6.7m. Last Tuesday in the same ITV slot, The Brits took 8.4m and a 33% share.

Crossroads' ratings also slid in its two regular daytime slots yesterday. At 1.30pm the soap had 1.7m, down from 2.1m on its Monday debut.

The 5.05pm repeat pulled 2.6m, 400,000 less than the previous day.

BBC1 enjoyed a good peaktime last night. Holiday 2001 undoubtedly benefited from being extended by five minutes to 7.35pm, picking up viewers switching over at 7.30pm for EastEnders.

The weekly BBC1 dose of escapism had 8m, up from 6.9m the previous week.

EastEnders is still riding high in the ratings in the wake of the Phil Mitchell shooting. Last night it pulled in 14.8m and a 58% share.

Then from 8.05pm Holby City beat The Bill. The hospital drama had 8.2m and a 34% share; while ITV's cop offering had 6.9m.

Overall last night, BBC1 had a 36% share of peaktime viewing, between 6 and 10.30pm. ITV had just 27%.

Channel 5 also enjoyed a good night, with its documentary about the younger Windsors from 8pm and Denzel Washington movie Courage Under Fire following on at 9pm.

The New Royals had 1.1m viewers and a 5% audience share; while Courage Under Fire drew 2.2m and a 12% share.

fields.headline: The colour field
fields.standfirst: Sean Ingle on shades of shirts and colours of players. Amongst other things
fields.trailText: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to answer them.
fields.body:
THE STRANGE LOCATION OF CHESTER CITY

"A friend of mine recently told me that Chester City's pitch lies half in England and half in Wales. Can this possibly be true or is my friend a bit of an idiot?" asks Chris Tarplee.

You do your mate a disservice, Mr Tarplee. For while he's not quite on the mark - it's actually the club's bar that lies half in England and half in Wales - he does highlight a peculiarity unique to Chester City FC, namely that they are an English club who actually play in Wales.

How do they get away with it? Well, although Chester's pitch is completely in Wales, the club's office, which lies just a few metres away, is just over the border in England - which is why they can be registered as an English club.

TRICKY TEASER NOT SOLVED SHOCK

"Arsenal cannot do it unless Arsene Wenger leaves. Manchester United have done it more than any other British club. Liverpool have done it once but not in the usual way. Everton, Oldham and Charlton have all done it once but Wimbledon will NEVER do it unless Crystal Palace go bankrupt. What is it?" asks Marcus Pretlove.

The answer is to do with rugby league matches, reckoned Rob Jordan last week. Oh no it isn't, responded scores of you in a pantomime chorus. Rob's answer is wrong for several reasons, you say: Huddersfield have hosted more rugby league matches than Manchester United; first-class rugby league has been played at Anfield, including games between St Helens v Castlefield and Wigan v Penrith; and Everton, Oldham and Charlton have all hosted more than one rugby league game.

Any sensible suggestions are welcome

MOST POPULAR SHIRT COLOUR

"Me and my friends got talking about this without resolution: what is the most popular shirt colour in all four divisions?" asked Stephen M.

"The answer is blue shirts with 19," says CC Goodwin. "Then comes red, white, and blue and white with 14 each. After that comes red and white with 11. Ten teams play in amber, yellow, orange or gold, four play in claret, three in black and white, and one each in red and amber, red and blue, and green.

"That's 92 clubs!" he exclaims.

DRAWS, DRAWS, DRAWS

"Is there any evidence that awarding three points for a win has made the game more exciting? Are there less draws than before the change? Would any English championships have been decided differently under the old system?" asks Stuart McGill.

A couple of weeks ago we claimed that the introduction of three points for a win has not affected the outcome of any championship since 1982. But as Doug Marx points out, we were wrong.

"In the 1994-95 season Blackburn won the championship," he says. "But if only two points had been awarded for a win, Manchester United would have won the title on goal difference.

"The final table read: 1) Blackburn: P42, W27, D8, L7, F80, A39; 2) Man Utd: P42, W26, D10, L6, F77, A28.

"For this reason alone the nation surely owes Jimmy Hill a debt of gratitude," adds Stephen Buckland.

PROVE A TOKYO BAR OWNER WRONG!

"The owner of our local bar here in Tokyo, states that Sweden, Holland, Belgium, France and Portugal are the only European sides, outside of the British Isles, to ever field a black player in a full international. We think that he is talking out of his arse, can someone please help us out, so that we can shut him up?" says Nigel Drake.

Last week we pointed out that Vicente Engonga played for Spain during 2000. Also, as legions of you wrote in to tell us, John Carew plays for Norway. Finally, Roger Sigrist says that Olympiakos had a black centre forward called Daniel Batista, who played for the Greek national side on many occasions.

LITTLE BROTHERS TRYING TO MAKE IT BIG: PART 3

"At the moment in Italy, Christian Vieri's little brother Massimiliano and Roberto Baggio's little bro' Eddy are playing together for Serie B side Ancona. Are there any other younger brothers of big name players attempting to do likewise?" asked Martin Casey.

"Nkwanko Kanu's little brother Christopher is a defender for Ajax," says Rick Buur, "while Cedric Seedorf - Clarence's younger brother - is the captain of the Dutch U-17 team and plays for NAC Breda."

"Finally, Carlos Hasselbaink, recently retired defender from Second Division Dutch team Haarlem, has a younger brother playing in England."

NOT-SO-BORING DRAWS: PART 3

"What was the highest ever drawn game in terms of goals scored?" asked Gary Ross.

In previous editions of The Knowledge we've mentioned 5-5 and 6-6 draws - but Paul Crankshaw has gone one better. "In a senior competitive match there was a 7-7 draw in the Dulwich Hamlet v Wealdstone FA Cup fourth qualifying round tie in 1930," he says.

"Amazingly, Dulwich were involved in an 8-7 FA Cup victory over St Albans City in the same round in 1923 - this game being famous for the fact that a St Albans player (Minter from memory) scored all SEVEN goals for his team - and ended up on the losing side!" he adds.

CAN YOU HELP?

"In the light of Ugo Ehiogu scoring for England last week - and what with me being a deeply sad individual - I was wondering if any other players had scored for England who had more vowels than consonants in their name?" asks Nathan-Madonna Byers.

"Can someone tell me who has played for the most professional clubs during a season or career?" asks Derek Tomkin.

"Does anyone know who has the highest ratio of international caps to league appearances? Surely Phil 'Overachiever' Neville is a prime candidate?" asks Chris Field.

webTitle: Sharon induction threatened by new violence

fields.headline: Sharon induction threatened by new violence
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon will be sworn in today as Israel's prime minister, supported by a broad based coalition government designed to end years of political instability, but threatened with a new wave of suicide bombings from Palestinian militants.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon will be sworn in today as Israel's prime minister, supported by a broad based coalition government designed to end years of political instability, but threatened with a new wave of suicide bombings from Palestinian militants.

Mr Sharon's accession to the prime minister's post was pending approval in the parliament of his national unity government, but that was generally expected to be a formality. Mr Sharon already fulfilled his first campaign promise by stitching together a coalition from centre left to far right, with the support of a solid majority among legislators.

The coalition will allow Israelis "to stand together, facing what at this moment poses the greatest danger - the deteriorating state of security," Mr Sharon told his Likud party this morning.

He said he would also seek to achieve peace with the Palestinians, but repeated his position that negotiations would begin "only after quiet will reign."

The unwieldy coalition government includes Nobel peace prize laureate Shimon Peres, the foreign minister, who will sit at the same cabinet table with the hawkish Rehavam Zeevi, the tourism minister, whose party advocates removing Palestinians from the West Bank.

Attracting the Labour party of defeated prime minister, Ehud Barak, then enlisting faction after faction in the fractious Knesset, the 73-year old Mr Sharon hopes to remain in power where others have fallen, serving out his term until mid-2003. Mr Sharon is Israel's fifth prime minister in less than six years.

fields.headline: Mirror poaches Mail's Francis
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Mirror head of news Richard Wallace has poached one of the Daily Mail's top reporters, Wayne Francis. By Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
New Mirror head of news Richard Wallace has poached one of the Daily Mail's top reporters, Wayne Francis, in the first step of an expected shake-up of the paper's newsroom

Mr Wallace would only say an announcement was "imminent", but insiders confirm Mr Francis is in the final stages of negotiation and is expected to join the Mirror in May.

Mr Francis has been at the Mail as a general reporter since 1997, where his taste in fast cars made him the envy of other journalists.

Before joining the Mail, he was the Sun's royal correspondent after working on Today as one of the original news team when the paper launched in the early 1980s.

Sources say Mr Francis has been offered "a significant amount of money", but claim he was attracted primarily by the Mirror's young news team.

"He's an experienced guy who works hard, plays hard and is used to generating his own stories," said one insider.

"He's being brought in to bring a bit of bottom to the news team, which is very talented but quite young."

Mr Francis joins weeks after Mr Wallace sent a memo out to his reporters warning them that if they failed to bring in decent exclusives they could go elsewhere.

Mr Wallace noted in his memo, which was sent to reporters' home addresses: "We know who you are".

The appointment of Mr Francis is believed to be the start of a wide-ranging overhaul of the newsroom, which sources say could result in "casualties" among reporters who are not pulling their weight.

Mr Wallace, the paper's former showbusiness editor, was promoted to the role of head of news late last year when Mirror editor Piers Morgan moved the existing head of news, Eugene Duffy, to associate editor.

fields.headline: Young urban thinkers' bible to relaunch
fields.trailText: 12pm: Limb By Limb is to relaunch as a free weekly newspaper amid reports it has hit financial problems, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Limb By Limb, the glossy magazine for "young urban thinking", is to be relaunched as a free weekly newspaper amid reports that the magazine has hit financial problems.

From April, the magazine will be published as an A2 weekly newspaper, given away free in bars and restaurants.

The spin-off is to be launched as a "news alternative", complete with cartoons and crosswords.

Editor Jasper Gibson was not available to comment on reports that the redesign had been forced by the magazine's inability to arrest mounting losses.

Limb by Limb was launched in 1999 by Ben Maschler, the son of Evening Standard restaurant critic Fay Maschler and Jasper Gibson, the grandson of arts guru Patrick Gibson.

The magazine, a self-styled bible of "young urban thinking", said at launch that it wanted to bridge the gap between Loaded and the Spectator, covering everything from tantric sex to politics.

Mr Maschler and Mr Gibson, who had no journalistic experience, claimed their lack of experience could be a plus.

"We've come into it fresh and relatively inexperienced so we're going to keep our dream pure," Mr Maschler said at launch.

"That's often the key to successful ventures," he added.

Limb By Limb won critical acclaim for its focus on hard issues and its satirical writing, and carried articles from some high-profile writers including the multi-award winning fiction writer Zadie Smith.

Neither of the founders ever revealed any information about the funding of the magazine.

fields.headline: US judge rejects twins' adoption
fields.trailText: An American judge ruled yesterday that the final custody decision over the so-called "internet twins" should be made by a court in Missouri, and that the two eight-month-old baby girls now in foster care in Britain should be sent back to the US as soon as possible.
fields.body:
An American judge ruled yesterday that the final custody decision over the so-called "internet twins" should be made by a court in Missouri, and that the two eight-month-old baby girls now in foster care in Britain should be sent back to the US as soon as possible.

Pulaski county chancery judge Mackie Pierce said neither Alan and Judith Kilshaw of Buckley, North Wales, nor Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernadino, California had met legal requirements to adopt the twins.

The ruling, in a court in Little Rock, Arkansas, is the latest twist in a saga that has seen the battle to adopt the twins shift from Missouri to California to Wales to London to Arkansas.

Shortly after the twins were born in St Louis, Missouri, to Tranda and Aaron Wecker last June, they were offered for adoption by their mother through an internet agency. The Allens believed that they had an agreement with the Caring Heart Adoption Agency to take the children and looked after them for two months while the adoption procedure was being carried out.

But the Kilshaws subsequently reached an agreement with the agency and travelled to the US. The babies' mother took the children from the Allens, saying she wanted to say a final farewell to them, and gave them to the Kilshaws, who took the twins to Arkansas where they were able to adopt them under the state's lenient adoption laws.

After the Kilshaws returned to Britain, the children were taken into the custody of the social services, where their status is now the subject of a legal battle.

Both of the twins' parents, who are separated, are now independently seeking custody of the twins in Missouri and have filed civil suits to secure them. Last week, a St Louis court also ruled that the decision about their future should be made in Missouri. This means there are now four separate claims on the twins.

The case had a new twist in recent days with the arrest in California last week of Mr Allen on charges of molesting two teenage babysitters. He denies the allegations.

webTitle: Number of nurses struck off up by half

fields.headline: Number of nurses struck off up by half
fields.trailText: The number of nurses struck off the register for professional misconduct rose by 50% last year as the authorities responded to increased complaints from hospital managers, patients and relatives.
fields.body:
The number of nurses struck off the register for professional misconduct rose by 50% last year as the authorities responded to increased complaints from hospital managers, patients and relatives.

Figures released yesterday by the UK Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting showed that 113 nurses were removed from the register last year, compared with 74 in 1999. It also imposed 41 cautions, compared with 22 the year before.

The council said the increase in disciplinary sanctions was probably caused by the public's greater willingness to complain rather than by any deterioration of professional standards.

"We can see no reason why there should be more misconduct now than there was 10 or 15 years ago," a spokesman said.

But the figures suggest that cases reaching a full hearing of the council's professional conduct committee were more likely than before to result in disciplinary action, suggesting that many of the complaints were well founded.

The report came as the General Medical Council, the doctors' disciplinary body, said it had suspended 25 doctors under the emergency banning orders introduced six months ago in response to the Harold Shipman case. Immediate suspensions pending a full hearing by the GMC's disciplinary committee were running at about one a week. They were made in cases where the allegations against a doctor were grave and did not prejudge the outcome of proceedings, a spokeswoman said.

Interim suspensions were introduced to protect the public during the GMC's lengthy investigations. A further 15 doctors have had conditions imposed on their practice pending a hearing.

The GMC last month re ported an unprecedented 50% increase in the number of complaints against doctors. There were 4,470 last year, compared with about 3,000 in 1999. The council said the rise could be due to the body's higher profile: "Because we dealt with several big cases last year, more members of the public know about us and take grievances to us."

Giving detailed figures for nursing, the UKCC said allegations of misconduct increased 16% last year to 1,255. Nearly half came from nurses' employers, about 22% from the public, 22% from the police or courts and 9% from other professionals.

The council's preliminary proceedings committee screened 1,522 cases (some hanging over from the previous year). It took no further action in 793 cases and referred 214 to the professional conduct committee for a full hearing, compared with 160 in 1999.

A further 327 cases were submitted for further investigation and 101 were forwarded to a panel of screeners which considers cases of nurses who may be unfit to practice on health grounds rather than misconduct.

Liz McAnulty, the council's director of professional conduct, said: "In some ways, the UKCC is a victim of its own success. Because we are now processing more initial complaints, the number of cases awaiting a hearing currently stands at 135 and is continuing to grow."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "The vast majority of nurses are providing the high quality care the public expects and deserve. It's a positive trend that patients and their families increasingly feel they have the right, and are able, to raise concerns."
