fields.headline: The killing of king Calcio
fields.standfirst: Something's wrong with Italian football. But while everyone can see the symptoms, nobody can find a cure. James Richardson dons his stethoscope and investigates
fields.trailText: Good news and bad news for football's Little Englanders - Italians now accept that Serie A has been overtaken as the world's top league. Not a huge discovery for the rest of Europe perhaps but for a nation brought up on 'il campionato piu bello del mondo' the trauma is something akin to losing an empire. (I mention bad news, because it's the Spanish Liga and not the Premiership that's being hailed here as the new number One. Sorry)
fields.body:
Good news and bad news for football's Little Englanders - Italians now accept that Serie A has been overtaken as the world's top league. Not a huge discovery for the rest of Europe perhaps but for a nation brought up on 'il campionato piu bello del mondo' the trauma is something akin to losing an empire. (I mention bad news, because it's the Spanish Liga and not the Premiership that's being hailed here as the new number One. Sorry)

Now this isn't the first time we've heard reports of the death of Calcio, but on this occasion there's some uncomfortable evidence; namely, the European Cups.

Consider: in the 90's alone, Serie A sides won 13 European trophies - not counting Supercups and World Club Cups - making these competitions the great barometer of Italian dominance. Outspending, outplaying and outwinning their rivals abroad, Serie A clubs dominated the Uefa rankings for so long that they ceased to question their supremacy.

By that same barometer the outloook is now bleak, to put it mildly. For the second year running Italy risks having no representatives whatsoever in the European semi-finals. Indeed, from a starting point of eight teams, there's only Milan in the Champions League still flying a tattered Tricolore, and even they may not make the Quarter-finals.

Meanwhile Roma, the side running away with the Italian league, were knocked out of the Uefa Cup, beaten 2-0 at home by Liverpool in the process. Reigning Italian champions Lazio performed a similar feat against Leeds, thus booking their early exit. Inter collapsed 2-0 at home to the celebrated Basques of Alavès, whilst the illustrious Juventus couldn't even emerge from the 1st group stage of the Champions league. On top of all of that, the Italian national side went and lost at home to Argentina last week. 'Pig Misery', as they say round here.

Now if last year's disasters could be written off as a freak occurrence, two lean seasons in a row have convinced Italians that it's truly Decline and Fall time. So why the collapse? The popular Gazzetta dello Sport points its inky finger at club directors drunk on huge TV contracts and distracted by shady passport deals. "You've destroyed our Football", squealed their front cover after the latest round of defeats.

Other papers here blame Italy's scant political weight. Because Serie A has no high level representative in Uefa, they argue, referees needlessly penalise them - and Garcia Aranca's intriguing performance during the Liverpool - Roma tie would be evidence for this. An interesting theory, and one that by extension would make Italy's past triumphs the fruit of friends in high places. Perish the thought.

For a more authoritative explanation, here's former Italy great and Minister of sport Gianni Rivera: "We're not building teams anymore, just soulless collections of exotic foreign names." Of course blaming the foreigners is hardly original, but have a look at the numbers all the same: no less than 81 foreign players were imported this season alone, and less than 30 of them turned out to be good enough for first team football.

It's not just a waste of resources however. By bringing in players in industrial quantities not only do Italian sides ignore home-grown talent, they also leave themselves with squads with precious little commitment to the team cause. Inter, Serie A's panic buyers, are a handy example - not so much a squad, more an episode of 'Mind Your Language'.

Claudio Ranieri, a noted foriegner himself, is more specific: "Italy's problems started with the arrival of foreign defenders. Their concentration isn't as good as the Italians. Before Bosman the imports were almost always in the midfield or up front, and every team had a solid group of Italians at the back."

Others take this theory further: for years Italian sides were feared, even reviled for grabbing the result even when they didn't deserve it. Since the advent of three points for a win though, they've become dangerously fancy and they're not comfortable with it. Thus, bring back catanaccio, and to hell with the critics.

It may yet come to that. If the Italians have learnt any lessons from this year's results (and they didn't last season) the near future should indeed see much talk about 'back to basics'. Their love affair with the footballing population of south America is also set to cool - 'Italian' squads are the new thing, thanks to the domestic success of the likes of Atalanta and Perugia.

Calcio's not yet dead and buried - it still claims more of the world's top players than any other league - but only time will tell how long it takes to reclaim its rightful place in society. 'Til then here in Little Italy they'll just have to grit their teeth.

webTitle: No kidding as Jacko calls for bill of rights

fields.headline: No kidding as Jacko calls for bill of rights
fields.trailText: In one of the strangest decisions of his deeply strange life, the multi-million selling singer Michael Jackson last night chose the Oxford Union to demand the right for children to be read a bedtime story without having to compete with the evening news. Tania Branigan reports.
fields.body:
In one of the strangest decisions of his deeply strange life, the multi-million selling singer Michael Jackson last night chose the Oxford Union to demand the right for children to be read a bedtime story without having to compete with the evening news.

In the star's first ever lecture, on the topic of child welfare, the man who settled a million-dollar claim for child abuse out of court was expected to speak of his sadness in missing out on a normal childhood and to launch a seven-point bill of rights for children.

Jackson, whose ever-evolving face provides gossip fodder around the world, had promised a speech "certain to surprise". His words could "bring healing to humanity and healing to our planet", he said.

"Childhood has become the great casualty of modern day living," he planned to tell his audience. "All around us we are producing scores of kids who have not had the joy, who have not been accorded the right, who have not been allowed the freedom, of knowing what it is like to be a kid."

He spoke of his own childhood: "Those of you who are familiar with the Jackson Five know that I began performing at the tender age of five and that ever since then, I haven't stopped dancing or singing.

"But while performing and making music remain as some of my greatest joys, when I was young, I wanted more than anything else, to be a typical little boy. "I wanted to build tree houses, have water balloon fights and play hide and seek with my friends.

"But fate had it otherwise and all I could do was envy the laughter and the playtime that seemed to be going on all around me."

In launching Heal These Kids, a new initiative from his Heal The World Foundation - whose board members include Dame Elizabeth Taylor and former Israeli prime minister Shimon Peres - Jackson said every child had the right "to be loved without having to earn it, to be protected without having to deserve it and to feel valuable, even if you came into the world with nothing".

His proposed bill of rights includes:

 the right to be loved without having to earn it

 the right to be protected without having to deserve it

 the right to feel valuable, even if you came into the world with nothing

 the right to be listened to without having to be interesting

 the right to be read a bed time story, without having to compete with the evening news

 the right to an education without having to dodge bullets at school

 the right to be thought of as adorable (even if you have a face only a mother could love).

Devoted fans of the singer, whose Thriller remains the best selling album of all time, last night crowded against crash barriers outside the Union building, waiting for the singer, who is on crutches because of his broken foot.

fields.headline: Trapped in the property wastelands
fields.trailText: Ministers are under growing pressure to rescue thousands of inner city home owners trapped in a cycle of negative equity and unable to sell houses because they have lost value and are often worthless.
fields.body:
Ministers are under growing pressure to rescue thousands of inner city home owners trapped in a cycle of negative equity and unable to sell houses because they have lost value and are often worthless.

Backed by Labour MPs and council leaders, the chairman of the Commons environment committee, Andrew Bennett, warned yesterday that unless urgent action is taken to reform compulsory purchase legislation and provide proper compensation, thousands of people, mainly in the north, could be left penniless.

At present, councils anxious to redevelop rundown areas can only compensate owners for the market value of their property - which means that many people stand to gain nothing and could be left with huge debts because their mortgage far exceeds the value of a house.

The full extent of the problem, particularly acute in Greater Manchester and Merseyside, has been underlined in a report from Birmingham University showing that 280,000 homes along the north-west's M62 corridor alone are blighted - 17% of properties - including almost 100,000 private houses.

Researchers working for 39 councils and housing associations have called for a government fund to tackle areas of low demand and abandoned housing because current programmes are inadequate to cope with a deepening crisis.

The issue was underlined at a recent Guardian North debate which highlighted the sharp north-south property divide - prices in even the poorer parts of Greater London remain buoyant - and the deep divisions within northern cities where apartments have been sold for up to £1m barely a mile from areas where property prices are collapsing.

Research undertaken for the Guardian by Brian Robson, a government urban adviser and head of Manchester University's centre for urban policy studies, warned that northern cities are increasingly characterised by the North American "doughnut" phenomenon - thriving, rebuilt centres surrounded by a wasteland of dereliction and abandoned housing, with many trapped in streets where prices have collapsed.

He highlighted the case of east Manchester, close to the vibrant city centre, "a huge swath of dereliction" embracing almost 2,500 acres and now covered by a government-backed urban regeneration company which planned up to 6,000 new houses over 10 years and improvements to several thousand older properties.

Professor Robson's report spoke of houses selling "if at all" for less than £10,000, with unemployment twice the Manchester average and a mortality rate 50% above the national norm. "In a city which now boasts of selling its first £1m flat, the terraces of east Manchester are largely unsaleable," he wrote. "A quarter of Manchester houses sell for less than £20,000 and in east Manchester many sell for £5,000 ... across the area, some 20% of housing is vacant and, in parts, whole streets stand empty. There is not a single secondary school in the area."

The city council wants stronger powers to halt the cycle of decline by earmarking whole streets as property improvement zones, where authorities - using public funds if necessary - will guarantee that prices will not fall below a certain level.

Andrew Bennett, MP for Denton and Reddish, in Greater Manchester, is now pressing the government for revised legislation to create the zones. "The very act of guaranteeing a 'floor' in the market, below which prices would not be allowed to fall, would maintain confidence in the area," he said. "It is now impossible to sell in some areas, although a mile or so away similar [terrace] houses are going for £100,000. It is an appalling situation, with some people unable to sell their houses - and others scared stiff of going into areas because they know if they buy a house it will lose value."

He fears that the problem of low demand and abandonment will spread from east Manchester to the neighbouring authorities of Stockport and Tameside, which embrace his constituency. "Already there are signs of the poorer areas spreading out and decline, once it sets in, can take root very quickly."

Dire position

A third of homes in east Manchester are vacant in a conurbation with more derelict land than any other part of the country. Terraces that have not been demolished are boarded up and vandalised. On some estates nearby, almost half the housing is vacant. Tom Bloxham, chairman of the Manchester-based developers Urban Splash, which has created 1,000 city centre flats in Manchester and Liverpool - several are on the market for £700,000 - acknowledges that the urban "doughnut" has left some neighbourhoods in a "dire position", with unsaleable houses and a string of social problems.

But he believes that the city centre property renaissance - central Manchester now has 10,000 residents - will eventually ripple out to east Manchester and elsewhere. "Ten years ago no one would have dreamt that so many old warehouses would be redeveloped and that people would invest in city properties on this scale," he said. "Now, as the city centre gets fuller the market will spread out. There is no reason why there should not be a radical transformation elsewhere."

Development is continuing to blight the countryside at the expense of rebuilding cities, in spite of planning guidelines introduced a year ago, according to a report published today by the Council for the Protection of Rural England.

Plans for 658,000 houses on green fields are still in the pipeline - enough to accommodate the demands of the top 80 housebuilders for six years before touching an urban site.

webTitle: True-life violence keeps Shakespeare pic out of cinemas

fields.headline: True-life violence keeps Shakespeare pic out of cinemas
fields.trailText: An Americanised update of the Shakespeare play Othello, completed nearly two years ago, looks set to have its release date bumped back yet again in the wake of Monday's fatal shooting in a school in San Diego, California.
fields.body:
An Americanised update of the Shakespeare play Othello, completed nearly two years ago, looks set to have its release date bumped back yet again in the wake of Monday's fatal shooting in a school in San Diego, California.

The movie, O, is set in a high-school and closes with the bloody death of four students. But true-life events have dogged it from the moment it completed production.

Directed by Tim Blake Nelson (best known as the doleful third escapee in the Coen Brothers' O Brother Where Art Thou), O boasts a vogeuish cast in Julia Stiles (playing "Desi"), Martin Sheen, Mekhi Phifer and Josh Hartnett.Yet, according to a report on Hollywood.com, the film has had to deal with the slings and arrows of outrageous fortune for almost two years.

O finished filming in the summer of 1999 and backers Miramax and Dimension set a release date of October 1999. It was put back on the shelf in the wake of the Columbine high-school massacre, when Miramax chairman Bob Weinstein explained that "we felt the responsible thing was to postpone the release due to the sensitive events occuring at the time." In the event, O idled there for the whole of election year 2000, as the federal Trade Commission and politicians such as John McCain and Joe Lieberman criticised what they regarded as a diet of movie violence targeted at teenagers. A US release date of April 27 2001 was finally set earlier this year. Now the San Diego shooting may well push the film even further into the future.

"We are not commenting on the release of the film, given the unfortunate incident that occurred in San Diego," Dimension publicist Elizabeth Clark told Variety. "What happened there is a very serious issue. The release of our movie is minor in comparison." Last word, for the time being, goes to star Julia Stiles: "There is some fear of it being controversial it's easy for people to associate the violence with what's happened recently."

webTitle: Hollywood strike could hit Britain too

fields.headline: Hollywood strike could hit Britain too
fields.trailText: The projected Screen Actors Guild due to shut down Hollywood this summer could have heavy repercussions for film production in the UK too.
fields.body:
The projected Screen Actors Guild due to shut down Hollywood this summer could have heavy repercussions for film production in the UK too.

It was initially thought that the SAG strike could benefit the British industry with American studios thought to be considering relocating productions to the UK and Europe. Now it appears that many of the UK's biggest stars are also members of SAG, and bound by the same restrictions.

The trouble is caused by the special relationship that these A-list stars enjoy with the US. According to the British actors' union, Equity, almost every British actor who works in Hollywood is also a paid-up member of SAG. In recent days the guild moved to close the loophole that might have allowed "runaway" Hollywood productions to relocate to Europe. SAG have published a set of guidelines for its non-US members. The guidelines state that a British SAG member can only work on a British-based movie if it is funded entirely by non-US money and has not been pre-sold to a US distributor.

Equity spokesman Martin Brown told Reuters that: "the strike will have an impact on Britain because of the large numbers of British actors who are members of SAG." Major league stars such as Kate Winslet, Ewan McGregor and Hugh Grant are said to be supportive of the SAG action, and are expected to abide by its rules. Unless an agreement is reached, the SAG strike should take effect from June 31.

webTitle: China drops homosexuality from list of psychiatric disorders

fields.headline: China drops homosexuality from list of psychiatric disorders
fields.trailText: Homosexuality will stop being regarded as a psychiatric disorder in China next month, on the publication of new guidelines by the Chinese Psychiatric Association.
fields.body:
Homosexuality will stop being regarded as a psychiatric disorder in China next month, on the publication of new guidelines by the Chinese Psychiatric Association.

They will say that homosexuality is part of "normal" sexual behaviour, with the proviso that those who are unhappy with their sexual orientation may still be judged to be in need of psychiatric help.

Wan Yanhai, who writes for a gay-oriented website, said the decision was "an important step for restoring the esteem of Chinese homosexuals".

The announcement follows a sometimes heated debate among Chinese psychiatrists. The traditionalists argued that homosexuality undermined family values, caused mental disorders and spread sexually transmitted diseases.

Those urging reform pointed to the existence of a gay minority in all societies and the change in China's social values .

Homosexuality has been frowned on since the 1912 nationalist revolution, when it was seen as part of the decadent imperial lifestyle. Al though not criminalised under communist rule after 1949, it became regarded as socially deviant. During the cultural revolution (1966-76) gay activity could lead to execution.

More recently gays remained liable to imprisonment without trial in re-education camps. If sent to psychiatric hospitals they were likely to receive electric shock treatment or aversion therapy.

The change in attitude reflects a more general shift in Chinese society - at least in urban culture - towards a greater tolerance of different kinds of sexual behaviour.

webTitle: How charities are tackling the problem of recruiting top quality people

fields.headline: Staff of life
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill on how charities are preparing to tackle the problem of recruiting - and keeping - top quality people
fields.trailText: Nicola Hill on how charities are preparing to tackle the problem of recruiting - and keeping - top quality people
fields.body:
Staff are leaving charities in growing numbers, and replacing them is proving increasingly tough. So tomorrow, 250 charity managers will gather at a conference in London to grapple with solutions.

One in three voluntary organisations which have sought to recruit staff in the past two years says it has been a struggle. Many applicants are said to be insufficiently qualified or experienced to fill posts, especially in management, fundraising and IT.

But recruitment experts blame low salary levels, lack of career opportunities and poor training. Elaine Smethurst, director of Working for a Charity, a training agency, says: "In order to advance themselves, charity staff are having to move from cause to cause. Organisations should look at long-term investment in people."

So what's the solution? Investment in career development, or higher salaries? And can charities afford either?

To kick-start the debate, a raft of publications will be released at the London conference. The Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation (VSNTO), which is organising the event in conjunction with the Royal Society of Arts (RSA), will publish a workforce development plan, setting out key recommendations for the sector. The RSA will issue a report on a project for accredited learning in small charities. And guides will be available on NVQs, management development and working in the sector.

Ben Kernighan, head of VSNTO, says: "The sector needs to have a two-pronged attack: invest in increasing the skills of staff and ensure good people are attracted to the sector."

Janet Fleming, who managed the RSA's project, says that research among small charities found that 80% of staff said training had increased their confidence and 57% said it improved motivation. Yet only 20% of the organisations had offered training previously.

The project developed a model for planning and delivering cost-effective training. "Charities aren't offering enough money, so they need to be prepared to take people on and offer them training," says Fleming. To save costs, she suggests, charities could ask corporate supporters to give them free places on their training courses.

Kernighan sees the launch next month of learning and skills councils, 47 local branches, responsible for training of the over-16s, as a great opportunity for the sector. "They have £6bn to spend, so voluntary organisations should form local networks to identify training needs and tap this new funding," he says. Funding bodies should also review their application processes and build in requirements that charities train staff, says Kernighan. A VSNTO report, Skills Matter, last year indicated that 40% of charities acknowledged gaps in planning and forward-thinking skills.

The VSNTO's new development plan advocates creative thinking about training opportunities. Mentoring, work shadowing and secondments are suggested as cheaper alternatives to courses. Smethurst suggests charities should encourage staff to volunteer for other organisations to gain experience. "Chief executives could become trustees of other organisations, rather than spending lots of money on courses," she says.

Conservation charity BTCV uses its resources creatively to enhance staff motivation by allowing office employees one day every few months to join volunteers. Spokeperson Len Liggins says: "We find it promotes team building and increases communication and cooperation skills among office staff."

In terms of attracting people, Kernighan thinks charities should start young. Introduction of citizenship classes in schools should be seized on as a chance to promote the voluntary sector as a place to work.

One of the guides being launched tomorrow shows results of research among 16 to 17-year-olds on attitudes to work. They want jobs to be meaningful, varied and satisfying.

Luisa Clarke, a 26-year-old publishing executive, was keen to switch from the corporate world but was put off applying for many voluntary sector jobs because the advertisements insisted on charity experience. She eventually joined Starlight Children's Foundation as a PR manager at the end of last year, but she advises: "Charities should emphasise that skills from the commercial world are transferable."

However, Maria Soltysiak, human resources director at Christian Aid, cautions: "If we recruit people who don't have all the skills, we spend money training them and then they move on in one or two years." Christian Aid has stemmed the outward flow of staff in the past 12 months, but Soltysiak says there still are not enough people available in IT, finance and fundraising who will accept lower salaries.

One of the recruitment agencies in the sector thinks the answer to recruitment is not just pay and is launching a career development fair this summer. Charity People hopes to attract new recruits to the sector by hosting forum3 starting on August 31st with workshops about skills development and what motivates people to apply for jobs.

David Lale, director of recruitment agency Charity People, identifies a particular problem with fundraisers. He says: "Unless organisations can connect their fundraising staff to their cause, develop their skills and provide a decent career path, then they would probably be better off outsourcing the whole operation to the private sector."

The VSNTO development plan is available free on 020-7520 2497. The RSA report, Making it Work - Learning and Accreditation in the Voluntary Sector, is available, at £5 inc, on 020-7451 6833.

fields.headline: Cult of the chairman
fields.standfirst: He presided over mass murder and cultural devastation. But 25 years after his death, Mao Zedong is a demigod with a lucrative line in merchandise. Ian Buruma on how China rediscovered the Great Helmsman
fields.trailText: He presided over mass murder and cultural devastation. But 25 years after his death, Mao Zedong is a demigod with a lucrative line in merchandise. Ian Buruma  on how China rediscovered the Great Helmsman.
fields.body:
A miracle happened in Shaoshan, birthplace of Mao Zedong, on December 20, 1993. President Jiang Zemin had come with an entourage of party grandees to unveil a 6 metre-high bronze statue of the late Chairman Mao, looking, as the guidebook has it, "firm and steady, and glowing with health". Anyone who sees it, the book continues, "can feel the magnetic power of a great leader, a victorious leader".

December in Hunan province is a cold, dark month, with constant rain or sleet. The freezing winds won't let up until the spring. But on that miraculous occasion, just as President Jiang was pulling the sheet off Mao's shining face, the sun came blazing through the clouds and, even stranger, the moon shone brightly.

I was shown photographs of the miracle when I visited Shaoshan recently, on a typically bleak, rainy day. You could buy the picture in all sizes, the most expensive ones framed in gold. You could also buy gold or marble busts of the chairman, tapes of his speeches, fine embroideries of his countenance, and coins, stamps, ballpoints, pencils, cigarette lighters, key rings, CDs, T-shirts and teacups, all with Mao's image on. Then there were the plastic domes with Mao inside that rained gold flakes when you shook them. And the golden amulets to bring good health and fortune with - instead of the more usual images of Buddhist or Taoist holy men - engraved portraits of the former Chinese leader.

Mao Zedong has clearly entered the pantheon of Chinese folk deities, along with the Yellow Emperor and other legendary sages and heroes in Chinese history. And Shaoshan, visited by millions over the years, is the Lourdes of his cult.

This is not so strange. Humans have been worshipped as gods for thousands of years in China, and the point of Mao, in the eyes of the believers, is no longer whether he was good or bad; such categories do not apply to godmen. The point, as a taxi driver in Hunan pointed out to me when I asked him about the Mao charm dangling from his rearview mirror, is that Mao was Great, or weida . Greatness, in the sense of projecting great personal power, is much admired among the Chinese peoples; think of the continuing popularity of Mein Kampf in Taiwan.

A godman in China or Japan can still have entirely human characteristics - more so, perhaps, than Jesus Christ, whose status with some Chinese is somewhat similar to Mao's. In Changsha, the capital of Hunan, where Mao went to school and founded the regional communist party, I visited the provincial museum, where there is a lavish display of Mao's underwear. That is the interesting thing about godmen: they are both divine and very human.

Divine beings in every society promise salvation and good fortune, and where there are miracles, there is business to be done. This, too, is universal. Mao's divine status has brought a great deal of business to Shaoshan. Indeed, it has become the main cottage industry of this small but prosperous town. Restaurants offer "Mao's favourite dishes". Snake-oil salesmen sell miracle cures for all kinds of diseases. And almost every shop is a purveyor of Mao memorabilia.

Shaoshan, as a pilgrimage site, is surprisingly traditional. Not only does it have all the characteristics of Chinese folk religion, which Mao affected to despise, but of higher Chinese culture as well; for example, the ubiquitous presence of Mao's calligraphy and poetry. One of the tasks of great Chinese leaders is to carry on Chinese civilisation, and the core of that civilisation is the word, which finds its highest expression in calligraphy. No matter how much tradition Mao and his followers smashed - and they smashed a great deal - he kept the word. And so did his successors. Not only is Mao's own rather wild calligraphy everywhere to be seen in Shaoshan - on paper, on rocks, on walls, on silk - but also that of Deng Xiaoping and Jiang Zemin. Shaoshan, the birthplace of the greatest wrecker of Chinese tradition, has become, in many ways, a repository of it.

There is, none the less, something curious about the cult of Mao, which began in the 80s, roughly 10 years after the Great Helmsman's death. First of all, folk cults are usually suppressed by a nominally communist government which officially, in good Marxist fashion, dismisses all religion as superstition. Governement approved, so-called patriotic churches, subservient to the party, are tolerated, but spontaneous cults are viewed with deep suspicion. Secondly, memories of the famines and mass murders associated with the Mao years have not faded away, even though younger generations often know little or nothing about them.

However, the bad memories - the bloody purges, the violent anarchy of the Cultural Revolution - are officially classified as "mistakes", committed when Mao was old and no longer in control of his evil courtiers. His alleged greatness - the reason for his divinity and the thing admired by the Hunanese taxi driver - is something very traditional. Mao is supposed to have created order in the Chinese empire by kicking out the barbarians, punishing evil-doers, and restoring virtue. His great achievement in the eyes of his admirers is moral, more than political. Or rather, politics and morality come to the same thing. As the Confucian phrase goes: "Only the virtuous can rule all under Heaven." Mao's revolution, so it is believed, brought back harmony and virtue were there had been chaos and corruption. And, like all peasant messiahs, Mao promised a society in which all men would be equal.

The deification of Mao happened just as Deng Xiaoping's economic reforms once again made chaos, inequality and corruption visible in China. Deng's reforms also meant a restoration of a different kind. Intellectuals, persecuted horribly under Mao, came back as advisers to the reformist rulers. They were the modern mandarins, as it were, at the court of Deng. Tired of utopian campaigns, they knew that a degree of inequality and corruption was an inevitable side-effect of China's rush towards economic modernisation. But these side-effects can become intolerable if political freedom fails to match economic liberties. That is what produced the protests on Tiananmen Square in 1989. It is also what produced the banned Falun Gong sect - and the cult of Mao.

A professor of history in Changsha, who supports the economic reforms and is afraid of cults and popular rebellions, told me: "The more intellectuals hate Mao, the more the poor people like him." Mao's admirers think that he stood for egalitarianism and righteousness, whereas the current elite looks greedy, corrupt and contemptuous of the lower classes.

Maoism was, in fact, a lethal mixture of Stalinism and Chinese authoritarianism. Like Chinese autocrats before him, he believed that obedience had to be enforced and that social harmony is a matter of imposing "correct thinking", not of finding peaceful solutions to inevitable conflicts of interests. The moral dogma to be imposed can be Confucianism or Marxism, or Maoism, or Communism with Chinese Characteristics. Whatever the dogma, opposition to it is not just wrong, it is immoral. When class enemies are wiped out, there will be no more conflicts. And those who still claim personal interests are evil, and have to be wiped out too.

Economic liberalism, towards which China has been moving in the past 20 years, is all about interests. Businessmen in the rich coastal cities do not necessarily have the same interests as farmers in Hunan, or factory workers in the industrial northeast. And academics and party cadres might have different interests altogether. Many Chinese are well aware of this, but the one-party communist system has no mechanisms to solve these conflicts: without party politics, a free press, and elected political representation, such conflicts cannot be solved.

So whenever conflicts come to the boil - students or Falun Gong supporters demonstrating in Beijing, farmers rioting in the countryside, academics writing critical articles on the internet, or workers protesting against factory closures - the government falls back on that old Maoist mixture of dogma and tradition. People are told to cultivate correct thinking, to redouble their studies of Marxism-Leninism, to strengthen China, and to struggle against foreign imperialists and class enemies.

Perversely, the same intellectuals and businessmen who support China's economic reforms are often as fearful of political reforms as the party leaders. They may hate communist propaganda, but they tend to associate multi-party politics with disorder, selfishness, and mob rule. And so, in the name of economic development and stability, they endorse authoritarian measures to control protesters.

What they often fail to see is that cults are a direct result of blocked politics. Just as autocratic Chinese governments have always justified their monopoly of power by claiming superior virtue, peasant rebellions and religious protests have done the same thing. They were the virtuous rebels who rose in the name of all kinds of folk gurus and deities, including Mao Zedong, to fight corrupt officials and evil rulers, and restore morality. This is why the government is now so spooked by Falun Gong and the many "underground" Christian cults: they offer alternative dogmas which undermine the rulers' already shaky claims to superior virtue.

There is no evidence that any of the cults in China are about to explode in violent rebellion. Most believers, like the pilgrims in Shaoshan, hope for good health, good fortune, or just a good time. But there is much resentment over betrayed loyalties and dashed illusions. Like the neo-Maoists, many Falun Gong believers wereonce fervent communists who believed that a new moral Chinese utopia was at hand. The spectacle of party hacks and gangsters helping themselves to riches, while others languish in the margins, has bred a great deal of anger.

There are democratic institutions to contain such anger. But without the freedom to build such institutions, the Chinese are reduced once again to waiting for the next Mao, or violent messiah.

fields.headline: Finding staff for life
fields.standfirst: Nicola Hill on how charities are preparing to tackle the problem of recruiting - and keeping - top quality people
fields.trailText: Staff are leaving charities in growing numbers, and replacing them is proving increasingly tough. So tomorrow, 250 charity managers will gather at the Learning and Skills in the Voluntary Sector conference in London to grapple with solutions.
fields.body:
Staff are leaving charities in growing numbers, and replacing them is proving increasingly tough. So tomorrow, 250 charity managers will gather at the Learning and Skills in the Voluntary Sector conference in London to grapple with solutions.

One in three voluntary organisations that have sought to recruit staff in the past two years says it has been a struggle. Many applicants are said to be insufficiently qualified or experienced to fill posts, especially in management, fundraising and IT.

But recruitment experts blame low salary levels, lack of career opportunities and poor training. Elaine Smethurst, director of Working for a Charity, a training agency, said: "In order to advance themselves, charity staff are having to move from cause to cause. Organisations should look at long-term investment in people."

So what's the solution? Investment in career development, or higher salaries? And can charities afford either?

To kick-start the debate, a raft of publications will be released at the London conference. The Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation (VSNTO), which is organising the event in conjunction with the Royal Society of Arts (RSA), will publish a workforce development plan, setting out key recommendations for the sector. The RSA will issue a report on a project for accredited learning in small charities. And guides will be available on NVQs, management development and working in the sector.

Ben Kernighan, head of VSNTO, said: "The sector needs to have a two-pronged attack: invest in increasing the skills of staff and ensure good people are attracted to the sector."

Janet Fleming, who managed the RSA's project, says that research among small charities found that 80% of staff said training had increased their confidence and 57% said it improved motivation. Yet only 20% of the organisations had offered training previously.

The project developed a model for planning and delivering cost-effective training. "Charities aren't offering enough money, so they need to be prepared to take people on and offer them training," said MsFleming. To save costs, she suggests, charities could ask corporate supporters to give them free places on their training courses.

Mr Kernighan sees the launch next month of learning and skills councils, 47 local branches, responsible for training of the over-16s, as a great opportunity for the sector. "They have £6bn to spend, so voluntary organisations should form local networks to identify training needs and tap this new funding," he said. Funding bodies should also review their application processes and build in requirements that charities train staff, says Mr Kernighan. A VSNTO report, Skills Matter, last year indicated that 40% of charities acknowledged gaps in planning and forward-thinking skills.

The VSNTO's new development plan advocates creative thinking about training opportunities. Mentoring, work shadowing and secondments are suggested as cheaper alternatives to courses. Ms Smethurst suggests charities should encourage staff to volunteer for other organisations to gain experience. "Chief executives could become trustees of other organisations, rather than spending lots of money on courses," she said.

Conservation charity BTCV uses its resources creatively to enhance staff motivation by allowing office employees one day every few months to join volunteers. Spokesman Len Liggins said: "We find it promotes team building and increases communication and cooperation skills among office staff."

In terms of attracting people, Mr Kernighan thinks charities should start young. Introduction of citizenship classes in schools should be seized on as a chance to promote the voluntary sector as a place to work.

One of the guides being launched tomorrow shows results of research among 16 to 17-year-olds on attitudes to work. They want jobs to be meaningful, varied and satisfying.

Luisa Clarke, a 26-year-old publishing executive, was keen to switch from the corporate world but was put off applying for many voluntary sector jobs because the advertisements insisted on charity experience. She eventually joined Starlight Children's Foundation as a PR manager at the end of last year, but she advised: "Charities should emphasise that skills from the commercial world are transferable."

However, Maria Soltysiak, human resources director at Christian Aid, cautioned: "If we recruit people who don't have all the skills, we spend money training them and then they move on in one or two years." Christian Aid has stemmed the outward flow of staff in the past 12 months, but Ms Soltysiak says there still are not enough people available in IT, finance and fundraising who will accept lower salaries.

One of the recruitment agencies in the sector thinks the answer to recruitment is not just pay and is launching a career development fair this summer. Charity People hopes to attract new recruits to the sector by hosting forum3 starting on August 31st with workshops about skills development and what motivates people to apply for jobs."

David Lale, director of recruitment agency Charity People, identifies a particular problem with fundraisers. He said: "Unless organisations can connect their fundraising staff to their cause, develop their skills and provide a decent career path, then they would probably be better off outsourcing the whole operation to the private sector."

 The VSNTO development plan is available free on 020-7520 2497. The RSA report, Making it Work - Learning and Accreditation in the Voluntary Sector, is available, at £5 inc, on 020-7451 6833.

fields.headline: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.standfirst: Moved to despair
fields.trailText: Moved to despair
fields.body:
Moved to despair

Our horror story two weeks ago about the international removals firm Cargo Forwarding and its many reincarnations sent shivers of dismay through many of you. Among the calls we have received were two from the British Association of Removers, anxious that we should point out that many removals firms have hearts of gold and unblemished reputations. That's doubtless true, but corporate perfection is not a theme you choose to write to us about, although if any of you have encountered a star removals firm do share your find with us.

G Mathur of Amsterdam was not so fortunate. When he left London to start a new life in Brussels he gave away most of his furniture, but was keen to hang on to his treasured hand-made bed. An ad alerted him to a company called Crown Worldwide Movers which, for the next four years, stored the bed and his clothes apparently in a Belgium depot. However, when Mathur sought to retrieve them the paperwork was lost and they were eventually discovered in Barking. The clothes, when they arrived, had been stained and the bed was battered, split and dented. A Crown official promised that the damage would be made good under Mathur's insurance policy, but months passed, emails went unanswered and Mathur eventually discovered that the claim had never been submitted, nor a replacement bed part ordered from the manufacturer. His case was finally taken over by another official who also failed to respond to emails. Seven months after his first complaint, Mathur is still sleeping on a mattress and hasn't even had the large dry-cleaning bill for his clothes refunded.

Like Cargo Forwarding, Crown tends to tire quickly of its identity. It began life in 1990 as Maxxim International, then shifted to Maxxum International and now goes by the name of Crown Relocation Services. Righteous dismay from its new head, who declares that he knew nothing of the saga which happened before his time and that he'd weeded out several unhelpful staff since then. Three months after Consumer alerted him, Mathur has finally received his bed back with a new part fitted. "It should never have taken so long to get it sorted," says our spokesman. What's the lesson to be learned? Always try to choose a removal firm that has membership of the British Association of Removers or the National Guild of Removers and Storers, so you can be sure of a listening ear if the worst should happen.

Bought by default

We all know that electrical retailers can earn more from extended warranties than from their total sales of goods, so Radio Rentals is to be congratulated for an apparently cunning strategy to flog the things. Leo Vita-Finzi bought an item on hire purchase, paid for by direct debit. Then, when he'd completed his payments, he moved house and gave the goods away. Later he noticed a new direct debit was making its way monthly to Radio Rentals. After two attempts to cancel it he discovered that a form had been sent to his old address asking if he wanted to take out insurance on his purchase now his payments were completed. The small print required him to return said form only if he didn't want to take out a policy. Naturally Vita-Finzi couldn't return it since he never received it, but Radio Rentals remains unmoved and declares it is not company policy to refund customers.

It changes its tune when Consumer gets in touch. "There was a system error on some accounts whereby customers were charged in error for continued insurance," says a spokeswoman. It's a thorough kind of error that sends out forms clearly stating that warranties will be sold by default. Funny, too, that Vita-Finzi was assured that the practice was "company policy" until Consumer intervened. Reassuringly, the Association of British Insurers says it has never come across "company policy" of this ilk. "It would be most unusual to sell insurance in this way," says a spokeswoman. Vita-Finzi has now been promised a refund.

Warning Psion

How's this for a speedy turnaround. A Sen of New Malden, Surrey, spent £400 on a Psion Series 5 organiser for her son and, shortly after the warranty expired, it broke down. Psion repaired it for £150, but a few weeks later it developed new ailments. Psion next replaced various parts of its anatomy, including the screen, and returned it, whereupon liquid mosaics began dancing across the new screen. Psion refused to accept liability and insisted Sen would have to stump up £100 for a further probe.

"This story has moved me," says Psion's PR when Consumer explains the saga. He promises a free replacement there and then and opines that such a dull story wouldn't look good on our page and since he'd responded to it effectively maybe we could leave it at that. But it would be a pity to let such soft-heartedness go unremarked, besides which, consumers should take note: your statutory rights apply to repairs, so if your equipment is damaged or not fixed by a botched job you are entitled to remedial action or compensation.

Split personality

For the past 14 months, Bill Kirton of Aberdeen has been living with a triple identity thanks to British Airways' surrealist bureaucracy. It began when his BA Executive Club account was merged with that of another Bill Kirton in Inverurie, Aberdeenshire, which meant that he received the unknown Mr Kirton's air miles allowance and the unknown Mr Kirton received his account statements. BA eventually succeeded in separating the pair, but has spent the past year trying to work out how to divide up their melded air miles, during which time Kirton has not been able to use his account. "I was getting used to quoting the two addresses they'd merged each time I rang customer services," he says. "But lately they've added a third - of a Mr Kirton in Belfast. Now they've started sending emails telling me how wonderful they are - addressed to William Davis."

Alas, Consumer must admit defeat on this one. After sending three faxes to three different BA officials apparently "on the case", and leaving six unreturned messages over four months we've given up. But we thought we'd tell you about it anyway so that BA doesn't think it can get away with its rude silence.

fields.bodyText: Moved to despair Our horror story two weeks ago about the international removals firm Cargo Forwarding and its many reincarnations sent shivers of dismay through many of you. Among the calls we have received were two from the British Association of Removers, anxious that we should point out that many removals firms have hearts of gold and unblemished reputations. That's doubtless true, but corporate perfection is not a theme you choose to write to us about, although if any of you have encountered a star removals firm do share your find with us. G Mathur of Amsterdam was not so fortunate. When he left London to start a new life in Brussels he gave away most of his furniture, but was keen to hang on to his treasured hand-made bed. webTitle: Legal challenges step up care homes crisis campaign

fields.headline: Legal challenges step up care homes crisis campaign
fields.trailText: A boycott of council-funded residents, a protest march and legal challenges aim to show local authorities that care home owners are serious about tackling underfunding.
fields.body:
Care home owners around the country are stepping up their campaign against local authority funding levels with legal challenges launched by groups in the north and the midlands.

Sheffield residential and nursing homes association has lodged a complaint with the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) over the differing level of fees paid to council and private sector homes, which they claim is illegal under the Competitions Act 1998.

They have also challenged the legality of Sheffield city council's accounts and called in the district auditor - a move also being made by Birmingham care home association.

Both associations will stage a protest march through Birmingham's city centre today under the "crisis in care" lobby banner - hot on the heels of Monday's National Care Homes Association lobby of parliament over underfunding of care homes.

The lobby attracted care home owners from across the country including many from the south west, where one company, the Highcare Group, issued eviction orders to council-funded residents at its St Margaret's care home in Bridgewater, Somerset, before Christmas. Barry Giddings, chairman of the group, said the funding no longer covered the cost of care.

The Birmingham march will be held jointly with supporters from Residents Action Group for the Elderly (RAGE), which has served an injunction on Birmingham city council under the Human Rights Act in a bid to stop the transfer of 30 council care homes to a private trust.

Jean Cowley, chairwoman of the Birmingham care home association, said: "There's a lot more in common between the private and public sectors than separates us. Neither side wants to see homes closed.

"We will deliver a letter to social services to say we are challenging their accounts. We think the budget set is illegal because it fails to put sufficient money aside to meet the needs of the elderly."

A Birmingham city council spokesperson said: "The social services 2000/01 budget includes a 3% increase on fees for private care homes which has been approved by the advisory team. That is nearly 2% more than last year in recognition of the need to maintain an adequate supply of homes and standard of care in the city."

Sheffield's district auditor is already investigating a complaint from Sheffield residential and nursing homes association that extra funding for council-run homes contradicts best value and is forcing homes into bankruptcy, reducing people's right to choose.

A spokesman for the OFT confirmed that a complaint about differing funding levels had been received and said it was examinining it.

While most care home owners are drawing the line at evicting tenants, Sheffield's residential home owners have said they will not accept new council-funded residents after April 5 unless the council increases the proposed £235 per week to the £330 they say it pays for its own homes.

Association chairman David Coldrick said: "If the situation remains at stalemate with no activity from the council, then the council will be in clear breach of its legal obligations to ensure the needs of the elderly can be met."

Sheffield council's head of adult services, Eddie Sherwood, said it was still consulting with home owners to reach a mutually acceptable decision but the new fee structure will consider the varying levels of care required by residents.

"As with all reviews of this nature, the legal and financial implications of the proposals are being carefully examined," said Mr Sherwood.

Crisis in care campaign organiser Lesley Graves, a director of three south Yorkshire care homes, said many homes around the country are preparing to follow Sheffield's lead in boycotting new council-funded residents.

webTitle: British designer's coup rounds off Milan fashion week

fields.headline: British designer's coup rounds off Milan fashion week
fields.standfirst: Skinhead culture
fields.trailText: British fashion had one of its best moments of the season yesterday. The honour of closing Milan fashion week fell not to Donatella Versace, or Giorgio Armani, but to a young Briton, Luella Bartley, showing her Luella label in the city for the first time.
fields.body:
British fashion had one of its best moments of the season yesterday. The honour of closing Milan fashion week fell not to Donatella Versace, or Giorgio Armani, but to a young Briton, Luella Bartley, showing her Luella label in the city for the first time.

The coup came about thanks to her connections with Bottega Veneta, the latest luxury goods firm to make the crossover from sensible leather handbags to fashion's cutting edge.

As well as having a British designer, Giles Deacon, Bottega Veneta has the London stylist Katie Grand (a friend of Bartley) as creative consultant. The Italian company generously offered to host Bartley's show, the better to show off its new state of the art headquarters and catwalk theatre.

Bartley accepted and, in a last minute rejig, Italian fashion's governing Camera Nazionale awarded her the final slot on the schedule.

It may have been Milan, but this was a very London show. Bartley explained beforehand that the collection, Looking Hard in the Yard, was inspired by "that late 1960s, early 1970s, rude boy skinhead thing. All my references are London references, about English subcultures."

The look was uncompromising. In cherry red Doc Martens, fringes of their spiky hair falling over one eye, models stomped along to the sound of the Undertones' Teenage Kicks. These were girls' clothes for girls who are too hard for girls' clothes: black and white striped trousers cropped above the ankle and held up with braces; red and white striped shirts buttoned to the neck; a canary yellow teddy boy trousersuit with black satin lapels.

A miniskirt worn over thick footless tights was almost completely hidden beneath a grey and yellow striped mohair jacket, worn oversized and falling off the shoulders in tried and tested hanging-around-on-street-corners style.

The brilliance of both Luella and Bottega Veneta, who showed a first class collection the previous evening, is the ability to take the harshest, most obstinately unpretty, stubbornly London look and, with a lick of gloss and sex, make it instantly desirable.

fields.headline: The Rumour Mill
fields.standfirst: Today's rumours adress the Oxford Union about the importance of kids. Why, we don't know
fields.trailText: Newcastle could make a renewed bid to sign Brazilian striker Ronaldo on loan, claims Teamtalk. According to the website, Newcastle are usually quick to dismiss transfer speculation, but when asked about Ronaldo "a spokeswoman merely said United 'have no comment to make on the story.'" So it must be true then.
fields.body:
Newcastle could make a renewed bid to sign Brazilian striker Ronaldo on loan, claims Teamtalk. According to the website, Newcastle are usually quick to dismiss transfer speculation, but when asked about Ronaldo "a spokeswoman merely said United 'have no comment to make on the story.'" So it must be true then.

Chelsea are hoping to sign Hassan Kachloul on a free transfer in the summer, reports the Daily Star. However they face competition from Tottenham, Newcastle and Sunderland.

David Pleat has confirmed that Spurs have watched FC Twente striker Jan Vennegoor. "He is one of several players we have looked at up front," he told Planet Football. "He is a player we like and we have seen him two or three times. We are definitely looking to sign another striker in the summer."

Meanwhile the Daily Mail reckons that if Spurs fail in their efforts to sign Vennegoor they will move for Sparta Rotterdam striker Ali El Khattabi instead.

Sunderland are considering an end-of-season bid for Francis Jeffers, reports Teamtalk. However the website claims that Peter Reid will have to offer around £10m and "beat off stiff competition from Manchester United, Arsenal and Tottenham to get their man."

Peter Reid is also considering bids for Argentina-based players Nicholas Medina and Hugo Benjamin Ibarra, reports the Sun.

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 8
fields.trailText: March 8: KFC marketing director John Prior has quit after two years in the job.
fields.body:
KFC marketing director John Prior has quit abruptly after two years in the job.

Virgin Energy has shelved a £10m advertising campaign in favour of telesales and a door-to-door sales drive.

Lycos Europe has named Steffen Seifarth as its chief marketer.

Reuters has appointed brand consultancy Lambie Nairn and advertising agency BMP DDB to the £1m launch of its Kalends events database service.

Sunday Business has hired Paul Woolfenden as managing director.

Dubble, the ethical chocolate bar endorsed by Fair Trade, is to sponsor next week's celebrity Big Brother show.

Unilever's Van den Bergh Foods is to target commuters at busy rail stations as part of a marketing drive for its new ready meal product, Rocket.

Egg has hired Nick Cross from retailer Selfridges to be its new marketing director.

The BBC has hired Granada Sky Broadcasting's Christine Madden to be the new marketing head for BBC1.

WH Smith is reviewing its £7m below-the-line business.

fields.headline: Did  Shakespeare  even exist?
fields.standfirst: Marlowe was definitely a writer and a spy. His fans believe he also faked his death and wrote many of the plays now credited to the Bard of Avon. Sarah Ebner reports.
fields.trailText: Marlowe was definitely a writer and a spy. His fans believe he also faked his death and wrote many of the plays now credited to the Bard of Avon. Sarah Ebner reports.
fields.body:
This looks like being Christopher Marlowe's year. Films are being made about his life; books are being written; Joseph Fiennes is about to open in his play Edward II; and Jude Law wants to star as Dr Faustus. Meanwhile, conspiracy theories proliferate about the writer and spy.

Little is known for sure about Marlowe, and the more people think they know, the more they disagree. What is generally accepted is that he was born in 1564 - the same year as Shakespeare - and educated at Cambridge. He was only granted his degree after the government intervened (a sure sign that he was involved in official work) and wrote his plays, including The Tragical History of Dr Faustus, Tamburlaine the Great, and The Jew of Malta, in just six years.

And at the age of 29, before Shakespeare had produced any of his greatest works, such as Hamlet, King Lear or Macbeth, Marlowe was stabbed to death in a tavern brawl. Unless, that is, you believe that he faked his death and resurfaced as the Bard of Avon.

Marlowe was sceptical about religion ("I count religion but a childish toy") and unafraid to deal with homosexuality - either his own or others'. No wonder he's so appealing to the 21st-century mind. "He's a fascinating, complex character who led such a colourful life," says Robert Jones, who is working on a film based on Anthony Burgess's Dead Man in Deptford. "He's very attractive and really rather modern."

That view seems to have inspired Rupert Everett's performance in the film Shakespeare in Love. His Marlowe was not only handsome and suave, but far more exciting than Joseph Fiennes's Shakespeare.

"He had a very sharp mind," says Lisa Hopkins, author of Christopher Marlowe: A Literary Life. "He wasn't sentimental, like Shakespeare, or pious, and he kept you on your toes."

"He also has very much a young man's viewpoint," says David Grimm, an American writer whose play Kit Marlowe was performed at New York's recent Shakespeare festival. "Marlowe's attitude was, 'I can do whatever I want and never pay for it.' "

But while all these Marlowe projects may bring in younger fans, he has his share of older devotees. Many would rather concentrate on his talents than on his private life - such as the members of the Marlowe Society, dedicated to presenting the writer "in his true light as a great poet and dramatist". Burgess's book is described by one member as "vile" (too much sodomy), while another is un happy at Marlowe being described as a spy. "He was a patriot," says Peter Barker, the society's treasurer. "When people say 'spy', they tend to think of Burgess and Philby. Marlowe was an intelligence agent."

The society's 10 executive members are hoping to get Marlowe his due, with a campaign to commemorate him in Westminster Abbey's Poet's Corner. Colin Niven, headmaster of Alleyn's School (named after Marlowe's leading man and original Dr Faustus, Edward Alleyn) is leading the crusade. "It is absurd that there is no Christopher Marlowe in what is a shrine to the great poets of Britain," says Niven. Why does he think that is? "His private life," he says with certainty. "But that's an irrelevance. Poet's Corner is stuffed full of homosexuals."

The problem with any cam paign to raise Marlowe's profile is the so-called Marlovians. Not only do they believe the playwright was as great as Shakespeare; they insist he was Shakespeare, writing under a pseudonym after faking his death in 1593.

The Marlowe Society as a group no longer makes this claim for lack of historical evidence. But many of its members still hold fast to their beliefs, much to Niven's discomfort as he attempt to persuade "world-class intellects" to back his Poet's Corner campaign.

"With this campaign, we cannot make any claims for Marlowe being anyone other than Marlowe," he says. "We've got great intellects supporting this campaign, and they don't want to be associated with that. Whether or not he went on to write the works of Shakespeare, the known works of Marlowe are so great that it is absolutely extraordinary he isn't in Poet's Corner."

That's not to say the Marlovians' unspeakable idea is being ignored. The other film now in production is rumoured to suggest that Shakespeare stole Marlowe's works and passed them off as his own. Johnny Depp is reported to be playing Marlowe to Jude Law's Shakespeare, but Natural Nylon, the film company run by Law and Ewan McGregor, among others, is reluctant to give anything away.

The Marlowe Society is especially excited by a documentary from Emmy-winning Australian film-maker Mike Rubbo. He has just finishing making Much Ado About Something, which looks at the Marlowe-Shakespeare link. "It's a literary road movie," says Rubbo, "and Marlowe proves satisfying and adequate for the role of hidden genius." But the director had problems getting the film financed and found there was "general nervousness" about the project.

That nervousness leads Marlowe Society member Frieda Barker to imagine all kinds of plots to stop the truth coming out. "No academic would allow you to say that Marlowe was the true Shakespeare," she declares. "But the evidence is there. There are hundreds of parallels between Shakespeare's and Marlowe's plays, and nothing was ever published by Shakespeare until after Marlowe is said to have been killed. I believe they're the same person and I want to prove it."

Crime writer MJ Trow, author of the Inspector Lestrade novels, is the latest writer to be attracted by the circumstances of Marlowe's death. His new book, to be published in June, is Who Killed Kit Marlowe? A Contract To Murder in Elizabethan England. In it Trow writes of contract killers and cover-ups stretching right to the top of the Tudor hierarchy. It's certainly true that the man reported to have killed Marlowe was pardoned by the queen 28 days later.

But some feel that this obsession with conspiracies has detracted from Marlowe's talents. "He's a magnificent playwright," says Lisa Hopkins. "It's clear that Shakespeare read Marlowe and was influenced by him, for example with the Merchant of Venice. But even without that Marlowe's work stands on its own. It's just that he also had this wonderful, exciting life."

fields.headline: Marketing Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 8
fields.trailText: March 8: Travel agency Going Places has ousted marketing director David Chambers.
fields.body:
Going Places, the Airtours-owned travel agency, has ousted marketing director David Chambers as part of a major staff clear-out.

Unilever has named James Hill as the new chairman of its Birds Eye Wall's frozen foods division.

The Tobacco Manufacturers Association is considering legal action over a new European Union directive that bans terms such as "light" and "ultra" from being used in tobacco branding.

Pepsi has launched a celebrity-driven education initiative that allows pupils to write about their favourite pop bands at school.

Kelloggs is to launch its Pokemon-branded cereal in the UK later this month.

Microsoft has consolidated its entire $425m global advertising account into McCann-Erickson.

Express Newspapers is launching a new mailing campaign targeting a million homes across the UK. The mail-out will ask, "Why have a second-class mail when you can have the first-class Express?".

fields.headline: The Budget
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about Gordon Brown's plan for your finances on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Like Christmas, the Budget comes but once a year. The likelihood of receiving a gift is, however, considerably smaller.
fields.body:
1. Like Christmas, the Budget comes but once a year. The likelihood of receiving a gift is, however, considerably smaller.

2. Yes, it's that time again when the chancellor cuts or puts up taxes, announces new initiatives (such as saving plans) and, for the good of our health, ups the duty on cigarettes and alcohol.

3. The Budget is his big day of the year; to celebrate, incumbent Gordon Brown invites his Treasury team over to Downing Street for a Budget breakfast.

4. It's traditional for the chancellor to drink alcohol during his speech, but prudent Mr Brown prefers a Scottish mineral water.

5. And in another break with tradition, he retired the battered red Budget box first used by William Gladstone in the 1860s. (In the Major era, Norman Lamont hid whisky in it, while his junior carried the Budget under his arm.)

6. For radical behaviour, however, Mr Brown is unlikely to surpass David Lloyd George, whose 1909 People's Budget imposed a supertax to fund state pensions, which, when it proved unpopular, prompted him to reform the House of Lords.

7. The most disastrous, in 1931, saw chancellor Philip Snowden cut the dole, public pay and put up taxes - right at the height of the great depression

8. The result was riots in Glasgow and London, and mutiny at the Invergordon naval yard. So many foreign investors rushed to take their savings out of London, the national reserves were exhausted, and the chancellor was obliged to take sterling off the gold standard.

9. Coming a close second in recent years was Nigel Lawson's 1988 Budget which slashed the top tax rates and launched the economy into a rapid and unsustainable boom. The housing market plummeted, interest rates escalated, Britain was thrust into a recession and sterling crashed out of the ERM.

10. Budgets: sound like a load of ill-thought out amateurish nonsense? See if you can do better with our Budget game.

webTitle: In brief: Crew member killed on Spiderman set

fields.headline: Crew member killed on Spiderman set
fields.standfirst: Plus: Movie memorabilia goes under the hammer; ER doctor to co-star with Jennifer Lopez; all-star cast for arms dealer thriller; Tori Spelling signs up for Scary Movie 2
fields.trailText: Plus: Movie memorabilia goes under the hammer; ER doctor to co-star with Jennifer Lopez; all-star cast for arms dealer thriller; Tori Spelling signs up for Scary Movie 2
fields.body:
 Production on Sam Raimi's Spider-Man movie was hit by tragedy on Tuesday morning when a crew member was killed while building one of the film's sets. The accident occurred when a crane toppled to one side, crushing an as-yet-unnamed welder who was at work on a New York building façade at the film's location in Downey, California. "The studio and film-makers are deeply saddened and send condolences to all involved," the film's backers Sony said in a statement. "We are co-operating fully with the authorities investigating the incident." Spider-Man stars Tobey Maguire as the web-slinging crime-fighter, Willem Dafoe as his nemesis the Green Goblin and Kirsten Dunst as love interest Mary Jane.

 A broadsword used by Mel Gibson in Braveheart was the hottest property at a Unicef charity auction in New York yesterday. The sword went under the hammer for an impressive £90,000, with the money raised being sent to combat the spread of Aids in Africa. The sale of movie memorabilia was hosted by Liam Neeson, who saw the lightsabre he used in The Phantom Menace sell for £33,000. The other big winner was the Indiana Jones whip, which went for a whopping £50,000. At the lower end of the scale were a shirt worn by Ralph Fiennes in The English Patient (£1,300) and Catherine Zeta-Jones's dress from The Mask of Zorro (£1,000).

 Noah Wyle has signed to co-star opposite Jennifer Lopez in the Columbia thriller Enough, to be directed by Michael Apted. Written by Nicholas Kazan, the film will star Lopez as a woman on the run from her abusive husband (Billy Campbell). Wyle, still best known for his role in TV's ER, will play a mysterious mentor figure who pops up like a jack-in-the-box throughout the movie's twists and turns.

 Wesley Snipes, Linda Fiorentino and Oliver Platt have all been corralled into Liberty Stands Still, a thriller co-financed by Lion's Gate and the German company Cinerenta. Written and directed by Kari Skogland, it sounds a schematic little affair, with Snipes playing a vengeful dad on the trail of the arms dealer (Fiorentino) who sold the gun that killed his daughter.

 Tori Spelling, star of Beverly Hills 90210 and daughter of the show's creator Aaron Spelling, is to star in Scary Movie 2, Warner Brothers' follow-up to last year's phenomenally successful horror spoof. Spelling will join an original cast that includes Chris Elliott and brothers Shawn and Marlon Wayans. Older brother Keenan Ivory Wayans will again be in the director's chair for the film which is slated to begin shooting at the end of this month.

fields.headline: Woolfenden joins Sunday Business
fields.trailText:
10.30am: The ousted commercial director of Express Newspapers has resurfaced at Sunday Business, writes Claire Cozens.
Feb 19: Express circulation chief joins rival
Feb 14: Express puts Woolfenden on gardening leave
fields.body:
Paul Woolfenden, the ousted commercial director of Express Newspapers, has resurfaced as the managing director of Sunday Business.

Sunday Business publisher Andrew Neil has hired Mr Woolfenden in a bid to restore the paper's circulation, which dropped to just 55,603 last year according to ABC figures.

The target circulation is 75,000.

The appointment precedes a raft of measures aimed at boosting the title's appeal.

These include a new 64-page supplement called Business and Pleasure and a second section called Sunday Investor.

M&C Saatchi will create a £1.5m advertising campaign to promote the revamped Sunday Business.

The campaign will feature Christine Keeler, the woman implicated in the 1960s Profumo scandal, to illustrate the Business and Pleasure principle.

Mr Woolfenden, who joined the Express in 1998 as marketing director, has been on gardening leave since leaving the company last month.

Related stories

Feb 14: Express puts Woolfenden on gardening leave

webTitle: Whatever happened to Rodney, Monica and OJ?

fields.headline: Whatever happened to Rodney, Monica and OJ?
fields.standfirst: One tried to launch a rap career and the other two have documentaries made about their lives. Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles on their continuing notoriety
fields.trailText: One tried to launch a rap career and the other two have documentaries made about their lives. Duncan Campbell reports from Los Angeles on their continuing notoriety.
fields.body:
Two names from the past. Rodney King and Monica Lewinsky.

It is the tenth anniversary this month of the beating of Rodney King, who is black, by four white Los Angeles police officers. A bystander famously captured the incident on video tape, which led to the trial of the officers. Their acquittal more than a year later sparked the riots that engulfed Los Angeles and led to the deaths of 55 people. So what has happened to King in the past decade?

He was awarded $3.8 million in damages, but around half of that money was eaten up in disputes with various legal representatives. He tried to launch a music career via his own rap recording label but that plan was shortlived.

He has had various run-ins with the police, been convicted of drunken driving and pleaded guilty to spousal abuse, which means that he is currently on probation and will be for the next two years. He lives in Pasadena, works for his brother's construction company and spends time with his three daughters.

Daryl Gates, the police chief who departed in the wake of the debacle, is unrepentant. Asked recently about the current state of the LAPD, which is in the process of paying out an estimated $100 million to other victims of police malpractice arising from the recent Rampart division scandal, he replied: "Why would you reform the best police department in the world?"

And what of Monica Lewinsky now that Bill Clinton has departed from the White House? Would her moment have passed too?

This week it has been announced that she will participate in a documentary about her affair with the former president. The programme will be made for HBO who are also responsible for The Sopranos, the finest thing on American television, and will be shown next January.

She said that there were still things she wanted to say about the affair because "the last couple of years have been such a time of intense growth and perspective for me."

The people producing the programme are Randy Barbato and Fenton Bailey. They also made a HBO documentary: Juror No 5: 58 days of duty on the OJ Simpson civil trial.

OJ Simpson lost the civil case brought against him by the relatives of his ex-wife and her friend whom he was accused of murdering, but they have been unsuccessful in collecting the money they were awarded.

Simpson was acquitted on the criminal charges of murder and it was speculated at the time that the jury did so because they feared riots, if he was convicted, on the scale of those following the acquittal of the officers filmed beating Rodney King.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst: Our diarist leaves her land for the first time in 11 days. The farm next door still awaits test results
fields.trailText: Our diarist leaves her land for the first time in 11 days. The farm next door still awaits test results.
fields.body:
My daughter Victoria and I escaped out into the big wide world this morning, after 11 days cooped up on the farm, but now we're safely back behind our defences. We were off our land for just over three hours for a very quick brace repair at the dental hospital in Newcastle - in and out of the building in less than 20 minutes. Finding a parking space was our biggest headache, but we managed after four attempts.

Our tortuous route there and back, avoiding all the farms with confirmed foot and mouth cases, added almost five miles and 20 minutes each way to the journey. Our road out of the farm remains treacherous, despite the partial thaw, but it no longer sets the heart racing as you drive down it. Within three miles of here the snow was getting steadily thinner and nearer the city all that remained was a sprinkling of the white stuff. Along the way we saw a plethora of official yellow Northumberland county council path-closure signs, carefully put out by the farmers.

I guess it's to be expected, but the roads around here are eerily empty. The first 11 miles to Newcastle, we spotted no more than half a dozen vehicles. Then as soon as we hit the main roads and made our way into the city, the streets and pavements were alive with cars and people, and that seemed strange, too, after 11 days cooped up and isolated on the farm.

In the post today we had a letter from our bank offering support and financial advice to its agricultural clients and a brilliant newsletter from our vet packed with vital information. The four-page guide contained colour photographs of the symptoms of foot and mouth, and more strict guidelines on the never-ending disinfection procedures. It warned that we must not become complacent about our endless precautions, as they are our only protection against the disease.

Julie Sedgewick, another of our neighbours (and we have nine separate farmers with fences bordering our livestock), rang up. She is worried that the barriers will come down too soon and that people will be pushing to get things back to normal too quickly because they're sick of the inconvenience. Peter agrees, and he remains concerned that the collective caution will break down and the disease will creep across the countryside farm by farm.

At last, the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) website contains much more useful information - including the tracings, which show how the confirmed cases are linked.

But still our friends Stuart and Jane Murray are waiting to hear the results of their test sample taken on Tuesday February 27. They have spoken to Maff every day over the past four days, but still no news. Their six-year-old son, Thomas, is due back at the hospital tomorrow and Jane has had to apply for another licence to leave their farm for the day using a set route.
