We were off our land for just over three hours for a very quick brace repair at the dental hospital in Newcastle - in and out of the building in less than 20 minutes. Finding a parking space was our biggest headache, but we managed after four attempts. Our tortuous route there and back, avoiding all the farms with confirmed foot and mouth cases, added almost five miles and 20 minutes each way to the journey. Our road out of the farm remains treacherous, despite the partial thaw, but it no longer sets the heart racing as you drive down it. Within three miles of here the snow was getting steadily thinner and nearer the city all that remained was a sprinkling of the white stuff. Along the way we saw a plethora of official yellow Northumberland county council path-closure signs, carefully put out by the farmers. I guess it's to be expected, but the roads around here are eerily empty. The first 11 miles to Newcastle, we spotted no more than half a dozen vehicles. Then as soon as we hit the main roads and made our way into the city, the streets and pavements were alive with cars and people, and that seemed strange, too, after 11 days cooped up and isolated on the farm. In the post today we had a letter from our bank offering support and financial advice to its agricultural clients and a brilliant newsletter from our vet packed with vital information. The four-page guide contained colour photographs of the symptoms of foot and mouth, and more strict guidelines on the never-ending disinfection procedures. It warned that we must not become complacent about our endless precautions, as they are our only protection against the disease. Julie Sedgewick, another of our neighbours (and we have nine separate farmers with fences bordering our livestock), rang up. She is worried that the barriers will come down too soon and that people will be pushing to get things back to normal too quickly because they're sick of the inconvenience. Peter agrees, and he remains concerned that the collective caution will break down and the disease will creep across the countryside farm by farm. fields.headline: FCUKing genius
fields.standfirst: Creative guru Trevor Beattie has reached his astrological mid-life crisis: will he abandon the fluff of fashion for a grittier political agenda?
fields.trailText: March 7: Creative advertising guru Trevor Beattie has reached his astrological mid-life crisis, writes Maggie Hyde.
fields.body:
Trevor Beattie, creative director of advertising agency TBWA/London, is a canny political Capricorn (December 24 1958).

However, up until now, you might never have guessed it.

This advertising guru started collecting jingles when other lads were collecting stamps. He loves flogging things and he's also a big boxing fan.

Over the past few years, he has been ducking and weaving his way around a significant turning point - his astrological mid-life crisis.

Known as the Uranus Half Return, this happens to everyone between the ages of 38 and 42 as Uranus, planet of independence and revolution, reaches a half-way point in its movement around the horoscope.

It marks a now-or-never mood in a person's life, a feeling that if you don't start doing the things you were "meant" to do now, then you never will.

So what was Beattie put on this planet to do?

His achievements to date have reflected his talkative, Peter Pan Gemini Moon, perfect for art, media and communication:

"This specimen does not merely understand media. They are little radios that jabber, jabber, jabber all day long. They simply need to express themselves... Thy trash and thy trivia, it comforts them... And what an ear for accents, buzz-words, slang!" (Debbie Kempton-Smith).

This jabbering Moon opposes playful Mercury, the "messenger of the gods" and planet of commerce, in a line-up that "can sell anyone anything".

When we add inventive Uranus to this, we have a true symbol of an advertising genius.

All the astrology textbooks wax eloquent about the talents of this combination:

"These planets indicate original talent: they usually give a quick and capable mind, with a considerable degree of independence. The native is very clever in certain special directions... able to express himself well, and has a dramatic sense... He may coin striking phrases or, if a writer, he may invent characters that seize the popular imagination," (Charles Carter).

So the wordplay of Beattie's French Connection FCUK campaign was written in the stars, just like his "Hello boys" for Wonderbra.

It's a gift he can always draw on but, at this stage in his life, clever bits of advertising with a short shelf-life are not enough.

In the next few years, Pluto pulls him towards grittier, more socially responsible commitments.

Capricorn is a political sign and Beattie, a staunch socialist, has said handling the New Labour account in the run-up to the election is "the greatest moment of my career".

His horoscope has stunning connections with the Labour party (February 27 1900). His Capricorn Sun is joined to Labour's Saturn, giving him the chance to make his mark on posterity.

This year, he is still in a Uranus phase and, with his horoscope keyed in to Labour's own Uranus and its socially reformist agenda, he can push political advertising to new and provocative limits.

The New Labour brief is just the beginning. By summer 2002, Beattie could get the chance to create an impact in areas of greater global concern, perhaps with campaigns for poverty, civil liberties or the third world.

So it's bye-bye boys. Beattie is now about to punch his weight in the real world of political and social concern.

webTitle: Analysis: give the poor some capital

fields.headline: Saving grace
fields.standfirst: The proportion of households with no savings has doubled in 20 years. The answer is not Tory tax breaks, but to give the poor some capital
fields.trailText:
The proportion of households with no savings has doubled in 20 years. The answer is not Tory tax breaks, but to give the poor some capital.
Special report: Budget 2001
fields.body:
We will see later today whether savings have been on Chancellor Gordon Brown's mind. They have certainly been the subject of a lot of recent thinking on the right and the centre left of politics. Traditional arguments in favour of savings - economic health and enhanced individual independence - have been advanced from both Labour and the Tories. The Tories say they want to scrap tax on savings for everyone apart from top-rate taxpayers at a cost of £3bn. In his recent speech about second-term priorities, Tony Blair also made clear his desire to help "young people accumulate assets early in life that give them a financial base for the future".

But savings touch on the distribution of wealth - which is why the government's policy on savings should be different.

Tory proposals raised a cheer from those who are already wealthy but do not have to pay the top-rate of income tax (many affluent pensioners, for example).

Excluding the very richest people from tax exemption bypasses the embarrassing problem of the Duke of Westminster receiving a windfall while average households count any gains they may receive in pennies. But most families on average income or below stand to gain little, if anything, from the Tories' exemption of savings from tax. To gain £60 a year, individuals would need to have £5,000 of savings. Those with the least will gain least.

Though Labour has yet to come forward with detailed proposals on savings, government thinking can be pieced together from recent statements. Last year, as part of the pre-Budget report, the Treasury expressed its interest in helping low-to-middle income groups increase their savings. Reference was made to schemes in America where the government matches savings made by low-income individuals on a two-for-one basis.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, has spoken passionately about the left's ideological mental block over the distribution of capital (as opposed to income) and asked how the government can help low-income parents save and invest in themselves and their children. Perhaps some clear red water may be opening up between Labour and the Tories on savings policy and on the role of the government in influencing the distribution of wealth.

Underlying trends in the distribution of financial assets should make any self-respecting social democrat shudder. As the chart shows, the proportion of households without any assets whatsoever doubled between 1979-1996. Some 50% of adults have less than £500 of disposable financial wealth and between 47% and 64% of families earning under £20,000 per annum have no savings at all.

But Labour's renewal of interest in this area is also likely to be driven by the desire to promote social mobility. Ownership of assets can have a powerful effect on key social outcomes such as labour market performance, health and entrepreneurship. Moreover, policies aimed at those with low levels of savings appear to work. The experience of individual development accounts (IDAs) in over 30 states in the US shows those on low and moderate incomes are keen to save if they get the right incentives, information and support. Generous matching payments rather than tax reliefs are a key feature of successful policy.

The approach by Labour and the Tories so far has been to encourage saving by means of tax exemption on the interest earned from savings schemes. All the evidence we have from Peps, Tessas and Isas is that tax relief only leads those who already have wealth to seek to reshuffle it. Tax relief does next to nothing for those with few or no financial assets. The next politician who declares that they want to encourage "savings for all" needs to be reminded of this.

Recently, the Institute for Public Policy Research has set out a different approach. Our idea is a new deal for savers which breaks out of this conservative consensus on tax reliefs. The focus of our proposals would be a savings account based on a small cash endowment paid to every newborn child. This "baby bond" would be invested, and on becoming an adult, the young person would access the bond to fund education, homeownership and entrepreneurship. Parents, relatives and friends would be encouraged to make contributions into the account, with children from low- and moderate- income families benefiting from matching government contributions.

Another policy option would be to boost the levels of financial security of low-to-moderate income adults by American-style development accounts which could be run by community and voluntary groups in areas where access to banks and building societies is difficult for people, or where there are high levels of illiteracy. Either of these could be introduced for a third of the cost of the Tory party's tax exemption proposals.

Underpinning these ideas is the conviction that there is nothing God-given about the distribution of asset ownership in the UK. The inequality we now see resulted in no small part from policies which systematically benefited affluent households. The Tories have now thrown down the gauntlet on savings policy with a proposal which is likely to accentuate these problems. Labour needs to respond. A new deal for savers is needed which should offer something to everyone but give most benefit to those in low- and middle-income households. A radical second-term agenda demands nothing less.

Sue Regan is at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

fields.headline: Henry keeps Arsenal afloat
fields.standfirst:
Henry 82
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Thierry Henry gave Arsenal a much-needed victory and at least kept their quarter-final fate in their own hands after Lyon failed to make life easy in Group C with a resounding victory over Bayern Munich.
fields.body:
The goal was late, the performance unimpressive but few here minded about that. In heading home Ashley Cole's corner eight minutes from time last night, Thierry Henry gave Arsenal a much-needed victory and kept their fate in their own hands.

Reaching the quarter-finals will not be easy. Assuming Lyon beat the already eliminated Spartak next Wednesday, Arsenal will have to win at Bayern Munich, whose defeat at Lyon last night means the German club are not guaranteed a place in the last eight.

Arsenal supporters could have been forgiven for feeling a little pessimistic. In Moscow in November their side had been hammered 4-1 by Spartak, and the team from Russia had won 5-2 here on their only other visit in 1982. A win was clearly paramount for Arsenal and inside 10 minutes Gilles Grimandi and the impressive Patrick Vieira had headed wide from set pieces as Spartak looked shaky in defending crosses.

Yet for all their possession and almost total early dominance, Arsenal's final ball from open play was too often unforthcoming. When Cole was sent clear on the left by Vieira, his cross was well beyond the reach of Henry, whose pace was clearly worrying Spartak's back line.

To the surprise of many, Henry was partnered up front by Dennis Bergkamp, with Sylvain Wiltord, the scorer of a hat-trick against West Ham on Saturday, left on the bench. The Frenchman may have felt he would have done better with the chance Henry wasted in the 20th minute. From a Robert Pires cross, he kicked fresh air from a few yards out.

Although Spartak looked to be ripe for the picking, being exposed down the flanks time and again by Arsenal's speed, there was an understandable frustration among the crowd as Arsène Wenger's players failed to take advantage, particularly as news filtered through that Lyon had taken a 2-0 lead inside 20 minutes with goals from Sidney Govou at home to Bayern. Pierre Laigle made certain for Lyon in the 71st minute to leave qualification hanging on next week's final group games. If Arsenal and Lyon do finish level on points, Arsenal will go through having beaten and drawn with the French club.

All Spartak offered in the way of a worthwhile shot in the first half was a long-range effort by the skilful Egor Titov, which David Seaman saved with the minimum of fuss, although on the odd occasion they made Arsenal look edgy in defence. They, too, had sprung a surprise in attack, leaving out the Brazilian Marcao, the scorer of two goals against Arsenal in November.

Of more concern to Wenger was the fact that Spartak's goalkeeper Alexander Filimonov was not being overworked either. Vieira did have a side-foot volley cleared off the line and then headed wide, both efforts from corners, but Arsenal produced precious few strikes on target.

Bergkamp sent a shot too high as half-time approached, with Arsenal looking increasingly short of ideas on how to break down a Spartak side who pulled men behind the ball and began to settle.

Wenger resisted the temptation to make changes at half-time but must have made it clear that he expected better. Fredrik Ljungberg's early claim for a penalty when he went down in a challenge with Jerry-Christian Tchuisse was optimistic, perhaps a sign of Arsenal's uncertainty as to how they would make the breakthrough.

With Spartak still looking uncomfortable on set plays, Arsenal frequently threatened whenever Bergkamp, Pires or Cole sent over free-kicks or corners. But a flick by Henry and a header by Tony Adams, saved by Filimonov, was as close as they came.

The sight of Wiltord and Nwanwko Kanu warming up on the touchline was hardly a surprise with Arsenal's final ball continuing to disappoint. Too many crosses or passes missed their target, and all the while Arsenal had to beware the danger of Spartak hitting them on the counter-attack.

The nerves which seemed to be afflicting Arsenal were all too apparent when Henry was given a rare sight of goal just past the hour. Ljungberg's mishit shot left the Frenchman with a chance he should have taken but he poked his shot wide.

Introducting Nwankwo Kanu for Bergkamp and Wiltord for Pires not long after was greeted with boos as Wenger desperately sought a winner.

Arsenal (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Grimandi, Adams, Cole; Pires (Wiltord, 72min), Lauren, Vieira, Ljungberg; Henry (Vivas, 90), Bergkamp (Kanu, 72).

Spartak Moscow (1-3-3-1-2): Filimonov; Mitreski; Tchuisse, Parfenov, Kovtun; Baranov, Bulatov, Kalynychenko; Titov (Pisarev, 54); Irismetov, Robson.

Referee: R Pedersen (Norway).

fields.headline: He may have stumbled but he's saved the best till last
fields.standfirst:
The Budget will confirm that the chancellor is in full control

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: This will be an abnormal Budget speech from an abnormal chancellor. Normally Labour goes into an election having cocked up the economy, forcing the chancellor to deliver his final Budget against a backdrop of crisis, followed by drastic belt-tightening.
fields.body:
This will be an abnormal Budget speech from an abnormal chancellor. Normally Labour goes into an election having cocked up the economy, forcing the chancellor to deliver his final Budget against a backdrop of crisis, followed by drastic belt-tightening. Normally he has spent all the public's money in the first, flush years in office and is now scrambling to repair his mistake. Normally, he would have begun as Santa - and would now have to play Scrooge.

But this is no normal Labour chancellor. Gordon Brown will announce neither spending cuts nor tax rises when he rises to deliver his fifth budget this afternoon. Instead he will break the Labour pattern by offering a blend of the exact opposite: yet another payola for the public services and a modest - "responsible," he'll call it - tax cut for everyone else.

He can do this because he has not been normal. Far from aping his Labour ancestors, who watched the economy spiral toward disaster, he has burnished a record superior to almost any of his predecessors, of either party. Even the International Monetary Fund has applauded his stewardship of an economy enjoying its longest stretch of growth without inflation for 30 years. He has pulled off the political equivalent of the double: record low inflation and low unemployment - and all just in time for polling day. With this year's surplus estimated at around £16bn, Brown has at least £3-4bn to play with this afternoon. Unlike his forebears, he wore the corset of restraint for his first two years, leaving him free to loosen a few buttons now. He began as Scrooge - so now he can play Santa.

But it is not just today's Budget which breaks the conventional pattern. So does Gordon Brown himself. For while most politicians normally focus on the day-to-day, the quick fix designed to get them through tomorrow's headlines and next week's opinion polls, Brown has done the very opposite. He is that rarest of political creatures: a long-termist. And sometimes it costs him dear.

Listen as he makes his case and you soon notice the difference. His goals are ambitious and stretch into the middle and further distance. He aims to halve child poverty in Britain by 2010. He wants to make Britain a land of full employment (we're already at 75%). He wishes to turn around five decades in which Britain was "under-invested in" and instead spend the money to secure decent, efficient public services. He wishes to do more than change the economic numbers: he wants to effect a cultural shift, by "rehabilitating tax-and-spend" in the public mind, restoring Britons' trust in government's ability to spend citizens' money wisely and in the common interest.

He wants to make life easier for the nation's poorest and to restore the centrality, even dignity, of work. His ambitions are so large, his energy so restless, that he even has global dreams. He aims to follow his campaign for the richest nations to cancel third world debt with new, international initiatives on child literacy and cheap medicines for the sick.

But all this focus on the big picture has come at a price. For Gordon Brown is sometimes so transfixed by the horizon, he misses the iceberg looming before him.

The most obvious example is also Brown's most blatant error. So clear was he on his long-term plan for pensioners - involving a complex set of credits and benefits aimed at the worst-off - that last year he allowed himself to offer the elderly a measly 75p increase. Never mind his (true) claim that he has spent more on pensions than if he had simply restored the link to earnings, as Barbara Castle and her grey panthers were demanding. Never mind that 75p was the figure the Treasury statisticians and their computerised formula spat out. A regular, normal politician would have taken one look at that 75p and told the statisticians to invent another formula - one that produced an increase over the psychologically crucial £1 mark.

But Brown didn't notice the pensioners until it was too late. He had the same trouble with last September's fuel protests: the warning signs were there, but the chancellor either did not see or did not heed them. In the end, as with the pension increase, he had to act anyway - but only after he and the government were seen to have suffered a defeat.

It is an irony that this master strategist - now commanding an election campaign which, he predicts, the right will fight more as a referendum on the government than a two-party choice between Labour and the Tories - sometimes forgets the basics. He sees the wood all right; it's just the twigs that trip him up.

Often it's a simple matter of communication. Labour is still feeling the pain of its two-year spending freeze, for example, not least in the lethargy of core supporters who struggled to see the difference between New Labour and the Tories who'd set the spending limits in the first place. Brown himself saw the larger picture, reckoning the two-year starvation diet would give Labour the credibility it needed with the markets and swing voters to spend more public cash later. Brown was probably right - but he never properly explained that vision to the Labour faithful, the people whose enthusiasm this spring could be so decisive.

The same can be said of Brown's battery of credits and measures designed to redistribute wealth to the poorest quarter of Britain's people. It has been one of the hallmarks of Brown's chancellorship and it is to be admired. But because it was redistribution by stealth - whispered, lest the horses of Middle England stir - he has got all too little credit for it.

Even now on the partial privatisation of the London Underground, Brown has a good, if complex, case. The trouble is, he is so convinced of his own rightness he has barely roused himself to make the argument in public. In the stand-off between himself and the London mayor, he has left Ken Livingstone a clear run at winning the capital's hearts and minds, if only by default. The chancellor seems to believe that, so long as it all makes sense on Planet Brown, the rest of us will eventually cotton on. He forgets that to lead is also to explain.

None of this is to suggest Gordon Brown is insufficiently political: only a fool could think that. He remains compulsively, viscerally political. Even his long-term, strategic management of the economy is pursued, in part, to ensure that, should he one day swap Number 11 for the house next door, he will inherit an economy as healthy as the one he can brag about today.

And, make no mistake, he remains ceaseless in pursuit of that goal, still feverishly cultivating the Labour tribe - from the one-on-one meetings with backbench MPs to his ultra-charming, networking appearances at trade union receptions. He knows who has the power to elect Tony Blair's successor and he never forgets them.

No, Gordon Brown is no slouch when it comes to politicking: that's why he wants a May 3 poll, to allow time for some of his previous Budget goodies to kick in during April. But with his eye so firmly on the future, he can miss the odd trick in the present. Still, don't hold your breath for a stumble this afternoon: he's a smart enough politician to have saved his best Budget for last.

webTitle: A plan to rebuild British farming

fields.headline: Down on the farm
fields.standfirst:
The Labour business leader presents a plan to rebuild the blighted British farming industry

Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: The Labour business leader presents a plan to rebuild the blighted British farming industry.
fields.body:
In the light of the disasters which have struck British farming in recent years, there is clearly a need for a radical review of agricultural markets and practices and the state's role as regulator and subsidiser. But the growing demand for a return to a pre-intensive, small farms environment would be both highly undesirable and impractical in terms of public safety, animal welfare and consumer value.

When I joined the dairy industry 40 years ago, my father, a farmer in County Wicklow, paid his milkman £500 a year. Today on that same farm my son pays his milkman more than £20,000 a year. My father was pleased if he achieved a yield from a cow of 400 gallons. My son gets a yield of 1,500 gallons. My father could only feed 40 cows, my son feeds 150. My father was delighted to achieve a yield of a ton an acre for his wheat. Today we are disappointed if we do not get three-and-a-half tons. Northern Dairies operated separate dairies to supply a population of 20,000 people. Express Dairies today has factories which supply a million people with milk.

Forty years ago, people, mainly women, had to shop several times a week, visiting several different shops, because food did not keep very long and most food shops were specialist. Today, busy families with both partners working can do their food shopping in one place once a week. Complaints about supermarkets may have some basis, but the vast majority of the British public would be up in arms if the convenience, variety and value offered by supermarkets was denied to them.

If this remarkable increase in productivity had not taken place, and consumers had to pay for the inflation of the past 40 years, the price of wheat would be more than £1,000 a ton instead of £70, and the farmer would be receiving more than £2 per litre for milk compared with the admittedly untenable existing price of about 18p. Consumers would be paying more than £2 for a loaf of bread, against less than 50p today, and a pint of milk would cost about £2 compared with less than 35p in a supermarket now.

Years ago, tuberculosis, mastitis and chronic lameness were rampant in dairy herds, the majority of pigs were fed swill, practically all livestock were sold through markets, chicken meat - which is generally recognised to be an essential part of a healthy diet - was far too expensive for the majority of the population and it was assumed that every raw chicken was a carrier of salmonella. My father's cowshed was a threat to the dairyman, the cow, and those who drank the milk and would be shut down today.

Today, while still a scourge, tuberculosis, mastitis and lameness are relatively rare and controllable diseases in cows. Only 100 of our 12,000 pig producers are licensed to give swill to their pigs (and that is 100 too many, because of the potential risk of introducing infections such as foot and mouth and swine fever). Traditional livestock markets have dwindled in size, as farmers have elected to sell their stock direct to abattoirs rather than through middlemen. There are still far too many unnecessary sheep transactions through markets, because they have been the catalyst for spreading foot and mouth across the country in the past two weeks.

While the creation of motorways has resulted in livestock, as well as humans, moving much greater distances, people were walking pigs to London from the south-west in the 19th century, boatloads of store cattle came in from Ireland in the 50s to be transported across England, and the Wall's bacon factory in west London bought live pigs from all over the country. Although people are understandably anxious about the intensive production methods of the poultry industry, almost everyone in this country now eats chicken, and the levels of salmonella, though still unacceptably high, are far less than they were a generation ago.

If we wanted to recreate the country side of 40 years ago, either the consumer or the taxpayer would have to pay at least twice as much (an extra £50bn) for food.

If food prices in real terms matched those of 40 years ago, rickets would remain a widespread problem because poor people could not afford enough milk, and tuberculosis and foot and mouth would be an endemic scourge. The standards of food safety which had to be acceptable in those days would result in practically every farm and food factory being shut down today.

A generation ago, Britain imported more than two-thirds of its food, whereas today that figure is less than a third, thereby contributing to a reduced trade deficit and a stronger, more stable currency. Furthermore, if we wanted to transform our food market to either a highly priced or massively subsidised one, we would have to withdraw from the European Union unless we could persuade all our partners to follow suit. And, in the unlikely event that Europe followed our somewhat eccentric route, we would have to reverse all our commitments to global free trade and reintroduce protectionist barriers against food imports from North America - which would in turn use barriers against our manufacturing exports.

But while acknowledging that the structural, technological and scientific revolution of agriculture in Britain and the rest of the world has contributed significantly to our health and prosperity, especially that of the poor, the young and the old, it is also necessary to recognise the many shortcomings and potential dangers arising out of modern farming and food processing methods.

Twenty years ago, arable farmers recklessly applied fertilisers and pesticides to their crops, and antibiotics to their animals. Although levels have reduced significantly, much more can be done to make their application compati ble with a sustainable environment without impairing economic viability and to reduce the use of animal medicines by paying more attention to the prevention of disease.

Pigswill should be banned, and all livestock should move direct from farm to slaughterhouse without passing through disease-spreading markets. The markets will still play a role in moving cattle from breeding farms to fattening farms, but there is no need for animals to go through several transactions before reaching their final destination. The live export of livestock for slaughter on the continent is unnecessary, adds extra cost and disease-carrying risk, as well as causing too much stress to the animals. Over-intensive methods in pig, and especially poultry production, need to be reviewed, but only by agreement with our European Union partners and North America.

One possible benefit arising out of the disaster of BSE is that we can at last reform the common agricultural policy (CAP) which is to blame for many disturbing and unsatisfactory practices. Subsidies encourage over-intensive methods, enabling farmers to plough up pastures for cereal production which are much more suitable for environmentally-friendly grass. The subsidy system is easily corrupted by middlemen. Its cost, while being minuscule compared with the proposal to create the countryside of the past, is still much too high.

The CAP should be renamed the common environmental policy and redesigned, so that farmers have to earn a right to public support rather than being automatically entitled to it. They would be rewarded according to the environmental and husbandry standards they achieved by a system of farm accreditation which might, for example, have prevented the practices which probably initiated the current foot and mouth outbreak.

It could be adopted to incentivise the less environmentally-conscious small farmers of new European Union members, such as Poland. It could be made flexible to meet the varying environmental needs of regions and countries. It would be consistent with free, fair global trade. And it would probably cost less.

Farmers must also change their attitudes - from a culture of dependency to one of enterprise. Many have already developed non-farming enterprises and alternative work opportunities to supplement their income. Much more can be done. Farmers must be more sensitive to the views of others in society, but the latter must not be unreasonably obstructive about plans to increase business activity in the countryside.

As long as the supply of food exceeds demand in the market, there will be downward pressure on prices from consumers and, therefore, from retailers. In other countries, even the US, farmers have created cooperatives to strengthen their buying and selling power. Such co-operation, though growing slowly in Britain, is very underdeveloped. Powerful competition laws already control retailer behaviour, but there is a strong case for codes of best practice between suppliers and retailers which would reinforce the obligation of retailers to be fair in their dealings with their suppliers.

And finally, while there have been serious failures in scientific innovation - most notably in the feeding of animal protein to cows - the benefits of such innovation far exceed the harm. We must find better ways of monitoring scientific innovation, including genetic modification. If we deny the science we put at risk the lives of 3bn additional global citizens anticipated in 30 years' time. They will go hungry if scientists fail to find ways of increasing global production of safe food by 50%. This is not just a middle-class British issue, it is one which affects the billions of poor people in the world.

Christopher Haskins is chairman of Northern Foods plc

fields.headline: Watchdog bans TV advert for offending Hindus
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A TV advert for a chicken sauce has been banned because it offended British Hindus, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A TV advert for a chicken sauce has been banned because it offended British Hindus.

Watchdogs have warned advertisers to be more sensitive over religious faiths after a series of complaints about the commercial for Chicken Tonight.

The Independent Television Commission ruling comes just months after the manufacturers of the alcoholic drink Reef were censured for portraying the haka, a Maori tribal dance, in an advert for the product.

The Chicken Tonight advert shows a woman meditating in front of a chicken.

The ITC said the combination of her Hindi-style chanting and the fact that the advert was for a meat-related product had offended the largely vegetarian Hindu population.

The watchdog received 16 complaints about the commercial, in which the woman chants to a ready-to-eat chicken before telling the bird, "You can't just sit there with your legs crossed, you're going to have to chant as well."

Chicken Tonight manufacturer Unilever yesterday apologised for the advert and said it had not meant to cause offence.

"Both the haka and the meditation adverts were a case of people complaining of personal offence to their culture or religion," said an ITC spokeswoman.

"In both cases - where the haka was linked to alcohol and the sauce to meat-eating - they were particularly offensive.

"Our guidelines are very clear on the need to avoid treatments that use stereotyped images or denigrate religion."

But the ITC rejected 60 complaints about an advert for Kronenberg 1664 in which a succession of men fall victim to gory accidents because they are distracted by a woman's pint.

The watchdog ruled that as the advert did not cause widespread offence or insult a particular group, it could continue to be shown.
fields.bodyText: A TV advert for a chicken sauce has been banned because it offended British Hindus. Watchdogs have warned advertisers to be more sensitive over religious faiths after a series of complaints about the commercial for Chicken Tonight. The Independent Television Commission ruling comes just months after the manufacturers of the alcoholic drink Reef were censured for portraying the haka, a Maori tribal dance, in an advert for the product. The Chicken Tonight advert shows a woman meditating in front of a chicken. The ITC said the combination of her Hindi-style chanting and the fact that the advert was for a meat-related product had offended the largely vegetarian Hindu population. The watchdog received 16 complaints about the commercial, in which the woman chants to a ready-to-eat chicken before telling the bird, "You can't just sit there with your legs crossed, you're going to have to chant as well." Chicken Tonight manufacturer Unilever yesterday apologised for the advert and said it had not meant to cause offence. "Both the haka and the meditation adverts were a case of people complaining of personal offence to their culture or religion," said an ITC spokeswoman. "In both cases - where the haka was linked to alcohol and the sauce to meat-eating - they were particularly offensive. "Our guidelines are very clear on the need to avoid treatments that use stereotyped images or denigrate religion." But the ITC rejected 60 complaints about an advert for Kronenberg 1664 in which a succession of men fall victim to gory accidents because they are distracted by a woman's pint. The watchdog ruled that as the advert did not cause widespread offence or insult a particular group, it could continue to be shown.

fields.headline: Hopes mount for Panorama move
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Hopes are mounting at Panorama that the BBC flagship show will be moved from its Sunday night slot, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Hopes are mounting among Panorama staff that the BBC flagship news and current affairs show will be moved from its graveyard Sunday night slot.

And speculation abounds that a weekday slot on BBC2 could be the answer to one of the BBC's trickiest scheduling problems.

High-level discussions are thought to be going on between BBC director general Greg Dyke, head of news Richard Sambrook and director of television Mark Thompson.

But nothing has been decided and there are fears that a midweek slot on BBC1 could still be a disaster in the ratings.

A weekday slot on BBC2 has been mooted before by the BBC when it planned to move Panorama out of its former slot on Monday night.

Sources say it would be difficult to see how Panorama could survive in a weekday primetime slot on BBC1 if the programme length stays at 40 minutes.

Options considered before the show was moved to Sunday night were Monday at 7.30pm or Wednesday at 9.30pm. The former was ruled out because it would pit the programme against Coronation Street on ITV.

It was felt it could do well in the ratings and provide an alternative but the slot was too difficult to sustain.

The Wednesday slot was also deemed tough. News chiefs considered shortening the programme but ultimately decided it may lose some of its impact if it was cut back to 29 minutes.

"Dyke and Thompson have been considering a move but how serious it is I don't know," said one insider.

"Richard Sambrook has signalled very clearly that he wants to give current affairs a higher priority, and Mark Thompson also believes that the Sunday night 10pm slot does not do justice to Panorama."

"Sunday may just have been a transition. If it moved to a weekday slot, possibly even to BBC2, it would increase its audience and get more share.

Sunday night is just a killer slot. No matter how good the stories are it doesn't have the impact on the audience," the source added.

"BBC1 is so tough now. You have to fight like a dog to hold onto share, the answer may well be BBC2."

The debate about the flagship current affairs programme was revived last week after the programme won the Royal Television Society's prestigious journalist of the year award for presenter John Ware.

Mr Ware, who secured the award for his investigation of the bombing of Omagh, has called again for the BBC to put the programme into a more prominent slot.

"I and all my colleagues hope that eventually the BBC will reinstate this programme in a weekday slot, where most of us think it should be," he told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

Panorama was shifted to Sunday night last year as part of the shake-up to BBC1's schedules which centred on the Nine O'Clock News being switched by 10pm.

A BBC spokesman denied anything was in the pipeline and said that Panorama would come back in the autumn in its usual Sunday night slot.

Related story

webTitle: Tories reject 'myth' of cradle to grave welfare

fields.headline: Tories reject 'myth' of cradle to grave welfare
fields.trailText: The Conservatives yesterday underlined their belief that the cradle to grave welfare system is gone for ever with proposals to encourage people to make their own provision for care in old age.
fields.body:
The Conservatives yesterday underlined their belief that the cradle to grave welfare system is gone for ever with proposals to encourage people to make their own provision for care in old age.

The shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said that those who took out insurance for long term care costs would have "some of their assets" protected rather than being taken by the state to cover expenses. Families who took responsibility for care of elderly relatives would be rewarded with tax breaks, Dr Fox told the right-leaning Politeia think tank.

The proposals, condemned by Labour as covert privatisation of health and social care, underline Tory determination to use the tax system to shift responsibilities from the state to individuals.

Dr Fox said that 160,000 elderly people had been forced to sell their homes under the four years of Labour government to finance long term care under a policy that penalised thrift. "They believed the myth of cradle to grave welfare," he said. "People working today need to be encouraged to make more financial preparations for their later years in order not to repeat the experience of many current pensioners and put all their eggs in the state's basket."

Those who insured themselves would be expected to meet bills of up to around £20,000, but would then have all costs picked up by the state, leaving assets to be handed on to relatives, Tory sources said last night.

The Conservatives are attempting to exploit controversy over government plans on long term care, which will see a new division between nursing and personal care. Under the reforms, nursing care for the elderly will for the first time be free in care homes - a policy the Tories intend to maintain - but residents in England and Wales will continue to have to pay their own personal care costs, such as bathing, dressing and feeding.

In Scotland, where the Liberal Democrats share power with Labour, both personal and nursing care costs will be free, in line with national Lib Dem policy and with the recommendations of the government's own royal commission on long term care.

Campaigners for the elderly, who have condemned the government's decision not to make personal care free, last night questioned the Tory scheme. Tessa Harding, head of policy at Age Concern, said care insurance was "not viable for most people because of the cost and the difficulty of finding a policy to cover an unknown future".

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Stepping up the beat

fields.headline: Stepping up the beat
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Police management is in a "bog standard" state. They arrive with the wrong skills: good at operational organisation (dawn raids, royal visits), but with few managerial skills on how to handle people or other agencies
fields.body:
The problem with the police is that they are "bogged down in a legacy of outdated rules, regulations and redundant practices". No, this was not a Downing Street briefing on the prime minister's thoughts - though he endorses this view, as did his two predecessors. The quote is from Sir John Stevens, Metropolitan police commissioner, calling for a radical shake-up of recruitment.

Fast-track entry into the police has been endlessly debated, but a more interesting idea is now being debated by policy-makers fitting together a 10-year crime plan: new incentives to keep the best beat officers on the beat. This is a familiar issue in health, education and social work - which have introduced incentives to keep nurses, teachers and social workers at the "coalface" rather than forcing climbs up management ladders to better pay - but still untried in the police.

There are reams of documents on the importance of neighbourhood policing, under a host of different names: patch, community, neighbourhood and sector. They emphasise the advantages which policing achieves when close relationships are established with communities. It is not a new concept. It dates back to Napoleonic times, when the French police paid local concierges to help improve their community contacts. The Chinese courtyard and Japanese koban systems developed it further, but little attention has been paid to what has been happening in Europe.

It began in Berlin in 1982 and quickly spread to Holland: the idea of not just giving more money to good beat officers to keep them in their locality, but also more influence. Other police operations - dawn raids, drug busts - require full consultation and sometimes consent of beat officers too.

The idea was floated by the Sheehy police review in 1993 but was thrown out with its other more controversial proposals. It won't be easy to achieve. The best beat officers are socially adept, making them obvious promotion material. Moreover, police management is in a "bog standard" state. They arrive with the wrong skills: good at operational organisation (dawn raids, royal visits), but with few managerial skills on how to handle people or other agencies. These can't be picked up by osmosis. Some are counter-intuitive and have to be taught.

This is where the new ideas fit together. Let's have Berlin bobbies, but genuine fast-tracking too. The current accelerated graduate scheme takes too long. Let's also try some direct entry middle management - but not, please, from the army. It was tried and failed. The police are not a militia. The nature of the job demands huge discretion devolved to the beat.

webTitle: Government's plan to introduce private security wardens

fields.headline: Byway patrol
fields.standfirst: Fear of crime is often as big a problem as crime itself. And while the call for more bobbies on the beat is constant, some areas have jumped the gun on the government's plan to introduce private security wardens.  Alison Benjamin reports
fields.trailText: Fear of crime is often as big a problem as crime itself. And while the call for more bobbies on the beat is constant, some areas have jumped the gun on the government's plan to introduce private security wardens. Alison Benjamin reports
fields.body:
Uniformed men in stab-proof vests patrol the mean streets . . . sounds almost like a scene from an American TV cop show. But this isn't Dallas or Detroit - it's Darlington. And these aren't cops - they are the new breed of "warden" law enforcers who could soon become a familiar sight in other British cities and towns.

Last week's announcement by home secretary Jack Straw that police-accredited private security patrols are to be introduced outside schools, commuter stations and other busy public places sparked controversy. But, in effect, many neighbourhood wardens already carry out the patrol duties set out in the government's 10-year crime plan.

The aim of the wardens, employed in most cases by local authorities or social landlords, is to prevent crime - and, more importantly, reduce the fear of crime - by providing a uniformed presence in crime hotspots, town centres and council estates. In Darlington, County Durham, wardens patrol alongside a beat officer and can impose on-the-spot fines of up to £100 on people caught dropping litter or allowing their dogs to foul the pavement. But, like all wardens, they have no powers of arrest.

"If they see a fight on a Saturday night, they will shepherd people out of danger's way while their police colleague will deal with the affray," says Andy Errington, head of the local council's youth offending and community safety service.

Since Darlington's three wardens sprung into action a year ago, they have become far and away the authority's most popular service, receiving an 85% approval rating from the public as well as contributing to a 40% reduction in crime in one area. Now the council is looking to recruit a further seven wardens with a £120,750 grant from the government's neighbourhood warden scheme.

The £13.5m scheme - introduced last year and jointly funded by the Home Office and the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions - allocated £7.5m to 50 schemes last September and a further £4.8m to 36 schemes last month, bringing the total number of wardens recruited under the initiative in England and Wales to 445. The Darlington patrols represent the "hard" enforcement end of the neighbourhood warden model.

Other types include super-caretakers, pioneered by the Peabody Trust housing group, whereby wardens combine odd jobs with patrolling; property-led schemes, like the 24-hour patrols in Swansea which have reduced vandalism of empty council homes and prevented heating systems being stolen; and community-based initiatives along the lines of Safer Merthyr Tydfil (SMT), a charity. What they all share is wardens who are paid employees, not vigilante volunteers.

"Our wardens are chosen for their life skills, not for a gung ho attitude," says Roger Mitchell, SMT project coordinator.

Launching the government's neighbourhood warden scheme, Home Office minister Charles Clarke declared: "They can improve communication between the police, residents and the local authority and mediate in minor incidents of anti-social behaviour."

This certainly seems true in Merthyr Tydfil. Local lads Marc Watkins, a former holiday camp red coat, and Rob Cunningham, who used to stack supermarket shelves, have been patrolling the streets of the Penydarren ward since January last year. Between 8am and 4.30pm from Monday to Friday, they check for broken paving stones, unsightly rubbish, street lights that need replacing and abandoned vehicles, stopping to listen to people's concerns, which they report to whichever organisation can best solve the problem. "Helping people gives you a great sense of achievement in this job," says Cunningham.

Trained in first aid, customer care and calming potentially violent situ ations, they have become community heroes for their actions - such as rescuing an elderly woman who had fallen in her kitchen.

"They never know when he can appear, so they'll be more wary in future. We don't want people locked up. Prevention is better than prosecution."

fields.headline: Drugs flagship rocked
fields.standfirst: Drop-out fear for rehabilitation programme
fields.trailText: Drop-out fear for rehabilitation programme
fields.body:
A leading provider of the government's flagship initiative to counter drug-related crime has voiced concern at the rate at which offenders are dropping out of the programme. The anxiety is echoed by probation officers, who fear the rate could be more than 50%.

Drug testing and treatment orders (DTTOs), rolled out nationally last October, are designed to break the cycle of reoffending through rehabilitation. Offenders convicted of an imprisonable offence, and deemed suitable for the order, are given a community sentence, provided they agree to attend a drug treatment course for a minimum of 15 hours a week for between six months and three years. Anyone subject to an order can be sent to prison if they repeatedly fail to attend the course, or are tested positive for drugs.

The scheme is seen by ministers as a key to breaking the cycle of drug misuse and crime. But Helen Cantrell, national criminal justice development manager for Addaction, a leading drug treatment charity contracted to deliver DTTOs, says: "Drop-out rates are very high. Most of the country is really struggling with implementing DTTOs."

The charity is contracted to deliver the orders in Surrey, Lincolnshire, Hastings, inner London and parts of Leicestershire and Derby shire, in partnership with the probation service, health authoritites, social services and the police.

While the philosophy behind the orders is "sound", she says, the practical expectations are unrealistic. "It was supposed to be needs-led and treatment-led, but it's become about number-crunching and pushing people to attend. There's not a problem with the uptake, but with how to keep offenders attending. It's a very demanding programme for a chaotic drug offender to achieve."

The Home Office says 546 DTTOs have been issued since October and only 20 have been breached. But Cantrell says that when offenders breach the conditions of an order it can take time to send them back to court. "I know the numbers of breaches are higher than that. Offenders have high, complex needs but they're being lumped into a group to meet time targets, which is resulting in individual treatment getting lost."

Harry Fletcher, assistant general secretary of the National Association of Probation Officers, says officers have had reservations about the initiative since it was piloted in three areas. They fear that offenders will be taken on to the scheme with little hope of completion.

"In the pilot, over 50% of orders were breached," he says. "The drop-out rate now is much higher. Officers feel they've been set up to fail."

Cranstoun Drugs Services and charity Turning Point, two other DTTO contractors, both say it is too early to measure the effectiveness of the orders. But Peter Glass, a director of Cranstoun,adds: "Addaction are more informed as they're very much at the forefront of knowing what's working well."

One drug offender, given a two-year DTTO in London, has told the Guardian that there is a "phenomenal" drop-out rate on his programme. "The format is so rigid and many people just can't do it," he says. "If they've got nowhere to live, and are struggling with addiction, it's just not possible to stick to the programme.

"It's not really addressing issues about housing and employment. We're put into groups and asked to talk about our week. Some people are very confused. It's not that the staff don't want to help. The ethos is very good, but for a lot of people it's just a way of staying out of prison.

"It's a case of the government saying, 'We're doing something about drug-related crime.' We're being fobbed off. It hasn't been organised properly and it's just not working."

The Home Office plans an evaluation of the scheme later this year. "We can't be drawn over speculative figures," says a spokesman. "We're aware it's early days, but are encouraged by the way things are going."

fields.headline: A winning double
fields.standfirst: Help for one, a place to live for the other:  Sarah Ebner on Homeshare's mutual benefits
fields.trailText: Help for one, a place to live for the other: Sarah Ebner on Homeshare's mutual benefits
fields.body:
Sceptics had their doubts about Homeshare. Many said that it simply wouldn't work, that the idea of young people being happy to live with, and help out, the elderly - albeit for a minimal rent - was unlikely to take off. Yet almost eight years on, the scheme is a fixture in London and is now spreading elsewhere.

"It's the simplicity of the idea that has led to its success," says Helen Collumbine, who has been running Homeshare for the last year. "Householders obviously benefit, while their families love us because we take the worry off their shoulders. No money is exchanged between the two people living in the same house, and that helps, too. It takes away any sense that it's a business arrangement."

Homeshare started in 1993 in London and recently opened offices in Oxford, Brighton and Colchester. It is a charitable organisation that places younger people, who could be working or studying, in the home of an elderly person. The average householder is in his or her 70s, while the younger person - the homesharer -has to be what Collumbine calls "mature", usually 25 or older.

"We advertise wherever young or old people go," she says, "and that might be in TNT [a free London newspaper aimed at young travellers], the local paper or a doctor's surgery."

Householders may apply directly to the project, although some are recommended by GPs or social workers. "The referral can be for any reason," says Collumbine. "A family might be concerned about their parent being alone at night after a fall or a hospital stay. Some elderly people also suffer from memory loss and their children are keen simply for someone to lock up at night."

Night-times are crucial and there are strict rules about the homesharer being around. They must sleep over every night and they get just one weekend off a month. They are allowed out on the occasional evening but must be in for at least four evenings a week.

The homesharer pays £50 a month to Homeshare, while the householder pays £65. In addition, the younger person is required to do 10 hours of housework a week - cooking, shopping or light cleaning. This demand often puts off possible homesharers, initially tempted by the prospect of low rent.

But housework is not the only reason why many younger inquirers realise that Homeshare isn't for them. There are other rules. "They have to commit for six months and not be in a relationship," says Collumbine. "We need them to focus their energy on the person they're living with and if they start a relationship during their stint, they are asked to leave."

Patricia Angadi, 86, lives in north London. She has had homesharers for four years and is very happy with the scheme. "I had lodgers before, but this is better," she says. "It stops me from being lonely, but you also don't get bothered during the day because they go out."

Her current homesharer is 37-year-old Tiina Tuliola from Finland. A trained carer, she is used to working with elderly people and has been a homesharer before.

"She's particularly good," says Angadi, "but I've had all sorts. I had one who was chaotic and used to leave the kitchen in a real state and another who started a relationship and spent evenings at her boyfriend's house. I've also had some very good ones I still keep in touch with."

Her son Shankara is impressed by the scheme. "It has transformed my mother's life," he says. "She lives in a nice flat surrounded by nice things but we started to think about whether it was going to be possible for her to continue to live there at all. The fact that there's somebody else there makes a colossal difference."

Shankara and his brother, who both live an hour's drive away from their mother, used to worry about her safety but now feel happier. "This gives us and my mother security," he says. "It's a real relief."

For Tuliola, Homeshare has been a good way to absorb British culture: "I learn about the language and the lifestyle. London can be a bit overwhelming and this is a secure way of starting life here.

"It works both ways," she adds. "I cook dinner and we eat it together. We keep each other company."

Shankara's only concern is that Homeshare might expand too fast. "What's really impressed me is that the people who run it know the ins and outs of the characters, and that's why it works," he says. "They have enormous depth of understanding and I don't know how they would retain that if they grow too fast."

Collumbine takes heed of the warning. "We're very careful in the way we run Homeshare," she says. "It takes time and effort to match people up and we don't want to risk that.

"At the moment, we want to look after what we've got. That's the priority."

Good moves from the matchmakers

Lisa Brown, a 25-year-old lawyer from New Zealand, is about to move in with 89-year-old Dorothy Edis in the centre of Brighton. "It appealed because you're living more or less rent free," she says. "But that wasn't the only reason. I also wanted to do it because I love old people and enjoy their company. I talk a lot and they seem to enjoy that."

She is not bothered by the restrictions but realises they could be problematic for others. "You have to be in my sort of situation or happily single to do something like this. My boyfriend is back in New Zealand for the next six months so to sleep here seven nights a week isn't a problem."

Brown had to go through a lengthy interview process before she was accepted by Homeshare. "They're keen to match you up properly," she says. "They want to find out your interests, so they ask you all sorts of questions, from whether you smoke to what kind of television programmes you like. They ask for both verbal and written references, too."

Dorothy has mild memory loss and so Homeshare is sending Lisa on a training course to help her deal with any potential problem. "I'm very happy about moving in with Dorothy," says Lisa, "but if I was her only support it would be different. She has a very supportive family who live locally as well as carers in the morning and the evening."

Margaret King, Dorothy's daughter, says: "My mother is a really sweet natured woman. She is active, but has a poor memory and nowadays does need someone there at night. This is pretty much the only way she's able to stay in her own home."

Homeshare is on 020-7378 6644

webTitle: Film professionals feature story of looked-after children

fields.headline: Moving images
fields.standfirst: Film professionals feature story of looked-after children
fields.trailText: Film professionals feature story of looked-after children
fields.body:
A small-scale drama project for teenagers and social work staff in Suffolk, about the issues of young people leaving care, has been turned into a professional film at a cost of £50,000.

The 30-minute feature, Moving On Up, starts a national tour today with a screening at the National Film Theatre on London's South Bank. In an attempt to change the often negative image of looked-after young people, the film uses the story of 17-year-old Billy, who tells his friends he is going into the army when he leaves care but who secretly wants to be a dancer.

The film grew out of drama workshops, set up as part of Suffolk county council's "listening to chil dren" programme, and run by Red Rose Chain, an Ipswich-based theatre company which does work on social issues. So impressed with the project were the council and the Eastern Arts Board that they agreed to fund the making of the film.

The council's chief executive, Lin Homer, says: "It's innovative projects like this which will change our behaviour, thinking and practice more effectively than a dozen training courses or conferences.

"The film has some tremendously powerful messages for everyone who works with looked-after children."

Martin Ayres, who chairs the project group, says: "The actors in Red Rose Chain are 15 to 17 years old and one of them grew up in care. They developed a unique level of understanding with the subject through talking with young care leavers, observing events in their lives, and the way they were dealt with by those caring for them."

Moving On Up was shot on location at Felixstowe, Suffolk, and has as its director of photography Sue Gibson, who has worked on such films as Hear My Song and Mrs Dalloway.

After today's screening in London, Moving On Up will be shown in: York; Lowestoft, Norfolk; Taunton, Somerset; Birmingham; Stowmarket, Suffolk. Further information from Red Rose Chain on 01473-723804.

webTitle: Theatre helps Leeds council estate to get over stage fright

fields.headline: Raising the curtain
fields.standfirst: Theatre helps Leeds council estate to get over stage fright
fields.trailText: Theatre helps Leeds council estate to get over stage fright
fields.body:
Three thousand people live on the Ebor Gardens estate in the centre of Leeds, 300 yards from a theatre with an international reputation for its productions and community work. But a new report shows that, until last year, only seven addresses with the estate's postcode had ever found their way into the database of 140,000 patrons maintained by the West Yorkshire Playhouse.

Residents faced two deterrents: one was the A64, a busy trunk road; the other a sense that the Playhouse "wasn't for them". As one community worker said: "A lot of people walk past it on their way to town, but for most round here it might as well be a million miles away."

Theatre staff set out to cross the great divide in a year-long project called In Our Neighbourhood, funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. It aimed to broaden the range of the Playhouse's offerings, to get more people taking up its services and products, and to increase staff awareness. At first, no one seemed to think that they might get more "local bums on seats". Yet over the 12 months, 417 tickets were sold to Ebor Gardens residents.

"We were frightened of offering people the thing we love," says Jude Kelly, the Playhouse's executive director. "We were giving our neighbours the tin instead of the cake. But then they said: 'We want to taste your cake.' And now we are borrowing each other's sugar."

The project coincided with hit shows such as Singin' In The Rain, which transferred to the National Theatre, and Stig Of The Dump, adapted from the Clive King novel. "We took 30 to 35 people from my end of the estate to Singin' In The Rain and everyone thought it was great," said a pensioner - quoted in the project evaluation report - who took advantage of cut-price tickets for community groups. "I had thought it would be too high-price for working-class people."

A community activist noted a change in attitudes. "I think people always thought of the Playhouse as off-limits, a snobby, over-priced place. They now see it as somewhere affordable, where people can have a night out with the family."

The report points out that the project coincided with refurbishment of the estate. New security measures helped residents go out at night without worrying about beingburgled. Contact between theatre staff and residents led to first-name familiarity, which broke down barriers and removed some of the fear of entering the theatre.

"For Ebor Gardens residents, the Playhouse became a group of people rather than a building," says Dick Downing, arts consultant and author of the report. "For Playhouse workers, Ebor Gardens became a community rather than an estate.

"It might be argued that there was a presumption that this community would not be particularly interested in theatre-going and that the focus should be on creating more community orientated activities. In the event, the number of theatre attendances and the uptake of support and advice clearly indicate that a theatre can be a significant resource for its local community."

webTitle: Scheme in Sheffield to help prostitutes quit the game

fields.headline: Street wiser
fields.standfirst: Kath Grant on an innovative scheme in Sheffield to help prostitutes quit the game
fields.trailText: Kath Grant on an innovative scheme in Sheffield to help prostitutes quit the game
fields.body:
Sheffield has twice flirted with decriminalising prostitution. Now it is tackling the issue in a different way, by piloting a scheme to get prostitutes not only off the streets but out of the business altogether.

The women, many of whom are trapped in prostitution because they are hooked on drugs, deep in debt or the victims of domestic violence, will be offered "exit strategies" including addiction treatment, help with housing, money advice and protection from violent pimps.

The scheme is being drawn up by Sheffield's prostitution forum, which includes police, local councillors, university employees, health staff, drugs counsellors and outreach workers. Matt Dixon, who chairs the forum, says: "Our priorities are the women's health and safety, but we also want to find ways of getting prostitution out of residential areas."

A study last week suggested that more than 80% of street prostitutes have been attacked while working. The finding came from a survey of three cities, including Glasgow, where a scheme similar to Sheffield's began last October and is now working with 30 women.

The approach involves a wide range of agencies - most crucially, groups which have the confidence of prostitutes. The Sheffield scheme will rely heavily on the expertise of the Sheffield Working Women's Opportunities Project (Swwop). With two colleagues and volunteers, project worker Sali Harwood spends three nights a week in the city's red light area, giving advice and information to the 260 prostitutes who work the streets between the city centre and Sheffield University.

"The women trust us and, if they meet staff in our van and get to know them by name, they are much more likely to keep follow-up appointments at the sexual health clinic or [the charity] Turning Point's community drugs project," Harwood says. "The majority of women on the streets have a drugs problem and they have to keep working to pay for it. There is always going to be prostitution, but we must try to make things safer for the women - and offer a way out for those who want to come off drugs and leave the streets."

Dixon acknowledges: "We need outreach workers like the people from Swwop if the project is to be a success, because they have gained the confidence of the women. It could never get off the ground if it was just coming from the police and politicians."

Two recent plans to decriminalise prostitution in Sheffield have failed in the face of protests. Four years ago, proposals for a red light tolerance zone were abandoned after complaints from residents whose homes bordered the area. Then, when the Liberal Democrats gained control of the city council in 1999, they wanted to introduce registration of the city's saunas and brothels. That idea was dropped after the Sunday Sport newspaper ran a story urging readers: "Come to Sheffield."

Dixon, a 22-year-old LibDem councillor, remains an advocate of registration of saunas and brothels and believes it will have to be introduced if street prostitution is to be eradicated. Meanwhile, he intends to focus on helping women who wish to escape the lifestyle.

Support will have to be available for as long as the women need it, Dixon says. "It's like coming out of prison and into the same situation that led a person into crime in the first place. These women have friends still working on the streets and, in many cases, their boyfriends are also their pimps and their drug dealers. They can't go back to all that if they are to stay off drugs and prostitution. It could mean having to relocate them to another area. That is why the multi-agency approach is essential."

Harwood agrees: "It is difficult staying off drugs if you are living in the same area and the people who sell them are doing their best to persuade you to go back on them. It is a big loss of revenue for the drug dealers - who are often well known to the women - and they are not going to lose their customers easily.

"Housing will have to play a key part in exit strategies, so that women can move away if necessary. Drop-in centres are helpful, but the forum must come up with ways of following up individual women and supporting them on a one-to-one basis."

The forum is establishing links with the city council's housing department and housing associations in Sheffield so that the women can be offered new accommodation if necessary. Debt counsellors from Sheffield's advice centres will give information on the best ways of tackling money problems. And women's aid refuges and the police's domestic violence unit will be involved in the planned exit strategies for those prostitutes who are being assaulted or threatened by pimps.

Police believe previous operations to get kerb crawlers and prostitutes off the streets have shifted them to other areas. And when the university increased the use of security cameras and lighting to deter would-be punters, it merely attracted more prostitutes to the area. "The extra security made them feel safer and, surprisingly, it didn't seem to deter the punters," Superintendent Steve Hicks says.

"Police operations only bring short-term solutions and we are now working with other agencies to address the roots of the problem. We know that many of these women would welcome the chance to get off the streets."

Harwood points out that by no means all the prostitutes are regulars. Some turn out perhaps once a week and others travel to Sheffield from nearby Barnsley and Rotherham, where there are no traditional beats.

"Then there are the ones we only see on a sporadic basis, perhaps every two months," she says. "Some work in the weeks before Christmas to get extra money for children's presents, and we don't see them again until the following year."

webTitle: Age Concern scheme to ease the isolation of the rural elderly

fields.headline: The lilac link
fields.standfirst: Claire Laurent on an Age Concern scheme to ease the isolation of the rural elderly through a volunteers' network
fields.trailText: Claire Laurent on an Age Concern scheme to ease the isolation of the rural elderly through a volunteers' network
fields.body:
When a phone call came in from a pensioner in their Oxfordshire village of Long Hanborough, asking for help to get a stairlift, Jeanette and Stephen Braybrooke-Tucker were able to make use of their knowledge and networks to give her the best information.

"She said she was breathless and couldn't manage the stairs any more," recalls Stephen, "so we went round and talked to her about the options."

Discussion turned to the "Staying Put" scheme run by Anchor Housing to help older people stay in their own homes. "We rang the local person and when he visited to make his assessment, we went with him," says Stephen.

Once it was agreed that a stairlift was needed, the couple were able to ask the woman whether she was claiming attendance allowance. She wasn't, so Jeannette helped her complete the forms for a successful application. This, in turn, entitled her to the stairlift free of charge.

The Braybrooke-Tuckers are "parish links" - volunteers under an innovative scheme run by the charity Age Concern in Oxfordshire. It started in 1998, building on and formalising work already being done by good neighbours in terms of supplying information, leaflets and newsletters in their communities.

Age Concern director Mary Daniel says: "It started as almost back-of-an-envelope stuff, looking at the needs of older people over the winter period. But it has really grown to become the heart of the way we deliver a lot of work in rural areas."

The value of the work done by parish links is highlighted in an Age Concern report, commissioned by Oxforshire's social services as part of the county's prevention strategy. The report, Lilac from the Garden, looks at meeting the need for dayservices for older people in rural areas. It says that more than 50% of people aged over 65 living independently in Oxfordshire are in rural areas. Of those areas, 79% lack a daily bus service and 50% have no shop.

Penny Thewlis, the report's author, talked to more than 200 older people in the course of her research. "There is a real absence of work on the experiences of getting older in the countryside," she says. "There is absolutely nothing recent: there are lots of rural studies, but none focuses on older people.

"Most of them have a single line saying it's hard for older people in rural areas, but they don't say how or why or what might be done about it. They don't say what older people themselves say."

Lilac from the Garden aims to address this gap. Thewlis found there were about 100 Age Concern parish links across the county who serve as a resource for older people in their locality. Unlike the Braybrooke-Tuckers, few are trained to give benefits advice, but they will direct people to where they can find out about home security and fire prevention, or how to get electric blankets safety-tested. They may organise transport to a doctor's surgery, or arrange for gardening or shopping to be done.

However, most of the parish links are in the larger villages, with older people in more remote parts having little means of contact with others. The report therefore recommends that the network be developed to try to reach the very fingertips of rural Oxfordshire.

"We have applied for a Home Office grant for extra staffing so that we can attack those gaps," Daniel says. The idea is that a community development worker could work closely with a small number of rural communities to recruit more parish links, before moving on to other parishes.

Age Concern has appointed a parish link coordinator to provide support to the existing network and is looking at setting up a small innovation grant for which parish links could bid and use to support local initiatives, such as an information coffee morning or an outing.

Parish links are volunteers and tend to be retired people. This is a reflection both of Age Concern's policy of engaging older people in its organisation and the hard fact that young, working people rarely have the time to volunteer.

"We have the time," says Jeannette Braybrooke-Tucker. "We can go and sit with people and spend three or four hours going through their forms with them. They wouldn't get that service elsewhere, but we're happy to do it and they know it will be confidential."

The Braybrooke-Tuckers work as a team. She has multiple sclerosis and is a wheelchair user, so she tends to deal with the many phone calls, record keeping and the paperwork. Stephen does most of the travelling: attending meetings, delivering leaflets and information packs and visiting older people's clubs and groups.

The need for such groups is highlighted in Age Concern's report, which shows how day centres can be developed to become the hub of a dynamic range of networks and extended services.

But many centres struggle with recruiting volunteers and organising transport - so crucial in rural areas - and there is a clear demand for alternative sources of help such as parish links and mobile services, which Age Concern wants to develop in Oxfordshire.

Thewlis says: "When I began this research, I was surprised at the extent to which people emphasised the need to just have access to the most basic of services, like a shop or information about healthcare. Getting access to health services was very hard for people, so much so that it prevented them making appointments for minor ailments."

"If you're trying to think prevention for older people, that's one of the things that worry me because it means a lot of things are going undiscovered for a long time, with no chance to intervene early."

When services are in place and do work, though, the results can be gratifying. The lilac in the title of the Age Concern report were the flowers brought by one appreciative service user to her local day centre from her own garden.

Lilac from the Garden - Day Services for Older People in Rural Oxfordshire is available free from Age Concern Oxfordshire City and County on 01865-240619.
