webTitle: Scrutiny urged on benchmark regulations for care homes

fields.headline: Standard bearers
fields.standfirst: Scrutiny urged on benchmark regulations for care homes
fields.trailText: Scrutiny urged on benchmark regulations for care homes
fields.body:
Welfare groups are calling on the government to ensure strict policing of new minimum standards for care homes for older people, due to take effect largely from April next year. The 38 standards are the first of a series of benchmarks and regulations to be published under the Care Standards Act 2000. This opening set covers all aspects of life in residential and nursing care, ranging from fulfilling social activities to dignity in death.

John Hutton, social care minister, says the standards will be seen as a landmark. "For too long there has been a lack of independence and consistency in the regulation of care homes. These minimum standards, developed following extensive consultation, will change that."

While the initiative has been broadly welcomed, groups representing older people want to see strong enforcement of the standards. Gordon Lishman, director general of charity Age Concern, says: "I sincerely hope it signifies a shift in approach and that this shift is translated down to a local level. Clearly all the new standards must be comprehensively implemented and rigorously monitored. Older people need the reassurance that, if changes are necessary, the government wil respond accordingly."

Care home standards were first set out in a consultation document, Fit for the Future?, in 1999. Controversy over proposed minimum space requirements for individual rooms was settled last year with a compromise on the basic single room minimum of 10 sq metres for existing homes. The standard will not apply until 2007 and will not be enforced where a home offers at least 9.3 sq metres and has more communal space than the stipulated minimum.

The Coalition for Quality in Care, representing more than 50 interest groups, says that while regretting the decision not to insist on 10 sq metres, it nevertheless believes that the standards will have "a major impact on improving quality of care in homes across the country". The coalition welcomes particularly the standards on staff training. From 2005, registered managers of care homes must have achieved NVQ level 4 or equivalent (or a nursing qualification where nursing care is provided) and at least 50% of other staff, excluding nurses, must have reached NVQ level 2. An approved training and development programme must be in place from next year.

Care Homes for Older People - National Minimum Standards is published at £11.25 by the Stationery Office, or is at: www.doh.gov.uk/ncsc

webTitle: Profile: Hamish Davidson, local government's headhunter

fields.headline: The king-maker
fields.standfirst: Hamish Davidson, local government's headhunter
fields.trailText: Profile: Hamish Davidson, local government's headhunter
fields.body:
A phone call from Ken Livingstone sealed Hamish Davidson's reputation as a local government mover and shaker. "The mayor said that he, and Transport for London, needed a transport commissioner. The brief was for a global search - and they wanted the best."

Headhunter Davidson and his team compiled a shortlist of four candidates from Britain and four from the US. Davidson put forward Bob Kiley, who had revitalised subway systems in New York and Boston, as a leading candidate.

"Bob was surprised to hear from us, but once I knew he was intrigued I realised we had a good chance of getting him. He was too busy to fly over, so we did the interview via video link. Bob was very impressive and confident. That brief was my most challenging yet."

The Kiley appointment confirmed Davidson's reputation as the real power behind various local government thrones - an energetic headhunter whose bulging contacts book and powers of persuasion have enabled him to help recruit Liverpool council's chief executive David Henshaw, Sheffield's Bob Kerslake and Newcastle upon Tyne's Kevin Lavery. He has also found chief executives for more than a third of all London boroughs and is currently searching for someone to fill the top job at Coventry.

He is uncomfortable with accolades - "I don't make the appointments, I just suggest to members who they might interview" - but is none the less proud to have brought an aggressive form of recruitment into the public sector.

After graduating from Keele University in international relations, Davidson worked as an auditor and then investment manager before deciding on a career in recruitment. "I enjoyed meeting people and selling, so I thought that headhunting would allow me to do both - meet people and sell their talent."

Now 42, Davidson was himself headhunted from a small company of recruitment consultants to join PricewaterhouseCoopers 13 years ago. He fell into public sector recruitment by chance. Asked to search out candidates for a director-level job at a local authority, he found few suitable people and was excited by the challenge.

As a partner, Davidson heads a 50-strong team of consultants specialising in local government. He describes his job as that of a "third party broker", although concedes that some members and officers might see him more as a pied piper figure, luring away staff.

Despite the fact that he is behind most of the high-profile local gov ernment appointments in recent years, Davidson says: "The public sector is more cautious about using headhunters than the private sector - the 'men in grey suits', what I call the old guard in local government, are always anxious about using headhunters."

One reason he is regarded with suspicion is that he is concerned with profit making. Yes, he concedes, PricewaterhouseCoopers does take a cut of 25% of the annual salary of the post in question, but he insists: "Using a headhunter increases your chances of finding a top-class candidate."

At best, Davidson is described by those recruited by him as "a real character". At worst, some say he is frustratingly unconventional. He criticises what he sees as local government's bureaucracy and inflexibility, which may dictate that just one or two days are set aside for interviews, that candidates must come to interview, or that job ads have to be staid and conventional.

Davidson disproved this last point nowhere better than in 1995, when he was given the challenge of recruiting a chief executive for Lambeth council, south London.

He spent hours at his desk, trying to create an ad that would make debt-ridden Lambeth, still struggling to rid itself of a "loony left" image, seem attractive. Finally, he tore up his ideas and wrote exactly what he felt. He described the post as "arguably the worst job in local government".

He says: "I didn't think members would ever go for it but they had the courage to do so. I was being honest and trying to provoke people into reading it."

Heather Rabbatts was headhunted by Davidson from nearby Merton council. Despite claimsthat her time at Lambeth was a matter of style over substance, she did at least raise the profile of the authority.

Davidson repeated the technique in December 1999, when searching for a new managing director for Hackney, east London - a post now filled by Max Caller, who was drawn by the advert describing the challenges as . . . "an absence of coherent political leadership, a disconnection between strategy and operation, poor financial management and a lack of focus on basic services."

In headhunting, says Davidson, you have to contact someone who's settled in their job, persuade them to go for a job which, after a long, exhausting process they may not get, and then you have to tell them exactly why they failed. It's not always a pleasant task."

webTitle: Theatre helps Leeds council estate to get over stage fright

fields.headline: Raising the curtain
fields.standfirst: Theatre helps Leeds council estate to get over stage fright
fields.trailText: Theatre helps Leeds council estate to get over stage fright
fields.body:
Three thousand people live on the Ebor Gardens estate in the centre of Leeds, 300 yards from a theatre with an international reputation for its productions and community work. But a new report shows that, until last year, only seven addresses with the estate's postcode had ever found their way into the database of 140,000 patrons maintained by the West Yorkshire Playhouse.

Residents faced two deterrents: one was the A64, a busy trunk road; the other a sense that the Playhouse "wasn't for them". As one community worker said: "A lot of people walk past it on their way to town, but for most round here it might as well be a million miles away."

Theatre staff set out to cross the great divide in a year-long project called In Our Neighbourhood, funded by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. It aimed to broaden the range of the Playhouse's offerings, to get more people taking up its services and products, and to increase staff awareness. At first, no one seemed to think that they might get more "local bums on seats". Yet over the 12 months, 417 tickets were sold to Ebor Gardens residents.

"We were frightened of offering people the thing we love," says Jude Kelly, the Playhouse's executive director. "We were giving our neighbours the tin instead of the cake. But then they said: 'We want to taste your cake.' And now we are borrowing each other's sugar."

The project coincided with hit shows such as Singin' In The Rain, which transferred to the National Theatre, and Stig Of The Dump, adapted from the Clive King novel. "We took 30 to 35 people from my end of the estate to Singin' In The Rain and everyone thought it was great," said a pensioner - quoted in the project evaluation report - who took advantage of cut-price tickets for community groups. "I had thought it would be too high-price for working-class people."

A community activist noted a change in attitudes. "I think people always thought of the Playhouse as off-limits, a snobby, over-priced place. They now see it as somewhere affordable, where people can have a night out with the family."

The report points out that the project coincided with refurbishment of the estate. New security measures helped residents go out at night without worrying about beingburgled. Contact between theatre staff and residents led to first-name familiarity, which broke down barriers and removed some of the fear of entering the theatre.

"For Ebor Gardens residents, the Playhouse became a group of people rather than a building," says Dick Downing, arts consultant and author of the report. "For Playhouse workers, Ebor Gardens became a community rather than an estate.

"It might be argued that there was a presumption that this community would not be particularly interested in theatre-going and that the focus should be on creating more community orientated activities. In the event, the number of theatre attendances and the uptake of support and advice clearly indicate that a theatre can be a significant resource for its local community."

In Our Neighbourhood is published at £13.95 by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation. A summary of its findings is at: www.jrf.org.uk.

webTitle: What can be done to improve the government's food policy

fields.headline: Leaps and binds
fields.standfirst: Britain's food policy is in a mess, as the government reels from one crisis to another.  Tim Lang and  Erik Millstone  offer an ambitious but readily attainable 12-point recipe for improvement
fields.trailText: Britain's food policy is in a mess, as the government reels from one crisis to another. Tim Lang and Erik Millstone offer an ambitious but readily attainable 12-point recipe for improvement
fields.body:
What can the government do about the farming crisis and the endless and linked cycles of animal and human disease, the decline of the rural sector, environmental degradation, problems with animal welfare and the massive power of supermarkets?

Economists call for freer trade and subsidy abolition. Others say trade liberalisation is environmentally damaging and weakens consumer protection. Health specialists argue that taxpayers meet the bills for ill health and environmental damage caused by industrial farming. Consumers are ambiguous, relishing cheap food but unhappy about the consequences of industrial farming.

All these crises impose extra costs. Everyone sees that now - especially Gordon Brown. The bill includes £4bn for BSE, £1bn a year for food poisoning, £1bn pa to treat heart disease, and £100m pa to remove pesticides from drinking water.

A new policy framework is needed to take an overview of the whole food system. It must focus on food and environmental quality, not just on price and quantity. It needs to rebuild local and regional food supplies to cut the distance food travels, and promote and protect ecological and public health. It must prioritise biodiversity throughout the food supply chain and ensure a healthy diet is available to, and affordable by, all. It must further force firms in the food chain to pay as many as possible of the environmental and social costs that they currently pass on to others.

It's a tall order but the UK government already has an embryonic policy framework. Last September, it signed the World Health Organisation's four-year programme to improve nutrition, food safety and sustainable food supply. Three months later, it backed the French presidency's commitment to audit all EU policies (including the common agricultural policy) for their impact on health. Such overdue audits need broadening.

Here is a preliminary shopping list of what is needed and what can be done now:

 Whitehall reform Labour has unfinished business. The safety focus of the Food Standards Agency is not wide enough. We need a new national Food Policy Council to integrate competing demands of environment, safety and health with a sustainable rural economy. The Ministry of Agriculture should either be abolished or become a Department of Food, Agriculture and Rural Affairs.

 CAP The common agricultural policy should become a common food and rural rolicy (CFRP). The commission, in the wake of BSE, is trying to bolt safety on to agricultural policy. Nutrition remains a marginal policy issue, although 1.5m Europeans die from heart disease each year. The proposed European Food Authority will be narrowly focused on microbiological and toxicological aspects of safety. It would be irrelevant to the current foot and mouth crisis. The commission needs an overview.

 Subsidies Export subsidies, which dump Europe's surpluses on world markets, damage developing countries. They must stop. The CFRP should shift to sustainable , extensive farm methods. Labour should back the organic targets bill, now before Parliament, with a goal of 30% of agriculture to be organic by 2020.

 Trade The government accepts the World Trade Organisation's vision of liberalised trade. Trade liberalisation, however, can drive down consumer protection standards and inflict greater environmental harm from farming, trade and especially transport. Why are we flying in luxury foods from countries that aren't feeding their own people properly?

 Codex The Codex Alimentarius Commission, the body the WTO uses to set global food standards, is stacked with corporate interests - helping set standards for their own products. It needs wholesale reform.

 Prices A sustainable food supply will mean (re)building local food systems, but not at any cost. If you want mangoes, don't expect them to be grown in subsidised European greenhouses. State-supported infrastructure, such as roads, enables food corporations to garner economies of scale but at huge environmental costs. Food prices should reflect the full costs of production, not just short-term fuel prices.

 Fair payments Farm-gate prices have declined but retail prices have not been reduced. A larger portion of the value generated in the food chain should accrue to farmers who grow the primary products. Shortening the supply chain would help. We either need to break up the big retail chains or tightly regulate competition among them, or both.

 Access to shops Diversity of shops is just as important as diversity of crops within a field. The hypermarket revolution gets consumers into retail sheds, while just-in-time delivery systems mean the motorways become the warehouse. This is brilliant logistics but crazy environmental or cultural economics. Access to shops and a wholesome diet is espedcially vital for the poor. Why is the social exclusion unit's access to shops report gathering dust?

 Food skills The growth of the catering sector shows the hunger of the British for good food, but too often it relies on cheap, unskilled labour. When schools don't teach cooking or treat other food skills as important, is the low esteem of food work surprising? Food life-skills should be introduced into schools.

 Food science Too many research grants are linked to commercial projects. Governments have failed to invest in research to improve the productivity of organic and extensive farming, or to study the adverse consequences of current practices, so it fails to produce evidence, and then interprets the absence of evidence of risk as if it were evidence of the absence of risks.

 Consumer protection There is no such thing as risk-free food. Equally, regulators must stop assuming that current food methods are safe until proven harmful. A new precautionary approach is needed. Strict liability rules need to be applied to all agricultural and food products, including GM crops. Exemptions that cushion the food system from taking responsibility for the costs it has long not paid should be abolished.

 Competition policy In every food sector, the share taken by larger companies grows. Behind the cafe society lie stock exchange giants. How is a market to be delineated? Currently, national markets are being redrawn as regional ones. What matters to consumers is their travel-to-shop time and distance. The regional development agencies should be charged with rebuilding local food sources.

The government has a lot on its food policy plate. The good news is that it now has the appetite to take on vested interests.

Tim Lang is professor of food policy at Thames Valley University. Erik Millstone is senior lecturer in science policy at the University of Sussex.

fields.bylineHtml: Tim Lang and Erik Millstone

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: letters
fields.body:
Home and away

It's a bit rich to blame planners for poor supply and consequent high prices in the housing market (Key workers in the cold, February 21).

A shortage of key workers in a given area simply implies that they are not being paid enough to compete against others when buying homes and that their commuting costs are too high. There are only two solutions: one is to pay key workers more and the other is to provide them with subsidised housing or travel costs.

Local authority planners have the knowledge to identify areas where affordable housing is needed. They have the powers and democratic mandate to ensure that, where homes are built, some of them are affordable. In the old days, local authorities could provide such housing themselves and allocate units to key workers; now, others are expected to help out. But developers, banks and building societies cannot be expected to subsidise new housing in the numbers needed. Government must step in, with subsidies funded through central taxation.

Even given a workable system for subsidising key worker accommodation, we have to question the level of demand. All our experience shows that employees do not necessarily want to live near their place of work. Other factors - schools, the quality of the environment, a partner's travel needs - weigh heavier. Even in the new towns, carefully planned to bring employment and housing closer together, typically half of residents still commute to the nearby cities. If only in the interests of the environment, however, we should seek to reduce the length of all journeys to work.

So let's stop blaming planners for making new development uneconomical. It is through the planning system that we can build broad and thriving communities that all will want to live in. The successful provision of key worker housing is only a small part of the equation.

Nick Davies
President, Royal Town Planning Institute

Dig for victory again

Even before this latest tragedy to hit British livestock, national food security had reached an all-time low (Kill or cure? February 28).

One would have thought that, as an island nation, we would have learned our lesson from the two world wars in the last century when, in times of crisis, it was imperative to use all our own resources to feed the nation. With so many mouths to feed, this country should cut imports and concentrate on home production once again. Our farmland is a vital resource and it should be cared for properly, not raped by industrial farming.

At the same time, individuals should realise that food safety for the family can come from growing as much food as possible at home in gardens and allotments, making use of every piece of land available as was done during wartime.

Brian Baxter
Swaffham, Norfolk

Women's initiative

I take issue with Michael Symmons Roberts's assertion that the women on Greenham Common were hijacked by "a sort of feminist-separatist policy" agenda (Nuclear families, February 28).

His opinion arises out of his failure to differentiate between a woman-only initiative, for a specific purpose, and separatism. In the early days - September 1981 to February 1982 - there were women and men living at the peace camp. A conscious effort was made to promote an image of women doing things in their own right and for their own reasons, and to counter the media's concentration on male personalities and male-oriented news.

After much reflection, it was decided to have a trial run at a women-only camp; the men left and didn't return.

As a women-only camp, we could claim our autonomy, which allowed us to develop politically a system that could respond to other injustices that were the result of domination by the military industrial complex. The spirit of the peace camp and its work travelled out across the country and the rest of the world.

Roberts should ask himself if the fact that he was a reporter for the Newbury Weekly News could have anything to do with the hostility he claims was directed at him by women. This was the newspaper that allowed Rage (Ratepayers Against Greenham Encampments) to run an advertising campaign in the form of vicious cartoons. The camp was attacked, maggots were thrown into the kitchen area, attempts were made to burn our tents and cement was poured into the standpipe - our only water supply. We were refused service in shops and travel on buses.

Roberts did not choose to mention this negative activity exercised by some of his local community.

Sarah Hipperson
London

Wholly healthy

I am a proselytising atheist and therefore well placed to judge if support for religious groups leads inevitably to religious brainwashing (Letters, February 28).

Last year I spent three nights observing the actions of a group of Christians who work the "winter watch "programme in Bolton. The team of seven (eldest 70, youngest 16) prayed before they started and when they finished - and why not? In 15 hours, I did not see or hear anyone mention Jesus or the word prayer to what the leader called "the customers".

Their prayers, short and extemporised, were practical. One woman asked not that the Lord would stop the tea urn from malfunctioning, but that he would give her the strength to cope when it did break down at the moment the doors opened and 20 hungry rough sleepers came rushing at the serving hatch. Healthy realism, that, not happy clapping.

Brian Lewis
Pontefract, West Yorkshire

fields.bodyText: Home and away It's a bit rich to blame planners for poor supply and consequent high prices in the housing market (Key workers in the cold, February 21). A shortage of key workers in a given area simply implies that they are not being paid enough to compete against others when buying homes and that their commuting costs are too high. There are only two solutions: one is to pay key workers more and the other is to provide them with subsidised housing or travel costs. Local authority planners have the knowledge to identify areas where affordable housing is needed. They have the powers and democratic mandate to ensure that, where homes are built, some of them are affordable. In the old days, local authorities could provide such housing themselves and allocate units to key workers; now, others are expected to help out. But developers, banks and building societies cannot be expected to subsidise new housing in the numbers needed. Government must step in, with subsidies funded through central taxation. Even given a workable system for subsidising key worker accommodation, we have to question the level of demand. All our experience shows that employees do not necessarily want to live near their place of work. Other factors - schools, the quality of the environment, a partner's travel needs - weigh heavier. Even in the new towns, carefully planned to bring employment and housing closer together, typically half of residents still commute to the nearby cities. If only in the interests of the environment, however, we should seek to reduce the length of all journeys to work. So let's stop blaming planners for making new development uneconomical. It is through the planning system that we can build broad and thriving communities that all will want to live in. The successful provision of key worker housing is only a small part of the equation. webTitle: Profile: Hamish Davidson, local government's headhunter

fields.headline: The king-maker
fields.standfirst: Hamish Davidson, local government's headhunter
fields.trailText: Profile: Hamish Davidson, local government's headhunter
fields.body:
A phone call from Ken Livingstone sealed Hamish Davidson's reputation as a local government mover and shaker. "The mayor said that he, and Transport for London, needed a transport commissioner. The brief was for a global search - and they wanted the best."

Headhunter Davidson and his team compiled a shortlist of four candidates from Britain and four from the US. Davidson put forward Bob Kiley, who had revitalised subway systems in New York and Boston, as a leading candidate.

"Bob was surprised to hear from us, but once I knew he was intrigued I realised we had a good chance of getting him. He was too busy to fly over, so we did the interview via video link. Bob was very impressive and confident. That brief was my most challenging yet."

The Kiley appointment confirmed Davidson's reputation as the real power behind various local government thrones - an energetic headhunter whose bulging contacts book and powers of persuasion have enabled him to help recruit Liverpool council's chief executive David Henshaw, Sheffield's Bob Kerslake and Newcastle upon Tyne's Kevin Lavery. He has also found chief executives for more than a third of all London boroughs and is currently searching for someone to fill the top job at Coventry.

He is uncomfortable with accolades - "I don't make the appointments, I just suggest to members who they might interview" - but is none the less proud to have brought an aggressive form of recruitment into the public sector.

After graduating from Keele University in international relations, Davidson worked as an auditor and then investment manager before deciding on a career in recruitment. "I enjoyed meeting people and selling, so I thought that headhunting would allow me to do both - meet people and sell their talent."

Now 42, Davidson was himself headhunted from a small company of recruitment consultants to join PricewaterhouseCoopers 13 years ago. He fell into public sector recruitment by chance. Asked to search out candidates for a director-level job at a local authority, he found few suitable people and was excited by the challenge.

As a partner, Davidson heads a 50-strong team of consultants specialising in local government. He describes his job as that of a "third party broker", although concedes that some members and officers might see him more as a pied piper figure, luring away staff.

Despite the fact that he is behind most of the high-profile local gov ernment appointments in recent years, Davidson says: "The public sector is more cautious about using headhunters than the private sector - the 'men in grey suits', what I call the old guard in local government, are always anxious about using headhunters."

One reason he is regarded with suspicion is that he is concerned with profit making. Yes, he concedes, PricewaterhouseCoopers does take a cut of 25% of the annual salary of the post in question, but he insists: "Using a headhunter increases your chances of finding a top-class candidate."

At best, Davidson is described by those recruited by him as "a real character". At worst, some say he is frustratingly unconventional. He criticises what he sees as local government's bureaucracy and inflexibility, which may dictate that just one or two days are set aside for interviews, that candidates must come to interview, or that job ads have to be staid and conventional.

Davidson disproved this last point nowhere better than in 1995, when he was given the challenge of recruiting a chief executive for Lambeth council, south London.

He spent hours at his desk, trying to create an ad that would make debt-ridden Lambeth, still struggling to rid itself of a "loony left" image, seem attractive. Finally, he tore up his ideas and wrote exactly what he felt. He described the post as "arguably the worst job in local government".

He says: "I didn't think members would ever go for it but they had the courage to do so. I was being honest and trying to provoke people into reading it."

Heather Rabbatts was headhunted by Davidson from nearby Merton council. Despite claimsthat her time at Lambeth was a matter of style over substance, she did at least raise the profile of the authority.

Davidson repeated the technique in December 1999, when searching for a new managing director for Hackney, east London - a post now filled by Max Caller, who was drawn by the advert describing the challenges as . . . "an absence of coherent political leadership, a disconnection between strategy and operation, poor financial management and a lack of focus on basic services."

In headhunting, says Davidson, you have to contact someone who's settled in their job, persuade them to go for a job which, after a long, exhausting process they may not get, and then you have to tell them exactly why they failed. It's not always a pleasant task."

webTitle: Why do we fear nature's retribution?

fields.headline: The silent spring
fields.standfirst: Why do we fear nature's retribution?
fields.trailText: Commentary: Why do we fear nature's retribution?
fields.body:
As I write, foot and mouth disease has not returned here in Shropshire. But it's coming closer. Just over the border, in the snowy hills of the Welsh Marches, the protection zone from an outbreak in Felindre, Powys, reaches the Shropshire town of Clun - a name that sounds like a farm gate closing.

The countryside is closing in on itself - and not just because of spreading bureaucratic measures and a halt to rights of way, markets, meetings and events - and an eerie silence is descending. The whole basis of modern life is being challenged. Out of this silent spring grows a special fear.

Fear is what the virus brings. Fear shuts the footpaths. Fear slaughters the animals. Specifically, this is a fear that wild nature will respond violently to our presence on Earth and our intervention in natural processes. This is not just what we feel about nature - this is our experience of how nature is.

This year, like the enactment of some apocalyptic, millennial fantasy, we have already had storms, floods and blizzards. Agriculture is still linked to BSE, e-coli, salmonella, bovine tuberculosis and swine fever. Now there's a visitation from a virus, reappearing from a painful, long-ago memory, and burning through the ecology of commerce like wildfire.

All these things are perfectly natural. A fear of them is a fear of nature's answering violence.

Throughout our history, and particularly in the history of those living closest to the land, people have thought of natural processes as having a purpose or design, influencing other things and being themselves amenable to influence. Although the official line has been that this is all nonsense, how often do we read that a particular river has "claimed another victim" or that some hurricane or earthquake is "nature's wrath"? These are not just figures of speech. They are old attitudes which have persisted despite official objection.

We blame intensive agriculture for a whole raft of ills afflicting the environment and people, but these are only modern manifestations of problems which are as old as agriculture itself. As long as we have tried to control nature, bend it to our will and, with increasing success, protect ourselves and benefit from it, we have had fears and anxieties about nature taking its revenge. Taking the offensive, we act against natural processes to exert even greater control.

Cattle, sheep and pigs are being sacrificed to prevent the spread of disease. Perhaps things are under control, perhaps not, but in an increasingly sectarian countryside stoicism is being pushed too far. Too many punches have been taken to be able to roll with them any more. A belligerent bursting point has been reached. When, during the early stages of this foot and mouth outbreak, commentators announced that we were "staring into the abyss", they may also have had in mind its possible effect on rural politics.

This kind of fear is not confined to the farms and villages. In the far more sinister shadows of Whitehall, a committee within the Ministry of Agriculture is plotting the extermination of wildlife. Close down the countryside and the wild, ungovernable forces of nature will take over.

There is a strange disparity between our attitudes towards domestic animals and those to wild ones. Although livestock has been made a commodity, we feel for the distraught farmers when their herds and flocks are killed and burned. Cattle, sheep and pigs are innocent, their pathetic deaths only a consequence of our action against some terrible calamity to restore order.

Wild creatures, though, can quickly turn from treasure to threat. Deer and birds can spread the disease. It would make an ideal opportunity for those who want to wipe out feral boar from Kent. However fond society is of it, if wildlife threatens commercial interests, and especially if it is linked to disease, there will be a lobby powerful enough to destroy it.

Badgers make a good precedent. Although protected and the emblem of the Wildlife Trust movement, they are being vigorously persecuted because they are suspected of carrying bovine tuberculosis. Perhaps because the political consequences of slaughtering wildlife at this stage in the foot and mouth epidemic would be dire, proposals for mass culls have been kept quiet. However, if this were an outbreak of rabies, the guns would be blazing at anything that moved by now.

There is a very thin line between love and hate, protection and persecution. What changes one to the other is fear.

The virus is part of wildlife too, and it brings us philosophical questions about our relationship with nature and the way we live in the world. But when the pyres of slaughtered animals are still burning, who cares?

When this crisis ends, there will be something else to worry about. Underlying that worry will be the same fear about nature's capacity to do us harm and the solutions to it will be the same kind of retaliation against nature.

When our fear of nature gets the better of our fondness for it, all our cherished notions about conservation and preservation are lost. Nothing shakes us more than the indifference of natural forces and a power against which we have little defence. Standing up for nature at a time like this may be difficult but, unless we do, how else can we break the cycle of fear and retaliation which causes so much environmental destruction and human misery?

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText:
Tutu discerning
Burglars stole 30 ballet dresses from a dancewear shop in Bournemouth but left the cash till untouched.
Sunday Independent, 18.2.01 (L Peters, Cullompton)
fields.body:
Tutu discerning
Burglars stole 30 ballet dresses from a dancewear shop in Bournemouth but left the cash till untouched.
Sunday Independent, 18.2.01 (L Peters, Cullompton)

Fizzling out
A chauffeur used two £30 bottles of champagne as an extinguisher when brake fluid caught fire in his Bentley limousine at a wedding near Yarm, Cleveland.
Yorkshire Post, 12.2.01 (P Lawrie, Hull)

Spiced up
The owner of a balti house in Sheffield is charging extra if customers ask for their curries to be spicier than the standard medium hot.
Southern Evening Echo, 23.2.01 (M Hobbs, Southampton)

Water course
Tourist board officers in Chichester, Sussex, are organising sightseeing tours around the 13 miles of pipes laid last year to pump flood water from the city's streets.
Local Government First, 10.2.01 (Gilly Sweet, Shoreham)

Short cut
A barber in Bristol has installed a webcam in his shop so that customers can see how long the queue is before leaving home.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 8.2.01 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

Ticked off
A man from Peterlee, County Durham, bought a gold Rolex for his wife's birthday in an internet auction, but later discovered the £4,700 he bid was only for a photograph of the watch.
Northern Echo, 15.2.01 (V Piekosz, Northallerton)

Horns of a dilemma
Firefighters were called to separate two stags whose antlers became locked together during a fight in a field at Covehithe, Suffolk.
Liverpool Daily Post, 18.2.01 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Busk shelters
Councillors in Bradford have criticised plans to use arts grants to fund the installation of bus shelters which play songs and tell stories to waiting passengers.
Bradford Telegraph and Argus, 20.2.01 (Eunice Frail, Bradford)

Good fortune
A property developer ripping out the ceiling of a house in Torquay found a bundle of large white £5 notes -valued at about £30,000 -wrapped in a 1955 newspaper astrology chart.
Western Morning News, 15.2.01 (June Newman, Chichester)

Shall we prance?
A businesswoman in Ilkley, West Yorkshire, is producing audio tapes of dance music suitable for exercising horses.
Bradford Telegraph and Argus, 19.2.01 (Jane Thewlis, Bradford)

Mall adjustment
Kent county council's tourist guide to the area contained a map that shows open countryside where Dartford - the town with Bluewater, Europe's largest shopping mall - should be.
East Anglian Daily Times, 3.2.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Blank looks
A retired bank manager in Ampthill, Bedfordshire, is to have his home searched by TV licensing authority officials because they won't believe he got rid of his television set 20 years ago.
Bedfordshire on Sunday, 18.2.01 (Janet Walker, Kempston)

Parking offence
Social services in Oldham, Greater Manchester, have told a woman with one arm that they won't renew her parking badge because she is not disabled enough to qualify.
Manchester Evening News, 15.2.01 (Peter Tapper, Burnley)

Curfew too many
A man from Chichester, West Sussex had a home curfew placed on him because he crashed his car after stopping off at the pub on the way to his girlfriend's house, following his appearance in court on a drink-driving charge.
Chichester Observer, 8.2.01 (M Rostock, Southsea)

Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

webTitle: Scrutiny urged on benchmark regulations for care homes

fields.headline: Standard bearers
fields.standfirst: Scrutiny urged on benchmark regulations for care homes
fields.trailText: Welfare groups are calling on the government to ensure strict policing of new minimum standards for care homes for older people, due to take effect largely from April next year. The 38 standards are the first of a series of benchmarks and regulations to be published under the Care Standards Act 2000. This opening set covers all aspects of life in residential and nursing care, ranging from fulfilling social activities to dignity in death.
fields.body:
Welfare groups are calling on the government to ensure strict policing of new minimum standards for care homes for older people, due to take effect largely from April next year. The 38 standards are the first of a series of benchmarks and regulations to be published under the Care Standards Act 2000. This opening set covers all aspects of life in residential and nursing care, ranging from fulfilling social activities to dignity in death.

John Hutton, social care minister, says the standards will be seen as a landmark. "For too long there has been a lack of independence and consistency in the regulation of care homes. These minimum standards, developed following extensive consultation, will change that."

While the initiative has been broadly welcomed, groups representing older people want to see strong enforcement of the standards. Gordon Lishman, director general of charity Age Concern, says: "I sincerely hope it signifies a shift in approach and that this shift is translated down to a local level. Clearly all the new standards must be comprehensively implemented and rigorously monitored. Older people need the reassurance that, if changes are necessary, the government wil respond accordingly."

Care home standards were first set out in a consultation document, Fit for the Future?, in 1999. Controversy over proposed minimum space requirements for individual rooms was settled last year with a compromise on the basic single room minimum of 10 sq metres for existing homes. The standard will not apply until 2007 and will not be enforced where a home offers at least 9.3 sq metres and has more communal space than the stipulated minimum.

The Coalition for Quality in Care, representing more than 50 interest groups, says that while regretting the decision not to insist on 10 sq metres, it nevertheless believes that the standards will have "a major impact on improving quality of care in homes across the country". The coalition welcomes particularly the standards on staff training. From 2005, registered managers of care homes must have achieved NVQ level 4 or equivalent (or a nursing qualification where nursing care is provided) and at least 50% of other staff, excluding nurses, must have reached NVQ level 2. An approved training and development programme must be in place from next year.

fields.headline: Napster fails to satisfy court
fields.trailText: Napster, the online song swapping service, has been ordered by a US federal judge in San Francisco to remove all copyright material from its website. By David Teather.
fields.body:
Napster, the online song swapping service, has been ordered by a US federal judge in San Francisco to remove all copyright material from its website.

The online service has three days to remove the songs once the music companies suing Napster for copyright infringement provide lists of the material they want blocked. Napster is facing legal action from music publishers including Sony, EMI and Universal.

It tried to pre-empt the injunction by offering to install its own software to filter out the songs but there have been reports of problems in blocking the catalogues.

The ruling by Judge Marilyn Hall Patel also requires the music groups to make a "substantial effort" to help weed out copyright material.

The injunction is the latest twist in a battle between the music industry and Napster that has been ongoing since December 1999, when the world's five largest publishers began legal action against the online service. It has been issued ahead of a final judgement from the courts.

BMG, the music business owned by Bertelsmann, has been the only one of the big five to break ranks so far and is working on an attempt to turn Napster into a paid-for membership service. Vivendi Universal has signalled that it would be prepared to license its product to Napster if it turns into a fee-paying business.

fields.headline: Putin evades web's sticky questions
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Russia
More net news
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It was intended as a PR stunt to humanise Russia's remote leader and connect him with the worldwide web. But the private life of the man behind Vladimir Putins KGB-trained mask remained as inscrutable as ever. By Ian Traynor.
fields.body:
It was intended as a PR stunt to humanise the stiff image of Russia's remote leader and connect him with the worldwide web. But the private life of the man behind Vladimir Putins KGB-trained mask remained as inscrutable as ever.

Two supportive Russian internet newspapers and BBC Online took their laptops into the Kremlin and went through the motions of grilling Mr Putin online.

Most of the thousands of questions from all over the globe went, of course, into the ethereal waste bin.

While Mr Putin pretended to wrestle with queries about economic reform, the Russian military, the war in Chechnya, and the new US administration, "Monica L (USA)" logged off without learning the answer to her question: "How often do you cheat on your wife?"

Asked why his wife, Lyudmila, kept such a low public profile, Mr Putin shrugged: "That's our manner. Some might like it, some don't.

"I hope the Russians elected me president and not my wife. I'm very grateful she bears that cross."

The live one-hour webcast, the first by a Russian political leader, was the brainchild of the Kremlin PR guru, Gleb Pavlovsky, who recently noted that the key difference between Stalin and Putin was that the latter was elected.

The live webcast is quickly becoming the favourite medium of political leaders wary of hostile and aggressive questioning by informed journalists and anxious to appear personable, democratic and accessible to Joe Surfer.

The questions about Mr Putin's sex life were ditched, the paranoid ravings of internet conspiracy theorists got short shrift (a Hungarian wanted to know if the former KGB was stirring up trouble among Gypsies to give Budapest a bad name in western Europe).

The blunt complaints from disgruntled Russians were refused an airing, too.

The websites spent most of yesterday trailing the Putin scoop as a no-holds-barred censorship-free zone. But no mention was made of the dozens of queries about the president's 16-year career in the KGB.

In a reference to that, a German emailer asked Mr Putin what he would think if a former Gestapo officer became chancellor in the German elections next year. That one was spiked, too.

Instead, Mr Putin was tossed a bone about his interest in the arts.

He liked foreign literature, because he was inspired by a teacher at school. French films were quite good, too.

Tchaikovsky and Liszt were his favourite composers. And Romy Schneider, the tragic Viennese icon who starred as Sisi, Habsburg Vienna's last tragic empress, was his favourite actress.

webTitle: Groucho Club is on the It list

fields.headline: Groucho Club is on the It list
fields.trailText: The Groucho Club, the Soho watering hole for the would-be famous, is about to receive a hostile takeover bid from a hotels company advised by It girl Tara Palmer-Tomkinson. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
The Groucho Club, the Soho watering hole for the would-be famous, is about to receive a hostile takeover bid from a hotels company advised by It girl Tara Palmer-Tomkinson.

Zoo Hotels, owner of two fashionable hotels in west London, is raising £1m through a flotation on the Ofex market and will ask Groucho members to swap their shares in the club for stock in the hotel group.

Benjamin Fry, 31, one of the founders of the K-bar night club chain and chairman of Zoo, last year tried and failed with a cash offer for the Groucho.

Last night Mr Fry said he was hopeful his new offer, made direct to shareholders, would at least allow him to build a strategic stake in the club that counts Steve Martin, Janet Street-Porter and Lord Archer among its 315 shareholders.

"I've seen the current Groucho management miss too many opportunities and fail to deliver on too many promises. I would love to play a role in upgrading the Groucho Club and restoring it to its rightful place in the London social scene."

Mr Fry is likely to face an uphill battle after the failure of last year's cash offer. The Groucho's chairman, Tony Mackintosh, owner of 20% of the shares, has resisted takeover approaches before.

Zoo's offer of two £1 shares for every Groucho share is less than the £2.30p cash Mr Fry offered last spring.

Deloitte & Touche was appointed last year to evaluate any takeover approaches amid rumours that PR guru Matthew Freud and chocolates heir Joel Cadbury were also considering making offers.

Mr Fry wants to bring the Groucho, which has 18 bedrooms, into his hotel group and open a sister venue in Beverly Hills.

fields.headline: France Télécom sets bond record
fields.trailText: France Télécom yesterday launched the largest ever corporate bond issue, aiming to raise some $16.4bn (£11.19bn). The move will help reduce its estimated €60bn (£38bn) of debt, run up as it spent heavily on licences for the next generation of mobile phones. By Mark Milner.
fields.body:
France Télécom yesterday launched the largest ever corporate bond issue, aiming to raise some $16.4bn (£11.19bn). The move will help reduce its estimated €60bn (£38bn) of debt, run up as it spent heavily on licences for the next generation of mobile phones.

The bond issue is more than double the size initially expected with dealers suggesting that investors had been tempted because the bonds were being offered at a generous discount to existing bonds in leading telecom companies.

The deal will overtake the previous record corporate bond issue of $14.6bn from Deutsche Telekom.

As well as offering the bonds at a discount to prevailing levels in the secondary market, France Télécom is giving in vestors protection against possible downgradings of its credit ratings.

Like other big telecom companies, France Télécom, which recently floated 15% of its mobile phone operator Orange, has run up heavy debts through acquisitions and the purchase of third-generation mobile phone licences.

Although a 3G presence in leading European telecoms markets was initially seen as a must-have capability, the costs have since led investors to worry about the speed and extent to which the new services will be able to generate profits.

Share prices have taken a hammering and some companies have seen their debt rating downgraded. France Télécom, headed by Michel Bon, has seen its shares fall to less than a third of their peak a year ago. Shares in BT have fallen almost as sharply while Deutsche Telekom shares have been hit even harder.

Last month France Télécom's sale of a stake in Orange fell victim to the downturn in sentiment, the price having to be cut to ensure investor support. The sale raised just over €7bn, well below the target.

France Télécom is expected to use the proceeds from the bond issue to refinance short-term debt and bank facilities.

The issue will allow France Télécom to extend the maturity of a tranche of short-term debt. "It's prudent treasury management," according to Duncan Warwick-Champion at rating agency Standard & Poor's.

He said the decision to build in protection for investors in the event of debt being downgraded was becoming standard for the industry.

"Over the last six to nine months it is something the in vestment market has required. Given the current negative outlook in the European telecoms sector, companies which don't have credit protection measures find it hard to sell their debt."

 Britain's telecom regulator, Oftel, said yesterday it had revoked an order requiring BT to provide its call minder voice messaging service on a wholesale basis to other operators.

The order, made in 1997, meant BT had to offer its call minder products to other operators and service providers on the same terms and condi tions and at the same price as to its own business.

"Changes to BT's licence and internal procedures mean that the order is no longer required and Oftel has taken the decision to revoke it," said David Edmonds, director general of telecommunications.

fields.headline: ASA clears PlayStation advert
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A company has been given the thumbs-up to use war images to sell computer games by advertising watchdogs, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A company that used images from the first world war to sell computer games has been told it can continue to do so by the Advertising Standards Authority.

Electronic Arts prompted an ASA investigation after it used a well-known black and white photograph of German soldiers marching through Paris in an advert for a Sony PlayStation game.

The advert, which appeared in the Sun newspaper, was headlined "Medal of honour underground. Join the fight".

But the ASA ruled it was unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence and gave the advertisers clearance to use it again.

But an advert for the telephone company Eurobell has been banned after the advertiser failed to prove its claims to watchdogs.

The advert carried the headline "Conclusive proof we can save you money" above a reprinted newspaper article that compared Eurobell with its rivals.

The ASA ruled that Eurobell had not proved that all customers would save money and asked it to drop the claim.

fields.headline: E4 grabs rights to Eminem concert
fields.trailText: 8.30am: E4 and Channel 4 have bought exclusive UK rights to a live concert by US rap star Eminem, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
E4 and Channel 4 have bought exclusive UK rights to a live concert by controversial US rap star Eminem.

Eminem: Live in Concert will go out first on new digital pay-TV channel E4 at 10.30pm on April 7 and repeated on parent service Channel 4.

The 90-minute show features a performance given by Eminem in Santa Monica, California, in January.

The controversial rapper has been heavily criticised for his sexist and homophobic lyrics, though many music pundits have hailed his work as ground-breaking.

Eminem is currently awaiting trial in the US on charges of felony assault.

The concert show was sold to Channel 4 by distributor Portman Television. The PrimeEnt subsidiary will be taking the programme to MipTV in Cannes early next month.

fields.headline: TV adverts no turn-off for UK housewives
fields.trailText: 8.30am: UK housewives twice as likely to stay tuned during a commercial break than their European counterparts, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Housewives in the UK are more than twice as likely to stay tuned during a commercial break than their European counterparts, according to a report from media agency Initiative Media.

The results of a Europe-wide survey show only 10.5% of UK housewives said they would switch off during the adverts, compared with a European average of 25.2%.

And UK housewives were also nearly twice as likely to enjoy the commercials.

Just 12.7% of the continentals said they enjoyed watching adverts, compared with 23% of the Brits.

Sue Elms, managing director of Initiative Media Futures - the research arm of Initiative Media - believes lax controls on advertising in Europe have led to a feeling of advertising overload.

"The UK's relatively uncluttered advertising environment has meant housewives are not bombarded with messages and become a more attentive audience," she said.

"However, we must also give credit to the quality of our advertising creatives and their successful targeting."

But Ms Elms warned the situation could change as digital media gain a greater foothold in the UK.

Increasing the amount of commercial TV on offer would increase advertising clutter and make people more likely to switch off.

And she warned viewers may be more likely to ignore interactive adverts.

"Interactive adverts use persuasion-based tactics to boost click-through rates.

"These will drive the viewer to switch off and force advertisers to rethink their strategies," Ms Elms said.

webTitle: Library restricts net access as children surf for porn

fields.headline: Library restricts net access as children surf for porn
fields.trailText: Glasgow city council has been forced to pull the plug on all public internet access at its libraries after children were discovered gathered around PCs looking at pornographic websites.
fields.body:
Glasgow city council has been forced to pull the plug on all public internet access at its libraries after children were discovered gathered around PCs looking at pornographic websites.

The council was alerted by a concerned parent after her young child came home and said she had "seen a naked lady" at the library. Internet access has been shut down until the council can put filtering software in place.

Unlimited access has been on offer since late last year when the city's libraries disabled filtering software that was considered too restrictive. The software had blocked access to generally inoffensive sites, such as national newspapers and magazines, if they contained keywords such as "sex".

Glasgow city council has apologised and accepted full responsibility for the problem.

"We should have paid more attention to how our libraries' internet access was running. There was no filter and there should have been," a spokesman said.

New filtering software had been due for installation at the end of this month to replace the overly restrictive system. But while unlimited access was on offer, the children of Glasgow were quick to take advantage of the situation.

The problem for Glasgow's libraries is that most filtering software is a blunt instrument at best, and keeping inappropriate sites out of children's reach can also mean keeping adults away from information they want or need.

Glasgow city council is well aware of the civil liberties issues. "The words filtered by the old software could stop an adult from reading an article about sex therapy in a national newspaper, for example," said the spokesman. "It was pointless having a system in a library that was so strict."

Paola Bassanese, an analyst with internet consultancy Ovum, said most of the tools available now filter by keyword or specific internet address. To get around the restriction, sites can use code words that will sound inoffensive to a filtering system or change their URL.

"This kind of software is pretty limiting as it will filter out an innocuous site," she said. "There is no foolproof solution."

Ms Bassanese suggests that libraries could put a computer chip on library swipe cards that would tell a computer what sort of internet access you should have: filtered for the under-18s and unlimited for adults. But she admits a solution that complicated may be too expensive for a library.

Meanwhile, Glasgow city council hopes to have internet access up and running again - with new filtering software - by the end of this week. And the kids will be left to think of creative new search words to outwit the filters.

fields.bodyText: Glasgow city council has been forced to pull the plug on all public internet access at its libraries after children were discovered gathered around PCs looking at pornographic websites. The council was alerted by a concerned parent after her young child came home and said she had "seen a naked lady" at the library. Internet access has been shut down until the council can put filtering software in place. Unlimited access has been on offer since late last year when the city's libraries disabled filtering software that was considered too restrictive. The software had blocked access to generally inoffensive sites, such as national newspapers and magazines, if they contained keywords such as "sex". Glasgow city council has apologised and accepted full responsibility for the problem. "We should have paid more attention to how our libraries' internet access was running. There was no filter and there should have been," a spokesman said. New filtering software had been due for installation at the end of this month to replace the overly restrictive system. But while unlimited access was on offer, the children of Glasgow were quick to take advantage of the situation. The problem for Glasgow's libraries is that most filtering software is a blunt instrument at best, and keeping inappropriate sites out of children's reach can also mean keeping adults away from information they want or need. Glasgow city council is well aware of the civil liberties issues. "The words filtered by the old software could stop an adult from reading an article about sex therapy in a national newspaper, for example," said the spokesman. "It was pointless having a system in a library that was so strict." Paola Bassanese, an analyst with internet consultancy Ovum, said most of the tools available now filter by keyword or specific internet address. To get around the restriction, sites can use code words that will sound inoffensive to a filtering system or change their URL. "This kind of software is pretty limiting as it will filter out an innocuous site," she said. "There is no foolproof solution." Ms Bassanese suggests that libraries could put a computer chip on library swipe cards that would tell a computer what sort of internet access you should have: filtered for the under-18s and unlimited for adults. But she admits a solution that complicated may be too expensive for a library. Meanwhile, Glasgow city council hopes to have internet access up and running again - with new filtering software - by the end of this week. And the kids will be left to think of creative new search words to outwit the filters. fields.headline: Italy prepares for election war
fields.standfirst: As Italy prepares to elect a new government, the two main presidential contenders, the former mayor of Rome and Italy's biggest media magnate, wage a war of personalities, not policies, writes  Philip Willan
fields.trailText: As Italy prepares to elect a new government, the two main presidential contenders, the former mayor of Rome and Italy's biggest media magnate, wage a war of personalities, not policies, writes Philip Willan
fields.body:
President Carlo Azeglio Ciampi is expected to dissolve the Italian parliament on Friday, formally opening an election campaign that has already developed a powerful head of vitriolic steam.

The clash between Francesco Rutelli, the photogenic former mayor of Rome, and Silvio Berlusconi, the media magnate who has long had a keen professional interest in finding the most effective route to housewives' hearts, will be a battle over personalities rather than policies.

The Americanisation of Italian politics proceeds apace: two skilled communicators will seek to woo the voters of the middle ground with carefully crafted slogans and minimal programmes. For weeks, each candidate has been seeking to demonise his opponent, warning the electorate that a victory for the other man would be a disaster for Italy.

Mr Berlusconi has described the moderate Mr Rutelli as a reassuring mask concealing the sinister Stalinesque features of the unreconstructed communists who dominate the centre-left Olive Tree coalition. For Mr Rutelli, it is the media baron, a man of Napoleonic ego and blunted democratic sensibilities, who would lead the country to ruin if he were elected.

Both men may be getting their message across. According to the results of an opinion poll published on Monday, Italians are becoming increasingly disenchanted with their political leaders and the largest party to emerge from the elections, expected in May, could be that of the non-voters. More than 23 percent of those questioned said they had still not decided whom to vote for, with a concentration of perplexity among the young.

"Many young people don't know whether and what to vote," pollster Renato Mannheimer wrote in the Corriere della Sera. "The debate between the parties seems distant from them, indecipherable and uninteresting. Their indecision is the fruit of their disenchantment with politics."

In a country that used to be obsessed by politics and where it is still a legal obligation for citizens to vote, this indifference is another symptom of the creeping Americanisation of Italian politics.

For Mr Mannheimer, a significant share of the undecided are today to be found among those who cast their protest vote for the federalist Northern League in 1996. A strong showing by the League is essential if Mr Berlusconi's House of Liberties is to secure its widely anticipated election victory.

Too strong a showing, however, could leave a Berlusconi government hostage to the whims of Umberto Bossi, the Northern League's mercurial leader, whose defection brought down a Berlusconi government once before.

One of the last acts of the current parliament is expected to be a federalist reform of the Italian state, due to be voted on in the senate on Thursday. The law, which appears to satisfy some of the demands made by the league, has actually caused bitter dissension between government and opposition.

Centre-right leaders have warned that the government is setting a dangerous precedent by pushing through a reform of the constitution that does not enjoy wide bipartisan support. Mr Bossi dismissed the new law as "pseudo-federalist" and part of a plan to impose communist government on Italy via the European Union.

His verbal intemperance may not be out of place in the rough and tumble of a robust election campaign. But his bluntly expressed hostility to immigrants has drawn parallels with Austria's Jörg Haider and the possibility that Italy might be cold shouldered in Europe if the league has a significant presence in a future Berlusconi government.

It is ironic that the first elections of the new millennium should be so dominated by the phantoms of the past. Few Italians are seriously worried by the communist component of the centre-left coalition that has governed them for the last four years. But if one were to believe the rhetoric of Messrs Bossi and Berlusconi, the country is teetering on the brink of a savage Stalinist dictatorship.

For all the rattling of 20th-century skeletons, victory will go to the candidate who promises greater prosperity and lower taxes in the future with the most convincing smile. When it comes to turning on the televisual charm, the amiable Mr Rutelli looks perfectly capable of giving Mr Berlusconi a run for his money.

fields.headline: Booksellers' novel myth
fields.trailText: There is a crying need for debate on the dual status of the book as both commodity and cultural icon. Congratulations then, to Matthew Engel for skewering the myth of the independent bookshop (Bookshops are closing. Hurrah, March 6).
fields.body:
There is a crying need for debate on the dual status of the book as both commodity and cultural icon. Congratulations then, to Matthew Engel for skewering the myth of the independent bookshop (Bookshops are closing. Hurrah, March 6).

After a week in which we have seen Oprah-driven reading groups improbably hailed as creators of a "brained-up" culture, and feverish speculation by the true believers that the second coming of the Messiah (aka Tim Waterstone) is at hand, it's refreshing to read an independent commentator who has not simply swallowed the trade line.

The book world has been opened up to the same pressures as have shaken every other sector of retailing. We are moving towards a market model in which only the very large, the very isolated, and the very specialist will survive. Sometimes the truth is simple: the best bookshop is the one that stocks the book you actually want to buy.

Engel's account of his experiences with independent bookshops of poor quality is a salutary counter to the nostalgic view which the trade likes to purvey, and which, in the end, serves nobody and certainly not the customer.
Paul Bowes
Llandinam, Powys

 I was delighted to read John Sutherland's piece (G2, March 5) about the rise of reading groups. I must point out, however, that there were such groups in this country long before Oprah Winfrey and Waterstone's. At the National Women's Register we have encouraged book clubs for over 20 years and many have flourished since.

I started a group in Stoke-on-Trent nearly 20 years ago. I can date it accurately as I remember the first book we discussed was The White Hotel by DM Thomas and we have never looked back, still avidly reading and enjoying the extra dimension to be gained from discussing books among friends.
Sarah Akhtar
Stoke-on-Trent

fields.headline: Adverts are unacceptable
fields.trailText: Two full-page adverts (March 5) asking if I "find it acceptable" - presumably to fraudulently claim unemployment benefit. What I do find unacceptable is asking people to live on £55 a week.
fields.body:
Two full-page adverts (March 5) asking if I "find it acceptable" - presumably to fraudulently claim unemployment benefit. What I do find unacceptable is asking people to live on £55 a week. The instance closest to me is of someone rewarded for 37 years of continuous ill-paid work by being made redundant a year ago. He was offered no comparable work by the Jobcentre and no new skills training for almost a year. He gained one interview from his own attempts, but was, for an unknown reason, considered not suitable. On £55 a week he is excluded from most of what we would call normal social activity.

A glance at MPs' interests would reveal many with a multiplicity of incomes. I imagine most people would find that less acceptable than trying to stay afloat by earning when you can. Some may set out to live by fraud. Others just suffer injustice. It has been for him a degrading, dehumanising experience. Unacceptable.
Philip Lodge
Liverpool

 You carry two full-page advertisements that are of interest to the unemployed. This is rare, as usually the goods you advertise are beyond their means. Unfortunately, the two pages are part of a continued demonisation of the unemployed as scroungers.

Meanwhile, there is an article in Office Hours encouraging, or at least accepting, workers fiddling their expense claims. Let's be clear, it is either wrong to fiddle the system or it is not. One of the reasons suggested for fiddling expensesis that workers feel they are not paid enough. In prosperous 21st-century Britain, I have met few unemployed people who are delirious that in April their benefits rise from £52.20 to £53.05 a week.

I agree that all cheating of the system is wrong, but society is judged on how it treats its weakest. By way of comparison, I know of a local landlord who charges tenants £5 a week more than they receive in housing benefit. He never asks for this extra rent to be paid until it has built up to a sum they cannot afford. Then, at his convenience, he can evict them for non-payment whenever he desires. Now that does deserve a national campaign.
Cllr Peter Jenks
Southampton

 Oh sure, the DSS will protest that they are aiming at those who defraud the system. What they won't mention is the number of claimants who are themselves defrauded by the system: claimants who are deprived of their rightful dues by officersencouraged to avoid mentioning benefits that might be available; claimants driven to distraction by DSS employees who have had little or no training; claimants who don't get their housing benefits because computer systems don't work.

When the DSS acts fairly to everybody who walks through their doors; when the DSS gets a computer system where each department talks to each other; when files don't go missing on a regular basis; then they will have a right to talk about benefit fraud. The real fraud is the amount of money that must have been spent on this unsavoury propaganda.
Andrew Dunkley
London

 Having seen the ads, I had a look at the website. It's chilling stuff. There will be plenty of scope for every bigot under the sun to indulge in a little malicious reporting. I cannot help drawing comparisons with countries where citizens were, or are, encouraged in similar activities. Why not take this idea to its logical conclusion and encourage schoolchildren to report their parents?
Ian Nicol
Weymouth, Dorset
iannicol@talk21.com

webTitle: Letters: A campaign is called for

fields.headline: A campaign is called for
fields.trailText: How I agree with Usha Kar (Letters, March 2) drawing attention to the dangers of level crossings. In the village of Mellis near here, only seconds after the half-width barriers come down, the London-Norwich trains thunder through at 100mph and more.
fields.body:
How I agree with Usha Kar (Letters, March 2) drawing attention to the dangers of level crossings. In the village of Mellis near here, only seconds after the half-width barriers come down, the London-Norwich trains thunder through at 100mph and more. There are no CCTV cameras to show the signalman if the crossing is clear. A concerted Guardian campaign is called for.
Stephen Schwarz
Eye, Suffolk
expression@netmatters.co.uk

 One presumes Robert Mugabe will cite Peter Tatchell's attempted arrest (Mugabe men beat up Tatchell, March 6) as a further example of the gay mafia he perceives to be running Britain. Was the assault on Mr Tatchell an indication of the heterosexual mafia running Zimbabwe? If so, then God Save the Queens.
Steve Taylor
Ilford, Essex

 I nearly wept for those miserable-looking, starving refugees from Milan (Faces of fashion, March 6). Surely the Home Office must be compassionate and offer them a good meal and a visit to the nearest hairdresser at the least. On which beach were they found?
Alastair Black
Ventnor, Isle of Wight

 As Fritz Spiegl knows (Letters, March 5), we scice of a certain age refer to our partner as miaowlgerl - undoubtedly a literal translation into feline of the canine female, with perhaps a touch of Bristol in the pronunciation.
Joe Doyle
York

 Before Fritz Spiegl's time the term for girlfriend or wife was Judy, as in: "I'm taking me Judy to the ossy" (hospital).
Marie Giddings
Poole, Dorset

 And in Dublin the girlfriend is called a mott (until married, after which she is known as the owl' mott).
Brian Lynch
Attleborough, Norfolk

webTitle: Anger as Pavlova's ashes leave London for Moscow

fields.headline: Anger as Pavlova's ashes leave London for Moscow
fields.standfirst:
St Petersburg arts elite sees plot to hijack its most famous dancer
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: St Petersburg arts elite sees plot to hijack its most famous dancer.
fields.body:
Plans for Anna Pavlova's ashes to be moved in triumph to Russia next week have been soured by the demand of her relatives and Russia's cultural elite that they should be left in peace in Golders Green crematorium in north London.

Two marble urns containing her remains and those of her husband will be removed from the shelf in the crematorium where they have stood for more than half a century and flown as cabin luggage to Moscow.

Next Wednesday they will be interred in a tomb in Moscow's most famous cemetery, the Novodevichy, alongside the graves of the writer Anton Chekhov, former president Nikita Khrushchev and the composer Sergei Prokofiev.

Invitations to the ceremony have been sent to stars of Moscow ballet. But the occasion has become the cause of bitter complaints from the dancer's family and firm disapproval from the ministry of culture.

"We can't understand why her remains are being disturbed, or who stands to benefit from the ashes going to Moscow," her niece Valentina Trifonova said yesterday.

"In the name of all the ballerina's surviving relatives, I'd like to request that she be left in peace."

Her disapproval echoed the concern voiced by the Russian culture minister, Mikhail Shvydkoy, who said the ministry had "grave doubts about the organisations which have initiated the burial of this great ballerina's remains".

"It is better not to touch people's ashes unless their express desire otherwise has been registered," he said last week.

"The people who have prompted this campaign refer to her last wishes but cannot produce any evidence that this is what she wanted.

Moreover her husband, Victor Dandre, made no plans for a posthumous journey to Russia. Therefore the legitimacy of such a burial is dubious in the extreme."

The long battle over Pavlova's ashes has been complicated by the lack of a will detailing her own wishes. After making her name on the stage of the Mariinsky theatre in her home town, St Petersburg, she left Russia in 1914 with her husband and manager and settled in London, where she lived happily until her sudden death in 1931, during a visit to the Hague.

The urn containing her ashes was placed in the Golders Green crematorium, near her London home. Her husband later stipulated in his will that if a serious request was ever made in Russia for her ashes to be moved there, then the crematorium caretakers should agree to it.

Behind the campaign for the ashes' removal is Valentina Zhilenkova, a passionate admirer of the ballerina and director of the Anna Pavlova Foundation of Mercy, a charity devoted largely to securing the remains for Russia.

Backed by Moscow's mayor, Yury Luzhkov, she has been negotiating with crematorium officials since the early 1990s. A spokesman for the crematorium said it had acceded "with sadness" to Ms Zhilenkova's request, because it felt this was appropriate.

Opposition has increased as the plans for the reburial have been revealed. The opposition in the St Petersburg ballet community has been particularly intense. Leonid Nadirov, the director of the ballet school from which Pavlova graduated in 1899, has written to President Vladimir Putin, appealing to him to put a stop to the burial.

The project had "raised grave concerns in St Petersburg's cultural establishment", he said; if there was a real desire to have her ashes returned home, it made no sense to bury her in Moscow - a city for which she had little affection.

Throughout her career, Pavlova danced only once at the Bolshoi theatre in the capital. He proposed placing the remains in the small St Petersburg graveyard where the dancer's mother is buried.

"There has always been a spirit of cultural competitiveness between Moscow and St Petersburg," Ms Zhilenkova retorted. "The Bolshoi theatre has a history of poaching the greatest dancers from St Petersburg and a lot of bitterness remains. I think that explains much of this protest.

"In any case, the city has done nothing to honour the memory of this wonderful dancer.

Pavlova was too ill to think about her final resting place when she was struck down by pleurisy in Holland. Her last words were said to be: "Prepare me my swan costume."
