Her last words were said to be: "Prepare me my swan costume."

fields.headline: Preaching to the converts
fields.trailText: There is nothing remarkable about Kenneth O'Donnell's assertion that President John F Kennedy intended to withdraw American forces from Vietnam after his reelection (News focus, March 3).
fields.body:
There is nothing remarkable about Kenneth O'Donnell's assertion that President John F Kennedy intended to withdraw American forces from Vietnam after his reelection (News focus, March 3). This is reported in the Pentagon Papers and was confirmed for me by Arthur Schlesinger. What is interesting is O'Donnell's account of how Kennedy planned his withdrawal.

In 1970, O'Donnell alleged that Kennedy told him he intended to install a leader in Saigon who would "ask us to leave". In early November 1963, Ngo Dinh Diem was overthrown in a US-supported coup led by General "Big" Minh. Before Minh had a chance to develop any policies, he was removed from power, with the approval of the new Johnson government, on the grounds that he was a "neutralist", ie someone who might "ask us to leave". When North Vietnamese forces encircled Saigon, guess who was hauled out of retirement to head an interim government and negotiate the best terms?
BJ Burden
Braintree, Essex

 It is ironic that, in attempting to protest against the Americanisation of British culture, the Manic Street Preachers should force western rock on Cuba (Our Manics in Havana, Friday Review, March 3). Cuba is a country with one of the richest musical cultures in the world.

The son, mambo, rumba, conga, guaguanco, cha-cha-cha all originated in Cuba, before becoming what we now know as salsa.

Had the group made more effort to find out about the country, they might have had second thoughts about using Cuba as a cheap marketing exercise.
Chris Barclay
London

fields.headline: We nerds
fields.trailText: I suffered years of daily bullying at school and can understand why someone would want revenge (Two killed by smiling student gunman, March 6).
fields.body:
I suffered years of daily bullying at school and can understand why someone would want revenge (Two killed by smiling student gunman, March 6). Such acts of violence cannot be condoned, but why are we surprised if the "nerds" of this world crack and hit back?
Julie Travis
London

 How brave of President Bush to call the murders an "act of cowardice". How likely is it that constantly being called a wimp led to yet another kid with problems seeking, and finding, guns?
Dr Mark Lewney
Cardiff
Mark.Lewney@patent.gov.uk

 Surely Bush's not introducing gun control legislation to stop these tragedies happening is the "disgraceful act of cowardice".
Tim Watson
Leeds

fields.trailText: I waited with bated breath, but I am pleased to see Mr Little's cruel nursery rhyme jokes at the expense of communities hit by foot and mouth disease has not triggered an avalanche of of imitations (Letters, March 5).
fields.body:
I waited with bated breath, but I am pleased to see Mr Little's cruel nursery rhyme jokes at the expense of communities hit by foot and mouth disease has not triggered an avalanche of of imitations (Letters, March 5). "Old Macdonald had a Pyre" is not funny in our neck of the woods. I note that your correspondent hails from Lytham St Annes. I bet he wouldn't be amused if a huge tsunami crashed down on the Fylde coastline.
Terry Jones
Warwick Bridge, Cumbria

fields.headline: Stamp on it
fields.trailText: You report (Unions give postal vote pledge, March 6) that electors will be able to "demand a postal vote from their local council". There's no need for anyone to get quite so shirty; electors just need to ask for one and we'll send it.
fields.body:
You report (Unions give postal vote pledge, March 6) that electors will be able to "demand a postal vote from their local council". There's no need for anyone to get quite so shirty; electors just need to ask for one and we'll send it.

You also say that unions will help Labour "exploit new laws ..." There is no exploitation necessary here; the new laws have been brought in to make postal voting easier, that's all. Unions - or any other organisation - are perfectly free to help their members push for the dictatorship of the proletariat ... sorry, to use this new facility to make voting easier.
Tony Miller
Brighton & Hove city council

fields.headline: Turning on Turner
fields.trailText: How depressing it is that the Tate's commemoration of the 150th anniversary of Turner's death is prefaced by that old excuse - that Turner, too, maltreated his works - for its own failure to live up to the potential of his bequest (Home from home with Turner, March 5).
fields.body:
How depressing it is that the Tate's commemoration of the 150th anniversary of Turner's death is prefaced by that old excuse - that Turner, too, maltreated his works - for its own failure to live up to the potential of his bequest (Home from home with Turner, March 5).

Amusingly Turner is nevertheless now portrayed by the Tate as having had better ideas for the background to his pictures than it has had. Ever since the Clore Gallery was planned, an element at the Tate has wanted to change this notable late 20th-century building into a Victorian one. Is that not philistine? Is it sensible? In its size, plan, situation and integral style, the Clore is fundamentally unsuited to the Turners, but could provide congenial space to some of the hundreds of other Tate works in store. Would it not be better to turn it over to those and erect a Turner gallery that needs no excuses?

Meanwhile, excuses are what we have had from the Royal Academy for the casual way it has treated the one-sixth of Turner's fortune, which it received. The Turner Medal has been expunged from its schools' prospectus, and was only awarded last week after persistent complaints. Whereas Turner wanted to encourage landscape painting, the latest winner is a printmaker, and has been given a medal bearing Michelangelo's effigy.

The message from both the RA and Tate seems to be that Turner's wishes only merit a token nod.
Dr Selby Whittingham
London

fields.headline: Biotech chief quits
fields.trailText: Confidence in the hi-tech healthcare company Biocompatibles is likely to be shaken by the departure of finance director Julian Steadman, which is to be announced within the next week.
fields.body:
Confidence in the hi-tech healthcare company Biocompatibles is likely to be shaken by the departure of finance director Julian Steadman, which is to be announced within the next week.

Biocompatibles has developed a special coating which replicates the body's natural fluids and is used to make contact lenses and coronary stents more comfortable.

One industry source said Mr Steadman had fallen out with chief executive Crispin Simon, a former Smith & Nephew executive who was appointed two years ago and has helped revive Biocompatibles' prospects. There were said to be differences over the firm's strategic direction.

Others said Mr Steadman was merely leaving because he wanted to manage a businesss rather than merely look after the finance side.

Biocompatibles' shares have been weak over the past year, slipping from a peak of 590p to 285p, valuing the company at just over £400m. Mr Steadman, who earned £151,000 in 1999, has been with the company since January 1997.

Neither Mr Steadman nor the company would comment yesterday. Biocompatibles has had a busy period. It won approval in September for a US launch of its specially coated stents - tiny pieces of scaffolding that hold open damaged arteries.

The company became Britain's-second biggest maker of contact lenses by buying rival Hydron for £38m. But Hydron's main factory, in Farnborough, was hit by a fire last month which required part of its operations to be shut down.

Biocompatibles is due to report full-year results imminently. They are expected to show its first ever profit, of just over £1m. The company has a chequered past: investors fled after the collapse of a large-scale marketing deal with Johnson & Johnson in 1997.

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: 'Hello, Khmer Rouge. How can I help you?'
fields.trailText: 'Hello, Khmer Rouge. How can I help you?'
fields.body:
Some time ago on the Today programme we interviewed the London representative of the Shining Path terrorist group, those Maoist psychopaths from Peru.

At the time, they were big news and had recently pulled off something spectacularly deranged, even by their standards. They'd strapped explosives to a young teacher and blown her up in front of her pupils - a course of action with which even Chris Woodhead might take issue.

Anyway, the man turned up for his interview and was subjected to fairly rigorous question ing. When asked about the appropriateness of political terror in general, he conceded that he thought Joseph Stalin had "gone a bit far". And so the interview ended.

The next day he called back, demanding to be put on air to issue a statement of clarification. Stalin had definitely not gone a bit far. Rather, he'd "gone about far enough".

The truly berserk do not appear on the Today programme often enough for my liking. Just occasionally, they provide a pleasing counterpoint to interviews with Andrew Lansley or Stephen Byers. But there are always problems. The more paranoid and disturbed the individuals, the more difficult they are about things like turning up at the BBC or giving out their phone numbers.

Terrorists are particularly tricky. We got through to the Khmer Rouge once, at the height of their terror campaign. We rang a number in Cambodia and a man answered and said: "Hello, Khmer Rouge. How can I help you?" So we asked if there was anyone available for interview and the man said "Um... no, they're all out at lunch."

And sometimes we lack an awareness of local sensitivities, as in the case of The World Tonight producer who, using the stock question to check an interviewee's voice for sound level, asked the hunger striker what he'd had for breakfast that morning.

I mention all this because we've been trying to get the Real IRA on the phone for the last few days, but they haven't returned any of our calls. They're more elusive than Keith Vaz, which is a shame. There's still debris around Television Centre, yards of red and white tape, boarded up windows and scores of policemen poking things and, frankly, we want to help.

Maybe we've uncovered a clue already. Last Friday, Sue MacGregor used the Today message board to complain about the catering that morning. "There was cold toast and none of the cereal anyone asks for," she wrote in her email before concluding, "can somebody please put a bomb under these people?"

Warning to all: don't mess with Sue MacGregor.

 Rod Liddle is editor of BBC Radio 4's Today programme. His column appears every Wednesday

fields.headline: Sharon's 'guard dog' bares his teeth
fields.standfirst:
Minister in new cabinet wants all Palestinians expelled

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Rechavam Ze'evi, who takes his place in Ariel Sharon's cabinet today, looked out of his office in the parliament building on to a glorious view of the hills coming alive with spring - and saw Arab armies at the gate.
fields.body:
Rechavam Ze'evi, who takes his place in Ariel Sharon's cabinet today, looked out of his office in the parliament building on to a glorious view of the hills coming alive with spring - and saw Arab armies at the gate.

"You can't defend Jerusalem from the hills. If a war was to start on the initiation of the Arabs, in three hours we would have to fight right here in the knesset," he said. "In four hours we would have to fight in Tel Aviv."

Mr Ze'evi's elevation to the cabinet has caused shivers in Israel. The former major-general, who is 74, wants the 3m Palestinians expelled from the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

He considers Jordan part of Israel's birthright, and thinks that Israel's 1m Arab citizens should not be allowed to vote, because they do not serve in the army. The incoming tourist minister, he believes visitors to Israel must speak Hebrew.

Mr Sharon told the knesset yesterday that he had formed a coalition and was ready to be sworn in today.

Labour doves say Mr Ze'evi's membership of the coalition is a "nightmare", and that Shimon Peres dirtied his Nobel peace prize by agreeing to serve in the same government.

Labour's left wing is also dismayed by the naming of Avigdor Lieberman as infrastructure minister. The leader of a Russian immigrants' party, Mr Lieberman has called for Israel to bomb Egypt's Aswan dam.

Mr Ze'evi, who founded the Moledet (homeland) party, seems flattered by the uproar. "If they want to call me an extremist, I am an extremist," he said. "It doesn't bother me."

But he has his own misgivings, suspecting that Mr Sharon will back down from his promise to hang on to every Jewish settlement in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

Describing himself as the prime ministerial "guard dog", Mr Ze'evi will push for the invasion of Palestinian-ruled towns to end the uprising.

To him, the hills outside his office are not just part of the West Bank which the Palestinians want for their state: they are the high ground from which the armies of Iraq, Syria and Libya would invade and wipe Israel off the map.

He wants to cleanse the West Bank of Palestinians. "The Arabs living in the West Bank and Gaza have to be transferred to their forefather's land," he said, adding that most Palestinians arrived as migrants during the last century. In the meantime he would "encourage" emigration by banning Palestinians from working in Israel and closing factories and universities in the West Bank.

He also wants Israel to lay claim to the kingdom of Jordan. "It's ours historically. Three of the tribes of Israel - Gad, Reuven, and Menashe, lived in what is now Jordan."

But those are long-term plans. For the immediate future he has been drawing up battle scenarios for the new prime minister, and has joined Mr Lieberman in demanding assurances that Mr Sharon will invade the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

He has also presented Mr Sharon with a plan to stop Palestinian gunmen on the edges of Ramallah from firing on the Jewish settlement of Psagot. "We move in and level the first row of houses," he said. "I can guarantee you that the people in the second row of houses will make sure nobody shoots from there again."

He also wants the army to unleash attack dogs on Palestinian demonstrators.

"We have to find the three of four weak places of the Palestinian Authority and press there, and they will crawl to us asking us to stop it," he said.

The military wing of Hamas claimed responsibility yesterday for the suicide bomb attack that killed three Israelis in Netanya on Sunday.

webTitle: Beijing tells US not to arm Taiwan

fields.headline: Beijing tells US not to arm Taiwan
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText: The Chinese foreign minister singled out US plans to sell advanced weapons to Taiwan yesterday as a test of the Bush administration's intentions in the region.
fields.body:
The Chinese foreign minister singled out US plans to sell advanced weapons to Taiwan yesterday as a test of the Bush administration's intentions in the region.

"The US should come to a recognition of the serious dangers involved," Tang Jiaxuan told a news conference held on the second day of the national people's congress in Beijing.

Mr Tang drew attention to the possible sale of sophisticated US seaborne and land-based radar and air defence systems, for which Taiwan has been lobbying.

"If the US side continues to fail to honour its commitment on the Taiwan question and insists on selling advanced weapons to Taiwan, including particularly the Aegis missile destroyers and the Patriot anti-missile defence system, that would send a very wrong signal to the Taiwan authorities," he said.

Departing from his normal flat diplomatic delivery, Mr Tang said that the US should "rein in its wild horse right on the edge of the precipice".

The issue is likely to become critical during a visit to the US later this month by the Chinese vice-premier, Qian Qichen, who oversees foreign policy. President Bush must decide on the Taiwanese request next month.

China also announced yesterday a substantial increase in its military budget - up by 17.7% on last year's figure to a total of 141bn yuan (£11.6bn).

The minister of finance, Xiang Huaicheng, said the increase was needed to increase the pay of army personnel, to "adapt to drastic changes in the military situation of the world", and to cope with the demands of "modern technology [and] especially high technology".

Mr Tang denied that this had anything to do with the Bush administration's enthusiasm for a national missile defence shield, but he acknowledged the need to "modernise our national defence system".

Most foreign analysts believe that the declared military budget excludes important items, but the latest figure may be a shift towards greater clarity.

Mr Tang said that since Mr Bush's inauguration the two countries' top leaders had "always kept in touch".

However, Mr Bush, as far as is known, has not made direct contact yet with President Jiang Zemin.

webTitle: Take five: the daily news quiz

fields.headline: Take five: the daily news quiz
fields.trailText: Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders
fields.body:
Each weekday, we set five questions based on the news. Send in all 25 at the end of the week. The first correct entry out of the hat wins a £100 electronic gift card from Borders (www.bordersstores.com).

C1 Deliberate faults to prevent plagiarism of Ordnance Survey maps include:

(a) An extra stream tributary

(b) An excess of oxbow lakes

(c) Missing apostrophes

(d) Imaginary farm buildings

C2 New maps designed for women contain

(a) fewer cartographic symbols

(b) smaller pages for ladies' tiny hands

(c) more flowers

(d) all roads in pink

C3 Which of the following is not a Chris Rea song?

(a) The Road To Hell

(b) Girl In A Sports Car

(c) Yes, It's Another Song About Roads

(d) Driving Home For Christmas

C4 How many branches of the Little Chef are there in the UK?

(a) 430

(b) Almost as many as Starbucks

(c) Not nearly enough

(d) You mean they actually still exist?

C5 I spy with my little eye, something beginning with "M"

(a) Motorway

(b) Map

(c) Mercedes

(d) Mummy

Entries must reach Take Five, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER by Wednesday March 14. The winner will be notified by March 23. One entry per person. No purchase necessary. The daily online news quiz is at www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/quiz

C1 Deliberate faults to prevent plagiarism of Ordnance Survey maps include: (a) An extra stream tributary (b) An excess of oxbow lakes (c) Missing apostrophes (d) Imaginary farm buildings C2 New maps designed for women contain (a) fewer cartographic symbols (b) smaller pages for ladies' tiny hands (c) more flowers (d) all roads in pink C3 Which of the following is not a Chris Rea song? (a) The Road To Hell (b) Girl In A Sports Car (c) Yes, It's Another Song About Roads (d) Driving Home For Christmas C4 How many branches of the Little Chef are there in the UK? (a) 430 (b) Almost as many as Starbucks (c) Not nearly enough (d) You mean they actually still exist? fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: Thinking Allowed | Performance On 3 - Richter Night | Kirsty MacColl's Cuba
fields.body:
An enterprising sports equipment firm, hoping to cash in on the widening popularity of golf, introduced a new range of low-priced clubs. It hardly sold any: they broke the game's inviolable rule that aura beats utility. A Golf World survey found the sport riddled with sexism, racism, and class prejudice. In Thinking Allowed (4.0pm, Radio 4) Laurie Taylor asks Will Hutton, a recent convert to the game, why it remains so out of tune with the times.

When Sviatoslav Richter died in 1997 at the age of 82, he had given some 4,000 public performances, averaging two a week, throughout his long career. The Russian pianist had a repertoire unmatched by any of his contemporaries. As host of Performance On 3 - Richter Night (7.30pm, Radio 3), Sir John Drummond recalls his genius. Four hours of recordings are interspersed with his friends' reminiscences.

It's an idle historical speculation but one wonders how events might have turned out had two musicians from Mali not had passport problems in March 1996. They were supposed to take part in a recording session organised by World Circuit Records in Havana. When they failed to turn up, a group of local musicians were pressed into service. And so was born the Buena Vista Social Club. The tracks cut that day roared into the charts all over the world. Their continuing impact is explored in Kirsty MacColl's Cuba (10.0pm, Radio 2).

fields.headline: TV pick of the day
fields.trailText: Fantastic Voyage | Live cricket
fields.body:
Films

Fantastic Voyage (Richard Fleischer, 1966) 12noon, 6pm, Sky Cinema Perky sci-fi adventure with an intrepid team and their submarine shrunk to almost nothing in order to operate from the inside on a comatose defecting scientist. Many hazards to negotiate in the journey's one-hour time limit: the attack of the white corpuscles, inner-ear storms, and a saboteur.

Working Girl (Mike Nichols, 1988) 8pm, Sky Cinema Witty, very deft romantic comedy with its heart firmly in the 30s. Melanie Griffith is the secretary trying to go places in the company, but she is being exploited by imperious corporate woman, Sigourney Weaver. Harrison Ford is the other point in the triangle, shifting allegiance from Weaver to Griffith: but the women are very much the bosses. Kevin Wade's script sparkles and there's hilarious comic support from Joan Cusack's secretary.

Quiz Show (Robert Redford, 1994) 9pm, 1.40am, UK Drama The true story of a notorious 1950s quiz-show cheat. Ralph Fiennes stars as the handsome, intelligent Charles Van Doren, who is the ideal leading man for NBC's mega quiz show, Twenty-One; so the bosses fix it for him to win. Every week. Until he is inevitably found out and sacrificed. It's superbly acted: the contrast between Martin Scorsese's mean-spleened corporate man and the hurt of Paul Scofield as upright Van Doren Senior epitomises the betrayal of trust.

The X Files (Rob Bowman, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier Bowman, a veteran director of the TV series, dumps agents Mulder (David Duchovny) and Scully (Gillian Anderson) into a dense but pleasantly familiar plot involving alien bodysnatchers and dodgy characters in smoke-filled rooms. There are impressive special effects and Martin Landau's manic conspiracy theorist stokes up the spooky atmosphere. The main problem is the uncertain tone: there's an uncomfortable shift from secret-agent heroics to alien horrors, and the biggest thrill concerns the pair's will-they-won't-they romance.

Arizona Dream (Emir Kusturica, 1993) 11pm, The Studio Shambolic, surreal comedy from the director of Time Of The Gypsies, who attempts to turn a similarly bemused outsider's eye on an alien community, in this case, America. Johnny Depp plays the young man who gives up his job counting fish (gulp) to attend Uncle Jerry Lewis's wedding, encountering a refreshingly barmy Faye Dunaway and her daughter (Lili Taylor) on the way. The journey across the MidWest was apparently inspired by Jack Kerouac's travels: both Kusturica and Depp were much taken with On The Road at the time.

Sport

Live cricket 4.15am & 7am, Sky Sports 2 The first Test was pretty painful for the English tourists, losing to Sri Lanka by an innings. There were, however, some rather questionable umpiring decisions along the way and, given a more even playing field, the English should at least improve on that performance in the second Test, which started this morning and continues for, well, at least a couple of days.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: Silent as the grave
fields.trailText: Silent as the grave
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Snow, driven down by a bitter north wind, dusted over the whole landscape the weekend before last. On a cold, crystal-bright morning with big blue skies, the sun appeared above the Edge for the first time since mid-November. It was a real cracker of a day, but a sense of unease was building. "If you live in the towns, stay out of the country. If you live in the country, don't come in to town", warned the newspapers. As if the countryside were not paranoid enough, along comes the spectre of foot and mouth disease. The reappearance of this virus, a strange and beautiful being, as illustrated in the Guardian, was striking into that well of fearfulness which seethes just below the surface of rural Britain. The 60s epidemic of foot and mouth began in Shropshire and it remains a powerful memory; an old wound is being reopened. The paths were eerily quiet.

On such a wonderful morning you might have expected to meet people out rambling, walking the dog or generally wandering about enjoying the snow and winter sunshine. But there was no one. I began to feel a twinge of guilt for just being there, a few yards from my house. This weekend, as the crisis unfolds, the countryside has virtually closed down. Avoiding any paths near farmland, I sneak into the woods like a fugitive. At times like this the only sensible thing to do is something rash. That's why I'm up this tree. Shinning up a young lime, with easy branches tipped with blood-red buds, I'm up in the high tree canopy of the Edge here. The landscape rolls out, pale green and dark wooded to the far snowfields on the mountains of the western rim. It may look beautiful but it's very tense and quiet. Is this the start of a silent spring?

fields.headline: Hopelessly devoted
fields.standfirst: If your favourite rock star died young, how would you mourn them? Buy their house? Wear their clothes? Weep at a payphone they once used? Tim Cumming on fans and fanaticism
fields.trailText: If your favourite rock star died young, how would you mourn them? Buy their house? Wear their clothes? Weep at a payphone they once used? Tim Cumming on fans and fanaticism.
fields.body:
A lot of people can remember exactly where they were when they heard that Elvis Presley had died, in the same way that old rockers like Keith Richards remember hearing Heartbreak Hotel for the first time. His beginning and his end had that kind of impact. Whereas rock's dried-out survivors circle the globe like Flying Dutchmen, dead Elvis represents something more pure than the persistence of survivors. However far he was perceived to have fallen by the end of his life, people in their tens of thousands descended on Graceland when he died. He and his kind represent for us the voice of eternal youth, our own stab at immortality.

A quarter of a century after his death, Elvis is a sort of godhead. He has legends of resurrection, and a worldwide following for whom tales of the star's excess mean little. He is the King, and he is everyman: last year, 30,000 fans gathered for a candlelit vigil at Graceland on the anniversary of his death.

Guy Gilbert, who filmed the gathering, came across his first rock shrine at Le Père Lachaise cemetery in Paris on Bastille Day 1992, when Jim Morrison's grave played host to an orgy of liberation that would have rivalled anything going down at Whisky A-Go-Go in 1967, where the Doors first entered rock legend. Morrison's final resting place has been a rock'n'roll shrine for years now, signposted from gate to graveside. Go there, and you may meet the man in Gilbert's film, handing out joints. He's there every day, and so are the fans, the diehards, the ones for whom the music is not enough, who make the pilgrimage.

Gilbert documented 17 rock shrines in Britain and the US, interviewing fans, friends and family, including Jeff Buckley's mother and Rolan Bolan, Marc's son, at the tree shrine where his father fatally crashed his car. The shrines - of musicians from Buddy Holly to Biggie Smalls - and the fans who tend them are as strange as anything in rock. Gilbert's programme is about the audience as much as the star, and explores the sense of identification and belief that made rock singers into legends in the first place.

These fans are a gentler breed than the celebrity stalkers of the living. Although a few do skirt the edges of parody at times, they reveal more clearly than any conventional star biography why rock music can mean so much, and also how far from normality it can take you. A middle-aged fan in the Marc Bolan film reveals how his marriage ended because of his obsession, but what brings tears to his eyes is his inability, still, to make sense of his idol's death. "Twenty-nine years old? My idol, my pop star who I followed, dead in a car crash?" He stares at the camera unblinking, wet-eyed. "No, I couldn't accept it . . ."

In one of the most haunting films of the series, we witness Nick Drake's fans gathering at the churchyard of St Mary Magdalene in Tanworth in Arden, near Birmingham. Gilbert was warned by the vicar there that many of them, like Nick, simply wouldn't talk. No footage survives of Drake, and its absence makes the film about him all the more poignant. All that remains are the recordings, and the truism that those who knew him feel that they never knew him, and those who only have his songs feel they know him intimately.

There's one Nick Drake fan I know of, who actually owns a pair of his trousers. She says they have a stain on the fly. Someone else I know of wears a pair of Ian Curtis's shoes on the anniversary of his death. That is possibly one step too far, but some people can never go far enough. In the film about Jeff Buckley, the fan who moved herself into Buckley's last home in Memphis declines to discuss the experience of dwelling in her idol's shadow, and refers to his house as "my healing process" before disappearing behind her - or is it his? - screen door. One wonders whose life she is really living. One wonders, too, about the Michael Hutchence fan who said she loved him, even in death, more than her own children.

Some stars you'd expect to have a shrine don't. Gilbert wanted to make films on Otis Redding, Marvin Gaye and Janis Joplin, but for these and others there simply wasn't a focal point. Sid Vicious's ashes were dropped accidentally on the runway at Heathrow, and the nearest Brian Jones of the Rolling Stones has to a shrine are the 320 blue ceramic tiles on sale from the swimming pool in which he drowned in 1969. As for Bob Marley, the village in which he was born is as poor as it ever was. When Gilbert filmed there for the first series of Rock Shrines, his guide pointed out an old man working the next field. It was Marley's uncle.

Rock music has always inspired a religious kind of devotion. When rock'n'roll was young it was the devil's music, a revolution in a century of revolutions. Now speed metal sells instant coffee, but when the young Elvis sang in the studio corridor to capture the echo, it was an underworld journey, forbidden fruit, a Promethean fire. People's lives were changed. Which is why the living dead of rock'n'roll refuse to die in the hearts of their fans.

And if they have to travel to the ends of the earth, as Buddy Holly fans do, every February, to Clear Lake, Iowa, to lay flowers at the remote, freezing spot where his plane crashed, then they go and do it. In the Holly film, an Elvis lookalike dances in the Surf Ballroom, site of Holly's last gig, as a Buddy impersonator belts it out on stage, and out of the crowd stands Buddy's last drummer, Carl Bush, back in Clear Lake for the first time after 41 years. "That telephone over there," he points, "was the last thing they used to call home to say goodbye to their loved ones." There's a plaque over the payphone. "It's a, it really is kind of hard," stammers Bush, "to breathe, sometimes, for me here . . ."

Rock stars, especially dead rock stars, get into our hearts in the way that no film or sports star ever can. Why, exactly, is hard to put into words. And perhaps that's the point. "People think we're daft," says one fan, "but that's just how we feel." There are the obvious reasons - how certain songs become your life's soundtrack, as if they were sung for you alone, and almost everyone Gilbert spoke to said that they felt it "like a brother" when their hero died. But there are no obvious reasons for the Elvis cult as it stands today, or for there to be a shrine for Bolan 24 years after he died. That's rock'n'roll. For non-believers it is one final absurdity. But for the Elvis fans mingling at the gates of Graceland, their suddenly uncomprehending eyes blinded by tears, what they feel is, I think, the most basic of emotions - grief for what has passed and what can never return. And what they hear in the music of their idol is a voice from the burning bush, something ancient and eternal. With the songs as their guide, the faithful come to pay homage to keep themselves young and their dreams alive.

Who knows whether their shrines will survive them? But in an age when rock music is increasingly an exercise in nostalgia, its diehard believers are among us to ensure their heroes will live on as long as they too are alive.

 Rock Shrines is on BBC Choice on Thursdays at 7.45pm, and on BBC2 later this spring.

fields.headline: Dublin rules out world cross-country
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Dublin has lost this month's world cross-country championships, the latest victim of precautions against the spread of foot and mouth disease. The event was switched yesterday to Brussels.
fields.body:
Dublin has lost this month's world cross-country championships, the latest victim of precautions against the spread of foot and mouth disease. The event was switched yesterday to Brussels.

The championships, originally scheduled for the Leopardstown racecourse, will go ahead in Belgium on March 24 and 25. The cancellation is expected to cost the Irish Athletic Association and the city more than £3m in outlay and lost revenue.

However, ice hockey's Super League rejected calls yesterday by the Northern Ireland government to call off Saturday's Challenge Cup final between Sheffield and Ayr in Belfast.

The league insisted it takes its instructions from the ministry of agriculture in London, and Super League's chief executive Ian Taylor added: "The final will go ahead unless the UK government agency tells us it shouldn't." But Brid Rodgers, the agriculture minister in Belfast, said she has the power to ban the final.

The crisis has wiped out all football fixtures in Ireland for a second successive weekend and the Republic's World Cup qualifier in Cyprus on March 24 is also under threat.

fields.headline: Informa rejects news of downturn
fields.trailText: Informa Group, the events organiser and business publisher, yesterday offered anecdotal evidence that the downturn in the media and telecoms markets may not be as sharp as some investors fear.
fields.body:
Informa Group, the events organiser and business publisher, yesterday offered anecdotal evidence that the downturn in the media and telecoms markets may not be as sharp as some investors fear.

GSM World Congress, the company's flagship exhibition aimed at the mobile phone market, reported a 30% increase in numbers of delegates to 7,200 and a 70% increase in revenues from exhibitors.

Informa chairman, Peter Rigby, said some 80% of the delegates had already booked for next year. The company's broader telecoms and media division reported an 89% increase in profits during 2000.

"We are of course cogniscent of what's happening in the market place and of some of the problems being faced by the companies which have bought third generation mobile licences for instance. But they absolutely haven't had an impact on our business yet and we are pretty happy with things going forward."

The group posted a 30% increase in revenues to £297m while pre-tax profits rose from £30.4m to £33.8m.

Informa also announced the acquisition of Eaton Massachusetts Business Trust, the US-based publisher of bio-research magazine BioTechniques for $32m. Mr Rigby said BioTechniques would complement the company's existing biotechnology conferences.

The business magazines market is in a period of restructuring and Informa has spent £152m on acquisitions in the past three years. It has another £80m of firepower following the issue of 5.8m new shares yesterday, raising £32.7m in cash. The company's share price fell 12.5p to 575p in response to the share issue.

Most of Informa's magazines and newsletters are subscription based and only 12% of revenues come from advertising.

The company's online ventures are largely run on the subscription model and last year turned in profits of about £4.5m on revenues of £26m.

Informa chairman, Peter Rigby, said some 80% of the delegates had already booked for next year. The company's broader telecoms and media division reported an 89% increase in profits during 2000. "We are of course cogniscent of what's happening in the market place and of some of the problems being faced by the companies which have bought third generation mobile licences for instance. But they absolutely haven't had an impact on our business yet and we are pretty happy with things going forward." The group posted a 30% increase in revenues to £297m while pre-tax profits rose from £30.4m to £33.8m. Informa also announced the acquisition of Eaton Massachusetts Business Trust, the US-based publisher of bio-research magazine BioTechniques for $32m. Mr Rigby said BioTechniques would complement the company's existing biotechnology conferences. The business magazines market is in a period of restructuring and Informa has spent £152m on acquisitions in the past three years. It has another £80m of firepower following the issue of 5.8m new shares yesterday, raising £32.7m in cash. The company's share price fell 12.5p to 575p in response to the share issue. Most of Informa's magazines and newsletters are subscription based and only 12% of revenues come from advertising. The company's online ventures are largely run on the subscription model and last year turned in profits of about £4.5m on revenues of £26m.

webTitle: Francis Wheen: Why Hague is lost

fields.headline: Why Hague is lost in his foreign land
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: If you watched The Human Body on television three years ago you'll probably remember Robert Winston's seductive invitation: "Let me take you on a journey into my ear." The camera obediently dived through Professor Winston's eardrum into the cochlea. This was followed by equally yuksome voyages through his veins, pores and throat.
fields.body:
If you watched The Human Body on television three years ago you'll probably remember Robert Winston's seductive invitation: "Let me take you on a journey into my ear." The camera obediently dived through Professor Winston's eardrum into the cochlea. This was followed by equally yuksome voyages through his veins, pores and throat.

Now William Hague is trying the same trick. "Let me take you on a journey," he told the Tories' spring forum last weekend, "to a foreign land - to Britain after a second term of Tony Blair." At a time when almost any travel in Britain is fraught with anguish, and when delegates in Harrogate were swapping horror stories about their epic rail odysseys from Esher or Budleigh Salterton, the use of the word "journey" was presumably calculated to make his audience shiver. The reminder of Winston's innards merely intensified the horror. Yet I wonder if Hague's speech was quite the cunning oratory that rightwing pundits would have us believe.

Though no one seems to have noticed, it was clearly inspired by Peter Hitchens's book The Abolition of Britain (Quartet, 1999), which warned that the referendum on the single currency would be "a last unrepeatable moment at which we can halt our extinction as a culture and a nation" - an opportunity that must be seized by "those many millions who feel they have become foreigners in their own land and wish with each succeeding day that they could turn the clock back".

Hitchens, too, took us on a journey. Whereas Hague conjured up a nightmarish future in which the prison population is falling and Britain remains in Europe, Hitchens led an imaginary female reader back to the London of 1965, around the time of Winston Churchill's funeral. What would she see? "Less litter, less dog muck and much less chewing gum stuck to the pavement."

So far so good. What else? "She would search long and hard for a public telephone . . . London itself would seem extraordinarily dark and dirty . . . At her hotel, she would be struck by the way the staff had never heard of credit cards, by the fact that her room lacked its own bathroom . . . Moving on to a cafe, she would gag at the thick gravy, push aside the watery murdered vegetables, refuse the stodgy pudding and reject the washy unrecognisable coffee." I'd guess that few modern readers, even those with conservative instincts, would share Hitchens's nostalgic fondness for a Paradise Lost of overcooked cabbage.

The same is true of Hague's attempt to make the voters' flesh creep with his vision of Britain as a foreign land. In an excellent speech to the Media Society two years ago, the journalist Amanda Platell attacked politicians who try "to make us all terrified about Europe". Even Sun readers, she pointed out, now eat pizza and chicken jalfrezi; they drink French wine and German beer; they cheer on Gianfranco Zola or Dennis Bergkamp; they hum Nessun Dorma and dream of holidays in Spain or Crete. "And the question is, can we still regard Europe as a sinister dark force? In my experience, what British people have already gone and done is embraced Europe."

I couldn't have put it better myself (not least because I helped her write the speech in a Soho bar). William Hague should have a word with Amanda Platell before he makes an even bigger fool of himself during the election campaign. When last heard of she was working in Smith Square, London SW1, as chief spin-doctor to the leader of the Conservative party.



Ministry on defensive

My comments last week about the armed services and their dodgy equipment elicited an instant email from the chief press officer at the Ministry of Defence, who accuses me of peddling two "urban myths".

Myth number one is my allegation that the only submarine on patrol in British waters on October 31 last year was a German U-boat. "This is bollocks," the MoD man says, showing a fine grasp of barrack-room lingo. In fact, the only inaccuracy was my suggestion that the Royal Navy paid to hire the vessel. It was covered by a credit agreement "whereby the German navy provide submarine time in exchange for RN operational sea training". This scheme "reduces the burden on our own submarines". Just as well, since our own submarines were out of action at the time. Stripped of all bollocks, the truth is that the only sub patrolling British waters on October 31 was a German U-boat - as I reported.

And so to urban myth number two: that the accident-prone SA80 rifle jammed during a firefight between British paras and the Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone last year. "We are not aware of any post-incident report, secret or otherwise, that mentions a jamming problem," according to the MoD's spinwallah. "A lessons-identified report produced by 1 Para on return from Sierra Leone does not mention any problem with the weapon."

If this is true then the MoD does indeed have grounds for complaint - not least with its own spokesman, who admitted after the firefight last May that "two soldiers said they could not release their safety catches". Even more culpable is Peter Hain, then the Foreign Office minister responsible for Sierra Leone, who told the BBC that "the safety catches jammed and some troops were put in danger. The lessons from that incident will be taken on board, because it must not happen again. The modification programme reflects the government's concern to ensure that this rifle is operating at the utmost level of efficiency."

Now we learn that the MoD is unaware of any problem. Why, then, has the rifle been modified more than 80 times since it came into service? Why does the SAS refuse to use it? Why has Nato suspended the SA80 from its list of approved weapons? And why does Whitehall rebuke newspapers for peddling "urban myths" when the sources for these stories are its own press officers and ministers?



Bedsit dirty tricks

From Azerbaijan to Zanzibar, admirers of British fair play have been outraged by the revelation that the Labour party recruited students to infiltrate local Tory associations "as part of an election dirty tricks campaign". The Mail on Sunday, which alerted the world to this shocking news, describes it as an "extraordinary underhand ploy". Michael Ancram, the amiable if harrumphing chairman of the Conservative party, says that "this is a perfect example of how low Tony Blair's Labour party is willing to stoop in its unprincipled quest for power".

But where did Labour learn this sneaky trick? Not, surely, from my old chum Julian Lewis? Julian first came to public attention in the mid-1970s as a loud and litigious member of Newham North-East Labour party, leading a crusade against "bedsit entryists" who were seeking to deselect the local MP, Reg Prentice. Lewis described himself as "a liberal democrat, an old-style Gaitskellite", and denounced those "Trotskyites" who dared suggest that Prentice was a Tory in all but name.

Prentice defected to Margaret Thatcher's Conservative party soon afterwards. It then transpired that Julian was something of a bedsit entryist himself. His expensive lawsuits had been financed by the National Association For Freedom (Naff by name, naff by nature), a rightwing pressure group not known for its Gaitskellite tendencies.

If Michael Ancram is to be believed, the Tories would never condone such a deplorable stunt. So was Julian Lewis cast into the outer darkness, where there is wailing and gnashing of teeth? As near as makes no difference: in the mid-90s he was appointed deputy research director at Conservative Central Office, and he now sits as the Tory MP for New Forest East.

fields.headline: No 1833 The devil
fields.trailText: Aka: Beelzebub, Lucifer, Satan.
fields.body:
Aka: Beelzebub, Lucifer, Satan.

Age: God knows.

Appearance: Scaly skin, horns, forked tail; sometimes appears as serpent.

Yes, but any distinguishing features? Old joke. Next.

Location: Usually found near deep blue sea.

Musical skill: Has all the best tunes.

Great fictional works he has inspired: Milton's Paradise Lost, Marlowe's Dr Faustus, Goethe's Faust, Damiano's The Devil in Miss Jones.

This is all mildly interesting, but is there some specific news you wish to impart? Cardinal Dionigi Tettamanzi, the archbishop of Genoa and a leading contender to be the next pope, has deemed the devil a very bad thing and produced a 10-point plan to combat him.

That's news? Things must be quiet. They are, but you have missed the full significance of the story: the cardinal has caused a furore by invoking Satan at a time when the Catholic church is attempting to un-demonise him.

Would you Adam and Eve it? Typical liberal do-gooders. Let me guess: dictatorial father, broken home, life was hell. More that blaming the devil lets mankind off the hook. Theologians are split over whether Satan is a reality or a symbol.

Fascinating. I do enjoy the cut and thrust of theological debate first thing in the morning, but I have a train to catch. Haste is from the devil.

Though doesn't he also make work for idle hands? Devious, isn't he?

Peculiar quote from Henry IV, Part I: "Now I perceive the devil understands Welsh."

What to say if confronted by the devil: Vade retro Satanas . . . or something rude in Welsh.

What to take if dining with the devil: A long spoon. (And don't touch the Granny Smith's unless they're organic.)

What to dial if you encounter Satan late at night: 999.

What not to dial: 666.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: King in court on sex charges | Sugar's sweet for theatre | One in 10 drive on drugs |  Australia shrugs off crime jibe | 'Great start' for Crossroads | Music choice crucial in cars | Ex-PC wins £258,000 | Man drowns in sea rescue | Easy pickings for thieves | St George's Day stamps | TV advert ruled offensive
fields.body:
King in court on sex charges

Pop mogul Jonathan King, 56, of Bayswater, central London, appeared at the Old Bailey yesterday charged with eight offences of buggery on boys under 16, four indecent assaults, and two attempted buggery offences between 1969 and 1987. His bail was extended to a further hearing on April 9.

'Great start' for Crossroads

The first episode of the new look Crossroads after an absence of 12 years was declared a "great start" for the soap by ITV yesterday. Unofficial figures showed that 2.1m viewers watched the lunchtime episode on Monday and 3m saw the teatime repeat.

Ex-PC wins £258,000

Former PC Angela Vento, 34, was awarded almost £258,000 damages yesterday following a three-year legal battle with West Yorkshire police. The award by a Leeds employment tribunal covered injuries to feelings, aggravated damages, and psychological damage at the hands of her senior officers.

Man drowns in sea rescue

A Briton died while trying to save a 10-year-old boy from drowning off the Canary Islands. Ian Davies, 42, from Manchester but living in Gran Canaria, got into difficulties trying to rescue a friend's son, who was later brought to the shore safely.

Easy pickings for thieves

More than 1m Britons make themselves easy targets for thieves by keeping their pin numbers alongside cash cards in wallets and purses, a study by the Abbey National found. The figure is 50% higher than a year ago.

St George's Day stamps

The Royal Mail is to issue a set of stamps to celebrate the history and heritage of England, to coincide with St George's Day on April 23. The set features the crowned lion of England for first class stamps and the three lions for second class.

TV advert ruled offensive

A TV advertisement for Chicken Tonight was offensive to Hindus, the Independent Television Commission ruled yesterday. Sixteen viewers had complained about the commercial, featuring a woman meditating and chanting in front of a ready-to cook chicken.

Pop mogul on sex charges

Pop mogul Jonathan King, 56, of Bayswater, central London, appeared at the Old Bailey yesterday charged with eight offences of buggery on boys under 16, four indecent assaults, and two attempted buggery offences between 1969 and 1987. His bail was extended to a further hearing on April 9.

Sugar's sweet for theatre

A £15m appeal to restore the 100-year-old Hackney Empire theatre in north London reached its target yesterday with a £1.3m donation from businessman and former Tottenham Hotspur chairman Sir Alan Sugar.

One in 10 drive on drugs

One in 10 people aged between 17 and 39 has driven a car while under the influence of heroin, cannabis, ecstasy or amphetamines, a Glasgow University study of 1,000 drivers has revealed. The study was commissioned by the Scottish Executive following the growing number of road crash victims who had traces of illegal drugs in their bloodstream.

Australia shrugs off crime jibe

The Australian high commission yesterday shrugged off a remark by Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, that appeared to blame its country's high crime rate on the fact that its first immigrants were convicts. He said the comment, during a speech to a conference on youth crime, was a joke.

Music choice crucial in cars

Seven out of 10 people admitted the music they listened to while driving affected their mood and influenced how they drove, said a survey of 3,000 drivers by Dixon Motors.

webTitle: PC run down and killed by stolen car

fields.headline: PC run down and killed by stolen car
fields.trailText: A police officer has been run over and killed while investigating a stolen car.
fields.body:
A police officer has been run over and killed while investigating a stolen car.

PC Alison Armitage, 29, and two male colleagues were checking the car in Oldham, Greater Manchester, on Monday evening. While they waited for a recovery truck to arrive and remove the car, a man returned, got in and reversed away. PC Armitage tried to get the driver to stop, but was run over. She died four hours later in the Royal Oldham hospital.

An 18-year-old was being questioned yesterday.

Chief Superintendent Eric Hewitt, of Greater Manchester police, said yesterday that, on the day PC Armitage died, he had been writing a report recommending she be commended for her part in the arrest of six men involved in an armed robbery last week.

A graduate of Leeds University, PC Armitage joined Greater Manchester police in 1996. Three months ago she was promoted to the operational support unit, which targets drugs and crime in Oldham. "She had a zest for life and her work that was truly infectious," Mr Hewitt said. "She was one of our most popular officers. She was really proud to be a police officer and I think she would love to just be remembered as a damn good constable."

Her mother, Lilian, from Malton in north Yorkshire, said: "Words cannot express the sadness we feel today for the loss of our lovely daughter. She was doing her very best in a career she loved."

fields.headline: Trawlerman survives 12 hours in sea
fields.trailText: Rescue teams searching for fishermen missing after their trawler sank in the Atlantic yesterday plucked one man from the sea more than 12 hours after his ship went down.
fields.body:
Rescue teams searching for fishermen missing after their trawler sank in the Atlantic yesterday plucked one man from the sea more than 12 hours after his ship went down.

Although waves in the north Atlantic had reached up to 15ft and sea temperature was described as extremely low, the exhausted crewman managed to survive a night with the aid of only an immersion suit.

But as the bodies of five of his colleagues were also recovered, hopes were fading last night for the final missing crewman of the German-registered trawler Hansa.

An international rescue mission was launched late on Monday when the Hansa sent a distress signal from 180 miles off the Scottish coast west of Benbecula, in the Western Isles. Overnight, nine crewmen were rescued from life rafts, but by yesterday morning, six were still missing.

Rescue workers feared there was little chance of finding any more survivors, but at around 12.15pm, an RAF Nimrod reconnaissance jet spotted one man in the water.

The crew of the jet dropped a survival pack - a dinghy and food - and then watched as the fisherman scrambled into the dinghy. He was later picked up by a fishing boat, before being flown to Benbecula, where he was diagnosed with severe hypothermia.

Michael Mulford, a spokesman for the RAF, described the rescue as "miraculous".

"A low-flying Nimrod pitched a life raft down to him in a quite dramatic rescue," he said.

"This man has been in the water since before midnight. He really must have the survival instinct - this is quite exceptional in the history of search and rescue operations."

The coastguard at Falmouth first picked up an urgent distress signal from the trawler, which had set sail from the Spanish port of La Caruna, at 11.10pm on Monday. As rescue helicopters from Stornoway and Prestwick made their way to the scene, a jet dropped life rafts for the stricken fishermen.

Nine men were rescued and taken to a reception centre on Benbecula suffering mild hypothermia.

Yesterday helicopters from Britain, Ireland and Norway searched for the missing men. There were 16 men on board the ship - one German and 15 Spaniards.

It is not yet clear what caused the Hansa to sink.

He was later picked up by a fishing boat, before being flown to Benbecula, where he was diagnosed with severe hypothermia. Michael Mulford, a spokesman for the RAF, described the rescue as "miraculous". "A low-flying Nimrod pitched a life raft down to him in a quite dramatic rescue," he said. "This man has been in the water since before midnight. He really must have the survival instinct - this is quite exceptional in the history of search and rescue operations." The coastguard at Falmouth first picked up an urgent distress signal from the trawler, which had set sail from the Spanish port of La Caruna, at 11.10pm on Monday. As rescue helicopters from Stornoway and Prestwick made their way to the scene, a jet dropped life rafts for the stricken fishermen. Nine men were rescued and taken to a reception centre on Benbecula suffering mild hypothermia. Yesterday helicopters from Britain, Ireland and Norway searched for the missing men. There were 16 men on board the ship - one German and 15 Spaniards. It is not yet clear what caused the Hansa to sink.

fields.headline: Alfred Cohen
fields.standfirst: Brilliant colourist famed for portraits of the stars and landscapes
fields.trailText: Although his professed heroes were Rembrandt and Picasso, the resolutely representational work of the London-based American artist Alfred Cohen, who has died aged 80, owed most to French post-Impressionist masters.
fields.body:
Although his professed heroes were Rembrandt and Picasso, the resolutely representational work of the London-based American artist Alfred Cohen, who has died aged 80, owed most to French post-Impressionist masters like Bonnard, Dufy and Rouault, to the roving expressionist Oskar Kokoschka, and to artists of the Jewish diaspora, such as Chagall and Soutine.

A devoted Europhile, who spent the second half of his life in England, Cohen was a brilliant colourist and deft draughtsman. In London from 1960, he had sellout exhibitions with the Brook Street Gallery, and later with Roland, Browse and Delbanco. Besides reworking the subjects of the commedia dell' arte , he offered vibrant oils of the Seine, the Thames and the Channel ports, and some telling portraits - his likeness of his friend, the actor Anthony Quinn, may be his masterpiece.

Born in Chicago, of Latvian émigré stock, Cohen's studies at the Art Institute of Chic- ago were interrupted by wartime service in the US army air force, chiefly as a navigator in Pacific-based Liberator and Flying Fortress bombers. A love of movement, and of the aerial view, had a lasting place in his art.

After graduating in 1949, Cohen was awarded a scholarship to travel in Europe - and never went home again, save for brief visits. In the 1950s, with his first wife, Virginia (née Adler), he shared a studio with the Californian artist Sam Francis in Paris, but was as likely to be found at the wheel of a Bugatti as painting. In France and Rome, he mixed with movie stars, including Ingrid Bergman, Sophia Loren and Kirk Douglas, and his patrons included James Mason, Sam Wanamaker and Stanley Baker.

Following his divorce, he moved to Kent with his second wife, Diana (née Snow), in 1963, and finally to north Norfolk in 1978. Here, painting was combined with print-making, and his hand- coloured etchings of flowers were to prove especially popular across Europe, America and Japan.

Cohen's strong sense of space and design was also turned to the renovation of old houses. When converting the former schoolhouse at Wighton, near Wells-next-the-sea, into a studio, print workshop and art gallery, he found an oddly familiar marble carving in the overgrown garden. Locals remembered that a Mary Moore, from Yorkshire, had been headmistress there in the 1920s, and that her art-student brother had often chipped away at stone blocks. The unfinished sculpture was duly returned to Henry Moore.

Despite the onset of Parkinson's disease in the mid-1990s, Cohen retained a restless energy. He produced witty cartoons and constructions, and seemed ready to paint or draw on any surface. Numerous artists received his advice and encouragement; one especially anxious painter was even given telephone tutorials when a tricky picture was close to completion.

A generous host, and a great raconteur, Cohen held centre-stage at any gathering, with a stream of astounding anecdotes. He had a matchless knowledge of Hollywood - on and off screen - and, indeed, there was a film star's air about him, and a particular echo of Anthony Quinn.

He is survived by his wife and his stepson from their marriage.

Alfred Cohen, artist, born May 9 1920; died January 25 2001

fields.headline: James Rhodes
fields.standfirst: US governor whose laudable record was forever scarred by the student killings at Kent State University, Ohio
fields.trailText: US governor whose laudable record was forever scarred by the student killings at Kent State University, Ohio.
fields.body:
The American politician James Rhodes, who has died aged 91, served longer as governor of Ohio than anyone before or since. He worked hard and successfully to improve his state's economy, but his admirable record was forever scarred by the actions of a single day.

On May 1 1970, at the height of the Vietnam war, President Nixon sent US forces into neutral Cambodia to disrupt North Vietnam's supply lines to the south. This sudden extension of a vastly unpopular conflict triggered student demonstrations across America, including one by some 3,000 at Kent State University.

Two days later, in the face of widespread rioting, Rhodes declared martial law in Kent and ordered the Ohio national guard on to the campus. Describing the local disturbances as part of a national revolutionary conspiracy, he banned all meetings - even peaceful ones - and assured the part-time volunteer guardsmen that he would back them to the hilt in whatever action they took.

The following day, in circumstances still strongly in dispute, four students lay dead and nine more were injured after the badly frightened and confused guards- men opened fire. In the endless official inquiries which followed, the soldiers claimed their lives had been in imminent danger. In fact, dozens of photographs showed that, when the volley was fired by Troop G, the students were too far from the guardsmen for their stones to reach.

According to James Michener's vast 1971 report on the tragedy, Jack Albright, an electrician working on the university's new library, was passing Troop G on his way to lunch when he clearly heard one of its officers order his men to "turn around and fire three rounds". This information was given to FBI investigators but apparently never pursued. In the end, after nine years' bitter legal tussle by the students' families, their claims against Rhodes and other state officials were settled for $675,000.

The immediate effect of the shootings on Rhodes was that he lost the following day's Republican primary for the US senate. In the long term, however, this shrewd political operator recovered his career to secure two further four-year terms as governor.

He liked to portray himself as a man of the people, risen from humble origins and immersed in what he called retail politics. He once claimed that, when he was mayor of Colum bus, a woman rang to complain about a hole in the road. He immediately turned up at her house with a work crew to fill it in. The story may have been true, but his account of his background was not.

Rhodes's father was a miner of Welsh ancestry, who had risen to become a mine superintendent able to provide his family with a comfortable middle-class living. That was certainly curtailed when Rhodes Sr died in the 1918 influenza pandemic, but the family was not quite as penurious as his son liked to suggest. Even in the depression years, which hit Ohio more severely than many other states, there were still funds to send him to university, though he did not finish his course.

Class warfare sharply divided the state in that New Deal period. Its senior senator, Robert Taft, responded to the excesses of the local strife by devising the notorious Taft-Hartley anti-trade union act. However, Columbus and its hundreds of small factory owners stayed staunchly Republican.

Rhodes's mother, a formidable influence on his life, shrewdly deduced that politics would be a more reliable career than the fast-food restaurant her son was then running. She pushed him into standing as a Republican ward committeeman - and he never looked back.

Within a short space of time, he was elected city auditor, using his two terms in that post to position himself for the mayoralty of Columbus. The ensuing three terms at city hall opened the way for three terms in the far more powerful position of Ohio state auditor. His election as governor in 1962 seemed almost inevitable. He certainly dominated the state's politics from the moment he got the job.

Rhodes had fought his campaign on the slogan "Jobs and Progress", and soon became notorious among other governors for the activities of what became known as Rhodes's Raiders. The moment news broke of any enterprise planning to establish itself in another state, Rhodes's team would be dispatched to offer better terms in Ohio. Honda and many other American and foreign firms got the message; unemployment fell well below the American national average, and family incomes rose correspondingly.

Though Rhodes lost the governorship in the aftermath of the Kent State disaster, he was re-elected in 1974 and 1978. He tried again in 1986, at the age of 77, but was crushingly defeated and retired from the field. His best epitaph probably came from one awed observer who recorded that "Rhodes was always able to dominate political discourse, whether people agreed with him or not."

His wife Helen died in 1987. He is survived by their two daughters.

fields.headline: Maurice Levitas
fields.trailText: Maurice "Morry" Levitas, who has died aged 84, faced death at the hands of fascists during the Spanish civil war, wrote the much-translated Marxist Perspectives In The Sociology Of Education
fields.body:
Maurice "Morry" Levitas, who has died aged 84, faced death at the hands of fascists during the Spanish civil war, wrote the much-translated Marxist Perspectives In The Sociology Of Education (1974), and, in the early 1990s, after the fall of the Berlin Wall, edited and translated the views of the longtime East German leader Erich Honnecker.

A member of the Communist party of Great Britain and an International Brigades volunteer, Morry was captured by General Franco's army in 1938, and, at one point, was marched off with his fellow prisoners to dig their own graves. By some quirk of fate, the guards changed their minds, after which Morry spent a year in one of Franco's prison camps, often beaten and subjected to "scientific" measurements by visiting Nazis testing their "theories" about the shape and size of Jewish skulls. He was released in March 1939.

Morry's parents had fled to Dublin from tsarist pogroms in Lithuania and Latvia at the turn of the last century. His father and uncles became active in a tailors' union, known locally as the Jewish union. With his three brothers and sister, he absorbed socialism and a love of Jewish culture and Yiddish, an eclectic brew that gave him a passion for learning and argument - and a large repertoire of Yiddish songs. Proud of his heritage, he later wrote articles under his Hebrew patronymic, Moishe ben Hillel.

Unemployment in the late-1920s forced the Levitas family to Glasgow and then to London's East End, where Morry found work on building sites and joined the Communist party. He took part in the 1936 battle of Cable Street, which checked the British Union of Fascists' East End march.

After wartime service in India and Burma with the Royal Army Medical Corps, he worked as a plumber and then trained as a teacher. He taught in London secondary modern schools from 1949 to 1963, using drama to get through to difficult pupils; some, in Ladbroke Grove, were coached to produce stirring productions of St Joan and The Merchant Of Venice.

As an external London University student, Morry later graduated with an honours degree in sociology and, in 1964, became a senior lecturer in the sociology of education at Durham University. Marxist Perspectives In The Sociology Of Education followed; Morry's history, early poverty and Jewish upbringing made it a book from the heart as well as the head.

Although he opposed the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968, Morry remained an unwavering Communist party member, and, at one stage, was secretary of the Hammersmith party branch. An old-style soap-box orator, he would have audiences hanging on his words within moments of beginning to speak in public. After retirement from university, he taught English in an East German school, returning to London after the fall of the Berlin Wall. He was never afraid to go out on a limb - which helped explain his last book, Erich Honnecker Cross- Examined.

Even in his late 70s, Morry could often be seen on de- monstrations, particularly those against racial injustice. In the 1990s, as an old brigader, he was awarded Spanish citizenship and, with other surviving Irish veterans of the International Brigades, he was given a civic reception by the Lord Mayor of Dublin.

He is survived by two brothers, a sister, four children from his marriage to the late Liz Scott, and two children from his second marriage, to Jackie Litherland.

Maurice Levitas (Moishe ben Hillel), teacher and Spanish civil war veteran, born February 1 1917; died February 14 2001

fields.headline: Sylvia Lawry
fields.standfirst: She launched the worldwide campaign against MS
fields.trailText: As a young woman in the 1940s, Sylvia Lawry, who has died aged 85, was studying to become a lawyer when her younger brother, Bernard, began experiencing visual and balance problems - the early symptoms of multiple sclerosis.
fields.body:
As a young woman in the 1940s, Sylvia Lawry, who has died aged 85, was studying to become a lawyer when her younger brother, Bernard, began experiencing visual and balance problems - the early symptoms of multiple sclerosis.

The family tried many cures without success so, in 1945, Sylvia placed a classified advertisement in the New York Times: "Multiple sclerosis. Will anyone recovered from it please communicate with patient." There were more than 50 replies. Thus began Sylvia's lifelong crusade to end the devastating impact of one of the most common diseases of the central nervous system.

She was in her late 20s, with no medical background or social contacts. So she researched the relevant experts, wrote to them, rang them up and camped on their doorsteps until she found more than 20 prominent (male) scientists with whom, in 1946, she founded the world's first MS organisation, the Association for Advancement of Research In Multiple Sclerosis. The scientists learnt what many others were to learn, that no one could say no to Sylvia Lawry.

Sylvia recognised that, in addition to the sponsorship of research, people affected by the disease needed information and services, and a year later the association became the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, a worldwide model for groups in the field.

In 1950, backed by a sympathetic senator whose daughter had MS, Sylvia lobbied a previously indifferent Congress into establishing what became the United States's National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Strokes. Her campaigning led to the formation of MS groups worldwide. In 1953, she had breakfast with Sir Richard Cave and, within 40 minutes, convinced him that he was the man to establish what became the Multiple Sclerosis Society of Great Britain and Northern Ireland.

Currently, more than 2.5m people worldwide have MS. In 1967, realising that a substantial part of the American society's research funds were going to teams outside the country, Sylvia founded the International Federation of Multiple Sclerosis Societies, now the Multiple Sclerosis International Federation, with its secretariat in London. The MSIF, of which I am chief executive, comprises societies from 39 countries, as far apart as Australia, Norway, Mexico and Japan.

Sylvia was born one of four children in Brooklyn. She read law at Hunter College, New York. Then came her lifelong campaign.

She had an extraordinarily persuasive personality - and was known for her nerve. She charmed her way past protective secretaries and administrators, cold-calling business and government leaders. One pioneer in the epidemiology of multiple sclerosis told me that Sylvia had once walked right across a crowded room and singled him out to dance. She had needed to know something - and that was her way of getting his complete attention.

Sylvia was executive director of NMSS until 1982, and remained a national officer and fulltime volunteer. Her office in the New York headquarters, which she maintained until the sudden onset of a respiratory illness last year, was crammed with photographs of her with the great and good in public- and private-sector organisations. Two years ago, she attended the last MSIF international conference in Switzerland.

Her biography is scheduled for publication in November. She never stopped working, having promised that she would retire only when MS retired. She was briefly married to Michael Lawry in the mid-1940s. Her second husband, whom she married in 1957, died in 1968. She is survived by her two sons, Stephen and Frank.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: A photograph accompanying a report headed Taliban blow apart 2,000 years of Buddhist history, page 16, March 3, was incorrectly captioned "A Taliban fighter ..." The person in the picture was not a Taliban but a member of the Hazara minority who form about a fifth of the population. The photograph was taken by the photojournalist A Raffaele Ciriello and can be found on his website www.ciriello.com as part of the series A Day in Bamiyan.
fields.body:
A photograph accompanying a report headed Taliban blow apart 2,000 years of Buddhist history, page 16, March 3, was incorrectly captioned "A Taliban fighter ..." The person in the picture was not a Taliban but a member of the Hazara minority who form about a fifth of the population. The photograph was taken by the photojournalist A Raffaele Ciriello and can be found on his website www.ciriello.com as part of the series A Day in Bamiyan.

We were wrong to say in our obituary of the footballer Stan Cullis, page 24, March 1, that Cullis played a part in the defeat of Germany in May 1938. He was a member of the touring party, but Alf Young of Huddersfield Town was centre-half on that day.

In a letter in Weekend, page 5, March 3, we had the writer say "the average glass of milk contains 112,899,408-plus cells". That should have been pus cells.

The Miskin Theatre, where a production of The Man Who Was Thursday is playing on March 14, is in Dartford, Kent, not Darlington (a mistake we made at the end of a review, page 18, yesterday). The play goes on to Darlington Arts Centre, Darlington. Details: Red Shift Theatre Company 020-7378 9787.

webTitle: Leader: Time to scrap the double jeopardy rule

fields.headline: Tried twice over
fields.standfirst:
It is time to scrap the double jeopardy rule

Special report: policing crime
Special report: Stephen Lawrence
fields.trailText: It is time to scrap the double jeopardy rule.
fields.body:
Any law dating back to Roman times and embraced by English common law since the 12th century should not be lightly overturned. Hence the understandable concern among leading lawyers and civil rights groups over this week's proposal to amend the double jeopardy rule, which protects defendants who have been acquitted in one trial from facing a second.

Law students are inducted in the overwhelming power of the state, the anxiety and insecurity which trials engender, and the risk that innocent suspects may be found guilty if forced to face a second trial. There are wider concerns. This was the very reform which William Hague called for last year, when he was desperately turning to populist measures to shore up his falling poll ratings. So is the government's readiness to go ahead with the change another example of ministerial cringe to populist clamour for law 'n' order? No. On this particular charge, it is not guilty. The initiator of the change was the Macpherson report into the murder of the young black teenager Stephen Lawrence by a gang of white racist thugs. Three youths were formally acquitted of the crime when a private prosecution for murder failed. Macpherson called for a review of the double jeopardy rule which precluded a second trial, despite the emergence of new evidence.

This was one proposal about which we expressed reservations, suggesting that the law commission, to which the review was referred, should protect the old concept. In its detailed final report on the issue this week, the commission has called for change. It suggests that in murder cases only, the appeal court could, where there is "compelling" new evidence, set aside an acquittal and require a second trial. Reluctantly, we agree.

Three arguments - two of them weighty - are being advanced by critics. First, that second trials would be unfair because juries would be bound to convict if they knew the retrial was based on evidence which the appeal court had found "compelling". That is worrying; but the jury would hear the evidence themselves and would be instructed to form their own opinion. Moreover, the aim would be to keep from the jury the fact that it was a retrial. There are many retrials already - following hung juries or deaths of jurors - where they are unaware that this is the case. Reporting restrictions will apply to appeal court hearings about a rerun. A second objection is that if the police are allowed a second bite, they may be less thorough the first time. That too is a genuine risk, but sloppiness can be stopped by the appeal court ruling out retrials where the relevant evidence should have been collected for a first trial. A new symmetry will be established, with both defence and prosecution allowed to apply for retrials on the emergence of new evidence.

A third objection - about breaches to the European convention on human rights - does not hold water. Several European states allow retrials. A new protocol to the convention specifically endorses retrials where new evidence emerges. Nor does applying the new principle retrospectively amount to a breach. A new criminal law would be, but this is a new procedure applied to an old criminal law. The new rule may be too narrowly drawn - why logically should it not be extended to manslaughter and rape? - but it will reinforce public support for the criminal justice system. That is important. There have been too many cases where people cleared of murder have subsequently bragged about their guilt. Civilised societies should seek to stop murderers getting off scot free.
