webTitle: Leader: Pooh and Piglet are lost to America

fields.headline: A heffalump swoops
fields.standfirst: Pooh and Piglet are lost to America
fields.trailText: Pooh and Piglet are lost to America.
fields.body:
Here is Winnie the Pooh, coming downstairs now, bump, bump, bump, on the back of his head, behind Walt Disney. As a bear of very little brain, he is possibly not yet aware that Disney has paid a cool £240m for the right to exploit him, along with his friends Piglet, Rabbit, Eeyore and Owl, for the next 25 years. The money will go to various causes, chiefly the Royal Literary Fund, which stands to make £90m, and the Garrick Club and Westminster School, each of which will land £60m. In his role as A Wise Old Owl, the former chancellor, Lord Lamont, urged that the Garrick's loot should be split equally between its members, including him. He was outvoted.

Disney's coup is not, however, an outcome which satisfies the Sun, which calls it a lost opportunity. Because of the short-sighted attitude of the late Christopher Robin Milne and his family, it complains, a huge commercial opportunity has been lost to Pooh's native land. "We calculate," it moans, "that the US taxman will earn $1.5bn dollars this year alone from Disney's Pooh profits. Schools will be built in America. Roads will be built in America. National debt will be paid down in America. The Milnes have sold to a gigantic media conglomerate. Did it ever occur to them that they could have been running their own?"

Probably not. The real life Christopher Robin seems to have been a gentle, reflective figure, unthrilled by the prospect of a Very Deep Pit full of money. Gigantic media conglomerates were hardly his kind of heffalump. Yet the Sun's complaining tones might have seemed endearingly familiar to him. "The Old Grey Donkey, Eeyore, stood by himself in a thistly corner of the Forest, his front feet well apart, his head on one side, and thought about things. Sometimes he thought sadly to himself, 'Why?' and sometimes he thought 'Wherefore?' and sometimes he thought 'Inasmuch as which?' . . ." Good to know that his spirit lives on in a thistly corner of Wapping.

webTitle: Leader: A challenge to short-termist thinking.

fields.headline: The perils of safety first
fields.standfirst: A challenge to short-termist thinking
fields.trailText: A challenge to short-termist thinking.
fields.body:
It is said that if you look after your pennies, the pounds will look after themselves. This is what has happened with a vengeance in the City, where institutional investors (mainly pension funds) manage more than £1,500bn of assets - over half of the quoted stocks - yet the ultimate responsibility for these investments lies with unpaid part-time trustees who cannot possibly have the expertise, let alone the time, to make sensible long-term decisions. Small wonder that the City has so often been accused of short-termism, when fund managers - investing our savings - are judged by their quarterly numbers rather than their long-term performance. It was to remedy this situation that the Myners committee, which reported yesterday, was set up. It is headed by Paul Myners, chairman of Gartmore and the Guardian Media Group. A key problem is that pension funds invest too much in "safe" government stocks and not enough in "risky" investments like venture capital start-ups, where many of the companies go belly-up but those that survive more than make up for the early losses.

This is not an easy problem to solve. From the point of view of long-term economic growth, Britain desperately needs more start-ups. Not much more than 5% of the pool of savings goes into them at the moment. This is far less than in the US, which is one of the main reasons why the US is so far ahead of Britain in the information technology race. But what about the security of savings? If pension funds had piled into some of the dot.com stars of last year they could have lost up to 99% of their - our - investment. Yet if pension funds, with their 25-year horizons, do not invest long, who will?

The Myners recommendations meet his own criterion of being "manifest common sense". Among a string of conclusions, pension funds are urged to radically rethink the way they manage funds - or face statutory controls. Trustees should be paid and have a US-style legal duty to be familiar with the principles of investment. And funds should be proactive in beefing up poor corporate performance. Trustees are urged to set an investment objective to break out of the vicious circle in which managers make short-term decisions to please actuaries. These measures are all worth trying. Whether they are enough to shatter the culture of short-termism embedded in industry as well as in the City is hard to call. But we have to start somewhere.

fields.headline: Sculpture has death-ray potential
fields.trailText: A sculpture commissioned as the crowning glory of Nottingham's new Playhouse Theatre has been put on hold, for fear it might blind people or incinerate the local birdlife.
fields.body:
A sculpture commissioned as the crowning glory of Nottingham's new Playhouse Theatre has been put on hold, for fear it might blind people or incinerate the local birdlife.

The Turner prize winner Anish Kapoor has designed a giant dish mirror to be erected outside the theatre. However, an astronomer has warned that the mirror could focus light into a reflected beam capable of barbecuing birds in its path.

Other potential victims of the concave steel mirror, six metres across and costing £900,000, include staff or visitors in the Playhouse bar and passersby.

The warning came from Michael Merrifield, a professsor at Nottingham University, who is the Sky Mirror project's consultant astronomer.

"The mirror will focus light, just as does a magnifying glass, down to a particular point that moves as the sun moves.

"You need to stop the sun from falling on it in the first place. If you don't there's a potential danger. Any pigeons which fly through the beam could be instantly barbecued."

The threat would come for 16 weeks of the year either side of midsummer day, June 21, between the hours of 6am and 8am when the sun rises above the Playhouse. For the rest of the year the sculpture would be shaded by buildings and trees.

Angled 16 degrees from the vertical and positioned in front of the Playhouse, the intention of the Sky Mirror was to reflect merely the sky. Instead, during the risk period, the sun's rays would be concentrated into a funnel shape projected upwards towards the theatre bar. Several inches wide and stretching for six metres, the beam would be as hot as 40 single-bar electric fires.

To combat the risk, a sun screen 7.5m long and 4.5m high is be erected on the Playhouse roof, and measurements will taken through the year to plot the sun's movements. Once the problem has been assessed, a less obtrusive retractable screen will be installed above the main entrance, to avoid detracting from the sculpture.

The project team denied that the problem had come as a surprise - saying they had been aware of the potential risk a year ago but had waited until the exact position and angle of the sculpture had been decided upon before developing a solution. "This is an insurance policy against any possible mishaps," said Alan Humberstone, the Playhouse's public art programme direc tor. However, since the building is listed, English Heritage must give permission for a screen, and the installation has been put back to April 27.

Kapoor, 46, was born in Bombay. He moved to England in 1973 and studied at Hornsey college of art and Chelsea school of art in London. In 1990 he won the Premio 2000 with the British pavillion at the XLIV Venice Biennial. He won the Turner in 1991. A retrospective at the Hayward in 1998 attracted large crowds.

fields.headline: Pretoria pressures drug giants
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: The giant pharmaceutical companies fighting to protect their drug prices in South Africa's high court were yesterday ordered to reveal the closely guarded secrets of their business practices, including pricing policies.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Johannesburg and Sarah Boseley
fields.body:
The giant pharmaceutical companies fighting to protect their drug prices in South Africa's high court were yesterday ordered to reveal the closely guarded secrets of their business practices, including pricing policies.

The case brought by 39 drug companies in Pretoria to abolish a law permitting the government to import cheap versions of their medicines was adjourned for six weeks to give the industry time to gather its material.

The ruling by judge Bernard Ngoepe, on the second day of the hearing, will dismay the global industry, which has been notoriously secretive of commercially sensitive information.

It is a major blow to the companies which already have a public relations disaster on their hands. There were demonstrations around the world on Monday, protesting that the industry was putting profits before the lives of people dying with diseases that are treatable in the west, such as HIV/Aids, and they appear to have lost international political support. The German government has joined the United States, European Union and World Trade Organisation in backing South Africa's right to introduce the laws, and calling on the industry to drop the lawsuit.

There are likely to be discussions behind the scenes at individual companies over the wisdom of continuing the case, but the biggest, GlaxoSmithKline, yesterday made it clear it felt the stakes were too high to let it go.

"I don't think any of us [the drug companies] want to be there. It doesn't help the industry and it doesn't help relations with the South African government," said a spokesman in London.

"But this law is open to interpretation that the patent system could be absolved in South Africa and that is a threat to the global patent system." The drug firms are claiming in court that legislation permitting the distribution of some imported generic drugs and other cheaper medicines breaches their patents and South Africa's constitution.

Yesterday's court order came after the judge ruled that a group campaigning for wider access to treatment for South Africa's 4m HIV-positive people could make a submission as a friend of the court. The Treatment Action Campaign, which has lobbied vigorously over the price of drugs, said the decision gave a voice to the people who stand to gain or lose most from the case. It intends to bring testimonials from people suffering from HIV/Aids and evidence about the different prices set by the industry for its drugs around the world.

The drug companies, represented by the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association (PMA), demanded a postponement of four months in order to prepare a response. The judge effectively called the drug companies' bluff. He agreed to put the hearings on hold for six weeks on condition the PMA responds point by point to the accusations in TAC's submission.

Mark Heywood of TAC said the ruling was unprecedented. "It's a very significant victory. It's going to force them to answer questions they have never had to answer before."

But the PMA's counsel, Fannie Cilliers, hinted that what he called the "patent protected research industry" might prefer to keep its secrets, when he told the court he did not think there was enough time to gather the necessary information from overseas.

The drug companies appear particularly concerned by questions about their pricing policies.

The manufacturers allege that excessive mark-ups by retailers is responsible for the high cost of drugs in South Africa's private health sector.

But the pharmaceutical firms refuse to reveal the prices they charge chemists and other suppliers or how they compare to prices in other developing countries and the west.

South Africa's stand has encouraged Kenya to follow suit. Yesterday, the health minister, Sam Ongerim, said the gov ernment will introduce legislation to permit the importation of cheaper generic drugs to treat Aids under a clause in international patent laws allowing countries to respond to a national emergency.

"We cannot operate in a situation where we have an epidemic, a national disaster and being asked to keep on observing the international patent law," he said.

webTitle: Leukaemia study finds unexplained home radiation

fields.headline: Leukaemia study finds unexplained home radiation
fields.trailText: Powerful, unexplained electromagnetic fields have been measured in homes that are nowhere near electricity pylons, scientists reported yesterday, throwing further confusion on possible links with cancer.
fields.body:
Powerful, unexplained electromagnetic fields have been measured in homes that are nowhere near electricity pylons, scientists reported yesterday, throwing further confusion on possible links with cancer.

Long-term exposure to high levels of electromagnetic radiation, such as that found near pylons, is associated with a possible two extra cases of child leukaemia each year on average, 0.4% of the total in Britain, the report said.

But this did not prove that electromagnetic radiation caused the cancer, said Sir Richard Doll, head of the report team. Nor was there evidence that the extra cases existed. He would "bet money" on a statistical quirk being responsible for the association.

The team's most startling finding was that only four-fifths of the estimated 275,000 Britons exposed to high levels of electromagnetic radiation lived close to pylons; the rest might be experiencing the effects of their domestic wiring, or the local electricity distribution network.

"The discovery that most high exposures are away from power lines is new," Sir Richard said. "It was quite a surprise." The report was prepared for the national radiological protection board. Stuart Allen, an NRPB expert who acted as consultant for the inquiry team, said he suspected mains supply lines to homes were involved, but could not be sure.

Electromagnetic fields are measured in teslas. A high domestic exposure is consid ered to be an average 0.4 microteslas or more. Household appliances generate much higher levels, but only at very short distances. The combined effect of scores of electric motors and pumps in a home would not be enough to bring the average exposure to children up to 0.4 microteslas.

Electromagnetic radiation in the home could be measured with a handheld device, but the NRPB said that, while more research was needed, it saw no reason to change guidelines in the wake of the report. Like the recent report on mobile phone radiation, the Doll group did not do field work, but collated results of nine projects around the world. They found exposure to more than 0.4 microteslas was associated with a doubling of the risk of leukaemia before age 15 from about one in 1,400 to one in 700.

But the numbers of children involved were so tiny that it was hard to prove this was happening in Britain, and impossible as yet to prove that any increase was linked to electromagnetic fields.

Unlike ionising radiation - the kind produced by nuclear reactions - there was no sign that electromagnetic radiation caused mutations in human cells, which can lead to cancer.

Sir Richard said he himself did not believe it was dangerous for families to live near power lines, but conceded that a link between electromagnetic fields and cancer had not been ruled out. "We can't say these fields cause cancer, only that the possibility remains that intense and prolonged exposure can increase the risk of leukaemia in children," he said.

"The discovery that most high exposures are away from power lines is new," Sir Richard said. "It was quite a surprise." The report was prepared for the national radiological protection board. Stuart Allen, an NRPB expert who acted as consultant for the inquiry team, said he suspected mains supply lines to homes were involved, but could not be sure. Electromagnetic fields are measured in teslas. A high domestic exposure is consid ered to be an average 0.4 microteslas or more. Household appliances generate much higher levels, but only at very short distances. The combined effect of scores of electric motors and pumps in a home would not be enough to bring the average exposure to children up to 0.4 microteslas. Electromagnetic radiation in the home could be measured with a handheld device, but the NRPB said that, while more research was needed, it saw no reason to change guidelines in the wake of the report. Like the recent report on mobile phone radiation, the Doll group did not do field work, but collated results of nine projects around the world. They found exposure to more than 0.4 microteslas was associated with a doubling of the risk of leukaemia before age 15 from about one in 1,400 to one in 700. But the numbers of children involved were so tiny that it was hard to prove this was happening in Britain, and impossible as yet to prove that any increase was linked to electromagnetic fields. Unlike ionising radiation - the kind produced by nuclear reactions - there was no sign that electromagnetic radiation caused mutations in human cells, which can lead to cancer. Sir Richard said he himself did not believe it was dangerous for families to live near power lines, but conceded that a link between electromagnetic fields and cancer had not been ruled out. "We can't say these fields cause cancer, only that the possibility remains that intense and prolonged exposure can increase the risk of leukaemia in children," he said.

webTitle: Britpop pioneers at centre of court fight

fields.headline: Britpop pioneers at centre of court fight
fields.standfirst: Couple who propelled Blur to stardom sue EMI for £250,000 royalties after album was not released in UK
fields.trailText: The band Blur were at the centre of a high court battle last night after the husband-and-wife team who propelled them to fame launched a claim against EMI Records for £250,000 in royalties.
fields.body:
The band Blur were at the centre of a high court battle last night after the husband-and-wife team who propelled them to fame launched a claim against EMI Records for £250,000 in royalties.

David and Helen Balfe sold their company, Food Records, to EMI in 1994 as part of a £475,000 deal which guaranteed them royalties from the next two albums released by the band, whose hits include Parklife, Country House and Song 2.

The first album, The Great Escape, sold 2.15m copies worldwide but the second, Live At Budokan - aimed at the Japanese market and not released in the UK - sold only 80,000.

The couple argue that they are entitled to royalties from the subsequent highly successful studio album, entitled Blur, which sold 2.4m copies. They say the low circulation live album should not be considered part of the royalties agreement. A judgment on the case is expected this morning.

Robert Englehart QC told the high court in London yesterday that the £250,000 claim also included royalties owing from albums by the group Shampoo. EMI had employed a similar tactic with the female pop duo, Mr Englehart told Judge Boggis QC, giving their second album a restricted release targeted on Japan, where the band had enjoyed an enormous fan following.

But he said it was the albums released by Blur, now "an extremely successful band", which had "by far the greater commercial significance" in the legal dispute.

Mr Balfe, a former keyboard player with Julian Cope's Liverpool-based psychedelic group the Teardrop Explodes, established the label in 1983, signing artists including the Woodentops, Zodiac Mindwarp and Jesus Jones.

In 1989 the label discovered Blur, then called Seymour and headed by an art student, Damon Albarn. The band were signed over a meal with Food executives in a Soho pizzeria.

Balfe, who with his wife owned 75% of the shares in Food, sold the company weeks before the release of Blur's album Parklife, amid tensions in' his relationship with the band. It entered the UK charts at number one and became the standard-bearer of the Britpop phenomenon. Shampoo were in negotiations to sign with Food at the time of the sale.

Albarn and fellow Blur members Graham Coxon, Alex James and David Rowntree went on to make Balfe the subject of their less than complimentary single Country House.

Representatives of Food Records and EMI refused to comment yesterday pending the outcome of the case.

EMI Records, one of the world's biggest record companies, is also at the centre of an investigation into alleged price-fixing of compact discs launched last month by the office of fair trading.

The watchdog said it had "reasonable grounds" to suspect that the company, along with Sony Music, Universal, BMG, Warner, Virgin and Pinnacle, was keeping CD prices in the United Kingdom artificially high.

If the allegations are proven, the companies could be prosecuted under the Competition Act and fined up to 10% of their turnover per year of infringement.

Artists for whom the label owns distribution rights encompass a vast range of eras and styles from the Beatles through Pink Floyd and Iron Maiden to Robbie Williams, Kylie Minogue and Geri Halliwell.

When the notes turn sour

Badfinger
In April 2000 Joey Molland, the guitarist and one of two surviving members of the suicide-ravaged pop band, which was signed to the Beatles' Apple label, won a battle recognising his entitlement to £46,650 in royalties from the 1974 album Day After Day.

Phil Collins
The singer had a hollow victory last April after a court agreed he accidentally overpaid horn players Louis Satterfield and Rahmlee Davis. The judge ruled the two had been entitled to royalties only on those tracks in which they had played on Serious Hits - Live!, but halved the amount to be withheld from them in future to £244,000 in recognition of the fact that they had not been to blame.

Spandau Ballet
Three members of the 1980s New Romantic group last April abandoned a long-running legal battle to claim royalties from songwriter Gary Kemp. Singer Tony Hadley, drummer John Keeble and saxophonist Steve Norman sought up to £3m from Kemp, but bore heavy financial costs from the abandonment of the action and were prohibited from performing as Spandau Ballet in their attempt to raise funds.

Morrissey
In December 1996 the former lead singer of The Smiths was described as "devious and unreliable" by a judge who found in favour of drummer Mike Joyce's claim, originally pursued with bass player Andy Rourke, to a quarter of the band's performance fees and royalties totalling about £1m. Morrissey and fellow member Johnny Marr had argued that the group had agreed a different division of income.

Robert Johnson
In June 2000 a US judge ruled that retired truck driver Claud Johnson, from Mississippi, was the son of the tormented blues guitarist. He could now be entitled to more than $1m in royalties from sales of work by the writer of Hellhound on My Trail, who died in 1963.

webTitle: Irish punters defy Dublin's racing fears

fields.headline: Irish punters defy Dublin's racing fears
fields.standfirst:
Little sign of big drop in festival visitors in vistors

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Against the wishes of their own government, Irish racegoers are set to descend upon Cheltenham for the three day National Hunt festival, which is likely to go ahead on schedule next Tuesday, despite the continuing foot and mouth outbreak.
fields.byline: Pete Nichols, John Vidal,  and Felicity Lawrence
fields.body:
Against the wishes of their own government, Irish racegoers are set to descend upon Cheltenham for the three day National Hunt festival, which is likely to go ahead on schedule next Tuesday, despite the continuing foot and mouth outbreak.

Though the Irish agriculture minister Joe Walsh has stated that he found it found it hard to understand the British stance on sporting events, his compatriots have clearly not had such problems.

While there will be no Irish horses for them to back at the meeting - the trainers and owners having followed their government's guidelines and withdrawn their animals - the punters have not been so easily deterred.

Hotels in the Cheltenham area have reported only a modest number of cancellations.

Ryan Air spokesman Enda O'Toole said that the airline was still heavily booked.

As a further measure to protect their farming, the Irish government said yesterday that the world cross-country championships, due to be held in Dublin this month, would move to Brussels.

Hopes that the foot and mouth crisis might have peaked were yesterday supported when only seven new cases were confirmed - four in Cumbria, two in Devon and another in County Durham and all believed to be connected to previous outbreaks.

But the authorities were investigating a second suspected case on Dartmoor, at a farm at Widecombe in the moor five miles from Dunna Bridge Farm, Two Bridges, where an outbreak was confirmed on Sunday. Both farms are owned by the Prince of Wales. ministry of agriculture officials have still not established whether the first case is linked to other outbreaks already confirmed in Devon. If it is not, it could lead to a cull of livestock on the moor.

Local farmers were yesterday reported to be terrified that the outbreak might spread to the 46,000 animals thought to be on the moor. Dartmoor supports more than 1,000 farmers on a quarter of a million acres of farmland.

"Dartmoor is on red alert. We are prepared to do anything to prevent having to kill all the animals on the moor", said David Hill, chairman of the National Farmers Union in Devon. "We are considering creating a human shield to literally stop any animals getting in or out".

Other options being considered by locals and the ministry if the virus does spread include asking the army to help divide the moor into quadrants, separating the animals and making them easier to control.

The junior agriculture minister, Lady Hayman, said a total of 201 abattoirs had now received special licences enabling them to slaughter animals again, and that "hundreds and hundreds of farmers" had applied for licences allowing them to send animals for slaughter.

But plans to set up holding centres for cattle and sheep en route to slaughter houses would not be up and running until next week, she said.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, ruled out state intervention to control prices despite reports that beef and lamb farmers were being offered prices at least 30% lower than the standard market prices before the crisis began.

Vets said it would be at least 30 days without any new cases before Britain could safely say it was free of the virus.

fields.headline: Vaccination could ruin export business
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Fifty million doses of foot and mouth vaccine stocked in the EU are ready for use, but putting them to use could threaten UK exports even further.
fields.body:
Is there a vaccine available for foot and mouth?

There are 50 million doses of foot and mouth vaccine stocked in the EU and ready for use. There are four types of virus so there are different types of vaccine to suit. The UK has the virulent type O, the vaccine to which works very well and protects cattle, sheep, pigs, goats and deer from getting the disease so to many people it seems the logical option.

Why don't we get on with it?

Vaccination is regarded as a policy of last resort. In the long run it would be costly because we would lose export markets as confidence in UK produce would plummet. Once vaccination is carried out it has to be repeated for new generations. Some animals still carry the virus although they show no symptoms and the countries who use it cease to be regarded as disease-free. Under international rules countries which vaccinate cannot export live animals and meat products to foot and mouth free countries because they carry the danger of infection.

When would we use it then?

Only if the disease was thought to be completely out of control, and then only if the standing veterinary committee - the top vets from all 15 EU countries - agreed. They met yesterday in Brussels and decided that the UK was coping and that the existing policy of slaughtering all animals would eradicate the disease. This means the UK would soon be able to resume its disease-free status. Vaccination will be reviewed again at another meeting but only if the situation got a lot worse and the UK asked for the policy to be changed.

What is the UK view?

It would be a calamity in the long run to lose the disease-free status because £1m exports a week at least would be lost. Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, has not wavered from the policy of no vaccination from the first day of the outbreak and believes that slaughtering to eradicate it remains the best option. The National Farmers Union and the UK vets have been 100% behind this view.

webTitle: Notebook: Gordon Brown introduced to the free lunch

fields.headline: Gordon Brown introduced to the free lunch
fields.standfirst: City tradition under insider fire
fields.trailText: Notebook: City tradition under insider fire.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown put an insider on the job of investigating Britain's pension management industry. For his trouble, he has received an insider's view of what is going on, how it has gone wrong and what might be done to put it right. Traditionalists in the City of London should be absolutely panic-striken by the action plan published yesterday.

For what Paul Myners, the chairman of Guardian Media Group who is better known in the Square Mile as the boss of Gartmore, is threatening to abolish in the wake of his review of institutional investment is nothing less sacred than The City Lunch.

This is not a joke.

We are talking about "lunch" in the broad sense employed in financial markets - namely, the traditional system of broking commission allocation, invitations to Cheltenham and the buying of drinks at dubious bars which, on current form, keep the City army marching.

Within his 200-page report, Mr Myners has zoomed in on some of the most opaque aspects of financial market and asset management practice, areas which were known about by clued up outsiders but which could only ever be scrutinised with real authority by someone on the inside.

Given the fact that the Gartmore chief made his fortune building a pension management business which has exploited all this opacity, some in the City will be questioning what sort of thanks Mr Myners is now giving.

Take one market thread: payment for the voluminous research on companies produced each and every day by investment banks and brokers.

Currently, this is funded by commission payments made by pension funds through fund management houses to various brokers and banks. The cost is often of the same magnitude that funds pay for active management of their assets, but it is the fund managers who decide which of their broking chums gets paid, while pension trustees rarely examine the payment receipts passed on to them.

A huge and lucrative industry is built around this system, with teams of analysts at all the big banks fuelling both their corporate finance departments and their institutional sales teams with corporate ideas - all paid for through arcane things like "commission recapture" by those of us contributing to our pension funds.

Mr Myners says there is inadequate scrutiny of these payments, in whatever form they come.

He reckons the interest of pension funds would be better served if fund managers had to absorb the cost of any commissions paid, treating these (sensibly enough) as a cost of the business of managing funds.

The headline price of fund management would rise as a result, but fund managers would be forced to look hard at the research and advice they were buying.

A commercial tension would be created between a fund manager's desire to cut costs, while at the same time achieving superior performance. It is likely we would see more so-called "buy-side" as opposed to "sell-side" research, while broking commissions would be driven even lower, requiring reams of City salesmen to find more productive ways of earning a living.

This is radical stuff - and all the more powerful in that it comes from a practitioner rather than a regulator. But if Mr Myners' proposals are to stick they need real political momentum. Cue the chancellor.

Gunning Greg

Greg Hutchings was keen to play down reports yesterday that he has been toying with the idea of launching a takeover bid for his old engineering group Tomkins, which Mr Hutchings left amid allegations of corporate excess last autumn.

A mad idea, his friends suggested, especially when he is currently negotiating a major pay-off with the current management.

Yet it would be no great surprise to learn that Mr Hutchings has been talking with corporate financiers about his next move. And his ignominious exit from Tomkins is unlikely to greatly worry venture capitalists or others.

Tomkins' share price was hammered down to an unacceptably low level in the past by investor frustration at the way Mr Hutchings had run the company as a conglomerate rather than just his alleged personal fiefdom.

And there is still plenty of cleaning up to do, such as in the US, where the company has to contend with issues such as depressed demand for automotive parts and potential legal action against its handgun subsidiary Smith & Wesson, which is now up for sale.

Whatever talks may have taken place, it must still be a fair bet that a Tomkins takeover is unlikely to go much further than Mr Hutchings plotting revenge on his favourite settee at his grand Wimbledon home.

Gunning Greg Greg Hutchings was keen to play down reports yesterday that he has been toying with the idea of launching a takeover bid for his old engineering group Tomkins, which Mr Hutchings left amid allegations of corporate excess last autumn. A mad idea, his friends suggested, especially when he is currently negotiating a major pay-off with the current management. Yet it would be no great surprise to learn that Mr Hutchings has been talking with corporate financiers about his next move. And his ignominious exit from Tomkins is unlikely to greatly worry venture capitalists or others. Tomkins' share price was hammered down to an unacceptably low level in the past by investor frustration at the way Mr Hutchings had run the company as a conglomerate rather than just his alleged personal fiefdom. And there is still plenty of cleaning up to do, such as in the US, where the company has to contend with issues such as depressed demand for automotive parts and potential legal action against its handgun subsidiary Smith & Wesson, which is now up for sale. Whatever talks may have taken place, it must still be a fair bet that a Tomkins takeover is unlikely to go much further than Mr Hutchings plotting revenge on his favourite settee at his grand Wimbledon home.

fields.headline: BBA's £25m restructuring unnerves investors
fields.trailText: Engineering group BBA is to spend £25m restructuring its troubled manufacturing business with the loss of 600 jobs.
fields.body:
Engineering group BBA is to spend £25m restructuring its troubled manufacturing business with the loss of 600 jobs.

Shares in the group fell 20% after the company revealed the need for a shake-up to counter falling margins in the US.

The City was already unnerved by the standing down this week of BBA's highly rated chief executive, Roberto Quarta, although his switch to non-executive chairman had been well flagged.

The new chief executive Roy McGlone said the share sell-off had been an "overreaction" and some analysts agreed.

The cuts will affect BBA's materials technology business which makes non-woven materials for products such as nappies.

Most of the £25m will go on redundancy payments to workers of whom 450 are based in the US and 150 in continental Europe.

Mr McGlone said the changes would not bring any large plant closures but would result in savings of £20m a year.

BBA reported pre-tax profits up 81% to £287m although they were boosted dramatically by asset sales.

Turnover on continuing operations was up 22% to £1.3bn while operating profit on continuing operations rose by 13% to £187m. The dividend was increased by 5% to 10.1p.

"As we enter 2001, aviation services continues its forward momentum. Our market-leading positions and the actions already in hand will place BBA in a strong position in the challenging economic environment we face in the year ahead," said Mr McGlone.

Over the past year BBA has offloaded its automotive business to concentrate on aviation and materials technology.

McGlone said: "If we felt value could be created by doing something different we would look at that. But we are not doing that now."

BBA has been adding new areas of operation in engine overhaul services and pilot training, and is expanding into new geographical areas such as South America.

The shares ended the day down 74p at 286p.

fields.headline: Heart doctor's warning to Cheney
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: There was speculation yesterday that Vice-president Dick Cheney would have to work less when he returns to the White House: the doctor who has just operated on one of his arteries has said there is a serious chance he could face renewed heart problems.
fields.body:
There was speculation yesterday that Vice-president Dick Cheney would have to work less when he returns to the White House: the doctor who has just operated on one of his arteries has said there is a serious chance he could face renewed heart problems.

Mr Cheney, 60, was recuperating at home last night less than 24 hours after an operation at a Washington hospital to repair a damaged artery. He has had four heart attacks since the age of 37, all described as mild.

Jonathan Reiner, his surgeon, said that there was an approximately 40% chance that the vice-president could face a recurrence of the problem.

Publicly, the White House continued to treat this week's problem as little more than a minor interruption in Mr Cheney's schedule. But in Washington there was much speculation that this latest scare may force a serious rethink of his hands-on role at the centre of the Bush administration.

There was no repeat yesterday of the news conference that Mr Cheney gave when he left hospital after having a mild heart attack in November. His media-free departure underlined the importance which the Bush administration attaches to a business-as-usual atmosphere.

"No restrictions have been placed upon his work," the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, said, adding that Mr Cheney was expected to return to his desk later this week.

Mr Cheney's health scare casts a serious shadow over the administration's planning: the vice-president is in many respects its key political decision-maker.

In addition to his public schedule, he chairs dozens of key White House meetings and is in charge of a task force on energy policy. He holds the casting vote in the tied 100-member US Senate, and has emerged as the administration's main media spokesman.

Mr Bush also relies on Mr Cheney as his most experienced and trusted adviser on a range of issues.

Mr Cheney went to hospital on Monday after having two bouts of chest pain in 48 hours. Doctors carried out a "balloon angioplasty" to reopen an artery that had narrowed since November.

webTitle: Bidder adds demands in Wolves deal

fields.headline: Bidder adds demands in Wolves deal
fields.trailText: The long-running struggle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has reached a new impasse, as leading contender Botts & Co demanded an extension to the April 5 deadline for formal bids.
fields.body:
The long-running struggle for control of Wolverhampton & Dudley Breweries has reached a new impasse, as leading contender Botts & Co demanded an extension to the April 5 deadline for formal bids.

Botts, which is run by leisure entrepreneur Robert Breare, has tabled a 500p-a-share proposal, valuing the business at £470m. This sent Wolves' shares up 16p to 460p.

However, Mr Breare has refused to make this a formal bid without commissioning further legal and accounting work, which he claims will take six weeks. He is not prepared to begin that process without a written assurance that once it is completed, Wolves' management will either recommend Botts' bid or refund the cost of the work.

A source close to the negotiations said: "We're getting towards the endgame at last."

Wolves & Dudley is Britain's biggest regional brewer - the company produces Banks's, Cameron and Pedigree ales. Its 1,700 pubs include the Pitcher & Piano and Varsity chains. Its ownership has been in the balance since last summer, when a series of profit warnings triggered unrest among shareholders.

NM Rothschild, which is conducting the ongoing auction of the company, yesterday said it had a number of proposals from potential buyers.

Wolves' management, led by managing director David Thompson, has carried out due diligence for a bid but has struggled to offer as much as 500p a share because its main backer, UBS Capital, is sceptical about whether the company is worth this much.

There has also been interest from Pubmaster, the privately owned chain of 2,000 tenanted pubs, although it is yet to carry out any detailed preparatory work. It is interested in bidding for several other pub estates.

In a statement, Pubmaster's chief executive John Sands said: "Whilst we cannot comment on our acquisition plans on an individual basis, the potential sale of Wolverhampton & Dudley to Pubmaster would present us with significant opportunity."

Botts' demand for more time has infuriated Wolves' advisers, who point out that the venture capital firm has been talking about a bid since August. One insider said Botts had initially asked for "four to six weeks", been offered five weeks and then demanded six weeks: "They're just trying to wind people up - they think they're the only game in town, which they're not."

fields.headline: Thorntons' new recipe
fields.trailText: Chocolate and toffee producer Thorntons has come up with a new plan to fatten up its profits - it intends to convert its stores to giftshops.
fields.body:
Chocolate and toffee producer Thorntons has come up with a new plan to fatten up its profits - it intends to convert its stores to giftshops.

At the same time new chief executive Peter Burdon plans to start selling the company's 55p-a-time chocolate bars through supermarkets and license the Thorntons brand on to products such as biscuits, and ice cream.

Thorntons put out two profit warnings last year and Mr Burdon yesterday outlined plans to scale back new store openings, but press ahead with opening more franchised outlets and Café Thorntons coffee bars.

"I didn't come into this business to give profit warnings," he said. He was outlining his strategy as the group posted half-year profits down from £10.9m to £10m on sales up 5.4%. Sales since Christmas have been down on last year's.

Mr Burdon's plans centre on research which has shown gifts are the "key strength" of the Thorntons business. As a result Mr Burdon says he is going to upgrade store interiors to display gifts better. "We have been pushing Thorntons as a personal treat, but the brand research shows we are a gift shop. We need to convey the sensuality of chocolate."

The Café Thorntons concept has been successful and he is rolling it out to 50 locations, from the current 23.

He is also expanding the e-commerce business - where average orders are around £25, compared to average store purchases of £7.

He added that he hoped to get Thornton's bars into supermarkets and was already in talks with one food manufacturer to license a range of Thorntons-branded ice creams, to be sold in multi-packs through supermarkets.

The shares, which have ranged from 66p to 180p in the past year, closed up 6p at 84.5p.

fields.headline: £100k bonus for Beeson brokers
fields.trailText: Staff at stockbroker Beeson Gregory enjoyed average bonuses of nearly £100,000, following rocketing profits as the firm milked last year's boom in technology stocks.
fields.body:
Staff at stockbroker Beeson Gregory enjoyed average bonuses of nearly £100,000, following rocketing profits as the firm milked last year's boom in technology stocks.

Beeson's full-year profits leapt 144% to £16.3m, despite a slowdown in the second half and a costly but failed attempt to conquer the US market.

Chief executive David Norwood said: "The first half was unbelievable - I don't think anyone could believe their luck. Then we had a downturn, which became more and more savage."

Under the firm's bonus scheme, Beeson's 135 staff will share £12.7m - an average of £94,000 each. The company's shares, floated in April at 300p, yesterday jumped 37.5p to 206.5p.

Beeson is one of the biggest private client brokers in the City, with customers including the late Conservative MP Alan Clark.

However, the firm revealed yesterday that its recent attempt to woo US investors had failed. Beeson closed its office in Boston at a cost of £1.5m. Mr Norwood said: "It was a mistake. It's not so much a question of what went wrong as that nothing went right."

The US office had six staff, two of whom were on secondment from London. Mr Norwood said there was an "opportunity cost" in keeping "two of our best guys" in America.

Mr Norwood, a former British chess champion, became chief executive in January, when Andrew Beeson stepped up to be chairman.

Beeson advised on 21 flotations last year, raising £417m, and 26 share placings by quoted companies, raising £302m.

fields.headline: RJB bounces back into black
fields.trailText: RJB Mining, the biggest coal producer in Britain, yesterday reported a swing back to profitability and admitted it was struggling to keep up with booming demand.
fields.body:
RJB Mining, the biggest coal producer in Britain, yesterday reported a swing back to profitability and admitted it was struggling to keep up with booming demand.

The company also sees a golden future in property assets and plans to bulldoze its existing sites as they run out of coal and sell them to property developers for housing.

RJB reported pre-tax profits after exceptional items of £17.8m compared to a £130m loss in 1999 mainly because of a write-down of its coal assets. The 2000 figure was boosted by £53m of state aid.

Shareholders will be the main gainers from the recovery with RJB paying a final dividend of 5p, making a total for the year of 10p, up from 7.5p last time. RJB's stock has risen 160% over the past year but last night slipped 2p to 82p.

It had risen last week when RJB announced the departure of Richard Budge, the founder, a significant shareholder and chief executive. Larger shareholders were worried Mr Budge wanted to invest in new facilities.

The company insisted there was no difference of opinion between Mr Budge and the board and yesterday again declined to comment on the reasons for the departure.

Acting chief executive and former finance director Gordon McPhie said the coal market was in better shape than for many years, boosted by high prices for rival fuels such as oil and natural gas.

Coal accounted for 37.5% of Britain's energy needs in 2000, compared with 30% in 1999. RJB told a meeting of analysts that it had been forced to buy in some supplies to keep up with demand.

This year it hopes to boost its output from 19m tonnes to 21m at a time when coal prices have reached $42 per tonne

RJB intends to maximise returns on all its assets by developing its considerable land portfolio. Mr McPhie said: The company says its property portfolio is worth at least £124m, compared with a previous book value of £80m.

But analysts believe the true value could be twice that because planning gain has been excluded. RJB took over most of the former assets of the National Coal Board in England and Wales yet uses only 15,000 of the 50,000 acres of land for mining purposes.

Among the four or five sites already up for development is the now-exhausted open-cast mine at Orgreave, scene of a bloody confrontation between the police and miners during the coal dispute of 1984-1985.

RJB says it is working on developing this site near Sheffield with regional development agency Yorkshire Forward. A mixture of residential housing and industrial amenities are planned.

Industry experts were unsurprised that RJB is not opening any big new mines, given they cost up to £500m.

webTitle: Mugabe brought in from cold by Chirac

fields.headline: Mugabe brought in from cold by Chirac
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: France ignored British unease about a meeting last night between Zimbabwe's leader, Robert Mugabe, and President Jacques Chirac, with the two men talking for more than an hour.
fields.body:
France ignored British unease about a meeting last night between Zimbabwe's leader, Robert Mugabe, and President Jacques Chirac, with the two men talking for more than an hour.

Officials in Paris said that Tony Blair had been informed of the agenda several days ago. They gave no indication of the prime minister's reaction.

In London, the Conservative opposition accused the Blair government of "shameful silence" for refusing to elaborate after reports said it was concerned at the "red carpet treatment" given to Mr Mugabe on the continent in recent days.

Downing Street later said Mr Chirac had been expected to raise human rights issues with Mr Mugabe and insist on the primacy of the rule of law; but Chirac advisers said these matter had not been included in a pre-arranged agenda.

The attack on French policy towards Zimbabwe was led by the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude. He called the French ambassador in London, Bernard Daniel, to say that it would be "wrong and unethical" if France were trying to increase its influence in central and southern Africa by receiving the Zimbabwean leader, whose status as a liberation icon has been eroded by his regime's attacks on the judiciary, its intimidation of opponents and white farmers, and its role in the ruinous and unpopular Congo war.

Mr Mugabe, who arrived in Paris on Friday, met Mr Chirac last night after a one-day visit to Brussels to see the Belgian prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt. Violent incidents in Brussels between Mr Mugabe's bodyguards and the British gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell went unreported by the French press.

However, police confirmed that the episode had led to tightened security in Paris.

French presidential advisers said the agenda for the talks between Mr Chirac, 68, and Mr Mugabe, 77, concentrated on finding a solution to the civil war in the Democratic Republic of Congo (formerly Zaire), where Zimbabwe has 12,000 troops backing Joseph Kabila. He succeeded his murdered father, Laurent Kabila, as leader last year.

Mr Mugabe's opponents at home allege that members of his administration and the army are involved in the war to protect dealings they have in the area's resources.

There is a suspicion that Mr Chirac wants to strengthen France's political and economic presence in the Congo and Zimbabwe, one of the English-speaking African states targeted by recent French diplomacy.

The opposition in Harare has accused France and Belgium of conniving to dominate the Congo, once a Belgian colony; it fears they will prop up Mr Mugabe to keep him as a go-between.

The main opposition leader in Zimbabwe, Morgan Tsvangirai, said there was concern that France and Belgium saw Mr Mugabe as a solution and not a cause of conflict in the Congo. Reports of arrests of Mr Kabila's Angolan advisers appear to have increased Zimbabwe's influence there.

fields.headline: US test failings make weapons 'unreliable'
fields.standfirst: Pentagon report lambasts missile shield evaluation
fields.trailText: Pentagon report lambasts missile shield evaluation.
fields.body:
Reduced and inadequate testing has led to a serious decline in the reliability of US weapons, a Pentagon report says.

Service chiefs are cutting too many corners and taking too many risks in their efforts to bring expensive new weapons systems into operational use before they have been properly tested, it concludes.

"Cost and schedule pressures are increasingly causing programme managers to accept more risk and it is showing up as performance shortfalls in operational testing," says the author of the annual departmental report, Philip Coyle, who resigned as the Pentagon's director of testing and evaluation in January.

The report is scathing about the increasing failure to test weapons systems properly, an issue at the centre of the argument about the government's plan to erect a multibillion dollar missile defence shield to protect the US and its allies from attacks by "rogue states".

Mr Coyle says that earlier tests of the missile shield were too simple to allow a properly informed decision whether to move from the current research phase to deployment, as the administration has made it clear it intends to do.

The missile defence test programme is "not aggressive enough to match the pace of acquisition to support deployment and the test content does not yet address important operational questions," the report says.

It makes it clear that the armed forces' desire to bring modern hi-tech weapons on stream is consistently running ahead of the proof that they can actually do the job for which they are intended.

The failure to submit new systems to adequate testing has caused repeated delays in all the armed services, the report says. "The impact of reductions [of testing] can be seen in the doubling of army systems that failed to meet reliability requirements," Mr Coyle writes.

In recent years 66% of all US air force programmes have had to stop operational testing because the system under test was not in fact ready for testing "due to some major system or safety shortcoming", the report says. In the past five years 80% of army weapons and equipment programmes have failed to achieve even half of their "reliability requirements", it adds.

The report is especially critical of the way in which the increasingly ill-fated and hugely expensive V-22 Osprey vertical takeoff aircraft programme has been allowed to get so close to deployment with so many basic safety and reliability issues unsolved.

The Osprey, which crashed twice last year killing 23 US marines, is a revolutionary cross between a helicopter and a plane. It is intended to replace the current generation of medium lift assault helicopters.

Tests were reduced "due to cost and schedule pressures", the report says. Instead of carrying out the planned 103 tests of the controversial tilt-rotor plane, the marines first cut the number to 49 and then conducted only 33.

Rather than test the Osprey's reliability under icing conditions or under air combat simulations, the US navy issued waivers to cancel the tests.

The report's criticisms of the national missile defence (NMD) programme come at a time when President Bush has ordered his defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, to conduct a review of defence strategy and needs, including the role of NMD.

It is expected to recommend a central role for a more extensive NMD system than the one that was tested under the Clinton administration.

The report is highly critical of the adequacy of the testing programme to which missile defences were subjected as part of the Clinton administration's more limited programme to examine the feasibility of a land-based system of about 100 anti-missile interceptors based in Alaska.

Unsuccessful NMD test intercepts in 1999 and 2000 were not only failures but were dogged by "considerable limitations" in reliability, Mr Coyle says.

These included a failure to achieve "realistic engagement conditions" with respect to radar tracking, range, intercept altitude and closing velocity, as well as other features.

The tests were of limited use, because they simulated "only unsophisticated counter-measures, such as simple balloons". In real combat, the report says, hostile missiles would be equipped with much more elaborate and effective decoy systems.

webTitle: RiverSoft rolling on despite big losses

fields.headline: RiverSoft rolling on despite big losses
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: RiverSoft, whose software detects faults on data networks, yesterday announced widening losses due to increased costs.
fields.body:
RiverSoft, whose software detects faults on data networks, yesterday announced widening losses due to increased costs.

The company, which raised £86.1m when it joined the London Stock Exchange TechMark in December, reported a pre-tax loss of £27m for the year, compared to £5.3m for the previous year.

Turnover increased from £0.5m to £5.2m over the year but sales and marketing costs increased to £14.3m from £2.3m in 1999.

The company, which claims to allow businesses to limit the effects of network flaws, has signed agreements with Cisco and Hewlett Packard both of whom have agreed to build RiverSoft software into their products, giving RiverSoft access to a much bigger customer base. The firm signed 39 new customers last year.

"Riversoft is concentrating on building its business organically," Phil Tee, chairman and chief technical officer, said. "That doesn't rule out acquisitions but it would have to be compelling."

Analysts were yesterday positive about the results, but emphasised it is still early days for the company. "I would expect to see more and more big customers signed, and to see them get more of their management applications to market place", one analysts said.

Shares in RiverSoft rose 4p to 127.5p.

fields.headline: At this price?
fields.standfirst:
TranXenoGen

Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: It is amazing what you can do with an egg, a little imagination and an appetite for something different. Biotech company TranXenoGen, for example, claims it can help dwarfs grow using chickens' eggs containing human growth hormone.
fields.body:
It is amazing what you can do with an egg, a little imagination and an appetite for something different. Biotech company TranXenoGen, for example, claims it can help dwarfs grow using chickens' eggs containing human growth hormone.

TranXenoGen's speciality is fiddling with chickens to make them secrete useful proteins in the whites of their eggs.

Producing growth hormones is still a year or so away, but TranXenoGen reckons it could begin extracting insulin by this autumn. The diabetic market is enormous, so if its technology works, TranXenoGen is on to something extremely lucrative.

In its maiden annual results, TranXenoGen yesterday announced a $1.97m (£1.35m) loss. The company is based in Massachusetts, although its primary listing is on London's Alternative Investment Market.

Since floating in July, TranXenoGen's shares have flown from 200p to 497p, valuing the business at £157m. Biotech analyst Larissa Thomas of house broker WestLB Panmure reckons the excitement has been driven by setbacks to other transgenic pioneers.

Across the biotech industry, more than 160 mono clonal antibodies are in clinical development, and 90 are already on the market. The challenge is to achieve low cost production of large volumes .

TranXenoGen's chickens are not free range - chief executive Steve Parkinson says that would increase the risk of salmonella.

The company's chairman is the Malaysian entrepreneur Kim Tan, who has a good track record as the founder of KS Biomedix - one of the hottest stocks of last year.

At the earliest, TranXenoGen's insulin will reach the market in 2005, so investors will require patience. The real test will come in the autumn, when the firm is due to crack open its first egg. Any delay will hit the share price, which has gone far enough already. Hold.

webTitle: Long lunch led to US sub's fatal collision

fields.headline: Long lunch led to US sub's fatal collision
fields.trailText: A long lunch caused delays which contributed to the collision between the US submarine Greeneville and a Japanese fisheries training vessel, in which nine people died, an inquiry was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A long lunch caused delays which contributed to the collision between the US submarine Greeneville and a Japanese fisheries training vessel, in which nine people died, an inquiry was told yesterday.

The submarine commander was 45 minutes behind schedule because of the lunch with visiting civilian VIPs, so he ordered a rapid surfacing manoeuvre in half the usual time, said Rear Admiral Charles Griffiths, who is leading the investigation into the sinking of the Ehime Maru off the coast of Hawaii last month.

"He wanted to get to periscope depth in a hurry," Admiral Griffiths told the court of inquiry in Pearl Harbour, Hawaii, appointed to decide what happened and whether there should be criminal charges.

"I can surmise it was because they were late from their previous schedule."

Lunch with the visitors took longer than it might have done because the Greeneville's mess room could cater for only 10 at a time and two sittings were needed.

Commander Scott Waddle considered it important to spend "quality time" with the guests, who were donors to a memorial fund for another submarine.

There were other mistakes on the day the submarine sliced through the hull of the 57-metre Ehime Maru.

"Control room instruments were broken, civilians in the control room distracted the crew, one of two sonar operators was a trainee who was not supervised consistently, a sonar search of the area was incomplete, and the submarine spent only 80 seconds at periscope depth before surfacing," Admiral Griffiths said.

The rapid surfacing manoeuvre - which took five rather than the usual 10 minutes - is considered the climax of public-relations civilian tours, which President Bush said after the tragedy should be reviewed.

webTitle: Darwin's pickled fish comes unblinking into the light

fields.headline: Darwin's pickled fish comes unblinking into the light
fields.standfirst: Natural History Museum begins transfer of 22m specimens to new premises
fields.trailText: Natural History Museum begins transfer of 22m specimens to new premises.
fields.body:
They emerged, with unblinking glassy stares, after decades and even centuries in the dark. They came out pickled, half cut and in one case cut to pieces. They were the first of 22m zoological specimens preserved in alcohol to move to new premises, and at last into the public eye, at the Natural History Museum in South Kensington, London.

They were wheeled out a few at a time. There was a giant spotted ray caught in the Indian ocean more than 40 years ago; a 12ft oarfish found by a man walking his dog in Whitby in 1981, so large it had to be cut into six pieces; the first pufferfish to be described by science, by Charles Darwin during his time aboard HMS Beagle; the first groupers, caught by Captain James Cook in the Marquesas islands in the Pacific; a shark from Harrods.

Some were "type specimens" - the first of their species to be described and named, the official representatives of their kind. Some of them had stayed on much the same shelves, far from the public gaze, in the research departments of the museum since it was built in 1881, and some were far older. Some were collected by Sir Hans Sloane, the 17th-century scientist who invented milk chocolate and gave his name to Sloane Square.

Altogether, the museum has 78m specimens of fish, bird, mammal, insect, plant, fossil, mineral and rock. The preserved fish and marine creatures will be seen by the public for the first time with the opening next year of the first £27m phase of the museum's Darwin Centre. Some were plucked from the seas more than two centuries ago and dunked in ship's rum to keep them from rotting. Most of them are now stored in 70% by volume methyl alcohol.

"We've got them since 1774," said Oliver Crimmen, curator of fish. "This is perhaps the longest running experiment in preserving biological specimens. Alcohol seems to work so far, so we are hoping it is more or less permanent. There is no finer method that we have discovered."

The march of the fish is only the beginning. They will be followed by tanks of sharks and turtles, and then reptiles, spiders and parasitic worms. Future stages will see the transfer of millions of transfixed beetles, butterflies, ants and bees, tens of thousands of dried and pressed plants, thousands of stuffed and dried mammals and birds.

Biodiversity

The specimens of once living tissue have huge scientific value: they are the cornerstone of a worldwide effort to understand the planet's biodiversity. Birds' eggs from public collections provided evidence of the threat to wildlife from organochlorine pesticides in the 1960s; experts from the museum 10 years later provided solutions to the pests that plagued cassava and other developing world staples.

Specimens are now providing DNA samples which could answer questions about evolutionary links. They are also still providing information about disease-bearing pests such as blackfly and mosquito, and about crops and animal diseases - as well as new clues to engineering design. Shark skin is not smooth: it has tiny teeth all over its surface.

"These cut drag and smooth water flows over the shark's body," Dr Crimmen said. Now we understand the technique, it is used on the hulls of boats, high performance swimwear and on the bodies of long-haul aircraft to cut fuel costs."

Some of the museum's largest preserved mammals - stuffed elephants, rhinos and so on - are kept in a controlled environment in a warehouse at Wandsworth. But the zoology department also has to move many of its 10m dried specimens to the new Darwin Centre. "It might be bones, it might be skins, it might be whole birds, moa bones, bits of dodo and so on," said Phil Rainbow, head of zoology.

"We are going to do guided tours to show people the collections we are now moving, but in addition to that we are going to have a meet-the-scientist session, twice a day. It may involve things like video links, and I hope we can use our Wandsworth collections in that respect, so we can have curators showing the public who come here some of the things we have got at Wandsworth."

Most museums can only ever show about a 10th of their collections. The Natural History Museum has never been able to show even a 100th of its material. The hope is that, by the time the museum has managed to raise a further £53m to complete the Darwin Centre, the bulk of the collection of life's astonishing variety will be open to public gaze.

One of the first to wheel a specimen from a dark Victorian storeroom to a partly finished building site was the director, Neil Chalmers. "It's what it is all about," he said. "It typifies what we are really trying to do. We are trying to replace this old and really unpleasant working environment."

"We'll have lifts to all of the floors, we'll have computer touchscreens so people can key in information they want themselves. It's really about opening the whole thing up. This symbolises it."

History of the collection

 The collection began with 1,555 fishes, 521 amphibians and 1,436 crustaceans collected by Sir Hans Sloane and left to the nation in 1753. Joseph Banks collected 500 fish, and Captain James Cook later collected the first kangaroo to be seen in Europe.

 By 1800, the British Museum had 140,000 specimens. To keep the numbers under control, the departmental head used to burn or bury specimens. With the move to South Kensington in 1882, keepers had to find room for 52,635 bottles of preserved specimens. By the outbreak of war in 1939, researchers had to store 250,000 bottles of pickled creatures in a quarry.

 Now 4.5km of shelving holds 2.5m fish specimens in 450,000 jars - along with a slide collection of 176,000 invertebrates. New specimens are being added at 50,000 a year. A further 10m specimens have been donated by the Institute of Oceanographic Sciences.

webTitle: 27 visits by social worker failed to save child

fields.headline: 27 visits by social worker failed to save child
fields.standfirst: Father gets life for killing girl after campaign of violent abuse
fields.trailText: A man who subjected his two-year-old daughter to a systematic campaign of violent abuse despite numerous visits by social services was jailed for life yesterday for her murder.
fields.body:
A man who subjected his two-year-old daughter to a systematic campaign of violent abuse despite numerous visits by social services was jailed for life yesterday for her murder.

Robert Brown, 33, was visited by the same social worker 27 times in the 10 weeks before he killed his daughter Chelsea. On each occasion the social worker, Norma McDevitt, accepted his claim that he and his wife had not harmed the girl.

Ms McDevitt knew Brown was a convicted robber with a record of violent offences against children but took no action despite Chelsea's numerous injuries, Nottingham crown court was told.

Brown variously told Ms McDevitt that Chelsea had fallen in the garden, walked into a table, or banged her head while on a bus. He also blamed his other daughter, claiming the 17-month-old left Chelsea battered and bruised by pelting her with toys.

Chelsea died on December 6 1999 after Brown shook her with a force comparable to that of a high speed car crash. On the night of the attack at the family home in Kirk Hallam, Derbyshire, he pointed at his younger daughter and told paramedics: "There's the culprit." Chelsea died in hospital the following day.

A postmortem examination found 47 injuries on her head and body, including bruises running the length of her spine. At the house, police found the imprint of her head in a ceiling where Brown had smashed her into it.

Bruce Buckley, director of social services at Derbyshire county council, accepted the authority had failed in its duty of care. "We made mistakes and we got it wrong. We terribly regret what happened to Chelsea," he said. "But at the time she was returned to her home no one could have predicted the outcome. The workers were concerned - that's why they visited so regularly. But there were difficult decisions to be made, and in this case we didn't make the right ones."

He refused to comment on Ms McDevitt's conduct and declined to say whether she was still employed by the council.

Sentencing Brown to life, Mr Justice Hunt said: "I have detected no remorse and no regret - simply an attempt to shift the blame on to your wife and accept no responsibility."

Chelsea's mother, Maria Brown, 25, was jailed for 18 months after she admitted child cruelty. "You have limited intellectual capacity but sufficient understanding to know what was going on," the judge said.

"You did nothing to protect Chelsea from your husband. And I cannot ignore that you were also harsh in your punishments and often unfeeling."

The court heard that Brown killed Chelsea after almost four months of abuse. Until August 1999 she had led a healthy, happy life in the care of her paternal grandmother Janice Johnson. But Mrs Johnson felt she could no longer look after her and the child was returned to her parents.

Ms McDevitt would regularly find fresh bruises on her - yet, despite knowing Brown's history, she did not remove Chelsea from the home. She sobbed as she told how she once found a lock on the child's bedroom door during one of 27 visits to the family. She accepted the couple's explanation that it had been fitted to stop her falling down nearby stairs.

On another occasion, two months before Chelsea was killed, Ms McDevitt took her to hospital with a black eye. "She was seen by a sister, who got a doctor - and he was happy the injury was accidental," she said.

Ms McDevitt described Brown's behaviour as "inappropriate", criticising him for the physical way in which he played with his children. Brown claimed to have been throwing Chelsea in the air to "toughen her up" on the night she suffered her fatal injuries.

But neighbours said they were tormented for weeks by the sounds of him abusing his daughter. John Milmo QC, prosecuting, told the jury: "They said it was always in the same sequence - crying, shouting, silence .. crying, shouting, silence."

Banging and thumping was often followed by Brown screaming "Have you had enough yet?" and "Now do you understand?" Social services received more than half a dozen calls from worried neighbours but on one occasion did not even bother to respond.

Two days before the fatal attack the parents were offered respite care by Ms McDevitt but turned it down, insisting they wanted Chelsea to stay with them.

fields.bodyText: A man who subjected his two-year-old daughter to a systematic campaign of violent abuse despite numerous visits by social services was jailed for life yesterday for her murder. Robert Brown, 33, was visited by the same social worker 27 times in the 10 weeks before he killed his daughter Chelsea. On each occasion the social worker, Norma McDevitt, accepted his claim that he and his wife had not harmed the girl. Ms McDevitt knew Brown was a convicted robber with a record of violent offences against children but took no action despite Chelsea's numerous injuries, Nottingham crown court was told. Brown variously told Ms McDevitt that Chelsea had fallen in the garden, walked into a table, or banged her head while on a bus. He also blamed his other daughter, claiming the 17-month-old left Chelsea battered and bruised by pelting her with toys. Chelsea died on December 6 1999 after Brown shook her with a force comparable to that of a high speed car crash. On the night of the attack at the family home in Kirk Hallam, Derbyshire, he pointed at his younger daughter and told paramedics: "There's the culprit." Chelsea died in hospital the following day. A postmortem examination found 47 injuries on her head and body, including bruises running the length of her spine. At the house, police found the imprint of her head in a ceiling where Brown had smashed her into it. Bruce Buckley, director of social services at Derbyshire county council, accepted the authority had failed in its duty of care. "We made mistakes and we got it wrong. We terribly regret what happened to Chelsea," he said. "But at the time she was returned to her home no one could have predicted the outcome. The workers were concerned - that's why they visited so regularly. But there were difficult decisions to be made, and in this case we didn't make the right ones." He refused to comment on Ms McDevitt's conduct and declined to say whether she was still employed by the council. Sentencing Brown to life, Mr Justice Hunt said: "I have detected no remorse and no regret - simply an attempt to shift the blame on to your wife and accept no responsibility." Chelsea's mother, Maria Brown, 25, was jailed for 18 months after she admitted child cruelty. "You have limited intellectual capacity but sufficient understanding to know what was going on," the judge said. "You did nothing to protect Chelsea from your husband. And I cannot ignore that you were also harsh in your punishments and often unfeeling." The court heard that Brown killed Chelsea after almost four months of abuse. Until August 1999 she had led a healthy, happy life in the care of her paternal grandmother Janice Johnson. But Mrs Johnson felt she could no longer look after her and the child was returned to her parents. Ms McDevitt would regularly find fresh bruises on her - yet, despite knowing Brown's history, she did not remove Chelsea from the home. She sobbed as she told how she once found a lock on the child's bedroom door during one of 27 visits to the family. She accepted the couple's explanation that it had been fitted to stop her falling down nearby stairs. On another occasion, two months before Chelsea was killed, Ms McDevitt took her to hospital with a black eye. "She was seen by a sister, who got a doctor - and he was happy the injury was accidental," she said. Ms McDevitt described Brown's behaviour as "inappropriate", criticising him for the physical way in which he played with his children. Brown claimed to have been throwing Chelsea in the air to "toughen her up" on the night she suffered her fatal injuries. But neighbours said they were tormented for weeks by the sounds of him abusing his daughter. fields.headline: BT banged to rights
fields.trailText: Amid the renewed enthusiasm for telecom stocks yesterday, one company was slow to join the fun - BT.
fields.body:
Amid the renewed enthusiasm for telecom stocks yesterday, one company was slow to join the fun - BT.

While the likes of Vodafone and Energis raced ahead, BT was more pedestrian, rising 15.5p to 575p. Dealers blamed fresh speculation of a BT rights issue.

According to the stock market gossip, Philip Hampton, BT's finance director, gave the clearest indication yet that BT considers a rights issue the best way to resolve its debt problem.

Mr Hampton is said to have indicated that a BBB credit rating was acceptable to BT and that it did not want to float BT Wireless at a knock down price. Traders interpreted this to mean that BT favours a rights issue over divestments.

Whether institutional shareholders would back a rights issue, without wholesale management changes, remains open to question.
