fields.headline: Signet suffers a short story
fields.standfirst: Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Is Signet about to become the latest company to be hurt by the US economic slowdown? In a strong market the jeweller's formerly known as Ratners slipped 3.25p to 74.25p in heavy volume, amid rumours that a profits alert will accompany full-year results on March 28.
fields.body:
Is Signet about to become the latest company to be hurt by the US economic slowdown? In a strong market the jeweller's formerly known as Ratners slipped 3.25p to 74.25p in heavy volume, amid rumours that a profits alert will accompany full-year results on March 28.

Market professionals, who were yesterday shorting the H Samuel owner, reckon the company has been hit hard by the decline in American consumer confidence and will warn on profitability in the year ahead with the figures. As Signet makes 70% of its sales in North America it is highly sensitive to the performance of the US economy.

Not everybody was convinced by yesterday's speculation. Sceptics pointed out that Signet updated the City on current trading only a month ago and found it difficult to be lieve that things had turned sour that quickly.

At the time, Signet reported a 3.3% growth in like-for-like sales in the 13 weeks to January 27.

But, the bears countered, the last update disclosed a worrying slowdown in US sales - which they believe has gathered pace. Although US like-for-likes sales were up 1.1%, this was a weaker figure than reported previously.

The company refused to comment on the rumours.

Signet was not the only old economy stock to suffer yesterday, as the market was shaken by a switch back into technology and telecom stocks after encouraging signals from New York.

Vodafone and chip designer ARM Holdings led the way, as the FTSE 100 regained the 6,000 level in scenes reminiscent of this time last year when the FTSE Techmark 100 reached its record high.

There was almost indiscriminate buying of anything that could remotely be deemed hi-tech, as the idea that market might have bottomed out suddenly found support. Overnight Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter had advised their clients, after five weeks of sharp declines, to buy US equities

The final scores showed the FTSE 100 ahead by 80.7 points at 6,012, with Vodafone alone contributing 50 index points, as traders rushed to cover short positions built up during the mobile phone company's recent decline.

Vodafone's rise - up 18.5p to 208.25p - also helped it regain its position as Britain's biggest company, knocking BP, up 8p to 589p, into second place, and GlaxoSmithKline , off 64p at £18.56, into third.

Meanwhile, Cable & Wireless put on 53p to 748p, Energis added 33p to 475p and telecoms testing firm Spirent advanced 34.5p to 452p, lifted by positive feedback from a lunch with Lehman Brothers on Monday.

But many traders remained wary, warning that the rally could falter quickly.

Over in the tech sector, yesterday's bounce - the FTSE Techmark 100 ended 96.24 points higher at 2,398.10 - was making a mockery of the notion that demotion from the FTSE 100 or the FTSE 250 affects stock prices.

Index compiler FTSE announces its quarterly reshuffle today and based on last night's closing prices Telecity , Orchestream , and Imagination Technology are all facing relegation to the small cap market. Yet, such was the power of yesterday's recovery they all ended higher - rising 57.5p to 425p, 22.5p to 180p and 9.5p to 107p respectively.

Elsewhere, the picture was much the same. Autonomy , which alongside logistics group Exel, is likely lose its blue chip status today, rose 118p to £13.70. Their places seem destined to be taken by Scottish & Newcastle , down 15.5p to 522.5, and Sema , unchanged at 552.5p.

Lower down the market, British Regional Air Lines , up 3.5p to 115p, was being chased higher on speculation that takeover talks - first revealed in December - are close to fruition. British Airways is widely thought to be the bidder.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: EU | China | Russia | New England
fields.body:
EU critic was fairly sacked

A senior British Eurocrat who was sacked for writing a book which savaged the single currency lost his appeal against unfair dis missal yesterday. In a test case, the European court of justice ruled that the severity of Bernard Connolly's criticism was bound to end his career, and noted that he had failed toask permission to write the book.
Andrew Osborn, Brussels

41 die as school collapses

Forty-one people were killed yesterday when a school collapsed in eastern China after an explosion.

Another 27 people were injured in the collapse of the two-storey building in Wanzai county, Jiangxi province, the Xinhua news agency said. The cause of the blast was not known.
Reuters, Beijing

Russian limo perks under fire

Russian civil servants have been accused of profligacy after figures showed that the number of official chauffeur-driven limousines for senior officials rose by 23,500 last year to 605,290.

Trud newspaper said: "A country which is just pulling itself out of a deep crisis cannot afford such extravagance."
Reuters, Moscow

Snow storm hits New England

Blizzards buried much of New England yesterday in heavy, wet snow, cut power to thousands of homes and flooded coastal communities. Hundreds of flights from airports, including Philadelphia, New York and Boston, were cancelled.
Reuters, Boston

fields.headline: Sonar seeks bridge victims
fields.trailText: A sonar search by the Portuguese navy detected objects in the river Douro yesterday which could be the vehicles in which an estimated 70 people died when part of a bridge collapsed on Sunday.
fields.byline: Martin Roberts in Castelo de Paiva and Giles Tremlett in Oporto
fields.body:
A sonar search by the Portuguese navy detected objects in the river Douro yesterday which could be the vehicles in which an estimated 70 people died when part of a bridge collapsed on Sunday.

The naval officer in charge of the search, Commander Augusto Ezequiel, said echoes had been picked up 100 metres downstream from where a bus and at least two cars plunged into the river.

"We detected something about 12 metres long ... and four other objects similar to cars," he said, standing beside the broken century-old bridge about 20 miles inland from the northern city of Oporto.

Divers were preparing to investigate the objects, which were lying in about 15 metres of water. But before they could go down, a diving platform had to be put in place, he said: "We cannot be certain of anything until we have been down to take a look."

The coach is believed to contain the bodies of 64 people. Finding it has become a national obsession as the government tries to claw back some credibility: people blame it for ignoring warnings about cracks in the bridge, between the towns of Castelo de Paiva and Entre-Os-Rios.

Only one body, that of a woman aged 50, has been found so far. It became apparent yesterday that the accident may have claimed more than 70 lives: a third car with an unknown number of occupants was reported missing.

The local paper Jornal de Noticias published a page of pictures of the dead yesterday, including many children and babies.

Criticism of the government was increased by the claim that the official body in charge of road bridges had only a handful of engineers but was stuffed with members the prime minister, Antonio Guterres's Socialist party.

President Jorge Sampaio visited the village of Raiva, where the chairman of the parish council, Antonio Rodrigues, said: "Whole families have disappeared."

Martin Roberts is a Reuters correspondent

fields.headline: Briton to combat Olympics threat
fields.trailText: A leading British counter-terrorism officer is to head an international team of security experts advising Greece on its preparations for the Athens Olympics in 2004.
fields.body:
A leading British counter-terrorism officer is to head an international team of security experts advising Greece on its preparations for the Athens Olympics in 2004.

In an effort to allay growing fear about Greece's ability to clamp down on terrorism and political violence before the games, David Veness, the Metropolitan police assistant commissioner for special operations, is to coordinate a specialist security team from the US, Australia, Spain, Israel, Germany and France.

The team will help with everything from training police officers and using information technology to advanced surveillance techniques and crisis management.

"We're happy to offer advice in any way we can," the Metropolitan police commissioner, Sir John Stevens, said.

"Major events such as the Olympics place exceptional demands on host countries' police forces. Our cooperation will not be just for the four weeks of the Olympics, but will pay long-term dividends."

Sir John was in Athens for talks with Greek officials on terrorism and progress in the case of Stephen Saunders, the British military attache in Athens who was murdered by terrorists in June.

Since the murder by members of the elusive November 17 terrorist group, Greece has been under intense international pressure to show results in its counter-terrorism efforts. November 17 has waged a 25-year campaign of violence against Greek and foreign targets with apparent impunity.

Some critics have suggested that it has received protection from members of the Greek establishment; others blame the lack of terrorist arrests on the incompetence of the poorly trained and unmeritocratic police force.

In addition to the security issue, the preparations for the games have been beset by missed deadlines, excessive bureaucracy and political infighting, and the Socialist government has been put on the defensive by persistent rumours that the games might be moved elsewhere.

fields.headline: Mafia's classics crime
fields.trailText: The Mafia has been suspected of many things in the past, but never of harbouring a predilection for the classics.
fields.body:
The Mafia has been suspected of many things in the past, but never of harbouring a predilection for the classics.

Yesterday, however, police arrested 14 people accused of helping it take over Italy's National Institute for Ancient Drama, which has been staging theatrical productions in the Greek amphitheatre at Syracuse, Sicily, for 87 years.

Investigators said the Mafia began controlling the theatre's car park, then the usher services and the renting of cushions, and eventually assumed complete financial control, boosting costs by up to 500%.

The influence of organised crime on theatre contracts transformed a 500,000 lire (£163,000) profit in 1994 into a 5bn lire loss four years later, they said.

Among those arrested was the institute's artistic director, Filippo Amoroso, 52, who is also a professor of drama at Palermo University and artistic director of the principal theatre in Catania. He was joined by Michele Midolo, an alleged Mafia boss linked to the Urso-Bottaro crime family.

Another suspect is a leading classical Greek scholar, Umberto Albini.

Theatre administrators have been charged with fraud, false accounting and rigging contracts, while their alleged accomplices are accused of extortion and Mafia association.

The arrests, dubbed "Operation Agamemnon" after an Aeschylus play performed by the institute in 1914, follow a three-year investigation based on information supplied by pentiti (Mafia supergrasses).

Police suspect the institute may also have been used to launder Mafia money, because some large purchases were paid for in cash.

The prestigious theatrical performances are popular with cultural tourists visiting Sicily and leading Italian actors and directors have been involved in the shows, which are staged every two years.

"The administrators knew perfectly well who they were dealing with and rigged contract tenders to favour them," Luigi Rossi, a public prosecutor, said, adding that their inertia had allowed the Mafia to take control of theatrical events and cream off large quantities of public money.

fields.headline: US judge rejects twins' adoption
fields.standfirst: Special report: babies for sale
fields.trailText: An American judge ruled yesterday that the final custody decision over the so-called "internet twins" should be made by a court in Missouri, and that the two eight-month-old baby girls now in foster care in Britain should be sent back to the US as soon as possible.
fields.body:
An American judge ruled yesterday that the final custody decision over the so-called "internet twins" should be made by a court in Missouri, and that the two eight-month-old baby girls now in foster care in Britain should be sent back to the US as soon as possible.

Pulaski county chancery judge Mackie Pierce said neither Alan and Judith Kilshaw of Buckley, North Wales, nor Richard and Vickie Allen of San Bernadino, California had met legal requirements to adopt the twins.

The ruling, in a court in Little Rock, Arkansas, is the latest twist in a saga that has seen the battle to adopt the twins shift from Missouri to California to Wales to London to Arkansas.

Shortly after the twins were born in St Louis, Missouri, to Tranda and Aaron Wecker last June, they were offered for adoption by their mother through an internet agency. The Allens believed that they had an agreement with the Caring Heart Adoption Agency to take the children and looked after them for two months while the adoption procedure was being carried out.

But the Kilshaws subsequently reached an agreement with the agency and travelled to the US. The babies' mother took the children from the Allens, saying she wanted to say a final farewell to them, and gave them to the Kilshaws, who took the twins to Arkansas where they were able to adopt them under the state's lenient adoption laws.

After the Kilshaws returned to Britain, the children were taken into the custody of the social services, where their status is now the subject of a legal battle.

Both of the twins' parents, who are separated, are now independently seeking custody of the twins in Missouri and have filed civil suits to secure them. Last week, a St Louis court also ruled that the decision about their future should be made in Missouri. This means there are now four separate claims on the twins.

The case had a new twist in recent days with the arrest in California last week of Mr Allen on charges of molesting two teenage babysitters. He denies the allegations.

fields.headline: Irish to rearrange England game
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The Irish Rugby Football Union is privately resigned to postponing the Six Nations Championship match against England in Dublin on March 24 because of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
The Irish Rugby Football Union is privately resigned to postponing the Six Nations Championship match against England in Dublin on March 24 because of the foot and mouth crisis. It is expected that it will today announce a revised date, with the first weekend in May the likely alternative, following talks with the Irish department of agriculture.

No final decision has yet been taken about France's home game with Wales on March 17, with the French authorities continuing to stress yesterday that a postponement could not be ruled out.

webTitle: Racing: French still hope to be at Festival

fields.headline: French still hope to be at Festival
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: French trainers were given a glimmer of hope yesterday that they might yet be able to send horses to the Cheltenham Festival when authorities gave the go ahead for racing to resume in their country.
fields.body:
French trainers were given a glimmer of hope yesterday that they might yet be able to send horses to the Cheltenham Festival when authorities gave the go ahead for racing to resume in their country.

France Galop chief executive Louis Romanet said: "The signs are more positive than yesterday. We have to be more hopeful of our horses going to Cheltenham now."

Chantilly-based Francois Doumen will be the biggest sufferer if the travel ban continues. He is responsible for leading Tote Cheltenham Gold Cup challenger First Gold as well as Royal & SunAlliance Novice Hurdle favourite Baracouda and Elite Racing Club Triumph Hurdle contender Bilboa.

Their plans were thrown into turmoil when the French acted to prevent the possible spread of foot and mouth disease with tough measures including a ban on the transportation of horses.

But after discussions yesterday the authorities have come up with a strict code of practice to allow horses to go to the races.

"We have had to call off a meeting at Enghien because there was a suspected case 10 kilometres from the course," said Romanet yesterday.

"But with the special regulations that have been brought in we are able to hold a trotting meeting tomorrow and will stage a Flat meeting on Thursday." He stressed, however, there was no word from the authorities regarding taking horses abroad.

"This is a difficult situation and anything could happen yet. The trainers might not know one way or the other until next Monday," added Romanet.

webTitle: Last minute £3m lottery claim could be bogus

fields.headline: Last minute £3m lottery claim could be bogus
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: National Lottery security officers were yesterday investigating "anomalies" surrounding a £3m jackpot claim made in a telephone call minutes before the six month deadline expired at 11pm on Monday.
fields.body:
National Lottery security officers were yesterday investigating "anomalies" surrounding a £3m jackpot claim made in a telephone call minutes before the six month deadline expired at 11pm on Monday.

If the claim proves genuine, it will be the longest time after a draw that a winner has waited to identify themselves. If it turns out to be a hoax, the jackpot will be the largest in the lottery's history to go unclaimed, and will be given to good causes.

The ticket was purchased in south Hertfordshire for a midweek draw on September 6 last year. The winning numbers were 6, 7, 11, 23, 32 and 44.

fields.headline: Gang 'charged migrant 24 years of pay'
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: A Chinese illegal immigrant was charged the equivalent of 24 years' salary by a criminal gang for smuggling him into Britain, the lorry deaths trial was told yesterday.
fields.body:
A Chinese illegal immigrant was charged the equivalent of 24 years' salary by a criminal gang for smuggling him into Britain, the lorry deaths trial was told yesterday.

Feng He, 20, endured a six-month journey from China to England, crossing the English Channel in an airless, hot lorry, Maidstone crown court heard.

He was then kept prisoner in a high-rise flat in London by minders of a snakehead gang until his family paid the fee for his journey, he said. His parents had to borrow nearly all the money from the gang at a high interest rate.

The former factory worker in Fujian province gave evidence on the fifth day of the trial of a Dutch lorry driver and Chinese interpreter accused of conspiring to smuggle 60 Chinese into Britain last June. Fifty-eight suffocated during the journey.

Feng He told the court how the translator, Ying Guo, had been his contact in London and had filled out his bogus asylum application form.

The lorry driver, Perry Wacker, 32, of Rotterdam, is charged with 58 counts of manslaughter and four counts of conspiracy to smuggle people into Britain.

Guo, 29, of South Woodford, Essex, is jointly charged with Wacker on another count of conspiracy to smuggle in immigrants. They deny all charges.

Mr He said he had lived with his father, a driver, his illiterate mother and brother, 18, in a city in China. He had worked in a factory for six months after leaving school, before being sacked for taking a week off sick.

The court heard he had always wanted to leave China and agreed to pay the snakehead gang around £17,000, 24 years' salary for him, to smuggle him to England.

He left China on August 3, 1999, and arrived in Britain on February 22 last year after being packed into a lorry with 50 to 60 other Chinese immigrants in Belgium or Holland.

Mr He said: "The lorry was big. It was dark and you could not see. It was lacking oxygen, and I had difficulty breathing."

When he arrived in England snakehead minders kept him in a high rise apartment block with 20 to 30 other immigrants. His parents had to borrow nearly £15,000 in a loan from the gang in China for his release, he said. The gang was going to charge them 2% compound interest a month.

On his release from the safe house Mr He said he called Guo's number, which snakeheads had given him. "It was answered after a while. I think it was Miss Guo."

The court heard that she arranged to meet him at Victoria station in London to advise him on claiming asylum.

The case continues.

Press Association

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Analysts with good memories will have been unusually thorough in their reading of yesterday's Treasury-sponsored Review of Institutional Investment.
fields.body:
 Analysts with good memories will have been unusually thorough in their reading of yesterday's Treasury-sponsored Review of Institutional Investment. The last one (by Don Cruickshank) contained a note hidden deep in its text, inviting the first reader to have got that far to ring a telephone number and win a bottle of champagne. But there are no such give-aways in the latest report, penned by Gartmore chairman Paul Myners - also chairman of Guardian Media Group and a great guy (no, really). Attentive readers will, however, spot on page 54, mention of "dissatisfaction with the investment performance of a number of leading balanced managers". A footnote simply reads: "Including Gartmore."

 We are proud to present an exciting new feature, exclusive to the Guardian: Titans Of Business Who Resemble Fictional TV Characters. Marvel at the uncanny similarity of Marks & Spencer bosses, and members of the Thunderbirds. Chief executive Luc Vandevelde is a dead ringer for family patriarch Mr Tracy, while UK managing director Roger Holmes sports the luxuriant eyebrows of Virgil Tracy. FAB.

 SurfControl, the UK-based company that makes internet filtering software, has seen its share price trampoline of late (down 17% last week, up 11% on Monday), and blames the City rumour mill. There looks like more bad news coming: SurfControl has taken to blocking The Register, the respected IT news website (and hardly the sort of filth the program is meant to block). The Register has just commissioned its latest ABCe readership audit, so vital for judging advertising revenues. "By blocking us, SurfControl is in effect, restraining our ability to trade," says a furious Drew Cullen, one of The Register's editors. Stand by for fireworks.

 News of a conspiracy theory to rival the shooting of JFK: who were the civilians on the US submarine that sank a Japanese fishing boat last month? They were donors to the USS Missouri restoration fund, the honorary president being none other than George (W) Bush. Eight of them, including John Hall who pulled the levers that caused the sinking - came from Bush's home state of Texas. Hall and two others work for Aquila Energy, a subsidiary of Utilicorp, which donates money to the Republicans.

 No City Diary tomorrow, because of Mr Brown's ramblings. Back on Friday.

webTitle: Outmanoeuvred by the men from the military

fields.headline: Outmanoeuvred by the men from the military
fields.trailText: My father, who served in the Royal Artillery, used to tell me as a lad that war consisted of long periods of tedium interrupted by moments of absolute terror.
fields.body:
My father, who served in the Royal Artillery, used to tell me as a lad that war consisted of long periods of tedium interrupted by moments of absolute terror.

In that case, peace is somewhat different for a soldier, consisting of lengthy periods of tedium interrupted by moments of absolute boredom. Or so one would gather from watching the new chief of defence staff, Admiral Sir Michael Boyce, being grilled by the committee on the armed forces bill yesterday.

Things began quietly. The "chair", Rachel Squire MP, asked "before we start, is there anything you would like to say on the subject of the armed forces bill?"

"No," said Sir Michael.

This was a good start, but things got even quieter. The subtext of the meeting was that the Tories (apart from the chairwoman, only one Labour MP was there, and he drifted in and out) wanted Sir Michael to fulminate against the bill, predict the imminent demise of our entire military reputation, and if he were to go red in the face and start roaring about not wishing to live to see the day when this nation's soldiers were sent into battle led by a bunch of women, human rights lawyers and shirt-lifters, so much the better.

But of course nobody gets to the top in any government department by carrying on like that, least of all in the Ministry of Defence. Invited to say that discipline was about to crumble, Sir Michael merely murmured that "I don't think there are things in the bill which would make it more difficult to maintain discipline. There are some ways in which it might improve".

I don't suppose that Alastair Campbell had to stand over him with a rubber truncheon to drill in that reply. It's just the way Whitehall warriors learn to talk.

No, he continued, there was no evidence at all that the bill would affect operational preparedness. Yes, he conceded, there might be "some increase in the bureaucratic load", but everyone would get used to that.

Another Tory, Quentin Davies, tried to persuade Sir Michael to demand that our armed forces be exempted from the Human Rights Act, as the French are.

You don't catch a wary old submariner out like that. "It would be easy to say 'yes, it would make things easier for us'. But I think in the long term it will be of benefit ..."

If there was a danger of our getting too excited at seeing Britain's top fighting man in ameliorative action, it was averted by the Venerable John Blackburn, QHC. He is the chaplain general at the Ministry of Defence, which makes him the country's leading sky pilot.

General Blackburn (this is a proper military rank, and nothing to do with the Salvation Army) is even more softly spoken than his boss - Admiral Boyce, that is.

Ms Squire asked him: "Is there anything you would like to say to us, chaplain general?"

Gen Blackburn: "only that I would like to thank you for your warm welcome."

Ms Squire: "Thank you."

This ferocious inquisition continued for some time. Sadly the MPs didn't get round to putting the question I've always wanted to ask a forces padre. What would happen if he were to say to say to his commanding officer, "look, sir, I've just been talking to the man upstairs - chief of combined ops as I think of Him, ha ha - and, frightfully embarrassingly, it turns out He's not on our side ..."?

But I suppose that's not really their job. As Robert Key, the Tory MP, put it, "you should have a private room in case you need to give some great big hunk of a man a shoulder to cry on".

Well, I've heard it called many things, but never that.

webTitle: Driver killed six after eight hour pub crawl

fields.headline: Driver killed six after eight hour pub crawl
fields.trailText: A driver who killed six people including three members of the same family in a car crash after an eight hour pub crawl will be sentenced today.
fields.body:
A driver who killed six people including three members of the same family in a car crash after an eight hour pub crawl will be sentenced today.

Peter Noble, 39, had been drinking with friends and had downed 13 pints of lager and two alcopops when the Toyota Landcruiser he was driving hit an oncoming Daewoo car, killing its three occupants and three of his passengers.

Noble had been on his way to an eighth pub when he crashed into the car on the opposite side of the A57 heading towards Kiveton Park, South Yorkshire.

The occupants of the Daewoo, Roy Holmes, 79, his wife Audrey, 69, and their daughter-in-law Diane, 47, had been travelling home from a family 21st birthday party. Three of the nine in the Landcruiser - John Heywood, 42, David Wood, 35, and father-of-three Dennis Royston, 36 - also died.

Noble, of Thorpe Salvin, in South Yorkshire, was convicted yesterday at Sheffield crown court of six counts of causing death by dangerous driving. He denied the charges, saying the amount he drank had not caused the crash and water on the road was to blame.

Jamie Holmes, whose mother and grandparents were killed, said: "This has totally changed my life. I lived with my mother and grandparents, there were five of us and now there are only two, me and my dad.

"I nearly got into the Daewoo but in the end I went with my great aunt and uncle because there was not enough room.

"I came home and they didn't arrive back. I telephoned my auntie and realised what had happened when the police knocked at our door. I could not ever forgive him for what he has done."

Mr Holmes's uncle, Brian Bailey, blamed a "sub-culture [in which] you can go about and do what you like without any regard for other people".

He said: "Six people died as a result of this irresponsible act, the sentence is irrelevant. It's been horrendous for us. His reckless, loutish behaviour has brought us to this instance and has not been addressed by this verdict."

The court had heard Mr Noble began drinking at noon on July 2 last year and driven from pub to pub picking up friends on the way. He looked glazed as he left the seventh pub and drove at up to 80mph just before the crash, swaying from lane to lane on the A57.

One witness who was knocked unconscious during the drive and woke to find Mr Royston, his best friend, covered in blood, said: "He was driving like a loony."

Mr Noble suffered only minor injuries and was freed from the wreckage. He fled and used his mobile phone to ask his girlfriend, Rachel Renshaw, for help.

She took him to his sister's house, where he slept the night, and his son Carl arrived with a change of clothes.

The next day he told police that one of his dead friends had been driving. He later changed his story, saying that he had lost control of the Landcruiser when it aquaplaned.

Miss Renshaw and his son admitted perverting the course of justice before the trial began. They are expected to be sentenced today
fields.bodyText: A driver who killed six people including three members of the same family in a car crash after an eight hour pub crawl will be sentenced today. Peter Noble, 39, had been drinking with friends and had downed 13 pints of lager and two alcopops when the Toyota Landcruiser he was driving hit an oncoming Daewoo car, killing its three occupants and three of his passengers. Noble had been on his way to an eighth pub when he crashed into the car on the opposite side of the A57 heading towards Kiveton Park, South Yorkshire. The occupants of the Daewoo, Roy Holmes, 79, his wife Audrey, 69, and their daughter-in-law Diane, 47, had been travelling home from a family 21st birthday party. Three of the nine in the Landcruiser - John Heywood, 42, David Wood, 35, and father-of-three Dennis Royston, 36 - also died. Noble, of Thorpe Salvin, in South Yorkshire, was convicted yesterday at Sheffield crown court of six counts of causing death by dangerous driving. He denied the charges, saying the amount he drank had not caused the crash and water on the road was to blame. Jamie Holmes, whose mother and grandparents were killed, said: "This has totally changed my life. I lived with my mother and grandparents, there were five of us and now there are only two, me and my dad. "I nearly got into the Daewoo but in the end I went with my great aunt and uncle because there was not enough room. "I came home and they didn't arrive back. I telephoned my auntie and realised what had happened when the police knocked at our door. I could not ever forgive him for what he has done." Mr Holmes's uncle, Brian Bailey, blamed a "sub-culture [in which] you can go about and do what you like without any regard for other people". He said: "Six people died as a result of this irresponsible act, the sentence is irrelevant. It's been horrendous for us. His reckless, loutish behaviour has brought us to this instance and has not been addressed by this verdict." The court had heard Mr Noble began drinking at noon on July 2 last year and driven from pub to pub picking up friends on the way. He looked glazed as he left the seventh pub and drove at up to 80mph just before the crash, swaying from lane to lane on the A57. One witness who was knocked unconscious during the drive and woke to find Mr Royston, his best friend, covered in blood, said: "He was driving like a loony." Mr Noble suffered only minor injuries and was freed from the wreckage. He fled and used his mobile phone to ask his girlfriend, Rachel Renshaw, for help. She took him to his sister's house, where he slept the night, and his son Carl arrived with a change of clothes. The next day he told police that one of his dead friends had been driving. He later changed his story, saying that he had lost control of the Landcruiser when it aquaplaned. Miss Renshaw and his son admitted perverting the course of justice before the trial began. They are expected to be sentenced today

webTitle: Unanswered questions from the Old Convent custody case

fields.headline: Family fall-out
fields.standfirst: The Old Convent child custody case was the longest in family court history, yet still there are serious questions unanswered.  Judy Hirst reports
fields.trailText: The Old Convent child custody case was the longest in family court history, yet still there are serious questions unanswered. Judy Hirst reports
fields.body:
Not for the first time, a charismatic, highly praised social carer has been exposed as a risk to those entrusted to her. Not for the first time, there are those who simply refuse to believe it.

The extraordinary case of Jeanette Roberts, a devout Christian and former "carer of the year", who was allowed to adopt or foster more than 80 children and young adults over the past three decades, has prompted deep soul-searching among care agencies. How could it be that an individual was regarded as so credible an operator that alarm bells failed to ring about a system characterised by, in the words of Mr Justice Hughes, "deceit, manipulation and considerable emotional damage to many dependent people"?

Yet even now, with the judge's words ringing in their ears, there are supporters of Roberts who claim she is victim of a vendetta, motivated by official panic and public hysteria over child abuse.

Until recently, the Old Convent, Roberts's converted convent deep in rural Essex, had been hailed by numerous celebrities and charities as a model community: a place of warmth, love and refuge for damaged children and vulnerable adults whom no one else wanted.

But on a November morning in 1998, all that changed. A hundred police and social workers raided the Old Convent, removing all its 26 residents to "places of safety" and arresting Roberts and four colleagues on charges of physical abuse.

Essex police and social services say they had no choice but to investigate what was a large number of serious complaints, launching a hugely expensive operation that prompted the longest family court case in history. Ian Grant, lead social services manager throughout the operation, insists you cannot put a price on justice.

Nevertheless, the recent outcome of the family court proceedings raises many unanswered questions - not least, about the morality of a care system which placed responsibility for so many highly vulnerable people in one individual's hands.

All criminal charges against Roberts and her associates have now been dropped. Some of the removed children and adults have been returned to Roberts's care - a decision taken as vindication of her innocence by supporters, including Family in Trust, a charity which supports the Old Convent financially.

Those who read the judge's published ruling may take a different view. Although the judgment does not find the regime at the Old Convent to have been habitually violent, and acknowledges the benefits Roberts brought to many individuals, it is very critical of her child-rearing methods. Confinement and other heavy-handed methods of discipline were used too freely; exclusive loyalty to the Roberts "family" was demanded at the cost of contact with birth families; and children were questioned intensely and inappropriately about previous sexual abuse.

Should this be surprising? As her biographer, Claire Lorrimer, recounts, Roberts (who herself came from a very abusive family background) rapidly became the foster carer who could never say no. Her undertaking became unfeasibly large: children, some severely abused and neglected; young people with multiple disabilities and grossly disturbed behaviour. From the time she began caring for youngsters in London's east end, these, and later their offspring, became her extended family, all taking the Roberts family name.

Thirty-six were adopted by her. And, despite her lack of training and frequent run-ins with the authorities, the shortage of carers - particularly for older, seriously damaged children - meant that hard-pressed social service agencies were only too happy to oblige. "She became a victim of her own success," says Pat Verity, deputy director of the National Foster Care Association. "Her ability to turn these children around was 'rewarded' with yet more placements."

From time to time, serious doubts were raised about Roberts's unconventional practices. But, by and large, she was left to get on with mothering her ever-expanding flock; largely unregulated and unsupervised by social services since, technically, she was not running a children's home.

Parents for Children, a charity which seeks homes for "hard to place" children, put seven young people with Roberts in the early 1980s. Its director, Karen Irving, believes that, given the dictates of the fostering and adoption market place, it was the best option available at the time. But with so many emotionally disturbed children directing such primitive emotions at their primary carer, she says, the circumstances were always there for a potential disaster.

Danya Glaser, a child and adolescent psychiatrist at Great Ormond Street children's hospital, London, argues: "In this kind of setting it's extremely difficult to avoid using undesirable methods of discipline. In fact, it's very questionable how far this number of children can form any kind of attachment with their 'mother'." A small, family-type setting can give fostered and adopted children a real sense of belonging, she says, but one on this scale can only enforce that sense of identity by draw ing increasingly artificial boundaries around itself - for example, by refusing to acknowledge its members originally came from somewhere else.

This, many childcare specialists, is one of the most disturbing features of the Old Convent regime. Roberts's defenders insist that adopting a new identity is therapeutic for some children coming from a life of abuse, and a useful safety device to protect them from former abusers. But, for her detractors, it smacks of an old-fashioned, Dickensian mission to "rescue" poor unfortunates and set them on a virtuous path.

"It amounts to a terrible denial and betrayal of a child's life history," says children's services consultant Christine Walby. "Everything we know about adoption tells us children have a desperate hunger to know about their past." Equally worrying is the apparent willingness of the statutory services to place so much trust in one super-carer. For Walby, who became Staffordshire social services director after the infamous "pin-down" scandal of the early 1990s, there are uncomfortable parallels with past experiences of charismatic individuals working with highly disturbed young people.

"Tony Latham's humiliating pin-down practices, and Frank Beck's abusive 'regression therapy' [in Leicestershire], went unchallenged for so long because of the pathetic and unrealistic search by managers and inexperienced staff for a quick fix," says Walby. "They stood in awe of anyone who could 'keep the little sods quiet' for a while."

There is plenty of scope in children's services for people with commitment, originality and flair who will go the extra mile, she says, "but their work has to be rigorous and rooted in respect for good practice. They need to be challenged, and be prepared to accept advice."

In Roberts's case, that was no doubt made difficult by her growing celebrity status; the accolades from Esther Rantzen, royalty and BBC's Children in Need appeal. But how, throughout all these years, could there have been - in the words of one witness to the court proceedings - such "serial corporate blindness". Was no one aware of the implications of placing yet another child or vulnerable adult in such a pressurised setting?

A Department of Health "serious case review" is now under way. Belatedly, it will ask why so many children were permitted to be fostered and adopted by one carer, and why none of the authorities and agencies seemed to know what the others were about. As for what has really gone on all these years at the Old Convent, some still take a "told you so" stance. Others continue to view Jeanette Roberts as a saint. Perhaps we will never know the full story. It is, after all, a family affair.

fields.headline: On-loan Upson undoes Palace
fields.trailText: Birmingham City kept up their chase for automatic promotion last night with a hard-fought victory over a Crystal Palace side troubled by the threat of relegation. While their performance offered little in the way of skilful football, Birmingham's power, pace and determination showed the qualities necessary to get out of this division.
fields.body:
Birmingham City kept up their chase for automatic promotion last night with a hard-fought victory over a Crystal Palace side troubled by the threat of relegation. While their performance offered little in the way of skilful football, Birmingham's power, pace and determination showed the qualities necessary to get out of this division.

The Palace manager Alan Smith has received a lot of plaudits for the way he galvanised a struggling side on his arrival as manager at the start of this season. But while his managerial shock tactics were applauded in the autumn there are rumblings of discontent in the spring.

Palace were five points above the relegation zone at the start of play, and had lost their last three league matches. The 2-0 home defeat by Preston last weekend saw Smith complaining about a lack of "mental toughness" in his squad, a similar refrain to the one he made on his arrival at Selhurst Park.

Smith's solution that time was to place several first-team players on the transfer list. He has done it again this week by putting the fans' favourite Jamie Pollock up for sale. And one of Smith's original wrongdoers, Clinton Morrison, was left on the bench last night - the 18-goal striker sacrificed to the god of poor form.

Palace started the brighter of the two teams and the new-look frontline of Mikael Forssell and Dougie Freedman played with pace and intelligence. As early as the second minute Freedman nearly punished a weak clearance by Ian Bennett with a fierce shot from just inside the box that the recovering keeper did well to turn over. Bennett's punched clearance then found the advancing Fan Zhiyi who placed the ball inches wide of the far post. Just before half-time Freedman had another opportunity to expose Bennett but could only tuck the ball into the keeper's grateful arms.

Birmingham's forward play in the first half did not relieve the pressure. Largely looking to send Andrew Johnson, the not so wealthy man's Michael Owen, past the last defender, they got little change from the formidable Zhiyi and the willing Jamie Smith.

All that changed at the start of the second half thanks to an unwelcome contribution from Palace's on-loan Matthew Upson. Upson, on Arsenal's books, is the latest in a line of Premiership players including Ashley Cole and Forssell to spend a spell in south London.

Upson was booked late in the first half for a rash challenge on Andrew Johnson and within three minutes of the restart he had put his side behind, deflecting a Nicky Eaden shot off his side and past the keeper Aleksandrs Kolinko. Upson was involved in Birmingham's second goal 11 minutes later. Another hopeful ball out from the Birmingham defence found Andrew John son. A flick from Johnson found the substitute Dele Adebola, a scuff from Adebola came back off Upson and Adebola tucked the ball inside Kolinko's far post from 20 yards. Three minutes later Palace pulled one back, Dean Austin rising high to meet Tommy Black's corner at the penalty spot and power a header past Bennett.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Kilmarnock rely on Wright
fields.trailText: Kilmarnock came from a goal behind to tame Inverness Caledonian Thistle at the third attempt and earn a quarter-final showdown with Hibernian on Saturday.
fields.body:
Kilmarnock succeeded where Celtic had failed last year, coming from a goal behind to tame Inverness Caledonian Thistle at the third attempt in the Scottish Cup and earn a home quarter-final with Hibernian on Saturday.

Davide Xausa opened the scoring for the visitors but Killie replied through Kevin McGowne and a Paul Wright penalty. This was a re-run of last week's replay at Rugby Park which lasted only 28 minutes and prompted a Scottish Football Association investigation. Kilmarnock had been banned by East Ayrshire council from using their undersoil heating the night before the game due to noise considerations.

Killie took their time to settle before Christophe Cocard's cross just eluded Alan Mahood and Peter Canero at the far post. Then Paul Wright had a go from distance but did not trouble Jim Calder in the Inverness goal.

Both sides tried to pass the ball in windy conditions but neither could find the necessary end product.

Mark Reilly thought he had put Canero in but the youngster was not quick enough and was crowded out to the home fans' disgust. They were baying for a penalty seconds later when Wright and Richard Hastings tussled but play continued. Hastings almost let Wright in when he chested down a Kevin McGowne cross but Calder managed to gather just in time.

Davide Xausa's low free kick just after half-time made Gordon Marshall stretch and the visitors look dangerous for the first time. Seconds later they were ahead: Hastings launched a long ball into the box from the left, finding a hole in the Killie defence and allowing Xausa to control before poking past the exposed Marshall.

Just after the hour Killie were level when Calder's punch from a corner reached Reilly on the edge of the box and he headed it back into a crowded area. McGowne beat two defenders to the loose ball to force it over the line.

Killie's next attack produced a penalty when Paul Sheerin chopped down Cocard and Wright blasted in.

fields.headline: Hughes makes Norwich pay penalty
fields.trailText: While West Brom supporters expect nothing less from a nephew of Cyrille Regis, Jason Roberts is beginning to look a class act. The young Londoner's pace and strength up front made a critical difference as the Baggies chalked up what could prove to be a crucial away win in a frantic but hugely entertaining game.
fields.body:
While West Brom supporters expect nothing less from a nephew of Cyrille Regis, Jason Roberts is beginning to look a class act. The young Londoner's pace and strength up front made a critical difference as the Baggies chalked up what could prove to be a crucial away win in a frantic but hugely entertaining game.

Albion's recent away form - four defeats in six games - saw manager Gary Megson make four changes to the team which lost to the only goal of the game at Blackburn. The availability or otherwise of strikers Jason Roberts and Lee Hughes is likely to be the critical factor in determining whether the Baggies will figure in the end of season play-offs, and the return of a partnership which had scored 32 goals going into the game caused Norwich problems from the start.

In fact with both sides playing a a genuinely positive 3-5-2, chances were being created regularly - mostly by the visitors. The best was made by Hughes, laying the ball off neatly for Michael Appleton arriving in the penalty area, but the midfielder's shot, a gentle sidefoot into the goalkeeper's stomach, was barely deserving of the name.

On the half hour however Albion's vigour and intent got the reward they deserved. Roberts, running into the area with the ball at his feet, felt the foot of the chasing Malky Malkay tap his ankles, and duly collapsed. The theatricality infuriated the Norwich supporters, but the contact looked clear enough and Hughes duly sent Andy Marshall the wrong way from the spot.

Coming into the game unbeaten at Carrow Road under Nigel Worthington, an eight match run which has seen the East Anglians pull away from the releagtion zone, Norwich came back strongly. Unfortunately the experienced but somewhat one-paced Iwan Roberts and the big but terribly raw Zema Abbey looked a measurably less potent front pairing than Albion's. Their failure to read Paul McVeigh's busy promptings ensured Norwich's only shots were from a distance never likely to trouble Russell Hoult in Albion's goal.

Roberts almost doubled the lead ten minutes into the second half, his curling effort from the angle of the penalty area drawing a deceptively fine diving save from Andy Marshall. Moments later Marshall did even better. Roberts found Ruel Fox on the right, and then was waiting on the penalty spot when the former Spurs man's cross arrived. The tumbling volley was good; the save on the line equal to it.

Norwich, though relatively blunt in comparison, should have equalised on the hour; ironically it was McVeigh, who presented with a simple chance from a rebound, could only sidefoot straight at Hoult.

Still Norwich pressed, Daryl Russell stinging Hoult's hands, but once again, from well outside the area. Roberts' substitition signalled Albion's intent to defend deep; their delight on the whistle signified the importance of the win.

Norwich, though relatively blunt in comparison, should have equalised on the hour; ironically it was McVeigh, who presented with a simple chance from a rebound, could only sidefoot straight at Hoult. Still Norwich pressed, Daryl Russell stinging Hoult's hands, but once again, from well outside the area. Roberts' substitition signalled Albion's intent to defend deep; their delight on the whistle signified the importance of the win.  You've read the piece, now have your say. webTitle: Carey's chickens come home to roost

fields.headline: Carey's chickens come home to roost
fields.trailText: Bristol City's optimistic and fading promotion hopes took another grim reverse despite an improved performance. They still lacked the jaunty style of a resurgent Walsall side, ironically guided by Bristol-born Ray Graydon. It was a match the error-prone Louis Carey will want quickly to forget.
fields.body:
Bristol City's optimistic and fading promotion hopes took another grim reverse despite an improved performance. They still lacked the jaunty style of a resurgent Walsall side, ironically guided by Bristol-born Ray Graydon. It was a match the error-prone Louis Carey will want quickly to forget.

Here were two teams painfully in need of a reversal of recent form which has affected their play-off hopes and mystified their fans. And it was Walsall who adjusted the trend in dramatic style with two goals in 90 seconds.

The first, after a quarter of an hour, came from the Portuguese striker Jorge Leitao. He dispossessed Carey, spurted forward and, helped by a slight deflection, drilled his shot past Steve Phillips.

That was a grim start for City who, weakened by injuries to key players - and forced to take a risk by bringing back their skipper Keith Millen, out on Saturday with an achilles injury - had produced a few spirited raids against mobile opponents.

But they conceded a second goal in Walsall's next concerted attack. It was the perfect debut for the midfielder Fitzroy Simpson, signed from Hearts until the end of the season. He moved on to a short pass and scored with the perfect left-foot drive from the edge of the penalty area.

Peter Beadle almost pulled back a goal immediately. His 30-yard free-kick curled over the wall, right on target. James Walker did particularly well to parry the ball, having seen it late.

A Bristol goal did come in the swirling rain after 32 minutes. Aaron Brown, effective near the left touchline in several eager home movements, crossed the ball and Tony Thorpe netted with a backward header, his 21st goal of the season.

With pools of water on the pitch, the two sides maintained a hectic pace with an encouraging emphasis on attack as if to demonstrate a rediscovered zest.

Just before the interval, Joe Burnell's thoughtful pass was pulled down by Thorpe whose shot was sharply saved by Walker. But It was a another Carey blunder which produced an own goal that settled matters.

fields.headline: Carteron leads Reid's foreign influx
fields.trailText: The Sunderland manager Peter Reid started his rebuilding work early yesterday when he agreed a £1.4m fee with Ipswich for the sale of Chris Makin and signed Frenchman Patrice Carteron on loan.
fields.body:
The Sunderland manager Peter Reid yesterday plunged into the transfer market as he started his rebuilding work early. Reid has agreed a £1.4m fee with Ipswich for the sale of 27-year-old full-back Chris Makin, while at the same time snapping up Frenchman Patrice Carteron on loan.

Makin joined Sunderland from Marseille in a £500,000 move in July 1997 and has made 142 appearances since. "He has been a great servant here and I hope things go well for him at Ipswich," said Reid. The right-back Carteron, 30, will arrive from St-Etienne on loan until the end of the season with a view to a permanent move.

Reid is also about to make a week-long scouting trip to Argentina. It is understood the 18-year-old Argentinian midfielder Nicolas Medina and Boca Juniors defender Hugo Ibarra are on his list. He is also believed to have renewed his interest in Brann's Norwegian midfielder Alex Valencia.

The Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson hopes to clinch the £1m signing of the Bradford forward Dean Windass today. The Teessiders have agreed to a £600,000 down-payment with a further £400,000 to follow if Windass helps them to avoid relegation.

The 31-year-old could get his first run-out in a friendly against St Johnstone at the Riverside tomorrow night. The Barcelona striker Dani, though, has turned down a £7m move to Middlesbrough.

The Ipswich midfielder Jim Magilton will have a personal hearing in London tomorrow after being charged with misconduct by the Football Association for comments he made to referee Andy d'Urso at the end of Ipswich's 4-1 defeat at Chelsea on January 20.

Manchester United are set to offer Teddy Sheringham and Denis Irwin new contracts.

The former Wolves and Aston Villa midfielder Mark Burke is set to become the first Englishman to play in Romania after signing for Rapid Bucharest from the Japanese side Omiya Ardija .

The Italian league leaders Roma have bought Antonio Cassano, an 18-year-old seen as a rising star, for a reported 60bn lire (£20m), Italian sports papers said yesterday. Cassano will earn a reported £1.3m a year.

"He is one of the biggest talents in Italian football," said Roma's coach Fabio Capello.

webTitle: Players threaten to sabotage transfer deal

fields.headline: Players threaten to sabotage transfer deal
fields.standfirst:
Football heading back to the courts after landmark agreement
The ins and outs of the new transfer system
fields.trailText: The European footballers' union, Fifpro, is planning a legal challenge to the sport's newly agreed transfer system, and has identified at least three players who could bring a landmark test case.
fields.body:
The European footballers' union, Fifpro, is planning a legal challenge to the sport's newly agreed transfer system, and has identified at least three players who could bring a landmark test case. This could overturn the proposals which are set to come into force from the start of next season.

The players, from Benelux countries, will claim in court that their freedom of movement is being restricted by the new proposals agreed on Monday night by a joint Fifa/Uefa taskforce and the European Commission.

The players will initially challenge the new transfer system proposals in their national courts, but the matter is likely to referred to the European Court of Justice.

The Belgian lawyer Jean Louis Du Pont, who represented Jean-Marc Bosman in the infamous court case concerning footballers' freedom of movement, and Luc Mission are leading Fifpro's challenge, having advised the organisation during the negotiations with Fifa/Uefa and the EC. Fifpro will either launch the action immediately, or wait until the new regulations come into force in the summer.

A source said: "Plans are already being made for legal action and the players who will bring the cases have already been identified. Fifpro's lawyers are just waiting for the right time."

Fifpro feels that the new proposals are too restrictive and do not give players enough freedom to break contracts.

But Mike Lee, Uefa's communications director, said last night: "No one will benefit from the sort of legal challenges Fifpro are talking about. It would distract football, distract money and resources.

"We think Fifpro would be better served working with the football authorities to make the new rules work in the best interests of European football.

"We believe that the proposed rules and regulations are legally sound, and clearly in reaching agreement with the Commission we took extensive legal advice. If Fifpro want to bring a legal challenge then that's up to them."

Sports lawyers in Britain last night warned that although many grey areas existed in the new proposals and were open to legal challenge, there were also many positive areas within what was agreed by Fifa/Uefa and the EC.

However John Taylor of Townleys solicitors, a leading firm of sports lawyers, said that the fact that football authorities and the EC had reached agreement on a new transfer system did not count for anything within British courts because national contract laws took precedence over any European ones.

For example, under the new proposals players who unilaterally break five-year contracts after a minimum of three years will not face any sanctions and be suspended from playing. However, this will not count for anything within English law and clubs could sue players for breach of contract.

Players too would have the right to sue clubs in English courts if they felt they were being treated unfairly.

Taylor, who specialises in sports competition law, said: "There are many areas within the new proposals that are vague and it is a basically a voluntary system that is not legally binding and is open to legal challenge. Each national court has the right to apply its own employment laws, regardless of what has been agreed by football and the EC."

Taylor added: "You have to praise football's governing bodies as well. They have got the EC to recognise many important issues within these proposals such as importance of stability, competition and that you need special rules in sport."

There was widespread concern throughout football yesterday at how the proposals would work and what impact they would have on the game.

Micky Cook, Colchester's youth director, said: "We need to know about the compensation side. It sounds as if there is a certain protection mechanism in place but how valuable will it be? You have to hope it reflects the current trends.

"We sold Lomano Tresor Lua-Lua to Newcastle this season for £2.25m and money like that helps to keep the club going. He was with us for around 2 years. But would the compensation under the new system be 2.25m?"

Phil and Jon Smith, who run the First Artist agency representing players such as Kanu and the Sunderland striker Kevin Phillips said that football authorities would be faced with endless court cases.

Phil Smith said: "The blueprint is in place but there are many splinter issues that need to be decided. If they try to implement the sporting sanctions you will end up with a queue of cases a mile long."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Alison Hennegan's top 10 lesbian books
fields.trailText: Alison Hennegan, who was for many years literary editor of Gay News, is a member of the faculty of English at the University of Cambridge. She has recently edited The Lesbian Pillow Book.
fields.body:
Alison Hennegan, who was for many years literary editor of Gay News, is a member of the faculty of English at the University of Cambridge. She has recently edited The Lesbian Pillow Book.

1. Sappho Through English Poetry, edited and introduced by Peter Jay and Caroline Lewis
No self-respecting list of lesbian books could omit Sappho, but which Sappho? Over the centuries she's been all things to all people: the ancients' most admired poet and the target of their comic dramatists' obscenities; lovelorn heterosexual woman, hurling herself off the Leucadian rocks when the handsome Phaon spurns her; and the archetypal lover of women whose island home of Lesbos has, for more than two thousand years now, given its name to one form of sexuality. In this book history's many Sapphos are reflected in a host of English translations culled from across the centuries.

2. What Sappho Would have Said, edited by Emma Donoghue
3. Love Shook My Senses, edited by Gillian Spraggs
Many other fine poets can be found in these two recent British anthologies These highly intelligent books wander far away from the now rather heavily beaten tracks of (mainly American) collections.

4. A Narrative of the Life of Mrs Charlotte Charke by Charlotte Charke
5. I Know My Own Heart and No Priest But Love from The Diaries of Anne Lister, edited by Helena Whitbread
If you're intrigued by the way in which women of earlier centuries made sense of their passionate feelings for other women and tried to understand the apparent conflict between their biological gender and their desires, try this trio of works. Charlotte Charke (daughter of the poet laureate, Colley Cibber) struggled against the constraints of gender all her life. Her spirited, albeit sometimes opaque, autobiography charts her precarious efforts to support herself as actress, writer, and man about town -but not, she insists, as highwayman. To many of her 18th century contemporaries she was known only as Sir Charles or Mr Brown (there was a Mrs Brown, too).
Anne Lister, the Yorkshire heiress, has left us marvellously explicit diaries, recounting the pleasures and perils of her many flirtations and affairs with women during the first decades of the 19th century, not only in her native country but also in France. These hitherto encoded diaries, magnificently transcribed and edited by Helena Whitbread, reveal an earlier lesbian world whose existence some historians have sought to deny.

6. Orlando by Virginia Woolf
7. The Well of Loneliness by Radclyffe Hall
Critics often use the first of these as a stick with which to beat the second, but they actually belong together. Both published in the same year, 1928, Hall's book was prosecuted and banned, Woolf's hailed by critics and readers alike (it was her first bestseller). Read them side by side and ponder anew why and how some forms of truth telling are venerated and rewarded, others silenced.

8. The Chinese Garden by Rosemary Manning
This marvellous autobiographical novel, first published in 1961, is a little gem. Its author is perhaps best known for her Green Dragon children's books, but here she recreates her last, sixth form year (1928) at a fiercely repressive girls' boarding school. The fear and confusion generated by the very public prosecution of The Well of Loneliness affect both girls and staff in far-reaching ways. A wonderful book, in which angry content, perfect narrative control and the finest prose combine to create something very special.

9. On Lies, Secrets and Silence by Adrienne Rich
10. Collected Poems by Adrienne Rich
An outstanding critic and poet demonstrates here the way in which sexual politics in general and lesbian politics in particular have, during the past 30-something years, shaped and changed the way in which she reads and makes literature. Here is one of America's greatest living poets at work.

fields.headline: Victims of sick housing market
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: On Sylvia Thompson's street, there is broken glass caked in dog turd. Visitors wade through litter floating on the wind.
fields.body:
On Sylvia Thompson's street, there is broken glass caked in dog turd. Visitors wade through litter floating on the wind. Half the redbrick, pre-1920 terrace houses are empty. Addicts and alcoholics crawl in and use them as dens.

Between the rows of boarded up windows are the net curtains and carriage clocks of people who bought into Salford when the area was popular. They are now trapped there. The market has collapsed and houses are worth as little as £1,500.

Mrs Thompson, 60, and her husband Arthur bought a two bedroom house in Langworthy, Salford, when they married in 1967. It cost them £600. Over the last 20 years, they have paid off their mortgage, built a £19,000 extension and redecorated. Twelve years ago their house was worth £34,000. This year it was valued at £7,500.

Less than two miles away, in central Manchester, two bedroom flats sell for £500,000.

Mrs Thompson said: "When we bought this house it was a sought after area. You had to fight to get in. We had no idea what would happen to what was once a fantastic community. We invested for our children and our retirement but we'll never get that money back. They call this place the Bronx. The council wants us to leave so they can rebuild the street. They have had the house valued at £7,500. What are we supposed to do with that?"

Mrs Thompson is a cleaner and her husband is a van driver. On their salaries, if they had to leave, they could not afford to rent. At their age, they cannot get a mortgage.

The kitchen floor has begun to subside, and the bathroom will have to be refitted. Salford council is developing a plan to destroy streets where more than three quarters of houses are derelict. Green areas will be introduced, home owners whose house value has plummeted will be asked to leave their homes to the bulldozers and will be offered nearby houses that match their current status. Community facilities will be improved.

But the Thompsons do not want to move. They want the council to revamp the area. They and people who bought houses 10 years ago have little hope.

Stephen and Dawn Curwen bought a two bedroom terrace for £26,000 in 1993. It is now worth £5,000. The couple, both 33, have three children and a high mortgage. They cannot afford to install central heating or do repairs to their roof and rotting windows and doors. if they know they will not see a return on their investment.

The Curwens' 11-year-old daughter and eight-year-old son share a room. Their three-year-old sleeps in a cot in his parents' room. The couple wanted to build an extension for another bedroom but now they cannot afford to.

"We are trapped here. What sort of life is this? There is nothing for my kids to do. We wanted to get our foot on the ladder but we fell through to the cellar," Mrs Curwen said.

webTitle: World music: An evening with the Parveen Sultana

fields.headline: An evening with the Parveen Sultana
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating:***
fields.trailText:
Queen Elizabeth Hall
London
Rating:***
fields.body:
She may be the "genius of Hindustani music" and the "ultimate soprano", but Parveen Sultana came on stage as if she was preparing to entertain a few close friends. Wearing an orange-red sari, jewellery and glasses, she sat down cross-legged on a small platform, surrounded by musicians playing tablas, harmonium and tambura, the four-stringed instrument that she also played as she sang. She called the audience "my friends", never asked for the house lights to be turned down, and confided that she needed tea for her throat at the interval.

Having established this intimate setting, she proceeded with an almost casual demonstration of her extraordinary vocal skills. She eased into her ragas gently, tamburas and harmonium providing a wash of sound against which she matched her gently drifting, trance-like vocals. Then in came the subtle, gently rousing tabla work of Mukundraj Deo, and the song began to change from mesmeric to exhilarating, as she suddenly moved into passages of quite remarkable, rapid-fire scales and improvisation. Now her voice was wailing and swooping as she showed off some of her three-and-a-half-octave range. She was singing at frantic speed, but never once gave the impression she was under any pressure. It was a remarkable tour-de-force, especially as the first song alone lasted nearly an hour.

Born into a family of musicians, Sultana gave her first classical recital at the age of 12 and was hailed as a child prodigy. Her ease, confidence and range established her as one of the stars of Indian music, occasionally moving away from her classical roots to provide songs for the Bollywood movie industry.

However, although she is a major celebrity in India, and has performed in concert halls around the world, Sultana has never become well-known in the west, despite the popularity of world music. Any artist of this stature from Latin America, Africa, or even the Arab world, would expect a multicultural following these days, but at the QEH the audience consisted almost entirely of her Indian fans.

The reason, presumably, is that she has never needed to seek a wider western audience, and has never established links with the western pop world, like Ravi Shankar or Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, the remarkable Pakistani exponent of rapid-fire classical styles and improvisation. Homely Sultana may not have quite his passionate intensity, but she is a remarkable performer who deserves an even wider audience.

webTitle: Theatre review: The Taming of the Shrew

fields.headline: Shakespeare meets the Hell's Angels
fields.standfirst:
The Taming of the Shrew
Royal Exchange
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
The Taming of the Shrew
Royal Exchange
Manchester
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Helena Kaut-Howson has never been the kind of director to be shy about throwing the melting pot into the melting pot: her vision of Shakespeare's most troubling early comedy suggests a Renaissance carnival gatecrashed by the Veronese chapter of Hell's Angels.

Most modern directors do not so much produce The Taming of the Shrew as construct elaborate apologies for it, so Kaut-Howson's gung-ho aesthetic, driven at full pelt in the pursuit of pleasure, is a striking departure. It's also so charmingly acted one is almost prepared to believe that the psychological torture inflicted on the heroine is a perfectly reasonable course of anger-management therapy.

Tanya Ronder's excellent Kate certainly simmers with an excess of fury - one wonders how this violent, blue-haired termagant can possibly meet her match, until Lloyd Hutchinson's magnificent Petruchio roars in on his horrible hot-rod and mows her down. That Kate should resist his persistent entreaties for a kiss is hardly surprising - she may be a shrew but there's no telling what manner of small mammals might be nesting in his beard. Their relationship is played, by and large, for hilarity rather than brutality.

Johanna Bryant's wonderful wardrobe concept aside, the production avoids emphatic interpretation. Having jettisoned at the 11th hour Snoo Wilson's specially commissioned adaptation of the Christopher Sly induction scenes, Kaut-Howson seems to have taken the text out of its inverted commas and played it as if it were packed full of exclamation marks instead.

A first-rate cast proves more than able to sustain the almost impossibly high energy levels required. The perplexing snub to Snoo Wilson can hardly be explained in terms of excessive playing time - this Shrew shoots by with scarcely a pause for breath. High-calibre performances such as John Branwell's bullish Baptista and Joseph Alessi's mercurial Tranio expertly reinforce the commedia dell'arte tint to the Paduan court, while Nick Cavaliere's vicarious Viking look makes him the perfect Petruchian lieutenant. Physical business is expertly accomplished with the aid of Toby Sedgwick's movement direction.

Overall, it's a thoroughly enjoyable evening, were it not for the nagging suspicion that the more problematic aspects of the text have been steamrollered rather than ironed out. Kaut-Howson provides the most trouble-free Shrew of recent times - and that's the trouble.

Until 14 April. Box office: 0161 833 9833.

fields.headline: Andy Summers Trio
fields.standfirst:
Pizza Express
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Pizza Express
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
In his past couple of albums, Andy Summers has explored one of jazz composition's most fertile historical periods by devoting whole albums to the lesser-known tunes of Thelonious Monk (Green Chimneys) and Charles Mingus (Peggy's Blue Skylight). This is a smart move: the rhythmically skewed, emotionally loaded melodies of both composers still sound vital on the old recordings, but it's great to sample this old wine in thoroughly contemporary bottles.

Summers has a talent for arrangement, which was used to spectacularly successful effect when he was one-third of The Police, where his instinct for space and simplicity helped jazzy songs sell by the million. Approaching each new song with fresh ears and sounds, Summers revitalised the tired cliches of the guitar trio for post-punk pop. So it was curious to see the same instrumentation - drums, bass guitar and guitar - just a few tables away in the basement ambience of the Dean Street pizzeria. This was a club gig of the old school - they even played a standard: I Fall in Love Too Easily.

The band bring to the jazz stage several elements of the rock world - the classy studio echoes and gizmos, the controlled overdrive, the headbanging pleasure of cranking up for a big solo. A whole vocabulary of guitar sounds, a lexicon of effects and techniques has grown up in the decades since Mingus and Monk wrote their best tunes, and the result rarely sounds contrived: if anyone has paid the right dues to rock out at a jazz gig, it's Andy Summers.

Tonight at Noon (Mingus) stormed along as a Cream/ Hendrix-style power-trio rocker, while Boo Boo's Birthday (Monk) became a vehicle for everything in the leader's axe-man repertoire - from fluent be-bopping to dissonant guitar heroics. Brilliant Corners and Evidence provided quirky rhythmic foundations with which drummer Anastasios Panos could have fun. And bassist Ric Fierabracci introduced a funky re-invention of Nardis (the Miles Davis-Bill Evans classic) with a multi-thumbed display of virtuosity before settling into an abrasive groove over which Summers stated the cool theme.

Fierabracci's firecracker solos on five-string bass were a delight. Best of all, though, was the joy of hearing Charles Mingus's sublime music in a new context, and the live trio arrangements had a looseness and energy that is sometimes lacking in Summers' meticulous recorded versions. When he performed the elliptical melodic lines and chord sequences of Opus Three or Reincarnation of a Lovebird, he made these great pieces of 20th-century contemporary music sound as if they were written for the guitar.

 The Andy Summers Trio plays Pizza Express Jazz Club, London W1 (020-7439 8722) until March 4.

fields.headline: Dresden Staatskapelle/ Haitink
fields.standfirst:
Dresden Staatskapelle/ Haitink
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Dresden Staatskapelle/ Haitink
Royal Festival Hall
London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Of all Bruckner's symphonies, the Third is the most problematic. First, there are three different versions of the score, all with their own validity - not to mention an extra one of the slow movement, and the various performing editions more or less well-meaning musicologists have concocted over the last century. And then there is the challenge of welding what is the most unwieldy of Bruckner's structures into a convincing, organic unity.

Bernard Haitink typically takes the pragmatic option: with the Dresden Staatskapelle on Sunday he conducted the 1877 score - the second of the three Bruckner produced - and brought to it the integrity and coherence that has been the hallmark of his Bruckner conducting for more than 30 years. Having at his disposal an orchestra with the tonal blend and awareness of tradition of the Staatskapelle was a huge bonus, of course. An orchestra that can trace its pedigree back 450 years, and list Weber, Mendelssohn, Schumann, Wagner and Richard Strauss among its former conductors, must inform its performance with a special historical perspective.

Certainly the Dresden sound is distinctive; there's no suggestion it has yet succumbed to the internationalisation of playing that makes it increasingly difficult to tell one orchestra from another. The reediness of the wind, the smoky, translucent strings, and the wonderfully unassertive brass are the constituents of a quickly identifiable ensemble.

The concert began with Mozart's Prague Symphony, No. 38, with everything studiously moulded by Haitink, but rather too massive and dogged. But if their approach to Mozart seems rather antiquated, it is perfect for the 19th-century symphonic repertoire, and Bruckner in particular. So, as Haitink steered his way with assurance through the excursions and occasional non sequiturs of the first movement, invested the Andante with a hymn-like radiance, and found a real sense of purpose in the diverse components of the finale, the sound world seemed absolutely right.

There are passages in three of the four movements that are pure texture - repeated-note figures that blur into a continuum. Here, so delicately played, they provided an extra element to bind the whole massive structure together. If the Third is never going to be rid of all its awkwardness, this account at least made much more sense of it than most.
