fields.headline: Two thousand years in 90 minutes
fields.standfirst:
Loveplay
The Pit
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Loveplay
The Pit
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
To complement its tumultuous Shakespeare history cycle, the RSC is presenting a short season of new plays generically entitled This Other Eden. But, while Moira Buffini's Loveplay is perfectly entertaining, in its attempt to cover two millennia in 90 minutes it emerges as a rather breathless mixture of La Ronde and 1066 and All That.

Each of the 10 scenes takes place in one London location: over the centuries it moves from Roman temple to medieval abbey, elegant town house, Victorian studio and 1960s squat, eventually becoming a modern dating agency. The constant factor is the quest, often doomed, for love and sex.

But, although Buffini seems to be reinforcing the point Peter Ackroyd makes in his book London about the spiritual continuity of certain sites, she generalises where he is specific: her sense of place is dramatically shaky, whereas Ackroyd discovers in Clerkenwell, for instance, a continuing home of political radicalism. Buffini's chosen form also risks turning the play into a series of rapid revue sketches.

Given her last play, Silence, imaginatively evoked the England of 1,000 years ago, it is strange that, here, Buffini gains in confidence as she approaches the present. She whisks us through Roman occupation and the Dark Ages, leading to an Elizabethan play-acting scene that feels like sawn-off Stoppard. The first really arresting scene has an 18th-century female rationalist hiring a labourer, so that she can explore his strangely alien body. It says a lot, touchingly and cryptically, about the co-existence of emotional restriction and intellectual advance.

At her best, Buffini is a sharp, witty writer: the final episode, in which a lesbian dating-agency owner has to use her lover as a guest at a singles night, neatly pinpoints both the heroine's corseted emotional inhibition and our reduction of sex to a commercial transaction. And, even if the play chews off more than it can bite, it is briskly directed by Anthony Clark and well acted by a six-strong cast: Niamh Linehan is particularly impressive as a number of solitary power-figures, including the Enlightenment scientist hungering for physical contact, while Simon Coates switches deftly from jolly, rogering 1820s patriarch to closeted Victorian cleric.

I'm still not persuaded the fragmented form best suits Buffini, who is a burrowing, research-conscious writer. But at least her play, in its portrait of the continuity of emotional repression, punctures any myth we may have entertained about England as an amatory Eden.

fields.headline: Families first in Brown's budget
fields.trailText: Chancellor Gordon Brown announced a Budget that, while aimed at helping the UK's families, held no surprises. It was viewed as a pre-election, largely bland effort, which would please family interest groups, but disappoint many looking for substantial tax cuts.
fields.body:
Chancellor Gordon Brown announced a Budget that, while aimed at helping the UK's families, held no surprises. It was viewed as a pre-election, largely bland effort, which would please family interest groups, but disappoint many looking for substantial tax cuts.

Despite this, Mr Brown was in a confident mood, as he stated the UK was now in a stable position, pointing out that there were the lowest levels of inflation since 1963. Interest rates also remain low, with long-term forecasts set at about 5%, which is similar to Germany and the US.

Tax experts Ernst & Young were not impressed. A company statement said: "From a personal tax point of view, we think he has yet again yielded to his compulsion to tweak things. We understand the argument for tax credits, but people have to claim them. They just aren't as immediate as tax cuts. Will voters be enthused?"

The key changes announced in the Budget are:

Taxes

Mr Brown announced a £1 billion a year tax cut, with the band of income taxed at 10p raised from £1,520 to £1,880. There was no change to capital gains tax. Many investors had been hoping the level - now £7,200 - would be increased, but it remains, with the tax fixed at 40%. Although inheritance tax affects few people, Mr Brown said the threshold would be raised to £242,000. He added that about 96% of people would continue to avoid paying the tax.

Savings

Mr Brown has kept the decision he made in the pre-Budget report last November to maintain the upper limit of £7,000 on annual contributions to an Individual Savings Account (Isa) for a further five years.

Families

The family was at the heart of Mr Brown's Budget and he is looking to reward families who work to provide for their children. He announced that the new children's tax credit, to be introduced in April, would be paid at £10 a week. This is up from £8.50 and will benefit some five million families. The tax credit will be increased up to £1,000 for mothers with newborn children and where the family earnings are below £50,000 from April 2002. Families on Working Families Tax Credit are to receive a rise of £5 a week, while the Disabled Person Tax Credit also goes up by £5 a week.

Maternity pay is to be increased from £60 in successive stages to £75 in 2002 to £100 a week in 2003 and also extended from 18 weeks to 26 weeks by the year 2003. Father will benefit from two weeks' paid paternity leave. Mr Brown also announced that childcare tax credit is to rise to £135 a week for those with one child and £200 a week for two or more.

The elderly

The chancellor was accused of not doing enough for less well off pensioners, despite announcing a basic pension rise of £5 a week to £72.50 for a single person and £8 a week to £140.55 for couples. Pensioners' tax allowances will be linked to earnings from 2003.

Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern, said: "This was heralded as a Budget for families, but it seems to ignore the fact that families also include older people. He is the first chancellor in 20 years to increase the basic state pension by more than the rate of inflation, as he announced he would do in November and this is a good first step, but we are still disappointed that, given the current national prosperity, he is not building on this further."

Mr Lishman said lower income pensioners would have to look to the means-tested system of income support and to the pension credit for an improved retirement income that "creates a massively complex system and endless form-filling for pensioners".

He commented that while the extension of the 10p tax rate would be welcomed by older taxpayers on modest incomes, this is "of no benefit to the 60% who already do not pay tax".

Pensions

While not referring specifically to the new low-cost private stakeholder pension plans that will be sold from April, Mr Brown is clearly hoping to give providers greater flexibility.

He announced that he had fully taken on board the recommendation of the Myners Review. This was prepared by Paul Myners, of fund managers Gartmore, and aimed at suggesting ways of improving pension performance.

The key area in the report said that the minimum funding requirement (MFR) should be scrapped. This is a solvency test introduced after the Maxwell pensions scandal and has been blamed from holding pension funds back from adventurous investments.

It will be replaced with a requirement of greater information disclosure by fund managers. It is expected there will now be investment in areas such as venture capital and more dynamic companies. Mr Myners also recommended that pension fund trustees should be better qualified, since some 62% have no investment qualifications.

No change to annuities was made - despite pleas from some pensioners and their advisers. An annuity is an income for life bought with the money that has built up in a pension plan, and Mr Brown was widely expected to scrap rules that now force everyone to have converted their pension money into an annuity by the age of 75.

There has been resentment, especially from those in poor health, who do not see why they should have to hand over money to insurers they feel should go to heirs on their death.

Stamp duty

This is to be abolished in some areas that have yet to be announced. These will be deprived, urban locations, with the aim to improve regeneration.

Car tax and fuel

All vehicle duty rates have been frozen and there are lower tax for cars under 1.5 litres. This is to be backdated to November, meaning some 70% of new cars to pay lower car tax. The duty on ultra low sulphur petrol is to be cut by 2p a litre. There will also be a 2p cut to unleaded petrol until June when supplies of ultra low sulphur petrol will be more widely available and a 3p off ultra low sulphur diesel. Duty on alternative fuels will be cut and duty on road fuel gases will be frozen until 2004.

Alcohol and tobacco

The duty on wine, beer and spirits is frozen. Health campaigners will be disappointed with the 6p rise on cigarettes. This was less than expected and only in line with inflation.

Betting

Betting duty has been abolished.

Pensioners' tax allowances will be linked to earnings from 2003. Gordon Lishman, director general of Age Concern, said: "This was heralded as a Budget for families, but it seems to ignore the fact that families also include older people. He is the first chancellor in 20 years to increase the basic state pension by more than the rate of inflation, as he announced he would do in November and this is a good first step, but we are still disappointed that, given the current national prosperity, he is not building on this further." Mr Lishman said lower income pensioners would have to look to the means-tested system of income support and to the pension credit for an improved retirement income that "creates a massively complex system and endless form-filling for pensioners". He commented that while the extension of the 10p tax rate would be welcomed by older taxpayers on modest incomes, this is "of no benefit to the 60% who already do not pay tax". Pensions While not referring specifically to the new low-cost private stakeholder pension plans that will be sold from April, Mr Brown is clearly hoping to give providers greater flexibility. He announced that he had fully taken on board the recommendation of the Myners Review. This was prepared by Paul Myners, of fund managers Gartmore, and aimed at suggesting ways of improving pension performance. The key area in the report said that the minimum funding requirement (MFR) should be scrapped. This is a solvency test introduced after the Maxwell pensions scandal and has been blamed from holding pension funds back from adventurous investments. It will be replaced with a requirement of greater information disclosure by fund managers. It is expected there will now be investment in areas such as venture capital and more dynamic companies. Mr Myners also recommended that pension fund trustees should be better qualified, since some 62% have no investment qualifications. No change to annuities was made - despite pleas from some pensioners and their advisers. An annuity is an income for life bought with the money that has built up in a pension plan, and Mr Brown was widely expected to scrap rules that now force everyone to have converted their pension money into an annuity by the age of 75. There has been resentment, especially from those in poor health, who do not see why they should have to hand over money to insurers they feel should go to heirs on their death. Stamp duty This is to be abolished in some areas that have yet to be announced. These will be deprived, urban locations, with the aim to improve regeneration. Car tax and fuel All vehicle duty rates have been frozen and there are lower tax for cars under 1.5 litres. This is to be backdated to November, meaning some 70% of new cars to pay lower car tax. The duty on ultra low sulphur petrol is to be cut by 2p a litre. There will also be a 2p cut to unleaded petrol until June when supplies of ultra low sulphur petrol will be more widely available and a 3p off ultra low sulphur diesel. Duty on alternative fuels will be cut and duty on road fuel gases will be frozen until 2004. Alcohol and tobacco The duty on wine, beer and spirits is frozen. Health campaigners will be disappointed with the 6p rise on cigarettes. This was less than expected and only in line with inflation. Betting Betting duty has been abolished.

fields.headline: Trapped in the property wastelands
fields.standfirst:
As inner cities are revitalised, house prices in derelict pockets are plunging

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: As inner cities are revitalised, house prices in derelict pockets are plunging.
fields.body:
Ministers are under growing pressure to rescue thousands of inner city home owners trapped in a cycle of negative equity and unable to sell houses because they have lost value and are often worthless.

Backed by Labour MPs and council leaders, the chairman of the Commons environment committee, Andrew Bennett, warned yesterday that unless urgent action is taken to reform compulsory purchase legislation and provide proper compensation, thousands of people, mainly in the north, could be left penniless.

At present, councils anxious to redevelop rundown areas can only compensate owners for the market value of their property - which means that many people stand to gain nothing and could be left with huge debts because their mortgage far exceeds the value of a house.

The full extent of the problem, particularly acute in Greater Manchester and Merseyside, has been underlined in a report from Birmingham University showing that 280,000 homes along the north-west's M62 corridor alone are blighted - 17% of properties - including almost 100,000 private houses.

Researchers working for 39 councils and housing associations have called for a government fund to tackle areas of low demand and abandoned housing because current programmes are inadequate to cope with a deepening crisis.

The issue was underlined at a recent Guardian North debate which highlighted the sharp north-south property divide - prices in even the poorer parts of Greater London remain buoyant - and the deep divisions within northern cities where apartments have been sold for up to £1m barely a mile from areas where property prices are collapsing.

Research undertaken for the Guardian by Brian Robson, a government urban adviser and head of Manchester University's centre for urban policy studies, warned that northern cities are increasingly characterised by the North American "doughnut" phenomenon - thriving, rebuilt centres surrounded by a wasteland of dereliction and abandoned housing, with many trapped in streets where prices have collapsed.

He highlighted the case of east Manchester, close to the vibrant city centre, "a huge swath of dereliction" embracing almost 2,500 acres and now covered by a government-backed urban regeneration company which planned up to 6,000 new houses over 10 years and improvements to several thousand older properties.

Professor Robson's report spoke of houses selling "if at all" for less than £10,000, with unemployment twice the Manchester average and a mortality rate 50% above the national norm. "In a city which now boasts of selling its first £1m flat, the terraces of east Manchester are largely unsaleable," he wrote. "A quarter of Manchester houses sell for less than £20,000 and in east Manchester many sell for £5,000 ... across the area, some 20% of housing is vacant and, in parts, whole streets stand empty. There is not a single secondary school in the area."

The city council wants stronger powers to halt the cycle of decline by earmarking whole streets as property improvement zones, where authorities - using public funds if necessary - will guarantee that prices will not fall below a certain level.

Andrew Bennett, MP for Denton and Reddish, in Greater Manchester, is now pressing the government for revised legislation to create the zones. "The very act of guaranteeing a 'floor' in the market, below which prices would not be allowed to fall, would maintain confidence in the area," he said. "It is now impossible to sell in some areas, although a mile or so away similar [terrace] houses are going for £100,000. It is an appalling situation, with some people unable to sell their houses - and others scared stiff of going into areas because they know if they buy a house it will lose value."

He fears that the problem of low demand and abandonment will spread from east Manchester to the neighbouring authorities of Stockport and Tameside, which embrace his constituency. "Already there are signs of the poorer areas spreading out and decline, once it sets in, can take root very quickly."

Dire position

A third of homes in east Manchester are vacant in a conurbation with more derelict land than any other part of the country. Terraces that have not been demolished are boarded up and vandalised. On some estates nearby, almost half the housing is vacant. Tom Bloxham, chairman of the Manchester-based developers Urban Splash, which has created 1,000 city centre flats in Manchester and Liverpool - several are on the market for £700,000 - acknowledges that the urban "doughnut" has left some neighbourhoods in a "dire position", with unsaleable houses and a string of social problems.

But he believes that the city centre property renaissance - central Manchester now has 10,000 residents - will eventually ripple out to east Manchester and elsewhere. "Ten years ago no one would have dreamt that so many old warehouses would be redeveloped and that people would invest in city properties on this scale," he said. "Now, as the city centre gets fuller the market will spread out. There is no reason why there should not be a radical transformation elsewhere."

Development is continuing to blight the countryside at the expense of rebuilding cities, in spite of planning guidelines introduced a year ago, according to a report published today by the Council for the Protection of Rural England.

Plans for 658,000 houses on green fields are still in the pipeline - enough to accommodate the demands of the top 80 housebuilders for six years before touching an urban site.

fields.headline: Pension industry faces radical overhaul
fields.trailText: The £800bn City pension fund industry faces a radical overhaul after stinging criticism yesterday of its "herd-like" attitude, which starves young companies of much-needed investment and at the same time denies millions of savers better pensions.
fields.body:
The £800bn City pension fund industry faces a radical overhaul after stinging criticism yesterday of its "herd-like" attitude, which starves young companies of much-needed investment and at the same time denies millions of savers better pensions.

Under a wide-ranging series of proposals unveiled yesterday by Paul Myners, a senior fund manager commissioned by chancellor Gordon Brown to review the industry, pension funds will operate under a new 10 point code of conduct.

Mr Myners, chairman of the Gartmore fund management group and the Guardian Media Group, allowed no part of the highly lucrative industry to escape unscathed with actuaries, pension fund trustees and fund managers, and major stocking broking firms all facing calls for radical change.

He criticised the industry for "slavish adherence to consensus" and described "herding" as "a pervasive feature of UK institutional investment".

His 200-page report, which is expected to be endorsed by the chancellor in his budget speech today, is also likely to lead to a new investigation into the way the life insurance industry operates.

Following the recommendations made by Mr Myners, the chancellor is expected to commission a new wide-ranging analysis of the relationship between financial advisers and insurance companies and the policies eventually sold to investors.

Mr Myners suspects that the way insurance policies are sold is on the basis of commissions and fees paid rather than on the performance of the financial products themselves.

A new investigation into the life insurance industry would affect 20% of the £1,500bn invested in the stock market each year. Another 20% is invested by the pension funds, which received most of Mr Myners' attention during his nine-month investigation to establish why so little money is invested in start-up companies, known as venture capital.

He said yesterday: "The review finds that savers' money is too often being invested in ways that do not maximise their interests. It is likely to follow too that capital is being inefficiently allocated in the economy."

The main thrust of his proposals, which calls for the code of conduct to be enshrined in law if it is not adopted voluntarily within two years, is to make pension trustees better equipped for their roles in deciding how pension fund money is invested, by whom and for how long.

For this reason, Mr Myners believes trustees should be paid and better trained. In this way their reliance on just four firms of pension fund consultancy firms, who provide 70% of all the advice received by the industry, would be reduced.

The ultimate aim is to make it easier for pension funds to invest their assets more freely, and ultimately into venture capital which could improve their returns to investors.

Towers Perrin, one of the investment consultants criticised by Mr Myners, said: "Mr Myners may have found the subjects of governance and management far more complex than he anticipated. Perhaps the lack of substance and practical content in the review is indicative of him finding the topic too hard."

Alan Pickering, chairman of National Association Pension Funds, which represents all the major pension funds, welcomed the report. "We are delighted that a prescriptive approach is not being recommended and that the temptation to pursue a box-ticking mentality for the investment process has been rejected. There is no viable alternative to a thoughtful and informed approach to pension fund investment. The recommendations are challenging."

webTitle: Aiming for a fund of knowledge

fields.headline: Aiming for a fund of knowledge
fields.standfirst: Education of trustees seen as essential in ending 'slavish' consensus that dogs pensions industry
fields.trailText: Education of trustees seen as essential in ending 'slavish' consensus that dogs pensions industry.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown is expected to use today's Budget to initiate a new investigation into the way life assurance and other savings policies are sold, following yesterday's attack on the "herd-like" behaviour of the pension fund industry by Paul Myners.

Mr Myners, a senior fund manager commissioned by Mr Brown nine months ago to establish why so little money is invested in start-up businesses, yesterday recommended a separate, independent investigation into the life industry after completing his wide-ranging review.

The chairman of the Gartmore fund management group and of the Guardian Media Group lambasted the £800bn industry of which he is part, saying it suffered from a "slavish adherence to consensus" and "herd-like" tendencies.

His analysis was the second commissioned by Mr Brown into the financial services industry and his approach contrasted with the combative one taken by Don Cruickshank when he scrutinised banking competition in 1999.

The prospect of a third inquiry at the behest of Mr Brown brought immediate warnings from the insurance industry of "review overload".

Mr Myners said yesterday there were issues about the way insurance products were sold, more on fees than performance, which needed to be investigated. "I've been worried about the engine beneath the bonnet of the car. Many people wanted to talk about the design of the car." His scrutiny led him to conclude that the pension fund industry, which has £800bn of assets to nurture on behalf of investors saving for their old age, tends to invest them in similar ways in identical stocks.

Cosy world

That meant "savers' money is too often being invested in ways that do not maximise their interests".

It also meant that venture capitalists, who invest funds in start-up companies, were fortunate if as much as 5% of this total went in their direction. Mr Myners cited statistics showing that, while investment by American pension funds in venture capital had tripled since 1996, British pension funds had reduced their investment over the same period.

This is the discrepancy Mr Myners was commissioned to address. He tried to lift the lid on the cosy world of institutional investment management and the relationship between pension fund trustees, the big fund management firms, actuarial consultants and big stock broking firms.

Mr Myners saw the root of the problem as pension fund trustees, who are rarely paid, may be poorly trained and have little support from their employers.

This increases the reliance of pension fund trustees on just four consultancy firms for advice about which fund management company to appoint. The fund managers are all measured against the same benchmark - often a stock market index such as the FTSE 100 - which again contributes to their "herd-like" behaviour and "short-termism".

At the same time, the fund managers buy research from City stockbroking firms to help decide which shares to buy and sell. This might also be a latent force in the "herd-like" mentality.

All of this contributes to an industry where the big pension fund managers -Schroders, Merrill Lynch, Barclays, Phillips & Drew and Hermes - try to be top of the all-important league tables so that actuaries recommend them to pension fund trustees. This also means that when their performance flags they tend to be replaced by the manager currently making better returns. This leads to a musical chairs every three years or so and enforces the short-termism.

In an attempt to break down this structural problem, Mr Myners outlined a 10-point code of conduct that would allow pension fund trustees to be paid and receive more training. Improving their knowledge was at the root of tackling the remaining distortions in the market.

He admitted that his code, which he suggested should be voluntary for the next two years before legislation is considered, was "manifest common sense".

His vision would place the onus on pension fund trustees to provide clear targets for fund managers on how to invest and how their performance is measured.

Some restricting rules, such as the minimum funding requirement introduced after Robert Maxwell raided the Mirror Group pension fund, also needed to be abandoned or updated, Mr Myners said.

Little detail was provided about how this would work in practice and prompted stinging criticism from Towers Perrin, one of the firms of actuaries providing advice to pension fund trustees.

Mark Duke, principal at Towers Perrin, said: "Mr Myners may have found the subjects of governance and management far more complex than he anticipated. Perhaps the lack of substance and practical content in the review is indicative of him finding the topic too hard."

Other firms were less scathing in their response. Andrew Kirton, William M Mercer investment practice leader, which is the biggest consultant in Britain, advising 20% of pension schemes, said: "We can argue about some of the details but there are lots of reasons to be supportive.

"Could the trustees be made more expert at investment decisions? Yes, but with trustees you are drawing people from a wide range of backgrounds."

Along with a number of fund managers, Mr Kirton pointed out that the industry was already moving along the path suggested in the Myners review of following more customised performance targets.

Andre Maclaren, head of asset allocation at Swiss-owned Phillips & Drew, one of the five biggest pension fund managers, said: "The herd game has been going on for several years, but it's becoming less profitable than it used to be, because it's been rumbled by the consultants."

Trustees also felt the ideas outlined in the Myners review were already being adopted. David Fry, a current trustee of the £100m Origin pension fund, said: "A lot of what is being recommended is what we and other big funds have been doing for some time, particularly in terms of training and support for trustees."

Mr Myners refused to indicate how much the cost of his proposals - paying trustees, for instance - would dent the pension fund industry. He suggested this would be outweighed by "huge opportunities for enhanced returns".

He asked the chancellor to give the industry two years to adopt his code before legislation was considered. This legislation would require an explanation from any pension fund flouting the rules, as with the Cadbury code on corporate governance.

While the industry insists that it is already progressing towards the ideas in the Myners review, some admit privately that a change in attitude will be needed. Mr Myners quotes economist John Keynes to describe the necessary change in mindset: "Worldly wisdom teaches that is better for reputation to fail conventionally than to succeed unconventionally."

Practitioners predict the death of the closet indexer

The pension manager

ANDREW MACLAREN, head of asset allocation at Phillips & Drew, part of UBS Asset Management, which looks after £124bn.

Phillips & Drew believes it is exempt from Mr Myners's condemnation of the "herd instinct" in the City, as its investment director, Tony Dye famously turned against the herd five years ago, predicting a downturn in markets. The bet - for the first few years - failed to pay off, and as clients headed for the exit, other fund managers saw it as a classic case of investment risk outweighing the commercial risk to the company.

Mr Maclaren says the Myners review will not result in a "step change" in fund management, but will mark the death of the "closet indexer" which avoids risk by clinging around an index but charges the full fees of active management. "The herd game is now less profitable than it used to be - it's been rumbled by the consultants. I see the market becoming more polarised between indexers and real active managers."

He is less than enthusiastic about the prospect for a rush into venture capital. "It's quite likely it will increase, but the market in the UK is not as deep as in the US, and the past track record is not significantly better than the FTSE."

The investment consultant

ANDREW KIRTON, head consultant at William M Mercer, the biggest adviser in Britain, working on behalf of 20% of UK pension schemes.

Consultants such as William M Mercer are best known as the all-powerful intermediaries that can make or break City fund management houses, running "beauty parades", used to decide if the manager will win - or lose - billions in pension fund money.

Mr Kirton believes the Myners review will result in significant, if not revolutionary, changes. "He's pushing at an open door. The changes will be that the mandates to fund managers will become clearer and more explicit; there will be a greater focus on the active versus passive management debate; the risk control elements will be less severely restricted, giving managers the opportunity to outperform; and there will be more demand from clients for private equity [venture capital]."

Cash going into private equity is not about to explode - Mr Kirton believes the biggest new investment area for pension funds over the next few years will be into hedge funds.

He also believes that the days when consultants poured money into the "big four" investment managers (including Mr Myners's company, Gartmore), which encouraged a herd mentality, are over. "Concentration had gone too far. The big managers have slipped as we've seen the arrival of companies such as JP Morgan, Capital and Fidelity into the market. Trustees are casting their net much more widely."

The trustee

DAVID FRY, managing director of the £2bn Philips UK pension fund between 1995-1999, and an independent trustee on a Philips offshoot, Origin, which has a £100m pension fund.

As part of a big multinational, Mr Fry was at the fortunate end of the trustee world, with significant re sources to draw upon and extensive internal support. He agrees with Mr Myners that many trustees are being asked to take crucial decisions without resources, expertise or internal support. At Philips, the trustees, drawn from employees and senior directors, are advised by an expert investment sub- committee, and new trustees are sent on training courses. "In the past that sort of training has been neglected, especially by smaller firms. But even with large funds, the courses that new trustees have gone on have tended not to focus on investment issues."

Hopes that the Myners review may lead to more capital for start-ups are likely to be dashed, he says. For example, the Philips fund has 45,000 members, but only 4,500 are contributing employees, and the rest are pensioners "in payment". With such a mature profile of liabilities, the fund is unlikely to want to invest in high-risk venture capital start-ups. "The fund has had some venture capital, but it will not be reinvesting." However, it has decided to spread its investments more internationally in recent years.

Trustee meetings take up about 10 days a year, but Mr Fry says this is in company time when the trustee is being paid. He believes extra payment, as proposed by Myners, should only be for work done over and above the meetings.

Ways to split up the herd

The problem

Pension fund trustees take crucial investment decisions yet lack resources and expertise. They are not paid.

This means they rely on a handful of investment consulting firms for advice and set objectives for fund managers which result in "herd-like" behaviour.

This ultimately deters investment in start-up or venture capital.

The Myners solution

 A 10-point Cadbury-style code of conduct under which trustees should be paid and investment managers given clearer, individual performance benchmarks which are not related to a stock market index.

 The minimum funding requirement, which was introduced after the Maxwell pension scandal and means funds have to buy a certain amount of government bonds, should be abolished.

 Shareholder "activism", as in the United States, should be endorsed to encourage underperforming companies to improve. Fund managers should be able to measure how effective they are in instigating change.

 The definition of people who are pension fund trustees should be changed so they become "familiar" with the issues on which they make decisions, as is the case in the United States.

 The law commission should be asked to look for ways of suggesting greater clarity in establishing the ownership of surplus pension assets.

 Institutional fund managers should include the cost of advice they receive from investment banking analysts for research on specific stocks in the overall fee they charge their pension fund client, rather than pass on the bill to the pension fund.

 The chancellor should commission a separate investigation into the life assurance industry to scrutinise the disclosure and visibility of the performance of personal finance products.

 While 70% of all consultancy advice is provided by four firms, a competition review is not necessary

Mr Myners saw the root of the problem as pension fund trustees, who are rarely paid, may be poorly trained and have little support from their employers. This increases the reliance of pension fund trustees on just four consultancy firms for advice about which fund management company to appoint. The fund managers are all measured against the same benchmark - often a stock market index such as the FTSE 100 - which again contributes to their "herd-like" behaviour and "short-termism". At the same time, the fund managers buy research from City stockbroking firms to help decide which shares to buy and sell. This might also be a latent force in the "herd-like" mentality. All of this contributes to an industry where the big pension fund managers -Schroders, Merrill Lynch, Barclays, Phillips & Drew and Hermes - try to be top of the all-important league tables so that actuaries recommend them to pension fund trustees. This also means that when their performance flags they tend to be replaced by the manager currently making better returns. This leads to a musical chairs every three years or so and enforces the short-termism. In an attempt to break down this structural problem, Mr Myners outlined a 10-point code of conduct that would allow pension fund trustees to be paid and receive more training. Improving their knowledge was at the root of tackling the remaining distortions in the market. He admitted that his code, which he suggested should be voluntary for the next two years before legislation is considered, was "manifest common sense". His vision would place the onus on pension fund trustees to provide clear targets for fund managers on how to invest and how their performance is measured. Some restricting rules, such as the minimum funding requirement introduced after Robert Maxwell raided the Mirror Group pension fund, also needed to be abandoned or updated, Mr Myners said. Little detail was provided about how this would work in practice and prompted stinging criticism from Towers Perrin, one of the firms of actuaries providing advice to pension fund trustees. Mark Duke, principal at Towers Perrin, said: "Mr Myners may have found the subjects of governance and management far more complex than he anticipated. Perhaps the lack of substance and practical content in the review is indicative of him finding the topic too hard." Other firms were less scathing in their response. Andrew Kirton, William M Mercer investment practice leader, which is the biggest consultant in Britain, advising 20% of pension schemes, said: "We can argue about some of the details but there are lots of reasons to be supportive. "Could the trustees be made more expert at investment decisions? Yes, but with trustees you are drawing people from a wide range of backgrounds." Along with a number of fund managers, Mr Kirton pointed out that the industry was already moving along the path suggested in the Myners review of following more customised performance targets. Andre Maclaren, head of asset allocation at Swiss-owned Phillips & Drew, one of the five biggest pension fund managers, said: "The herd game has been going on for several years, but it's becoming less profitable than it used to be, because it's been rumbled by the consultants." Trustees also felt the ideas outlined in the Myners review were already being adopted. David Fry, a current trustee of the £100m Origin pension fund, said: "A lot of what is being recommended is what we and other big funds have been doing for some time, particularly in terms of training and support for trustees." Mr Myners refused to indicate how much the cost of his proposals - paying trustees, for instance - would dent the pension fund industry. He suggested this would be outweighed by "huge opportunities for enhanced returns". He asked the chancellor to give the industry two years to adopt his code before legislation was considered. This legislation would require an explanation from any pension fund flouting the rules, as with the Cadbury code on corporate governance. While the industry insists that it is already progressing towards the ideas in the Myners review, some admit privately that a change in attitude will be needed. Mr Myners quotes economist John Keynes to describe the necessary change in mindset: "Worldly wisdom teaches that is better for reputation to fail conventionally than to succeed unconventionally." Practitioners predict the death of the closet indexer The pension manager ANDREW MACLAREN, head of asset allocation at Phillips & Drew, part of UBS Asset Management, which looks after £124bn. Phillips & Drew believes it is exempt from Mr Myners's condemnation of the "herd instinct" in the City, as its investment director, Tony Dye famously turned against the herd five years ago, predicting a downturn in markets. The bet - for the first few years - failed to pay off, and as clients headed for the exit, other fund managers saw it as a classic case of investment risk outweighing the commercial risk to the company. Mr Maclaren says the Myners review will not result in a "step change" in fund management, but will mark the death of the "closet indexer" which avoids risk by clinging around an index but charges the full fees of active management. "The herd game is now less profitable than it used to be - it's been rumbled by the consultants. I see the market becoming more polarised between indexers and real active managers." He is less than enthusiastic about the prospect for a rush into venture capital. "It's quite likely it will increase, but the market in the UK is not as deep as in the US, and the past track record is not significantly better than the FTSE." The investment consultant ANDREW KIRTON, head consultant at William M Mercer, the biggest adviser in Britain, working on behalf of 20% of UK pension schemes. Consultants such as William M Mercer are best known as the all-powerful intermediaries that can make or break City fund management houses, running "beauty parades", used to decide if the manager will win - or lose - billions in pension fund money. Mr Kirton believes the Myners review will result in significant, if not revolutionary, changes. "He's pushing at an open door. The changes will be that the mandates to fund managers will become clearer and more explicit; there will be a greater focus on the active versus passive management debate; the risk control elements will be less severely restricted, giving managers the opportunity to outperform; and there will be more demand from clients for private equity [venture capital]." Cash going into private equity is not about to explode - Mr Kirton believes the biggest new investment area for pension funds over the next few years will be into hedge funds. He also believes that the days when consultants poured money into the "big four" investment managers (including Mr Myners's company, Gartmore), which encouraged a herd mentality, are over. "Concentration had gone too far. The big managers have slipped as we've seen the arrival of companies such as JP Morgan, Capital and Fidelity into the market. Trustees are casting their net much more widely." The trustee DAVID FRY, managing director of the £2bn Philips UK pension fund between 1995-1999, and an independent trustee on a Philips offshoot, Origin, which has a £100m pension fund. As part of a big multinational, Mr Fry was at the fortunate end of the trustee world, with significant re sources to draw upon and extensive internal support. He agrees with Mr Myners that many trustees are being asked to take crucial decisions without resources, expertise or internal support. At Philips, the trustees, drawn from employees and senior directors, are advised by an expert investment sub- committee, and new trustees are sent on training courses. "In the past that sort of training has been neglected, especially by smaller firms. But even with large funds, the courses that new trustees have gone on have tended not to focus on investment issues." Hopes that the Myners review may lead to more capital for start-ups are likely to be dashed, he says. For example, the Philips fund has 45,000 members, but only 4,500 are contributing employees, and the rest are pensioners "in payment". With such a mature profile of liabilities, the fund is unlikely to want to invest in high-risk venture capital start-ups. "The fund has had some venture capital, but it will not be reinvesting." However, it has decided to spread its investments more internationally in recent years. Trustee meetings take up about 10 days a year, but Mr Fry says this is in company time when the trustee is being paid. He believes extra payment, as proposed by Myners, should only be for work done over and above the meetings. Ways to split up the herd The problem Pension fund trustees take crucial investment decisions yet lack resources and expertise. They are not paid. This means they rely on a handful of investment consulting firms for advice and set objectives for fund managers which result in "herd-like" behaviour. This ultimately deters investment in start-up or venture capital. The Myners solution  A 10-point Cadbury-style code of conduct under which trustees should be paid and investment managers given clearer, individual performance benchmarks which are not related to a stock market index.  The minimum funding requirement, which was introduced after the Maxwell pension scandal and means funds have to buy a certain amount of government bonds, should be abolished.  Shareholder "activism", as in the United States, should be endorsed to encourage underperforming companies to improve. Fund managers should be able to measure how effective they are in instigating change.  The definition of people who are pension fund trustees should be changed so they become "familiar" with the issues on which they make decisions, as is the case in the United States.  The law commission should be asked to look for ways of suggesting greater clarity in establishing the ownership of surplus pension assets.  Institutional fund managers should include the cost of advice they receive from investment banking analysts for research on specific stocks in the overall fee they charge their pension fund client, rather than pass on the bill to the pension fund.  The chancellor should commission a separate investigation into the life assurance industry to scrutinise the disclosure and visibility of the performance of personal finance products.  While 70% of all consultancy advice is provided by four firms, a competition review is not necessary
